Q12: Both sequences deal with a journey of discovering a career path, and how interests and responsibilities change over time
Q13: Both stories involve a journey of personal and professional calling, and uncertainty regarding the appropriate path to take
FullA: I wanted to be an artist when I was in high school , but I actually started in nursing school. We were really poor , and my dad died when I was six , and I saw my mom struggle working in a sewing factory. And I thought , well this is crazy to be a starving artist. I better do something practical. So I went to school for nursing. And photography and me was a better fit. It just felt like a better fit. So, started at the Miami Herald as a staff photographer, just from there moved on to do international stories, so I bounced around a lot. I traveled a whole lot. You know, when you can capture a moment, capture history , I don't know, just preserve that second of time, that's meaningful in some way. If it makes you feel, it's probably gon na make someone else feel too. But those were the moments that I always look for. And I feel like there's all different types of photography that you have to appreciate. You can do all these stylized beautiful perfectly composed pictures , but for me, journalism, I think the only thing that matters is the content in the moment and making someone feel. Because you can make someone think, but to make someone feel is the ultimate goal. The more you can do to connect people, the less hatred there will be in the world, the more understanding there will be.
FullB: and I suddenly realized something about science that I hadn't know before which was that if I wanted to be in science I'd have to pick one thing and I liked everything way too much to pick one thing. I really loved writing. I really loved helping students and teaching and I loved art  and with all that known, I kind of went off to Boston University with a vague idea of something communications. I did not know  and it wasn't until I was in my sophomore year and I was taking that first journalism class that they teach and then one day Professor Brand said, " What are you majoring in? '' And I said, " I don't know. PR? '' And he said, " PR?! " The best people are in journalism , you can do this! You could be in journalism , '' and I thought, " Wow . '' In hindsight everything has come together almost eerily logically. How did you prepare to take those risks when nothing really felt like it was going to come together? People would say to me, " Oh newspaper? " You'll never get a job in a newspaper. Never! '' I thought, ` Why not? It could happen to me , it's as likely as anybody else. ' And then my job is, make it as likely as I can make it by being as good as I can.
EventsA: My dad died when I was six — I saw my mom struggle working in a sewing factory — I went to school for nursing — I started at the Miami Herald as a staff photographer — I moved on to do international stories — I traveled a whole lot
EventsB: I realized I had to pick one thing in science — I went to Boston University with a vague idea of something communications — I took the first journalism class in my sophomore year — Professor Brand asked me what I was majoring in — I said I didn't know and suggested PR — Professor Brand encouraged me to pursue journalism

Q12: Both sequences are about a series of actions leading up to an achievement, however the context is slightly different, with Story A about music entrepreneurship and Story B about personal art
Q13: Both stories are about individuals pursuing their passion despite uncertainty, however the context is different, with Story A about music whereas Story B is about personal creativity
FullA: five or six bands, you know, 'cause people would come to me and go , " Oh we got a band, too . '' And by having the most popular band in St. Louis, which was a band called the . We were-became the radio station's band, which meant they played like 80-100 commercials a week. " Hey, the , " we playin ' at 66 Drive-In. '' And it'd be, " Steve on trumpet [do-do-do-do-do-do ] '' So being the popular band in town , I started booking other bands, 'cause when I was already booked, I didn't see any reason to turn people down. I said, " Wait a second, let me see if I can get another band. '' Well, that eventually led to booking 1100 bands. So we were the largest band-booking agency in the country , and I was like 18 years old. So went from local bands, regional bands, to national bands. And the first show we did was in 1969 was the Grateful Dead. You guys sitting here all have ideas. Whether you pursue them ot not is up to you. Don't later on look back and say , " God, I wish " I would've done that. ''
FullB: something with business. I didn't know exactly what I was going to do. My passion wasn't there , but that's where the money was at. And I'm thinking, " This oughta pay the bills , " I ` ma have a family. This is what I'm going to do. " I'm just gon na paint on the side. '' But it got to that point where I couldn't work because I kept hearing that I got to pursue my dream as a, as an artist. That Obama shoe came to me. And I woke up at two o'clock in the morning and I painted that shoe. And I went to the mall and took a picture, put it on MySpace. No big deal. Didn't think nothing of it. And then like the first big thing that happened was the Smithsonian e-mailin ' me and I thought it was a joke. And I cried. I was like, I was almost homeless in January. Like, had I quit, had I quit a month before I made that shoe , had I quit an hour before I made that shoe, and decided, " I'm just gon na forget about art , '' this would have never happened.
EventsA: became the radio station's band — played 80-100 commercials a week — started booking other bands — booked 1100 bands — became the largest band-booking agency in the country — did the first show in 1969 with the Grateful Dead
EventsB: I woke up at two o'clock in the morning — I painted that shoe — I went to the mall and took a picture — I put the picture on MySpace — The Smithsonian emailed me — I cried

Q12: Both stories are about discovering a career path, through exploration, action, and development
Q13: Both stories are about a career path journey, diverging from initial expectations to find a meaningful profession through exploration
FullA: Where were you when you were our age, 22, 23? I was in Chile. I was about to finish college. And I have a bachelor's in linguistics, English linguistics, so I spoke English before i came here. And at that time the only possibility I'd say that was offered to me was to teach English. I was coming from the third world to the first world. I didn't get out of my apartment for about year. And then I came across this ad. They were looking for a coordinator in this place. I think that there are roads for you in life. And if you want to take a different road life is always going to take you back to that one. For example, teaching for me. As soon as I started teaching, I loved it.
FullB: I actually had no idea that tech was a thing. I was in my third year studying chemistry and biology. And I had a friend that graduated , and he taught himself how to code. And we were hanging out , and I was just watching him type away at his computer. And I was like, I used to write code when I was eight years old. And had I known that software was a career that was an obtainable thing for me to do , I would have hands down done it much earlier. But I think also even when I was in school, the idea of computer science classes just seemed really intimidating. From a distance, it looks so complex. But then if you actually learn how to code, it's like, every line is actually very simple. Pretty much just, I sunk my teeth in and was like, I got ta just do it until I make it happen. And so from then on, as a professional software engineer, you're building stuff everyday. And they ask me, what do you want to work on? I'm like , I wan na work on something I haven't done before. I mean , I don't know how to do it immediately, but I know how to figure it out.
EventsA: I was in Chile — I was about to finish college — I spoke English before I came here — I didn't get out of my apartment for about a year — I came across an ad — They were looking for a coordinator — I started teaching — I loved teaching
EventsB: A friend graduated and taught himself how to code — I watched him type at his computer — I remembered writing code when I was eight years old — I decided to learn to code seriously — I became a professional software engineer

Q12: Sequence A involves a professional and family-focused theme, whereas Sequence B is about a personal, emotional experience
Q13: Both stories are focused on personal growth and finding purpose, but have different contexts. Story A is about education, whereas Story B is about emotions/confidence.
FullA: So at Alchemy we are taking the concept of chemistry and science and turning them into game based learning tools for students and for instructors, but in a way that allows for experimentation and play. The path was going toward academic chemistry. I was good at chemistry , I was good at research and all that stuff. But I realized that I always liked working with young people. So I actually, in 1994, went and worked at Detroit Country Day School, which is a private school. And started my job there and loved it, and raised my children. They went through the school , they went to U of M. And after that I started sort of feeling like not as connected to my school as it used to be, because my kids were gone. So I started to look for new things and that was the beginning of Alchemy. And if my learning tools can be shown to help students from everywhere get better. And there's like 50 % fail organic chemistry. If I could cut that down to 40 %, I think that would be success. But, this is not an easy path, it's really hard. But if you're solving a problem that you know needs to be solved, then the hurdles don't feel quite so high.
FullB: where you weren't truly able to talk about emotions, you know. So writing was my vehicle, the doorway out of there. I worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading , and I was so insecure that if there was 50 people listening to me and one person yawning, I'd feel like I failed. And I'd see that person yawning , and I'd have to do something else , you know , I'd have to climb on the chair or, go in their face. And one person got up and applauded , and after a year, after a lifetime of no encouragement, that one person applauding was enough to make me feel, have the confidence to find my destiny. Believe in that destiny, that there's something for you , and then someday it's gon na materialize.
EventsA: went and worked at Detroit Country Day School in 1994 — started my job at Detroit Country Day School — raised my children — my children went through the school — my children went to U of M — started to look for new things — began Alchemy
EventsB: worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading — saw one person yawning — did something else by climbing on the chair or going in their face — one person got up and applauded

Q12: One is about pivoting careers and one is about making it work in the same career path.
Q13: Although these are both about careers, one is in an interview format, and one is way more about pivoting careers than the other.
FullA: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
FullB: So going back into the time when you were first starting out and into producing, how is it like coping with being dyslexic and trying to work around that? When I came out and I had this film , I then started looking for jobs and I just was trying to figure out what should be the next step and going for job interviews and I was nervous about working for other people. I was worried that people would find out that there were skills that I really couldn't do. So I shied away from certain things and that led me to people who were being independent filmmakers, because they were more peers  and we were all saying, okay , let's go raise money. Let's go try to do this. And in retrospect, it was great and it sort of lead me down an interesting path , but I think it was partly, cuz I was scared to do the other. I was scared that I would be found out. I think the best thing about having LD that helped me in film is I've never been somebody who assumed you wouldn't make mistakes. I've never thought that anything was gon na be a straight line and that you get there quickly. That's just not how I've learned and how my life ever went in school, certainly. So I think that's sort of applicable to most young people that you have to be willing to assume that might happen to you, but don't you think a lot of LD kids already know that. You're already kinda prepared that, that's gon na be true. So I think if you're not ashamed of that, if you own that, it makes it so much easier.
EventsA: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop
EventsB: I came out and had a film — I started looking for jobs — I went for job interviews — I shied away from certain things — I met people who were independent filmmakers — We decided to raise money — We tried to make a film

Q12: They are both about someone's career progression and end with entrepreneurship.
Q13: They are both someone talking about their career paths.
FullA: When I got out of college, I went into the Army Reserve, through the Communications Officer. And ended up back in 89 getting a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory. At an Engineer and Developing Technology, to make weapons smarter, new technology to be able to kind of carry weapons. And so this whole focus was on creating capability. But when you're in the entrepreneurship world and the commercial world, that's a different mindset. Yeah. See, when I worked for the government. I could spend the government money on my ideas. But I'm out here as an entrepreneur , I have to spend my own money. So that was hard for me, to try to get that switch going on. My approach, and what I always tell people is you have to start connecting, networking. And a lot of people thinks that's hard , but it is not really hard. It's just a matter of meeting people , and let them know what you do or what you wan na do.
FullB: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
EventsA: I got out of college — I went into the Army Reserve through the Communications Officer — I got a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory — I worked at an Engineer and Developing Technology to make weapons smarter — I tried to get the switch going on from government work to entrepreneurship
EventsB: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science

Q12: One is about career progression and one is about recognizing where one is in their career.
Q13: These stories are both about the journey of getting where you want to go in your life.
FullA: The single worst job I ever had was washing dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. And I was the guy who was doing the communicable diseases stuff. So I had to wear the heavy gloves, and man, that stuff was just nasty. And so the whenever I started working my way up the ladder, reminding myself of, well, I could be doing that, which was always very helpful. And also I think it helped me to never look down on somebody for what they're doing, because if somebody looked down at me washing those eight patients ' dishes, they would of misjudged me completely. Remember, that anybody who tells you that they kind of woke up and were whoever they were, they're kidding you, right? So everybody gets started somewhere. If somebody figured something out, you can too, cuz they did the hard part. They figured it out the first time, right? And so when we meet with a lot of these folks, just know that where you are right now, that could be you in 10, 20 years. Don't measure yourself in terms of my gosh , I've got so far to go. If you end up not running a marathon anytime soon, my father used to run them. I remember him training , and it was a little bit of time, right? And eventually, you get there. Just know that if you keep plugging away, it will work out, right? I'm a big believer , you do the right things, good things happen.
FullB: Like let's say I went out with my husband and we went to dinner and we were meeting people. And they're like, " Oh, what do you do? '' I was like, " Oh, I make things. '' And we'd get in the car  and he'd be like, " Why didn't you say " you were an artist ? '' And I was like , " Well, " you know , I don't know . '' I mean I went to school for it , you know , I make images. But I was just having a hard time I guess accepting that as who I was or what I was going to be. I think I used to really obsess or focus on what I wasn't doing rather than what I was doing. And I think that's a huge... something that can really paralyze you. So I think it's really good to say, " What am I working on? " What is great? What am I happy about? " What am I doing good? '' And to do that and then know that you have a whole life. You'll get there.
EventsA: The narrator washed dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. — The narrator wore heavy gloves to handle communicable diseases. — The narrator started working their way up the ladder. — The narrator remembered that they could be doing the dishwashing job. — The narrator recalled their father training to run marathons.
EventsB: I went out with my husband — We went to dinner — We were meeting people — I said I make things — We got in the car — He asked why I didn't say I was an artist

Q12: One is more about personal development and the other is more about professional development.
Q13: One of the stories is about someone being true to themselves and the other is about someone's journey into their career.
FullA: When I was a kid, I used to hide everything, like hide all the terrible details of my life. And kind of pull them close to me and try to make them look like something else to other people when I told the story. Yeah. And I think when I was 17 and I went away to college , I got very tired of trying to keep track of all my lies. So I decided I would never tell a lie again. I got to tired of it , I walked right in to my college roommate , and I just kinda blurted out like, my mother left me when I was a baby , my father doesn't want me and my cousins all tried to rape me. And I'm not a Christian anymore , I don't believe in God, and I'm here on a scholarship. And I don't think she spoke to me again for the rest of the semester , but basically I think that was a valuable accident I happened upon because after that I was just like the tell all girl. The tell too much girl. And I think when I became a lesbian I continued to be that kind of person, telling everyone about it in a culture that was violently homophobic.
FullB: My name is David Shotts , I'm the Vice President at Ascend Insurance Brokerage and we work directly with the entertainment industry. So, we work with music venues, music festivals, touring artists, event safety, event security companies. I kinda got into this industry by accident. I was playing in a band  and we were touring the country, and having a lot of fun, and not really thinking about insurance, to be quite honest. My broker said no one knows this industry like you, come to work for me , and I have just kind of found out I was really good at it. It's cool because I'll talk to people and I'll tell them  what I do and most commonly people are like, I didn't even know you could get insurance for that. I think it's kind of the beauty of the industry is that the insurance is everywhere. It doesn't just stop with home, auto, life. So if you're into extreme sports, I know a brokerage in California that focuses on extreme sports. If you're into hunting and fishing, I know underwriters that specialize in that industry. Get an idea of what's out there. If you're sitting there going I'm not quite sure what I wan na do in this industry, that's okay. As I said earlier, there's a lot of opportunity in this industry so feel around.
EventsA: I went away to college — I decided I would never tell a lie again — I walked right in to my college roommate — I blurted out my personal story to my roommate — My roommate did not speak to me for the rest of the semester — I became a lesbian — I told everyone about being a lesbian in a homophobic culture
EventsB: David Shotts played in a band — David Shotts toured the country with his band — David Shotts' broker invited him to work for him — David Shotts started working in the insurance industry

Q12: Both sequence basically talk about different things and the only thing that relates them is the fact that they are doing a new job.
Q13: The way the used previous experiences to lead into the final point about being about doing what you want to do are very similar even if the actual experience they had are different.
FullA: I knew during high school that I wanted to study biology and I did try out the research field for a little while. I then took a teaching job in the middle school , and after that, I took a curriculum writing and editing job. You know , I did some good jobs but I did go into them not knowing if okay I'm gon na love this and this is gon na be what I do for the rest of my life. And I think that sometimes young people put that pressure on themselves. I need to know exactly what I'm going to do for the rest of my life and I need to know it now. Yeah. And it's not really realistic , nor do I think that it's necessarily helpful. Just having experiences, those can really help you know who you are and what you want to be about.
FullB: I wrote some compositions. You know , as kids do, I just wrote these little things , and my mother put them in for an arts festival in our village. Everybody, in England, every village has an arts festival. And the time came for giving out the awards and prizes. And he held my compositions above his head  and he said, " These compositions are so bad that not only can I not consider " them for the competition , that goes without saying, " but this young man should be discouraged from ever " composing again . '' That's what he said. So it's important to know what you're after. And then if you know what you're after and you really want it , then you don't look around wondering if you're better or worse than the next person. Because it's not about that. It's about what you want to do.
EventsA: I tried out the research field for a little while — I took a teaching job in the middle school — I took a curriculum writing and editing job
EventsB: I wrote some compositions. — My mother put the compositions in for an arts festival. — The time came for giving out the awards and prizes. — He held my compositions above his head. — He said the compositions were so bad that he could not consider them for the competition. — He said I should be discouraged from ever composing again.

Q12: They both involve going into entrepreneurship but the first event sequence involves a lot of stuff that sequence B does not have.
Q13: Similar in that they had some similar themes like entrepreneurship qualities but a lot of the structure and the way they arrive to that point are almost completely different. The first story the person is more interesting in making something or building it up, the second person is more focus on charity work.
FullA: I'm really an early stage person. I love to make the new thing and so as something gets bigger and more structured , I usually hand it off to people and there's people who love to run stuff that's structured. So when I joined Google we were about 1,200 people and when I left we're over 50 or 60,000 people, so it was sort of fly the plane while you're building the plane. I had gone from working in Silicon Valley and working at Google on a lot of topics. It was fun, incredible teammates. And then I was in Africa for some work with some entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya and I got an email and it said email from the US CTO. And so 33 days later, President Obama called and offered me the job which was incredible. It's an honor to get to serve your country. So when you're doing this work, know that you belong. We all come with different histories and those histories are culture add. There's this weird idea that Silicon Valley had of culture fit. It's very destructive. I don't want you to fit , I want you to add.
FullB: The point of which I decided to be entrepreneur was when talking point just took off. It snowballed from there. So, I have to say my entrepreneurship journey is pretty accidental. Often the public image of an entrepeneur is very glamorous, but actually a lot of my work is not glamorous. And I don't think people see that from the outside. A lot of my role is essentially being a champion. I'm a doer at heart. And it's going from I'm a real doer to I need to delegate or I need to be able to align everyone to get to the same big vision and the big goal. And it's not just me anymore, so kind of a a chicken and an egg where it's both hard and challenging, but exciting.
EventsA: joined Google when it had about 1,200 people — left Google when it had over 50,000 people — went to Africa for work with entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya — received an email from the US CTO — President Obama called and offered the job 33 days later
EventsB: Talking Point took off — I decided to be an entrepreneur

Q12: They are people who academically were struggling but were able to find their way in the end.
Q13: These two stories are about people doing something academically and not feeling like they fit in but they stuck with it and even with some doubt were able to find their niche for their careers.
FullA: called Mary College. And I went on a basketball scholarship. I played ball for them. But I would still party, you know? Pretty, pretty...  pretty crazy back then, and uh... I-I flunked out. I started looking at the-the uh, what I was going to do in the parks here really, really made sense to me. By the time that I got through with that first summer, I realized this is what I want to do for a career. I really did. Two days before my graduation, I was told by this nun -- I went to a catholic boarding school -- she said , " You know, " the best thing you can do with your life , '' she said. She was serious about this. She says, " Get a good job " pumping gas. At a gas station. " And stay with it. That's your life. '' The highlight of my life...  wow, some highlight was that, was going back to that same school and being the last graduation speaker they had. And I got to tell the whole audience, " I'm not working at a gas station, by the way. " I'm a park superintendent. ''
FullB: uh, chemistry teacher, got excited about chemistry. Uh, it made sense. It was the first time that somebody explained to me how science works. And I went to college and I majored in chemistry. That was what I liked , and I liked it there, too. But I just couldn't see going on the way I'd been. I just didn't fit. Ah, and then, I had to figure out, okay, well then , then what? If I think I like the biological approach , and I think maybe I'm interested in its application to people , maybe I should go to medical school. And sometimes you got ta try a lot of things out before you land on one. These days, people will tell you , you know , the average person has five careers. I didn't know that when I was starting out. I thought you had exactly one , and if you messed up in picking it the first time, you were in deep trouble.
EventsA: went on a basketball scholarship — played ball for Mary College — flunked out — started looking at the parks for a career — realized after the first summer that parks was what I wanted to do for a career — was told by a nun two days before graduation to get a job pumping gas and stay with it — went back to the same school and was the last graduation speaker — told the audience that I was a park superintendent and not working at a gas station
EventsB: chemistry teacher got excited about chemistry — somebody explained how science works — I went to college — I majored in chemistry — I couldn't see going on the way I'd been — I had to figure out what to do next — I thought about going to medical school

Q12: They are not remotely similar sequence A is an office worker who saw a girl in a bad condition while the person in sequence B was someone who was beginning to be fed up about their job.
Q13: These two stories are completely different. Story A is about someone using the American dream as a catalyst to help others while Story B is more about someone going out and doing something different with great risk.
FullA: or work in the office or not work. And so I worked in an office , and every place that I worked at I ended up computerizing. Ended up starting a company, um, in manufacturing. But I always, always knew that I was meant to do something to help other people. And I was in Niger. And there was a little girl that came up to me with flies on her face. And I just felt that that's intolerable. I mean, for one thing, that could have been my granddaughter. How could I not do something? I think that I have the opportunity to live what I think should be the American Dream, when what I think should be the American Dream is that we use these resources, we use these talents, to help those that didn't get that.
FullB: rainy, in Seattle, on a project, drinking a tea like this one actually. I was just like, " I can't do this anymore. '' People put up their entire life in their cubicle farm , and it's like their pictures of their vacations , and it's like, " I'm outta here. " This is it. '' And I was drinking a tea, and, " Wow. '' Everyone I went to said it was a horrible idea. " You're doomed to failure, you have no experience, " retail's a painful existence, '' um... " Coffee's where it's at , " so what are you thinking ? '' So it's hard to, how do you kick yourself in the pants? Like, is it easier to get a job and kind of pay the rent, or is the pain of not knowing what your self-actualization greater? And generally, I think, pursuing that pain is pursuing the unknown, which is frightening , and most people don't do it. That's why. It's easier just to just go, just follow the path. But you may wake up in 50 years saying, " What was my, gosh, what the heck did I do? ''
EventsA: worked in an office — computerized every place that I worked at — started a company in manufacturing — was in Niger — a little girl with flies on her face came up to me
EventsB: I said I can't do this anymore. — I decided I'm outta here. — I was drinking a tea. — Everyone I went to said it was a horrible idea.

Q12: A likes to be around big cities to study the soft science of psychology. B taught a stem prograbiology to students during high school.
Q13: A kind of knew what field she wanted to be in. B didn't know what field to major in. With the help of a counselor, she decided.
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I knew during high school that I wanted to study biology and I did try out the research field for a little while. FullA: So I'm a program manager at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and I work in our Criminal Justice Reform Department and we're working to safely reform the criminal justice system. Reduce incarceration while keeping our neighborhood safe , and it's an exciting role , I really love what I do. I love meeting the people who've been impacted by our criminal justice system. I'm also system-impacted. I ultimately spent 12 years in state corrections and it was definitely the toughest part of my life. I came out and I owned what got me incarcerated. Really was able to dive down deep in myself and really think how did I get there. One of things that it's given me is it's given me a perspective that other programs managers that are working in criminal justice reform don't have. I don't know how many different ways we have to recycle a plastic bottle, right? We think of people as disposable  and we've got ta shift the narrative around that, right? We don't want people leaving our jails and prisons and not having opportunities to thrive and contribute. I think there's a lot of work to be done here. And it's a really crazy turn of events of where I've ended up in life , but I feel like I'm where I should be.

EventsA: I spent 12 years in state corrections — I came out — I owned what got me incarcerated — I thought deeply about how I got incarcerated

FullA: Generally, the schools that we work in are pretty negative environments. Our students grow up in homes where they don't necessarily get a chance to learn proper anger management techniques. And so you see a lot of students who get in fights. Or they throw something so that they can get suspended. Or they do something so that they don't have to be there. There's usually something behind that, whether it's they don't feel they are able to succeed. Whether it's they're afraid of what might happen if they do succeed. Whether it's afraid that they are just unable to grasp a concept, so it's kind of sad , but there's always a bright light. City here is there to find those bright lights and make them brighter. We work with kids in attendance, behavior, and course performance, English and math. And our numbers show it, where at the beginning of the year there's so many suspensions, so many fights , and then by the end of the year those are all decreased. You talk about going to something and really wanting to help. What about the people that just don't seem to want it? How did that feel? How'd you work through that? We had these little catchphrases that people throw around , and one of them is, this is hard, be strong. Find something that they do know how to do. Find something that they do like to do, and build that relationship on that. I know that what I do right now is very important. And I'm influencing a student everyday. Every student can succeed , we just need to find the right way to make that happen.

FullA: Made a couple bucks and I wanted to go race. I read about a guy in Motor Trend Magazine who raced at Pike's Peak and he was just basically an average guy. Before I went to Pike's Peak, I read about a race in Nevada called the Silver State Classic. It's a 90 mile race in Nevada where they take a public highway, a state highway , and they just shut it down. And you go as fast as you can go from one city to the next. And so I averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles. So I went 90 miles in 34 minutes. And at that point, I was totally hooked. I got fourth place in the race.

Q12: both involve going to a new place

FullA: My name's Laura , I run Allied Woodshop. We're a collective woodshop. We are home to about eight furniture makers who make their living making furniture in the shop here. And we also teach woodworking classes. Most people think I make my living making furniture , but most of my time is spent managing Allied Woodshop. My whole family has this ethic of working with their hands and being able to do things for themselves. And that's something that I grew up with and I saw , and it's not something that I had in my jobs. I was finding myself in jobs where I was behind computers , I was on the phone. I thought the work was very important , but, at the end of the day, I wasn't very happy with how my time was spent during the day. And so I eventually took a year off, moved up to Northern California. Went to the Krenov School. It's a year-long certificate program on furniture making. That's kind of how I got into woodworking. It's something that keeps me feeling like I'm connected to my family and my roots. So be introspective, and do some soul-searching and think about what your strengths are, what it is that you love to do, and figure out if there's a way to turn that into your career path.
FullB: So I graduated from high school in 2007 and took a trip to Tanzania. Where I met this wonderful young man named John. He told me he wanted to become President of Tanzania which I thought was awesome. But I learned shortly thereafter that he actually couldn't afford to go to high school. You just kind of take a lot of things for granted like I  took the fact that I could go to school for granted, that I could go to college for granted. That's what made this experience of meeting John so shocking to me. And then from there I was inspired to create the School Fund, which is a nonprofit that connects people with student in the developing world that just need a bit of money to continue their education. So one of the things that I think is really awesome about being a young person is, we don't always see all the roadblocks that other adults might see. So here I saw this kid John and I was like, wow this is a big problem, let's do something about it. And I didn't necessarily see all the road blocks of , oh we have to register as a non profit and yadda yadda yadda. We just threw it out there and kinda got going with something. I think it's important that everyone of all ages finds a way to give back, so spend a little time figuring out what you're passionate about and what you enjoy doing and don't be afraid to just jump start and get going with something.
EventsA: She took a year off — She moved up to Northern California — She went to the Krenov School — She completed a year-long certificate program on furniture making
EventsB: graduated from high school in 2007 — took a trip to Tanzania — met a young man named John — learned that John couldn't afford to go to high school — was inspired to create the School Fund

And I didn't know why. And I didn't know what to do with all my emotions. So I was hungry when I could get around good teachers. And I fortunately did and I began dancing. FullA: I'm an Assistant Professor in Astronomy at California Institute of Technology and Caltech. And I study the dynamic universe. So what I do is, with the beautiful telescopes here at Palomar Observatory, we have some robotic telescopes that are continuously making a movie of the night sky. So we image the sky over and over again and we look for what changed. You might go out there and think universe is the same old thing every time , but it's actually not. It's full of these little explosions, which last for a very short amount of time , so they're very But they're very energetic. It's like cosmic fireworks lighting up our sky. So why did you choose to pursue the degree path that you did? I would say that in my own case, I mean , it was not at all clear that one day I would do a PhD. I grew up on a farm in India with 100 cows and fields of weeds and chick peas. And I had left home when I was 15 , and I was a girl in India in a small place. The entire community was up in arms, you know? There were people like neighbors, relatives , you name it. People I haven't even seen before coming into the house and trying to talk my parents out of this crazy decision to send their daughter alone on this journey into other end of the world to pursue something called Astronomy or whatever that was. The community was completely unsupportive. How did you deal with that? In my case, the best way to deal with it was to just let that fade away in the background and not engage with the two directly, but focus on what is motivating me, on what is giving me joy and just let everything else just fade away in the background.
FullB: I've been put in situations where, if you don't talk to this person, your opportunity is gon na pass you by. But once you tell yourself, you know what, I'm gon na not let this opportunity pass, it's just a conscious decision. You know what, I'm just gon na go with it. What's the worst that can happen? And now it's kind of natural. If I need to talk to somebody, I might not want to , but I'll go up and be like yo let's handle this business , you have to have that. You know? Even if you shy, like you just got ta push through it. Once you get through that little fear, everything just comes. So where do you see like your confidence level now? Just I know that I can, like there's nothing you can tell me that I can't do, you know what I'm saying? So, just knowing that in the back of my mind. I got this, no matter what. Even if I don't make it today, I'm gon na make it tomorrow. If I fail today, then I'm gon na get right back up, and do it again. So, knowing that, just having that failure , and then coming back from it. The ground comes under me. I'm just going build a new ground.
EventsA: I studied the dynamic universe — I used robotic telescopes at Palomar Observatory to make a movie of the night sky — I imaged the sky repeatedly to look for changes — I grew up on a farm in India — I left home when I was 15 — The community tried to talk my parents out of sending me away — I decided to focus on my motivation and joy and ignore the community's opposition
EventsB: I told myself I was not going to let the opportunity pass — I decided to go with it — I went up to talk to somebody despite feeling shy — I pushed through my fear — I experienced failure — I got right back up and did it again

You know those Family Circus cartoons, where the kid sort of takes the long way around?
EventsA: went for a semester in Boston — realized I wasn't going to be able to go back because of financial hardship — took two years off from school — worked at a supermarket at night for two years — worked at a bookstore for a little while — booked all the bands that played at the bookstore cafe — worked in the cafe making coffee — realized after a year to a year and a half that I missed writing and sports
EventsB: worked at a comic shop part-time — did samples and sent them off to comic book companies — received 300 rejections — got a job offer from a comic book company — started doing comic books — completed ten pages of comic book work

Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. FullB: I always grew up with tea being a stable at our dining table. One of my colleagues from my previous job, knew a recruiter at eBay and he recommended me and they ended up hiring me. But one day I was trying to make loose-leaf tea at my desk , and by the time I would make it , I would be late for a meeting. And every time I tried to use tea bags instead, I was never satisfied with the quality because it was not as flavorful, it didn't have as much aroma. That was my first point of inspiration to think about the idea for tea drops. It took me about a year and a half of experimenting. I would spend my weekends and my week nights kind of blending and I was obsessed with figuring it out. And once I had that, I started sharing it with my colleagues and friends and family. Now we're available in over 1,600 retail stores. My logic was, even if this failed, even if nothing ever comes of it, I know I would have gained so much in trying
EventsA: lost my job — left my wife — was homeless — a headhunter told me Marvel Comics was looking for somebody with a business background who reads comic books — became president of Marvel Comics

Q12: The two paragraphs describe completely different progressions.
Q13: They both discuss getting motivated, build their successful career.
FullA: My own personal story, I have come to understand that it's a teaching story  and it is my greatest credential, to be really honest with you , is where I've been. I had a childhood that was with a certain privilege but also with a certain degree of violence in my environment and an overlay of alcoholism. And so by the time I was a teenager  and I was slipping into disordered eating, and drug use and abuse, promiscuity, and just poor choices at certain levels. I was really angry. And I didn't know why. And I didn't know what to do with all my emotions. So I was hungry when I could get around good teachers. And I fortunately did and I began dancing. And it was no question in my being that I needed to be moving my body. But it wasn't like okay , and now I'll take steps A, B, and C.  And that's the biggest message I wan na give to all the young people, to know that it's just one right step at a time to build a beautiful career and a life work.
FullB: of airplanes. I mean, just, airplanes was it. I had to fly 'em , I had to build 'em. I had to understand them, study them. The whole nine yards. I was out there in Key West in A7s. It was, um, my second kind of go around ah, to kind of qualify at the ship. And there were plenty of people in front of me that had not qualified and they were sort of farmed off to other careers. Between now and the next three minutes it takes to fly aboard , I'm either gon na get a thumbs up or that's it. You live your life for moments like that. For me, it was, you know, really all about perseverance. Whether it's pride or something else, but failure was just not an option. I'm not gon na wash out. I'm not gon na give up. You have to force yourself out of your comfort zone , I think, a lot of the time just to see who you are and how the world reacts to you.
EventsA: I had a childhood with a certain degree of violence and an overlay of alcoholism — I slipped into disordered eating, drug use and abuse, and promiscuity as a teenager — I was really angry — I was hungry when I could get around good teachers — I began dancing
EventsB: He flew airplanes. — He built airplanes. — He studied airplanes. — He was in Key West in A7s. — He tried to qualify at the ship for the second time. — He faced a moment where he would either get a thumbs up or fail.

FullA: I remember when I turned 30 , I was so depressed on that birthday cuz I felt like I had not accomplished what I needed to and what my friends had accomplished. I just felt that all the people around me had it so much more together than I did , and I should say I started Linda.com when I was 40 , so I'm gon na turn 60 in January. And I didn't touch a computer until I was 28 years old. So I had a lot of life between when I found my career, my calling. And I definitely felt that I wasn't good enough and that I, and I don't know, I think almost , that's almost normal. You're in the majority of people who don't know what they want and what they like until they experience it.
FullB: We had a lot of bad things happen on our tour , we had the double truck suicide bomb, blew up our base , we had multiple mass casualties , there's some really bad stuff that happened out there. I know a lot of guys that have true PTSD, and struggle with it , and they struggled with, finding something that identify themselves with, and have some sort of self worth. My self worth comes from working, and feeding my family, and doing something that I enjoy. The area we have chosen to hunt in is much higher , and in more difficult terrain, but that's where the big bull taur live. Little time just being by yourself in nature that, that's what recharges my batteries. There's just something about being outdoors that does it for me, always has, ever since I was a little kid.
EventsA: I turned 30 — I felt depressed on my 30th birthday — I started Linda.com when I was 40 — I didn't touch a computer until I was 28
EventsB: a double truck suicide bomb happened — the base blew up — multiple mass casualties occurred

Q12: They both went through their work history.

FullA: I work here at Fossil. I'm an IT solution manager working in the e-commerce division. Typically a day in e-commerce for me , I manage a team that we're currently rolling out global websites for fossil.com. But I didn't know growing up what is it that I wanted to do , okay? I took a leap of faith , and so in 2000 I started a company called BTV Corporation and where I was doing consulting work for about eight years. It was a little bit risky , but I think the way to advance , you're going to have to take risk, right? But you want it to be a calculated risk. You want to make sure that you're making smart decisions, okay, and not impulse decisions, if you will. So, would my life be different had I not started my own company or even came to Fossil? I'm sure it would be. I don't know what that would be , but I would say , in the end, I am happy with where that journey took me and I appreciate all those that's been around me to kinda support me through that effort.
FullB: When I was really little I think I had a few teachers when I was in kindergarten and first grade that I just adored. And so I would come home and practice being a teacher. From then on, I kind of just thought that's what I wanted to do. And I actually didn't know that I was dyslexic until I started my college career. I did a little part-time internship in a first grade room  and in that classroom, there were kiddos with dyslexia. And so I was learning more with the teacher, just kind of asking questions. And the more that I learned about it, the more it hit home that that's exactly what was going on with me as a kiddo. But it's amazing to get to teach student with dyslexia now. And know exactly what they're going through. It's just , it's really neat that they had that, they had that connection with me.
EventsA: I took a leap of faith — I started a company called BTV Corporation in 2000 — I did consulting work for about eight years

Q12: They were both about actions in other countries.
Q13: They were both about foreign cultures adapting to American culture.
FullA: I was born and raised in Chicago , but my first language is Spanish because everybody in my family spoke Spanish. From the moment I learned a bit of English, I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter. I started seeing kind of more of how the disenfranchised were being treated. This was pretty much the ah-hah moment for me and the other co-founder Victor Arellano. We were at the Department of Homeland Security here in Chicago. I was gon na do an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test. So this Polish couple gets called , federal agent comes up that's gon na administer the test. And he says , well, where's your interpreter? And they were just kind of like, I don't know. And she yells out at the crowd in the waiting room, does anybody here speak Polish? Some lady raises her hand , she's like, I speak Polish. So mind you , now one of the most important interviews of this couple's life lays in the balance of a person that says she speaks Polish, which she very well might. But how do you know how much her proficiency is in that language? And that's kinda like, where we're just like, you know what? There has to be a better way , there has to be a better way. So that's kind of where Interpreter Tap was born.
FullB: and um, co-owner of two restaurants, and how did you get from where you were at our age to where you are right now?  [New Zealand accent] I suppose at your age, I left school and really the same thing, I was totally unsure of what I wanted to do. I had um , a burning passion, which was not to cook -- mine was to travel. Went to Israel and worked on a kabutz for six months  'cause I met an Israeli guy and thought, " Oh this is quite cool . '' And started cooking in the kitchens there , and I was cooking with a couple of women who said to me then, " My god, you've got such a good talent for this. '' Then came home and thought, " Yup, this is what I'm gon na do. " I can just sort of live at Mum and Dad's " and save and go through uni, '' and then just started from there.  What kept you from just going out and doing something else?  'Cause I knew I couldn't, I didn't wan na do anything else. I knew, no matter how hard it was gon na be, I had to just keep going. I just had to keep going. 'Cause really, the whole thing is, you're focusing on what you wan na do.
EventsA: I learned a bit of English — I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter — I started seeing how the disenfranchised were being treated — I and Victor Arellano were at the Department of Homeland Security in Chicago — I did an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test — A federal agent asked the Polish couple where their interpreter was — A woman in the waiting room said she spoke Polish — Interpreter Tap was born
EventsB: left school — went to Israel — worked on a kabutz for six months — met an Israeli guy — started cooking in the kitchens there — cooked with a couple of women who praised my talent — came home — decided to pursue cooking — started university

Q12: One talked about their incarcerations whilst the other talked about their internships.
Q13: They both introduced their backgrounds to the readers.
FullA: So I'm a program manager at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and I work in our Criminal Justice Reform Department and we're working to safely reform the criminal justice system. Reduce incarceration while keeping our neighborhood safe , and it's an exciting role , I really love what I do. I love meeting the people who've been impacted by our criminal justice system. I'm also system-impacted. I ultimately spent 12 years in state corrections and it was definitely the toughest part of my life. I came out and I owned what got me incarcerated. Really was able to dive down deep in myself and really think how did I get there. One of things that it's given me is it's given me a perspective that other programs managers that are working in criminal justice reform don't have. I don't know how many different ways we have to recycle a plastic bottle, right? We think of people as disposable  and we've got ta shift the narrative around that, right? We don't want people leaving our jails and prisons and not having opportunities to thrive and contribute. I think there's a lot of work to be done here. And it's a really crazy turn of events of where I've ended up in life , but I feel like I'm where I should be.
FullB: My name is Tom Arviso, Jr. , I'm the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated. And I've been here about 27 years now. And I started here as a college intern. And I studied journalism with the intent of becoming a sports writer. That was my passion. But once I got here to the Navajo Times, things just kind of gradually evolved , and I just kind of rose through the ranks to the point where now I'm running the company. I never looked back ever since I started doing that and just been trying to go and do as much as I can possibly do in regards to telling stories, telling people stories, and being good at it. Being right. Being ethical. Being honest. This profession, it's a field where you really have to have a passion for what you're doing, a belief in being a storyteller. If you're sincere about what you do, about your craft, about being a good journalist, then things will fall into place for you if you're patient.
EventsA: I spent 12 years in state corrections — I came out — I owned what got me incarcerated — I thought deeply about how I got incarcerated
EventsB: Tom Arviso, Jr. started as a college intern at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. rose through the ranks at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. became the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated.

FullA: I'm really an early stage person. I love to make the new thing and so as something gets bigger and more structured , I usually hand it off to people and there's people who love to run stuff that's structured. So when I joined Google we were about 1,200 people and when I left we're over 50 or 60,000 people, so it was sort of fly the plane while you're building the plane. I had gone from working in Silicon Valley and working at Google on a lot of topics. It was fun, incredible teammates. And then I was in Africa for some work with some entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya and I got an email and it said email from the US CTO. And so 33 days later, President Obama called and offered me the job which was incredible. It's an honor to get to serve your country. So when you're doing this work, know that you belong. We all come with different histories and those histories are culture add. There's this weird idea that Silicon Valley had of culture fit. It's very destructive. I don't want you to fit , I want you to add.

A lot of my role is essentially being a champion. I'm a doer at heart. And it's going from I'm a real doer to I need to delegate or I need to be able to align everyone to get to the same big vision and the big goal. And it's not just me anymore, so kind of a a chicken and an egg where it's both hard and challenging, but exciting.
EventsA: joined Google when it had about 1,200 people — left Google when it had over 50,000 people — went to Africa for work with entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya — received an email from the US CTO — President Obama called and offered the job 33 days later

Q12: the two stories are completely different and do not overlap in anything

FullA: This is our physical space in Los Angeles. We started it in 2002, ten years ago as I mentioned in honor of my folks who were community activists and died much too early in my life. Losing my family very young was kind of a life changing experience. I've been working in the film industry for a number of years  and so to kind of channel that energy and that angst I was feeling, I wanted to open a school, a cinema and a retail space. I really don't want today just to be about me and because obviously Lisa Marr is a teacher. We fell in love, she'll tell the story much better than I, but literally on the opening day - I was walking around in my neighborhood of Echo Park and I walked into a storefront and there was this man there and he had a beard and he said , we're opening a film center today. She was walking down the street  and I said we're opening a film center and she's like, really? And she came in and she started volunteering and we had this platonic relationship that evolved into a romantic relationship. It was the beginning of a whole new chapter in my life. I had just started making films. I had been in a band for many years and did some photography and painting and there was this space right in my own neighborhood that was opening and encouraging people to come in and exchange ideas and watch films together and make their own movies. The education, in the last 10 years we've taught a couple of thousand kids for free. So for the ten year anniversary, we decided let's take everything we do on the road. Again, for us, filmmaking is about storytelling. It's not about the technology , it's not about expensive equipment , it's about an idea and some energy.
FullB: He was exploring the deep sea, deep sea submersible. And I asked my dad, " What does that guy do? '' Ah, and he said, " He's a marine biologist. '' And really, that was it , okay. " I'm gon na be a marine " biologist. '' You know , I knew I could go to school and be a marine biologist , you know? I knew that there was a degree that I could get. But nobody really ever counseled that a degree wasn't a job. And it wasn't until the last year or two that I had the epiphany that, okay , I'm gon na have my degree, my life's dream, but that's not a job. I don't have a career leaving college. I don't know what I wan na do. I knew what I wanted to do for my whole life. Too many times, people are doing things because they think they should be doing them.
EventsA: Started the physical space in Los Angeles in 2002 — Walked into a storefront in Echo Park on the opening day — Met a man with a beard who said they were opening a film center — Lisa Marr walked down the street and entered the film center — Lisa Marr started volunteering at the film center — Their platonic relationship evolved into a romantic relationship — Decided to take everything they do on the road for the ten year anniversary

Q12: what makes them similar is that the two people are trying to figure out what they want to do in life
Q13: what makes them similar is that the two people are trying to figure out what they want to do in life
FullA: I wanted to be an artist when I was in high school , but I actually started in nursing school. We were really poor , and my dad died when I was six , and I saw my mom struggle working in a sewing factory. And I thought , well this is crazy to be a starving artist. I better do something practical. So I went to school for nursing. And photography and me was a better fit. It just felt like a better fit. So, started at the Miami Herald as a staff photographer, just from there moved on to do international stories, so I bounced around a lot. I traveled a whole lot. You know, when you can capture a moment, capture history , I don't know, just preserve that second of time, that's meaningful in some way. If it makes you feel, it's probably gon na make someone else feel too. But those were the moments that I always look for. And I feel like there's all different types of photography that you have to appreciate. You can do all these stylized beautiful perfectly composed pictures , but for me, journalism, I think the only thing that matters is the content in the moment and making someone feel. Because you can make someone think, but to make someone feel is the ultimate goal. The more you can do to connect people, the less hatred there will be in the world, the more understanding there will be.
FullB: and I suddenly realized something about science that I hadn't know before which was that if I wanted to be in science I'd have to pick one thing and I liked everything way too much to pick one thing. I really loved writing. I really loved helping students and teaching and I loved art  and with all that known, I kind of went off to Boston University with a vague idea of something communications. I did not know  and it wasn't until I was in my sophomore year and I was taking that first journalism class that they teach and then one day Professor Brand said, " What are you majoring in? '' And I said, " I don't know. PR? '' And he said, " PR?! " The best people are in journalism , you can do this! You could be in journalism , '' and I thought, " Wow . '' In hindsight everything has come together almost eerily logically. How did you prepare to take those risks when nothing really felt like it was going to come together? People would say to me, " Oh newspaper? " You'll never get a job in a newspaper. Never! '' I thought, ` Why not? It could happen to me , it's as likely as anybody else. ' And then my job is, make it as likely as I can make it by being as good as I can.
EventsA: My dad died when I was six — I saw my mom struggle working in a sewing factory — I went to school for nursing — I started at the Miami Herald as a staff photographer — I moved on to do international stories — I traveled a whole lot
EventsB: I realized I had to pick one thing in science — I went to Boston University with a vague idea of something communications — I took the first journalism class in my sophomore year — Professor Brand asked me what I was majoring in — I said I didn't know and suggested PR — Professor Brand encouraged me to pursue journalism

Q12: both of the stories are some what similar because they talk about pursuing paths in life
Q13: both of the stories are some what similar because they talk about pursuing paths in life
FullA: I'm from El Salvador. I came to the United States when I was eight years old. My mom left me at age four with my grandma and my sister that was two years old at the time. Obviously searching for the American dream. So I was in El Salvador. My grandma raised me until I was eight and I remember one day she's like so your mom says one of you can go with her. And that's cuz my mum had finally saved enough money to pay a coyotaje. And so my mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States and so I remember being with a group of people and I was the only child. I'm lucky that I was I was okay the whole time , but it was a journey of about over a month. How do you still have a story of yourself that you identify with, that a lot of people don't relate to. But then still have this professional grounding, this world that you've created for yourself? I think it traces back to family. I get my work ethic from my mother. And it's because in high school she was working all the time. The financial struggle that I saw at home, also pushed me to complete my four year degree cuz I knew I wanted more. And even today, she still has the same lifestyle. I live at home with her still. But ever since the day I came back from college, I support financially. So I know that I have to provide rent money in order for my mom, my sister, my niece to have a home. Cuz my sister's also a single mom.
FullB: That sophomore year was that critical year where everything kind of just hit me that you really have to take ownership of this education thing. The investment you're making in time and money has a lot of risk or potential to be wasted. And I didn't have the good fortune of something being maybe given to me on the back end in terms of a family business or something I could fall back on. I really had to make something happen in school. That wasn't maybe very clear to me, that freshman, first part of sophomore year. But the sophomore year came to a close. I started to get my act together a little bit and find that direction. Maybe as I said earlier, it's really about being drawn to the next adventure in career or life. Some of the most impactful job changes weren't necessarily going to the next higher level of responsibility, but really more what people might consider lateral moves. Those lateral moves really had an impact on expanding my breadth of experience, my understanding. When you're not driven just by the financial rewards , but you're driven by the broader set of rewards, how it makes  you feel inside, how you can impact people around you. I feel those are the things that really start to hit home in terms of making the right choices, at least for me. I think we all have to find that path for ourselves, though.
EventsA: My mom left me with my grandma and my sister — My grandma raised me until I was eight — My mom said one of us could go with her — My mom saved enough money to pay a coyotaje — My mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States — I traveled with a group of people to the United States — I completed my four year degree — I came back from college — I started supporting my family financially — I provided rent money for my mom, sister, and niece
EventsB: The sophomore year came to a close — I started to get my act together — I found that direction

Q12: Both feature a moment of truth.
Q13: Both stories are about persevering in the face of adversity.
FullA: My own personal story, I have come to understand that it's a teaching story  and it is my greatest credential, to be really honest with you , is where I've been. I had a childhood that was with a certain privilege but also with a certain degree of violence in my environment and an overlay of alcoholism. And so by the time I was a teenager  and I was slipping into disordered eating, and drug use and abuse, promiscuity, and just poor choices at certain levels. I was really angry. And I didn't know why. And I didn't know what to do with all my emotions. So I was hungry when I could get around good teachers. And I fortunately did and I began dancing. And it was no question in my being that I needed to be moving my body. But it wasn't like okay , and now I'll take steps A, B, and C.  And that's the biggest message I wan na give to all the young people, to know that it's just one right step at a time to build a beautiful career and a life work.
FullB: of airplanes. I mean, just, airplanes was it. I had to fly 'em , I had to build 'em. I had to understand them, study them. The whole nine yards. I was out there in Key West in A7s. It was, um, my second kind of go around ah, to kind of qualify at the ship. And there were plenty of people in front of me that had not qualified and they were sort of farmed off to other careers. Between now and the next three minutes it takes to fly aboard , I'm either gon na get a thumbs up or that's it. You live your life for moments like that. For me, it was, you know, really all about perseverance. Whether it's pride or something else, but failure was just not an option. I'm not gon na wash out. I'm not gon na give up. You have to force yourself out of your comfort zone , I think, a lot of the time just to see who you are and how the world reacts to you.
EventsA: I had a childhood with a certain degree of violence and an overlay of alcoholism — I slipped into disordered eating, drug use and abuse, and promiscuity as a teenager — I was really angry — I was hungry when I could get around good teachers — I began dancing
EventsB: He flew airplanes. — He built airplanes. — He studied airplanes. — He was in Key West in A7s. — He tried to qualify at the ship for the second time. — He faced a moment where he would either get a thumbs up or fail.

Q12: Completely different industries.
Q13: Both narrators are talking about something they're incredibly passionate about, and briefly describe what they're doing in those industries.
FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
FullB: I always knew I wanted to do journalism since I was a little kid. I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade. But by the time I graduated , I still didn't know if I wanted to do newspaper, or if I wanted to do TV and I ended up doing TV. And I just feel like, I just really enjoy just talking to people, in general. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. I feel sometimes like, am I stunting myself in my career? Am I where I'm supposed to be right now? Am I doing all that I can to get to the next point? But you don't always know if you're doing the right thing , but I don't know , it works out. I feel like things work themselves out. They do. They just do.
EventsA: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science
EventsB: I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade — I graduated — I ended up doing TV

Q12: Both stories end up in insurance.
Q13: Both stories feature narrators that found themselves in insurance without looking for it. Both stories also mention how insurance can be used for any number of things.
FullA: My name is David Shotts , I'm the Vice President at Ascend Insurance Brokerage and we work directly with the entertainment industry. So, we work with music venues, music festivals, touring artists, event safety, event security companies. I kinda got into this industry by accident. I was playing in a band  and we were touring the country, and having a lot of fun, and not really thinking about insurance, to be quite honest. My broker said no one knows this industry like you, come to work for me , and I have just kind of found out I was really good at it. It's cool because I'll talk to people and I'll tell them  what I do and most commonly people are like, I didn't even know you could get insurance for that. I think it's kind of the beauty of the industry is that the insurance is everywhere. It doesn't just stop with home, auto, life. So if you're into extreme sports, I know a brokerage in California that focuses on extreme sports. If you're into hunting and fishing, I know underwriters that specialize in that industry. Get an idea of what's out there. If you're sitting there going I'm not quite sure what I wan na do in this industry, that's okay. As I said earlier, there's a lot of opportunity in this industry so feel around.
FullB: I'm Laura Woop. I am the director of risk management at Tiffany & Co.. I started that Tiffany not in insurance. And back when I was in school, had I even thought I was interested in insurance, there wasn't any programs at that point, right? So a lot of us that are in the industry now don't have that sort of experience or schooling in our background. Risk management means we're responsible for insuring the assets of the company whether those are our employees, or jewelry, our property or buildings. And protecting us from the risks that are generated by the things that we do in the course of our business. Taking jewelry out on photo  shoots, our jewelry isn't just sitting in a case waiting for someone to buy it, right? It's working for us every day. And just by virtue of that fact, it's creating an exposure. Most people would think insurance is just boring and a stuffy suit type job. Yes it is the insurance industry , but I'm not living my day in an insurance policy day in and day out. It's something different everyday. If you're an accountant, you're doing debits and credits everyday, right? When I graduated, I realized I do not wan na do debits and credits everyday. So I'm very happy that I found the path that I did, even if it took a couple of turns to get there.
EventsA: David Shotts played in a band — David Shotts toured the country with his band — David Shotts' broker invited him to work for him — David Shotts started working in the insurance industry
EventsB: Laura Woop started working at Tiffany & Co. — Laura Woop realized there were no insurance programs when she was in school — Laura Woop became responsible for insuring the assets of the company — Jewelry was taken out on photo shoots — Laura Woop graduated — Laura Woop decided she did not want to do debits and credits every day — Laura Woop found her career path in risk management

FullA: When I joined the military, I had literally nothing. I was in a holding center, in a juvenile holding center and my recruiter came and rescued me. When I joined the military, I originally signed up as a gunner's mate. I got out, felt like something was missing, I ended up moving out here for a job, and I was, like, guns , I know guns. I can do this job, that was easy. That was my turnaround moment. Okay.

And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. I really love doing what I do, and hearing these stories from these individuals that come up to you and say hey , I would not be where I am today if it wasn't for my experience with SLUG Magazine.
