Q12: They took their personal experience and done started a task related to this.
Q13: They both involved a decision by the writer to get involved in the subject of their perspective stories by making it their career.
FullA: So I entered foster care when I was about three and a half years old. During that time, I had 14 different foster homes. I wasn't always placed in the most ideal circumstances. These were people who had problems with drugs, alcohol, violence, pedophilia. So I had this sense of I've got ta do something. I've got ta say something , this is not okay, and that kind of kept eating at me. And I think that's the motivation that kept me from turning to drugs, or running away, or becoming part of that statistic, that label that they expected of me. I had to do something differently. And so all of that gave me this perspective that it's not enough to complain about something if you're not willing to be a part of the solution. So a really big sticking point for me was that I'm not just going to walk around complaining about foster care or complaining about this system of care that's not protecting kids, no. I wan na be directly involved in the very system that failed me so that I can make it better. And I ultimately opened a non-profit organization that provides direct services to children and families. So all of my experiences kind of led to me serving others in a way that I wish I had been served when I was a young person.
FullB: towards food that I did. And so we would entertain a lot of our friends. And so all the wine dinners, all of a sudden , somehow we started home brewing. It was a simple enough question that deserved a simple answer. " Well there aren't any good American beers , " well we will supply the pipeline. '' And so we started a really naive way of thinking , but I really believe that all good thoughts come out of just a desire, a simple idea. And then the passion that you have is gon na really drive that.

Q12: Similar steps from college to career.
Q13: Both involve continuing their education.
FullA: When I got out of college, I went into the Army Reserve, through the Communications Officer. And ended up back in 89 getting a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory. At an Engineer and Developing Technology, to make weapons smarter, new technology to be able to kind of carry weapons. And so this whole focus was on creating capability. But when you're in the entrepreneurship world and the commercial world, that's a different mindset. Yeah. See, when I worked for the government. I could spend the government money on my ideas. But I'm out here as an entrepreneur , I have to spend my own money. So that was hard for me, to try to get that switch going on. My approach, and what I always tell people is you have to start connecting, networking. And a lot of people thinks that's hard , but it is not really hard. It's just a matter of meeting people , and let them know what you do or what you wan na do.
FullB: My wife and I call ourselves, laughingly, that we're fixers , so it's our job now to go in and help institutions and organizations that are flailing or floundering. Because my wife, myself, we come from a generation where we were told Indians are good with their hands, they're not meant for college. So just get a high school education and go to work. What drove me truly was, I wanted to help my people and I went to Community College , transferred to Black Hills State College , graduated from there in 1985. And immediately after law school, immediately came home to the reservation and there were no jobs in the Legal Profession. But the college had a directors position in institutional development and they hired me. And lo and behold they hired me as the acting president in 1991. So that's become the passion now is to help our children and our grandchildren to succeed and to again, instill with them a higher passion than just a job from eight to five.
EventsA: I got out of college — I went into the Army Reserve through the Communications Officer — I got a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory — I worked at an Engineer and Developing Technology to make weapons smarter — I tried to get the switch going on from government work to entrepreneurship
EventsB: I went to Community College — I transferred to Black Hills State College — I graduated from Black Hills State College in 1985 — I finished law school — I came home to the reservation — The college hired me as a director in institutional development — The college hired me as the acting president in 1991

Q12: One talks about their academic history while the other is talking about their failed music effort.
Q13: Both talk about their professional career but have different journeys.
FullA: I knew during high school that I wanted to study biology and I did try out the research field for a little while. I then took a teaching job in the middle school , and after that, I took a curriculum writing and editing job. You know , I did some good jobs but I did go into them not knowing if okay I'm gon na love this and this is gon na be what I do for the rest of my life. And I think that sometimes young people put that pressure on themselves. I need to know exactly what I'm going to do for the rest of my life and I need to know it now. Yeah. And it's not really realistic , nor do I think that it's necessarily helpful. Just having experiences, those can really help you know who you are and what you want to be about.
FullB: I wrote some compositions. You know , as kids do, I just wrote these little things , and my mother put them in for an arts festival in our village. Everybody, in England, every village has an arts festival. And the time came for giving out the awards and prizes. And he held my compositions above his head  and he said, " These compositions are so bad that not only can I not consider " them for the competition , that goes without saying, " but this young man should be discouraged from ever " composing again . '' That's what he said. So it's important to know what you're after. And then if you know what you're after and you really want it , then you don't look around wondering if you're better or worse than the next person. Because it's not about that. It's about what you want to do.
EventsA: I tried out the research field for a little while — I took a teaching job in the middle school — I took a curriculum writing and editing job
EventsB: I wrote some compositions. — My mother put the compositions in for an arts festival. — The time came for giving out the awards and prizes. — He held my compositions above his head. — He said the compositions were so bad that he could not consider them for the competition. — He said I should be discouraged from ever composing again.

Q12: Story A is more in depth and gives a narrative about overcoming struggle while story B is just a sentence about something that happened.
Q13: Both stories talk about overcoming struggles but story A is more focused on family.
FullA: I'm from El Salvador. I came to the United States when I was eight years old. My mom left me at age four with my grandma and my sister that was two years old at the time. Obviously searching for the American dream. So I was in El Salvador. My grandma raised me until I was eight and I remember one day she's like so your mom says one of you can go with her. And that's cuz my mum had finally saved enough money to pay a coyotaje. And so my mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States and so I remember being with a group of people and I was the only child. I'm lucky that I was I was okay the whole time , but it was a journey of about over a month. How do you still have a story of yourself that you identify with, that a lot of people don't relate to. But then still have this professional grounding, this world that you've created for yourself? I think it traces back to family. I get my work ethic from my mother. And it's because in high school she was working all the time. The financial struggle that I saw at home, also pushed me to complete my four year degree cuz I knew I wanted more. And even today, she still has the same lifestyle. I live at home with her still. But ever since the day I came back from college, I support financially. So I know that I have to provide rent money in order for my mom, my sister, my niece to have a home. Cuz my sister's also a single mom.
FullB: August of 2005 , I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina. And then September of 2005 was when I received my cancer diagnosis. So it's like this happened and then this happened. And so, hey, you're a veteran now. And I really didn't know what that meant. Mm-hm. But it basically meant that I was on my own. And I had thought at that particular time that maybe I was an isolated case and then I saw that there were tens of thousands of women veterans who were homeless. Is that what helped motivate you to provide this non-profit organization for homeless women and children? Yes, it definitely was. It's ultimately like everything came full circle, that maybe this is why I went through these things. So I had to be that catalyst, to be that voice for this forgotten population.
EventsA: My mom left me with my grandma and my sister — My grandma raised me until I was eight — My mom said one of us could go with her — My mom saved enough money to pay a coyotaje — My mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States — I traveled with a group of people to the United States — I completed my four year degree — I came back from college — I started supporting my family financially — I provided rent money for my mom, sister, and niece
EventsB: I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina — I received my cancer diagnosis

Q12: Two differrent topics being discussed.
Q13: They are on two totally different topics
FullA: Born and raised here in Detroit. I went to public school. I knew I wanted to go to college but didn't know how I was gon na get there. Had a very supportive family, but financially , we didn't have any money tucked away. And fortunately, I was able to get a scholarship to a college. Got my Bachelor's degree in communication. Out of college, I did sales for a number of years just kind of really trying to find my way. And my wife was a student here at Wayne Community College , they had an opportunity, an opening on the phones. One day the chancellor of the college was on the other end and I had no clue. And I was just excited to be answering phones for the college. And he wanted to meet me and I had opportunities to advance from there. Now I am the associate vice chancellor for students services. So, I tell everybody, I'm not supposed to be here, statistically speaking. I'm a black male  and I grew up in Detroit with all the gang violence, with all the drug violence. So, don't be defined by the neighborhoods that you came from. Don't be defined by whether or not you're a first generation college student, whether you're a minority. Whatever that is, you can go and do and be whoever you wan na be.
FullB: You were there for Toy Story and. I was there for Toy, that's what I was hired to do, is Toy Story. Art direct Toy Story. Cool. Every project is so different. Every four years is a four year graduate course in the subject matter of that film. And just to take advantage of that, have fun with some research. Once you get interested in something, go and find out as much as you can about it. It's not that hard to do, especially with the Internet. You can always get a dozen books on the subject and just read through them, and just keep doing that. That's really it.
EventsA: I got a scholarship to a college — I got my Bachelor's degree in communication — I did sales for a number of years — My wife was a student at Wayne Community College — I answered phones for the college — The chancellor of the college wanted to meet me — I had opportunities to advance from there — I became the associate vice chancellor for student services
EventsB: You were there for Toy Story. — I was hired to art direct Toy Story.

Q12: Both talk about their careers, though they do different things.
Q13: They both talk about their professional journey, but story A is more robotic and mechanical while story B gives more of a look into the writers personal struggles along the way.
FullA: When I got out of college, I went into the Army Reserve, through the Communications Officer. And ended up back in 89 getting a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory. At an Engineer and Developing Technology, to make weapons smarter, new technology to be able to kind of carry weapons. And so this whole focus was on creating capability. But when you're in the entrepreneurship world and the commercial world, that's a different mindset. Yeah. See, when I worked for the government. I could spend the government money on my ideas. But I'm out here as an entrepreneur , I have to spend my own money. So that was hard for me, to try to get that switch going on. My approach, and what I always tell people is you have to start connecting, networking. And a lot of people thinks that's hard , but it is not really hard. It's just a matter of meeting people , and let them know what you do or what you wan na do.
FullB: My wife and I call ourselves, laughingly, that we're fixers , so it's our job now to go in and help institutions and organizations that are flailing or floundering. Because my wife, myself, we come from a generation where we were told Indians are good with their hands, they're not meant for college. So just get a high school education and go to work. What drove me truly was, I wanted to help my people and I went to Community College , transferred to Black Hills State College , graduated from there in 1985. And immediately after law school, immediately came home to the reservation and there were no jobs in the Legal Profession. But the college had a directors position in institutional development and they hired me. And lo and behold they hired me as the acting president in 1991. So that's become the passion now is to help our children and our grandchildren to succeed and to again, instill with them a higher passion than just a job from eight to five.
EventsA: I got out of college — I went into the Army Reserve through the Communications Officer — I got a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory — I worked at an Engineer and Developing Technology to make weapons smarter — I tried to get the switch going on from government work to entrepreneurship
EventsB: I went to Community College — I transferred to Black Hills State College — I graduated from Black Hills State College in 1985 — I finished law school — I came home to the reservation — The college hired me as a director in institutional development — The college hired me as the acting president in 1991

Q12: One story discusses from the third party angle and the other is from the first hand perspective and on a different topic.
Q13: Both discuss things that bring them interest
FullA: I'm 53 years old , I'm trying to decide what I'm gon na do when I grow up. My grandfather farmed , he went out and said , hey do you wan na plant a garden? And I got started that way , we planted some radishes in a spot about this big and I thought it was the coolest thing. I was debating between agriculture and ornamental horticulture, like growing flowers. But I thought if I'm gon na spend my life doing something, I would rather spend my life helping to feed the world. So our job is to develop a hybrid seed that will help the farmer in his business. So if you take two inbreds, like that , and you cross them , that's your hybrid. So people are like, why do you have hybrids? It's like, that's why I have hybrids. Some people feel like , okay , I just wan na make a lot of money. But if you can find something you have a passion for, you love it, you think about it in the morning when you wake up. And then you can figure out an intersection of that thing with something that you can make a living doing , That's a pretty sweet place to be.
FullB: the Olympics. So I always wanted to be on an Olympic team. And uh, my aunt lived next to a bicycle store , and they had a Sunday morning bicycle ride , and I went on the Sunday morning bike ride. And the owner of the store said, " I can make you an Olympic " cycling team. '' So I stopped playing football , I stopped running track, and I rode a bike. It was pretty simple. From my family, I had, I had great support. It was different in school. I always felt I was challenged because I wanted to race a bike or be a professional athlete. And there was no preparation for that, you know? " What do you mean? " You're gon na do this as a profession? '' You know , part of the challenge of youth is to learn, right? It's the puzzle. That's ... that's what makes life interesting. If you have all the answers, then it'd be very boring.
EventsA: Grandfather asked if they wanted to plant a garden — They planted some radishes in a small spot — They debated between agriculture and ornamental horticulture — They decided to spend their life helping to feed the world — They developed a hybrid seed to help farmers — They crossed two inbred plants to create a hybrid
EventsB: I went on the Sunday morning bike ride — The owner of the store said he could make me an Olympic cycling team — I stopped playing football — I stopped running track — I rode a bike

Q12: Start off in the same environment at college, set back, and then where they are now.
Q13: Both stories discuss a slight set back in their life that influenced what they are doing now.
FullA: And so I had kind of just spent three years, three-four years, um, just kind of working service jobs. I finally enrolled back in college , but I really didn't know what I wanted to do. And so I ended up , you know, I mean, basically partying my one year in college away. You know , my grades were so bad , I wasn't invited to go back. I think, just kind of at the back of my mind , I had always wanted to do something that was creative. But, you know, when you're growing up on the reservation, I mean, you can be creative, but you probably won't get paid for it. 'Cause when I started doing radio, I absolutely loved it  and, you know , I just ran with it. I tried to do the best job that I could. It was while I was doing that job that I stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary that I worked on. I mean , I kind of just went with the film thing from there. I think you just know when you discover what it is that you want to do.
FullB: and uh, loved it. You know, I was in one of those graduate programs and on, you know, a good salary , and I enjoyed it , but I always felt like I couldn't express myself enough and there was perhaps, ah, some environment somewhere where I could really make a difference. And you know , I was almost nine years in the bank. I could have gotten my superannuation and been set up with a nice house somewhere. I didn't wan na be that person in years, you know, in years in the future, uh, and not have had taken risks. And I was in a very comfortable environment , and I just didn't have this need to take a risk , and I was like excited about taking a risk and not really knowing what the outcome would be. And uh, we didn't know a whole lot back then , but we just made our classes so much fun. People would laugh the whole way through , and so as a result, it just exploded. We went from 23 people our first night to about 200 people after eight weeks. If you've got that feeling inside that there's something else, it's very hard to get rid of -- which is a good thing. I think there's that something driving you to say , " Well there's something else " out there . ''
EventsA: enrolled back in college — partied the one year in college away — was not invited to go back to college — started doing radio — stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary — worked on the first documentary
EventsB: I was in one of those graduate programs — I was almost nine years in the bank — We made our classes fun — The number of people in the class grew from 23 to about 200 after eight weeks

Q12: Both sequences discuss how they started, the events that impacted them, and how they found their passion for their career.
Q13: Both stories discuss how they began and got inspiration to find their passion.
FullA: I was born and raised in Chicago , but my first language is Spanish because everybody in my family spoke Spanish. From the moment I learned a bit of English, I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter. I started seeing kind of more of how the disenfranchised were being treated. This was pretty much the ah-hah moment for me and the other co-founder Victor Arellano. We were at the Department of Homeland Security here in Chicago. I was gon na do an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test. So this Polish couple gets called , federal agent comes up that's gon na administer the test. And he says , well, where's your interpreter? And they were just kind of like, I don't know. And she yells out at the crowd in the waiting room, does anybody here speak Polish? Some lady raises her hand , she's like, I speak Polish. So mind you , now one of the most important interviews of this couple's life lays in the balance of a person that says she speaks Polish, which she very well might. But how do you know how much her proficiency is in that language? And that's kinda like, where we're just like, you know what? There has to be a better way , there has to be a better way. So that's kind of where Interpreter Tap was born.
FullB: and um, co-owner of two restaurants, and how did you get from where you were at our age to where you are right now?  [New Zealand accent] I suppose at your age, I left school and really the same thing, I was totally unsure of what I wanted to do. I had um , a burning passion, which was not to cook -- mine was to travel. Went to Israel and worked on a kabutz for six months  'cause I met an Israeli guy and thought, " Oh this is quite cool . '' And started cooking in the kitchens there , and I was cooking with a couple of women who said to me then, " My god, you've got such a good talent for this. '' Then came home and thought, " Yup, this is what I'm gon na do. " I can just sort of live at Mum and Dad's " and save and go through uni, '' and then just started from there.  What kept you from just going out and doing something else?  'Cause I knew I couldn't, I didn't wan na do anything else. I knew, no matter how hard it was gon na be, I had to just keep going. I just had to keep going. 'Cause really, the whole thing is, you're focusing on what you wan na do.
EventsA: I learned a bit of English — I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter — I started seeing how the disenfranchised were being treated — I and Victor Arellano were at the Department of Homeland Security in Chicago — I did an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test — A federal agent asked the Polish couple where their interpreter was — A woman in the waiting room said she spoke Polish — Interpreter Tap was born
EventsB: left school — went to Israel — worked on a kabutz for six months — met an Israeli guy — started cooking in the kitchens there — cooked with a couple of women who praised my talent — came home — decided to pursue cooking — started university

Q12: Both have events that led to how their life was supposed to go and then how it changed.
Q13: Both describes events that led them to change their life into the opposite direction.
FullA: I was learning how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy, to figure out whether their ships are gon na be able to get through a storm or not. How big are the waves gon na be in two days time out in the middle of the Pacific? And it turned out that my students started using that to figure out when to go surfing. And I was in academia , I was in that track. So when I did make that decision to leave there were some people that were shocked  and also people thought it was a waste of a Ph.D, even though my original aim was to join the Navy. I ended up not feeling all that comfortable with the fact that a lot of the research I was doing was effectively weapons systems. But now what I do is, people get up in the morning and they can say , should I go surfing today or not? And they can look at what we make and go , yeah , I might go surf, and it puts smiles on people's faces.
FullB: I come from farm worker parents. It wasn't until I married and I was 28 years of age that I realized that I wasn't gon na go anywhere unless I have an education. So I had to turn my life around to do  what I wanted to do, and what I wanted to do was be in this world of media. So I went to a community college and I transferred to UCLA , and I became a writer. And so, from that to what I do today, I'm an advocate. I do civil rights, civil rights and specifically, in media. When reporting about the Latino community, it was a crime blotter. It was Maria killed Jose because Jose molested her child and the child was doing drugs on the side. It was like that , it was terrible. So we formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition, because how we are perceived is always going to be the way that we are treated. If we're perceived that being the laborers out in the field and so forth, you'll be treated that way. And, we're that, sure of course we are. Right? But the fact is that we're also a great deal more. Never believe that somebody else is gon na do it for you. You have to take the bull by the horns and make the changes.
EventsA: I learned how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy — My students started using the maps to figure out when to go surfing — I made the decision to leave academia — People were shocked by my decision to leave — People thought it was a waste of a Ph.D — I ended up not feeling comfortable with the research I was doing
EventsB: I married at 28 years of age — I realized that I needed an education — I turned my life around — I went to a community college — I transferred to UCLA — I became a writer — I became an advocate — We formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition

Q12: Both events start at the beginning, discuss something that impacted the choice in their career and ends with what they are currently doing.
Q13: Both stories discuss how they came to be at their career in their life and the steps that got them there.
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I worked in technology up until 1998 in which I struck out on my own and I built an engineering company. Had good contracts. 9/11 hits a couple of years later, and all of a sudden a lot of the major corporations and people  I was dealing with, their stocks fell, and they stopped giving work. I went and became a screener at the airport. I want you to think about this. I worked for a major corporation, I'm a screener, people that were my clients and then I work with , were coming through the airport. You got me reminiscing and thinking back here. But, I stuck to my principles. I knew I was better than this, all right? And I had a plan. So I took what I knew, even though I was working in terrorism and mass transit, I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl. And so, I knew from that, I was as good or better than anybody there.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I struck out on my own — I built an engineering company — 9/11 happened — major corporations and people I was dealing with stopped giving work — I became a screener at the airport — I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl

Q12: Story A made the same mistake repeatedly.
Q13: Both stories someone that left a job that wasn't making them happy.
FullA: when I was four, but um ... growing up without a mother -- 'cause she died when I was six -- growing up with just my dad and my brother , I was obviously very, um, just very independent and strong-willed. And my dad's best friend was a stockbroker, and for some reason, because I was so good with money, that I decided that I was, that I would be a really good stockbroker. And fortunately, throughout high school, we had work exchange and work experience, and um , they used to send me off with all sorts of random checks and things to, you know, with million dollars in my hand to go and deliver somewhere, and I had no idea where I was going or how to get there. And being the little surfy chick that I was , it just made me realize that wasn't the avenue I wanted to go down. Ultimately, to become successful in anything , you have to be relatively selfish. You have to be so one-dimensional. I also believe that there's no such thing as a mistake , it's only a learning experience. The only mistake is not learning from it. But even then, you're just gon na be given the opportunity to learn it and learn it and learn it until such time as you do. So I made the same " mistake '' over and over again until I actually got the lesson.
FullB: They would always listen to this great jazz station called KADX. And one, for I just saw what they were doing  and they were having the best time, laughing and listening to this great music , and I said, " Can I, can I do that with you next week ? '' He said, " Okay, son. '' So I actually came to sort of a reckoning in my life at a very early age , and it was the last time that I worked at a fast-food restaurant. And I remember on that Friday, before I quit , I said that was the last time I was gon na ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke. I would oftentimes get a little disheartened , and I would never, of course, tell them. When I would hear parents tell my students that, you know, " You got ta grow up and get a real job, '' I would think that a real job that is a s-s-successful job for someone is a job that is driven by their passion and their love, and not a job that's just there because you're getting the paycheck.
EventsA: Her mother died when she was six — She decided she would be a stockbroker — She was sent off with million dollars in checks to deliver somewhere — She realized being a stockbroker was not the avenue she wanted to go down — She made the same mistake over and over again until she learned the lesson
EventsB: They were having the best time, laughing and listening to music. — I asked if I could do that with them next week. — He said okay. — I came to a reckoning in my life at a very early age. — I worked at a fast-food restaurant for the last time. — I said that was the last time I was going to ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke.

Q12: Tom stayed with his same company the entire time. In sequence B, the person worked at a law firm first.
Q13: Both stories talk about people going through their careers and ending up in different spaces than they originally intended.
FullA: My name is Tom Arviso, Jr. , I'm the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated. And I've been here about 27 years now. And I started here as a college intern. And I studied journalism with the intent of becoming a sports writer. That was my passion. But once I got here to the Navajo Times, things just kind of gradually evolved , and I just kind of rose through the ranks to the point where now I'm running the company. I never looked back ever since I started doing that and just been trying to go and do as much as I can possibly do in regards to telling stories, telling people stories, and being good at it. Being right. Being ethical. Being honest. This profession, it's a field where you really have to have a passion for what you're doing, a belief in being a storyteller. If you're sincere about what you do, about your craft, about being a good journalist, then things will fall into place for you if you're patient.
FullB: I still play in a band, even now, at my age. Cool. Yeah. What do you play? I'm sorry. I play electric guitar. Oh, awesome. Yea, and sing. And when I was first out of college, I didn't know what I wanted to do. I went to work for a law firm. From that point, I decided I really did want to try to become a recording engineer. And that led me to become an audio person for Microsoft , and this was what led to museums. But it wasn't, like I said , I'm gon na be a museum person. I think you have a lot of skills and brains, obviously, a lot of talent, and all you need is to just relax. Open up your eyes to what moves you and what doesn't move you. And you'll find that you have pathways open up, just by being you. And I think sometimes when you don't know what you wan na do it's because you sometimes don't know yourself. So I think to try to clear out fear, clear out the people who are around us telling us what we need to want, and really try to take some quiet time to really figure out what you want is really valuable time spent.
EventsA: Tom Arviso, Jr. started as a college intern at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. rose through the ranks at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. became the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated.
EventsB: I played electric guitar and sang — I went to work for a law firm — I decided to try to become a recording engineer — I became an audio person for Microsoft

Q12: A pivot occurs in both but story B had decided their fate at a young age.
Q13: Both stories are about having an original plan and pivoting to something else.
FullA: Originally, I thought I was just gon na be a contractor. Then I decided I was gon na study architecture so I moved out to California. And throughout all that, Eli and I met each other out in California. And I tried Switchel for the first time. A month later, we sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont. And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. It takes a lot of time to manage people when you bring them on. So I'm gon na go for the person who's already shows that they're halfway there.
FullB: I'd be a UN official. Early on, I won an award, at age 15, was sent around the world. Um...  and uh, transformation. And I knew, " My life's international work. '' And I was gon na learn languages , and you know , I just knew it. And I could say , " Well I " was blessed with clarity and a great breakthrough . '' And it would have been logical for me to now set focus on that. But happily, I did this  and I did that, and-and I stumbled and I didn't join the UN. But I had a very enriching and confusing bundle of experiences , but it allowed me to have an eclectic set of tools that I think really made it possible for me to make a difference. If you aren't completely uncomfortable, completely off-balance, completely beyond your competence, you're missing. Because it's in being off-balance that you really see.
EventsA: I decided to study architecture — I moved out to California — Eli and I met each other in California — I tried Switchel for the first time — We sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont
EventsB: I won an award at age 15 — I was sent around the world — I had a great breakthrough — I stumbled — I didn't join the UN

Q12: Both focused on internal motivation.
Q13: One story summarized not being supported by a community and the other was motivation as to why it's important to create opportunities for yourself.
FullA: I'm an Assistant Professor in Astronomy at California Institute of Technology and Caltech. And I study the dynamic universe. So what I do is, with the beautiful telescopes here at Palomar Observatory, we have some robotic telescopes that are continuously making a movie of the night sky. So we image the sky over and over again and we look for what changed. You might go out there and think universe is the same old thing every time , but it's actually not. It's full of these little explosions, which last for a very short amount of time , so they're very But they're very energetic. It's like cosmic fireworks lighting up our sky. So why did you choose to pursue the degree path that you did? I would say that in my own case, I mean , it was not at all clear that one day I would do a PhD. I grew up on a farm in India with 100 cows and fields of weeds and chick peas. And I had left home when I was 15 , and I was a girl in India in a small place. The entire community was up in arms, you know? There were people like neighbors, relatives , you name it. People I haven't even seen before coming into the house and trying to talk my parents out of this crazy decision to send their daughter alone on this journey into other end of the world to pursue something called Astronomy or whatever that was. The community was completely unsupportive. How did you deal with that? In my case, the best way to deal with it was to just let that fade away in the background and not engage with the two directly, but focus on what is motivating me, on what is giving me joy and just let everything else just fade away in the background.
FullB: I've been put in situations where, if you don't talk to this person, your opportunity is gon na pass you by. But once you tell yourself, you know what, I'm gon na not let this opportunity pass, it's just a conscious decision. You know what, I'm just gon na go with it. What's the worst that can happen? And now it's kind of natural. If I need to talk to somebody, I might not want to , but I'll go up and be like yo let's handle this business , you have to have that. You know? Even if you shy, like you just got ta push through it. Once you get through that little fear, everything just comes. So where do you see like your confidence level now? Just I know that I can, like there's nothing you can tell me that I can't do, you know what I'm saying? So, just knowing that in the back of my mind. I got this, no matter what. Even if I don't make it today, I'm gon na make it tomorrow. If I fail today, then I'm gon na get right back up, and do it again. So, knowing that, just having that failure , and then coming back from it. The ground comes under me. I'm just going build a new ground.
EventsA: I studied the dynamic universe — I used robotic telescopes at Palomar Observatory to make a movie of the night sky — I imaged the sky repeatedly to look for changes — I grew up on a farm in India — I left home when I was 15 — The community tried to talk my parents out of sending me away — I decided to focus on my motivation and joy and ignore the community's opposition
EventsB: I told myself I was not going to let the opportunity pass — I decided to go with it — I went up to talk to somebody despite feeling shy — I pushed through my fear — I experienced failure — I got right back up and did it again

Q12: An event occurred in story A that inspired reflection.
Q13: Both stories reflect on being unsatisfied in a work setting.
FullA: or work in the office or not work. And so I worked in an office , and every place that I worked at I ended up computerizing. Ended up starting a company, um, in manufacturing. But I always, always knew that I was meant to do something to help other people. And I was in Niger. And there was a little girl that came up to me with flies on her face. And I just felt that that's intolerable. I mean, for one thing, that could have been my granddaughter. How could I not do something? I think that I have the opportunity to live what I think should be the American Dream, when what I think should be the American Dream is that we use these resources, we use these talents, to help those that didn't get that.
FullB: rainy, in Seattle, on a project, drinking a tea like this one actually. I was just like, " I can't do this anymore. '' People put up their entire life in their cubicle farm , and it's like their pictures of their vacations , and it's like, " I'm outta here. " This is it. '' And I was drinking a tea, and, " Wow. '' Everyone I went to said it was a horrible idea. " You're doomed to failure, you have no experience, " retail's a painful existence, '' um... " Coffee's where it's at , " so what are you thinking ? '' So it's hard to, how do you kick yourself in the pants? Like, is it easier to get a job and kind of pay the rent, or is the pain of not knowing what your self-actualization greater? And generally, I think, pursuing that pain is pursuing the unknown, which is frightening , and most people don't do it. That's why. It's easier just to just go, just follow the path. But you may wake up in 50 years saying, " What was my, gosh, what the heck did I do? ''
EventsA: worked in an office — computerized every place that I worked at — started a company in manufacturing — was in Niger — a little girl with flies on her face came up to me
EventsB: I said I can't do this anymore. — I decided I'm outta here. — I was drinking a tea. — Everyone I went to said it was a horrible idea.

Q12: They have a slightly similar progression, where both have a traumatic initial event and then the main character's reckoning with it.
Q13: They are both about shocking and traumatic events, although details and circumstances differ
FullA: being six years old , postcards coming into my family, as one after another of the relatives that my parents had were, you know, dead in the concentration camps. And I remember just being very affected by that as a six or seven year old. I became convinced right then , I think, that I did not want to be one of those people. I wanted to be a kind of person that helped other people. That instead of bringing suffering , I wanted to try to alleviate suffering. And what better way to try to alleviate the suffering of human beings than being a doctor? I think everyone has to make a choice which will bring themselves inner peace and happiness as the best they can achieve it. No matter what you do, you will have an opportunity to impact on other people's lives, just by who you are and the way you act.
FullB: and the next minute, you know , I'm thrown over 50 feet from a car  and they thought I died, you know? And they thought I'd never walk again. And people have often asked was I not angry or bitter , and the answer is no. It just is.  Everything seems so minimal, you know, when I'm sitting here talking to you. But just, you know, your mother, the accident...  why not just, " You know what, I cant ''? Like, you know --?  What would have been my option? You see it, don't you? You're sitting, waiting on the first of the month to get a check. Stuck in a wheelchair. You know... That-that's an option? I don't take reality checks from anybody. I want to follow what my passion is in life more than anything else. Don't give me a reality check because reality will tell you what you can't do. " You need to deal " with the real world. '' No, my world is real to me.
EventsA: Postcards came into the family from deceased relatives in concentration camps — The narrator became convinced that they did not want to be like those people — The narrator decided to become a person who helped others — The narrator decided to become a doctor to alleviate human suffering
EventsB: He was thrown over 50 feet from a car — People thought he died — People thought he would never walk again

Q12: They are very similar in almost every way except for the beginning. One starts out where he wants to go, and the other one changed her plan. So because of that difference, I put that they were moderately similar.
Q13: Both of them are about people finding their places in life. The first one is about a boy finding out that he actually fits very well into the military. He knows guns and he can do guns. The second one is someone who finds out her desire is to sell drinks at the farmers market. Both are similar, although there are plenty of differences in terms of circumstances.
FullA: When I joined the military, I had literally nothing. I was in a holding center, in a juvenile holding center and my recruiter came and rescued me. Needless to say , when I went to boot camp, I thought it was actually kind of easy and like I had never had so much food before in my life. When I joined the military, I originally signed up as a gunner's mate. I got out, felt like something was missing, I ended up moving out here for a job, and I was, like, guns , I know guns. I can do this job, that was easy. That was my turnaround moment. Okay.
FullB: Originally, I thought I was just gon na be a contractor. Then I decided I was gon na study architecture so I moved out to California. And throughout all that, Eli and I met each other out in California. And I tried Switchel for the first time. A month later, we sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont. And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. It takes a lot of time to manage people when you bring them on. So I'm gon na go for the person who's already shows that they're halfway there.
EventsA: I joined the military — My recruiter came and rescued me — I went to boot camp — I signed up as a gunner's mate — I got out — I moved out here for a job
EventsB: I decided to study architecture — I moved out to California — Eli and I met each other in California — I tried Switchel for the first time — We sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont

Q12: They are slightly similar in the sense that they both talk about characters and their steps into their careers. However the progression changes when the one talks about what she has learned in her field at the zoo and the other talks about how he got into his role as an editor.
Q13: Both are about people who find out that they have a deep passion for a certain field and then pursue it for a long time. They both learn things and have a blast. There are some differences between them, so that is why I didn't make them very similar, but they are still moderately similar stories.
FullA: I am Kimberly Lazer , I'm the curator of Behavioral Husbandry and Welfare for Oklahoma City Zoo. So I spend a lot of time looking, observing, learning everything we can about the species and about what their needs are to give them many choices in their environment. So that they have varied days and they have a very dynamic environment that they're living in. When I was five years old, I had an encounter with a dolphin. And I was able to look that animal in the eye and that was it for me. I wanted to dedicate my life to working with animals. When I left college, I thought, well, that's it , I'm ready. Put me in a job , I know what to do. And what I found was the animals were the best teachers. They have taught me humility. I think that's a big one. They've taught me compassion, to be a little bit more open and be very understanding. Especially to other human beings. That was something I learned when I left college. I had amazing experiences in college and I loved my classes but I don't think I really started becoming well rounded until I got out of the classroom. And I really started learning the real world stuff. So talk to people, hear their stories, and keep an open mind because every person has something to teach you.
FullB: I think it was an LA Times that my dad sent me , and it was just a really ambiguous ad saying, photographers, editors, technicians needed for sports photography agency. And I was like, what is this about? I was an athlete at one point in my life , I like sports, so let's check it out. At that point, didn't really much experience in photography. Realized  I was kind of out of my league for their photography positions, but the door was open to be an editor. So I immediately jumped to that job, knowing that in the back of my head I want to be a photographer , so I just took that opportunity knowing that I was eventually going to parlay it into to where I wanted to go. So in my spare time I'd go out and take photos, cuz the thing was, working for that company allowed me the access that I wanted to get to take photos at sporting events. And I didn't think that I'd be here 25 years later still kind of doing it. The moment you capture something and you just know you've got it in your camera , it's magical. So I just walked through the doors that were opened for me , and I just took them and here I am now. And I'm just fortunate to do something that I love , and it trips me out that I get paid for it. So doors are going to open and close , and it's going to come down to which ones you walk through
EventsA: I had an encounter with a dolphin — I looked the dolphin in the eye — I wanted to dedicate my life to working with animals — I left college — I found that the animals were the best teachers — The animals taught me humility — The animals taught me compassion — I started learning the real world stuff — I talked to people — I heard their stories — I kept an open mind
EventsB: Dad sent an LA Times ad — I checked out the ad — I realized I was out of my league for photography positions — I took the editor job — I took photos in my spare time — Working for the company allowed me access to take photos at sporting events — I captured a moment with my camera — I walked through the doors that were opened for me

Q12: Both of them are about a beginning state where they start, they get some opportunities and then they find themselves in a position they think is pretty neat. Because of this, I put moderately similar.
Q13: Both of them were about people thinking they were going to be moving in one direction, but then turning out to move in a different direction. There are many differences though, so I put slightly similar.
FullA: with my guidance counselor and we decided that, you know, I had an artistic streak and I was good in math , and therefore I should be an architect. And I think it was about the third year in school , I realized I wasn't really that good at it and I kind of didn't even like it that much. And the next couple of years were pretty scary 'cause um , I-I had a degree in something I was pretty sure I was never gon na use. And I just kind of didn't know what course my life was gon na take. By the time I graduated from college I actually had a few nationally-released records , and they didn't make that big of a splash or make that much money , but it was enough to get me thinking like, " Wow, well this would be cool " to do this for a living. I like this more than being " an architect or hovering over a drawing board " for 20 hours a day. '' It's a clichÃ © , but you do have to kind of follow your dreams. Especially, you guys are all young , and, you know , this is the time to do it. If I were you, I would definitely go for what makes you happy. The big irony of my life and my career is that I've outlasted most of the people I've parodied over the years.
FullB: my uncle did was give me a copy of Doom on a floppy disk. It was a lot about games. But um, through the games, ah, I learned a lot about computers , you know. And I think that's what really got me embedded in the computer world. Uh, now I'm here working with this robot which is ...  ah, her name is Nexi. And this one is kind of designed to do personal interaction between humans and robots.  I can tell you that I'm sad, mad, confused, excited, or even bored, just by moving my face.  You never know where these things lead. You just kind of have hope and faith that like, what you're doing is gon na lead to something bigger.
EventsA: I decided to become an architect with my guidance counselor — I realized I wasn't good at architecture and didn't like it — I graduated from college — I had a few nationally-released records
EventsB: My uncle gave me a copy of Doom on a floppy disk. — I learned a lot about computers through the games. — I worked with a robot named Nexi designed for personal interaction between humans and robots. — I expressed emotions by moving my face.

Q12: The first one has a very clear up-down progression and change. The other one is just a very short narrative. So I put that they weren't very similar.
Q13: These really aren't that similar. One of them is a story about a man who is able to rise beyond his settings and his original spot into something awesome. The other one is just talking about where a person worked at and his project. So I put that they were not very similar.
FullA: Born and raised here in Detroit. I went to public school. I knew I wanted to go to college but didn't know how I was gon na get there. Had a very supportive family, but financially , we didn't have any money tucked away. And fortunately, I was able to get a scholarship to a college. Got my Bachelor's degree in communication. Out of college, I did sales for a number of years just kind of really trying to find my way. And my wife was a student here at Wayne Community College , they had an opportunity, an opening on the phones. One day the chancellor of the college was on the other end and I had no clue. And I was just excited to be answering phones for the college. And he wanted to meet me and I had opportunities to advance from there. Now I am the associate vice chancellor for students services. So, I tell everybody, I'm not supposed to be here, statistically speaking. I'm a black male  and I grew up in Detroit with all the gang violence, with all the drug violence. So, don't be defined by the neighborhoods that you came from. Don't be defined by whether or not you're a first generation college student, whether you're a minority. Whatever that is, you can go and do and be whoever you wan na be.
FullB: You were there for Toy Story and. I was there for Toy, that's what I was hired to do, is Toy Story. Art direct Toy Story. Cool. Every project is so different. Every four years is a four year graduate course in the subject matter of that film. And just to take advantage of that, have fun with some research. Once you get interested in something, go and find out as much as you can about it. It's not that hard to do, especially with the Internet. You can always get a dozen books on the subject and just read through them, and just keep doing that. That's really it.
EventsA: I got a scholarship to a college — I got my Bachelor's degree in communication — I did sales for a number of years — My wife was a student at Wayne Community College — I answered phones for the college — The chancellor of the college wanted to meet me — I had opportunities to advance from there — I became the associate vice chancellor for student services
EventsB: You were there for Toy Story. — I was hired to art direct Toy Story.

Q12: they both had a reckoning to switch jobs/goals and move to better ones for them
Q13: both stories of young people figuring out they didn't want to do their current job and figured out a better option for them
FullA: when I was four, but um ... growing up without a mother -- 'cause she died when I was six -- growing up with just my dad and my brother , I was obviously very, um, just very independent and strong-willed. And my dad's best friend was a stockbroker, and for some reason, because I was so good with money, that I decided that I was, that I would be a really good stockbroker. And fortunately, throughout high school, we had work exchange and work experience, and um , they used to send me off with all sorts of random checks and things to, you know, with million dollars in my hand to go and deliver somewhere, and I had no idea where I was going or how to get there. And being the little surfy chick that I was , it just made me realize that wasn't the avenue I wanted to go down. Ultimately, to become successful in anything , you have to be relatively selfish. You have to be so one-dimensional. I also believe that there's no such thing as a mistake , it's only a learning experience. The only mistake is not learning from it. But even then, you're just gon na be given the opportunity to learn it and learn it and learn it until such time as you do. So I made the same " mistake '' over and over again until I actually got the lesson.
FullB: They would always listen to this great jazz station called KADX. And one, for I just saw what they were doing  and they were having the best time, laughing and listening to this great music , and I said, " Can I, can I do that with you next week ? '' He said, " Okay, son. '' So I actually came to sort of a reckoning in my life at a very early age , and it was the last time that I worked at a fast-food restaurant. And I remember on that Friday, before I quit , I said that was the last time I was gon na ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke. I would oftentimes get a little disheartened , and I would never, of course, tell them. When I would hear parents tell my students that, you know, " You got ta grow up and get a real job, '' I would think that a real job that is a s-s-successful job for someone is a job that is driven by their passion and their love, and not a job that's just there because you're getting the paycheck.
EventsA: Her mother died when she was six — She decided she would be a stockbroker — She was sent off with million dollars in checks to deliver somewhere — She realized being a stockbroker was not the avenue she wanted to go down — She made the same mistake over and over again until she learned the lesson
EventsB: They were having the best time, laughing and listening to music. — I asked if I could do that with them next week. — He said okay. — I came to a reckoning in my life at a very early age. — I worked at a fast-food restaurant for the last time. — I said that was the last time I was going to ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke.

Q12: they both had major changes in what they were doing, but had mostly different paths in how they went about it so only slightly similar due to that
Q13: they both had big goals for themselves, just did them in different ways, one went to school and the other didn't but still found success
FullA: I come from farm worker parents. It wasn't until I married and I was 28 years of age that I realized that I wasn't gon na go anywhere unless I have an education. So I had to turn my life around to do  what I wanted to do, and what I wanted to do was be in this world of media. So I went to a community college and I transferred to UCLA , and I became a writer. And so, from that to what I do today, I'm an advocate. I do civil rights, civil rights and specifically, in media. When reporting about the Latino community, it was a crime blotter. It was Maria killed Jose because Jose molested her child and the child was doing drugs on the side. It was like that , it was terrible. So we formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition, because how we are perceived is always going to be the way that we are treated. If we're perceived that being the laborers out in the field and so forth, you'll be treated that way. And, we're that, sure of course we are. Right? But the fact is that we're also a great deal more. Never believe that somebody else is gon na do it for you. You have to take the bull by the horns and make the changes.
FullB: It's sort of a pattern in my life. I didn't get my culinary degree -- I got thrown out -- but I mean , I went and apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe , so, that's really where I learned. But going from a fine dining chef to running , you know, a beer bar seems like it's a downgrade in a way, but it really wasn't. It was actually , there's a lot of things that are more challenging about what I do. We didn't have a business plan. Didn't write one , there's no such thing. I've never written a business plan in my life. Yeah, I learned everything on the fly. I learned how to tap kegs -- never tapped a beer keg in my life. It's been amazingly educational, but sometimes you just learn by doing. Again, there's no school for this. Culinary school didn't teach me this. No one told me what to do -- not my dad, my mom. I did what I wanted to do without any exterior influence. When you say, " Where do you " find the motivation? '' The only motivation that's ever genuine comes from within.
EventsA: I married at 28 years of age — I realized that I needed an education — I turned my life around — I went to a community college — I transferred to UCLA — I became a writer — I became an advocate — We formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition
EventsB: I got thrown out of my culinary degree program — I apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe — I went from being a fine dining chef to running a beer bar — I learned how to tap kegs

Q12: they went step by step how they made their eventual decisions so they felt mostly similar
Q13: they both talked about how they finally decided what they wanted to do for an occupation
FullA: And I was like, " I-I could just die. " I don't have time doing something I'm not " excited about. '' Ah... and so I quit my job and went back to school. I was a literature major and I decided I wanted to be an engineer. And so I started with pre-algebra, algebra --  Oh so you went back to undergrad?  Oh yeah , calculus, pre-calculus, all from the bottom up. I think in our society, from a very early age , it's sort of you're humanities or you're hard science. And that's not true. You can do both.
FullB: Where was I at 18 or 19? Yeah. Out of high school trying to pick a major, taking all my core classes, and there just was nothing adventurous enough, I mean tried accounting, tried economics. They were just blah, boring. And I was doing this for my spending money on the side a couple days a week, lobstering. I went to college , and while at school, I learned how to work on computers and got a job, and did the 9 to 5, yes sir, no sir. Can I have a raise, sir? But the whole time I was doing it , I wasn't happy. I couldn't wait to get done with it and get back out there. So. I went back to lobstering, kind of where I started out and took a long time to get where I got. It's what I've been doing for the last five years up here measuring lobsters. That's awesome. And I wouldn't do anything else given the choice. So you feel lucky? Oh, I know I'm lucky, definitely. I'm glad I didn't follow the nuclear lifestyle. It's like success is like this whole journey. You realize it's not something that kind of snaps and happens. I don't need to sit here and say I'm gon na be this , I'm gon na be that. I'm gon na be who I am right now.
EventsA: I quit my job — I went back to school — I decided I wanted to be an engineer — I started with pre-algebra, algebra, calculus, and pre-calculus
EventsB: tried accounting — tried economics — went to college — learned how to work on computers — got a job — did the 9 to 5 job — went back to lobstering — measured lobsters for five years

Q12: these sequences were totally different in what was happening
Q13: they are both people with goals and wanted to see change, but the way they did it was totally different and they were not on the same path at all
FullA: For a lot of us, growing up in St. Louis, we were determined to leave as soon as we possibly can. You know, after graduating school , I decided to come home. You know, I could do like so many other people did, which is just move to somebody else's neighborhood, or move to a nicer neighborhood, and put on your blinders, and say everything's fine here. I don't know what's happening over there, or over here , but I decided I wanted to live in my neighborhood. And in order for me to do that, and to really make it a place I want to raise kids, I got ta get to work. So when I became an alderman one of the things I first noticed is that the city doesn't really, you know, take care of these neighborhoods like they need to. So we created this nonprofit as an organization that can deal with what is not happening in the schools. What we know is that what happens after school and on a weekend can be just as powerful as what is, or is not happening in the classroom. A lot of these kids go to really poor performing public schools , so we formed this organization to try to start providing some stability and some direction in the lives of young people. Too many kids over here feel abandoned by their city, and by the rest of the world , and so we're opening their eyes to a lot of what is available in their own city. And in that way too, also helping them take some ownership of their city. You know, that is yours too, don't think that's somebody else's, you are a St. Louisan, so that is yours too and you should experience it.
FullB: My company is Palo Santo Designs. I'm the founder and executive director of the company. And what we do is we design and build homes and commercial buildings that are highly sustainable. That exemplify my personal interest and concern for the state of the environment. And essentially, I kind of just stumbled into it. I was in an environmental science program at the University of New Hampshire. And then, I stumbled across this book about earthships. And it was these people who were building homes literally out of all recycled materials, basically out of trash. The principles behind it were the things that sort of inspired me. I decided to go out and get my own contractor's license  and eventually, built a small company. The thing that I really love about what I do is sort of creating something out of nothing. If you feel happiness on a day to day basis, you're succeeding in life.
EventsA: I graduated school — I decided to come home — I decided I wanted to live in my neighborhood — I became an alderman — We created a nonprofit — We formed an organization to provide stability and direction to young people — We opened kids' eyes to what is available in their city
EventsB: I stumbled across a book about earthships — I decided to go out and get my own contractor's license — I built a small company

Q12: they both made strong decisions to go one direction in their live's goals
Q13: these were both stories about younger people figuring out what they wanted to do with their lives and getting advice from older people that helped them decide
FullA: I'm 53 years old , I'm trying to decide what I'm gon na do when I grow up. My grandfather farmed , he went out and said , hey do you wan na plant a garden? And I got started that way , we planted some radishes in a spot about this big and I thought it was the coolest thing. I was debating between agriculture and ornamental horticulture, like growing flowers. But I thought if I'm gon na spend my life doing something, I would rather spend my life helping to feed the world. So our job is to develop a hybrid seed that will help the farmer in his business. So if you take two inbreds, like that , and you cross them , that's your hybrid. So people are like, why do you have hybrids? It's like, that's why I have hybrids. Some people feel like , okay , I just wan na make a lot of money. But if you can find something you have a passion for, you love it, you think about it in the morning when you wake up. And then you can figure out an intersection of that thing with something that you can make a living doing , That's a pretty sweet place to be.
FullB: the Olympics. So I always wanted to be on an Olympic team. FullA: So I entered foster care when I was about three and a half years old. During that time, I had 14 different foster homes. I wasn't always placed in the most ideal circumstances. These were people who had problems with drugs, alcohol, violence, pedophilia. So I had this sense of I've got ta do something. I've got ta say something , this is not okay, and that kind of kept eating at me. And I think that's the motivation that kept me from turning to drugs, or running away, or becoming part of that statistic, that label that they expected of me. I had to do something differently. And so all of that gave me this perspective that it's not enough to complain about something if you're not willing to be a part of the solution. So a really big sticking point for me was that I'm not just going to walk around complaining about foster care or complaining about this system of care that's not protecting kids, no. I wan na be directly involved in the very system that failed me so that I can make it better. And I ultimately opened a non-profit organization that provides direct services to children and families. So all of my experiences kind of led to me serving others in a way that I wish I had been served when I was a young person.
FullB: towards food that I did. And so we would entertain a lot of our friends. And so all the wine dinners, all of a sudden , somehow we started home brewing. And then the passion that you have is gon na really drive that.

FullA: 19 years ago, actually, I started working for SLUG Magazine. The previous owner of SLUG heard about me, and called me up and asked me to shoot a cover. So that's how I first became a staff member of SLUG, was shooting a cover. And then from that point forward, I became a managing editor , and then two years later, I had the opportunity to take over the magazine , and that's when I officially became editor and then publisher. And I've always felt different from my family , and from kind of being part of the peer group that I grew up in, I just always didn't quite connect. But then I kind of learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is, and the work here that we could do to find others that feel that way. Where they may not feel that way at home, or at school, or in a lot of other environments. But here in SLUG Magazine, we can really appreciate them for being different. I think it goes back to that love, right? I really love doing what I do, and hearing these stories from these individuals that come up to you and say hey , I would not be where I am today if it wasn't for my experience with SLUG Magazine. Hearing that feedback and that validation from other individuals about how we've affected their lives in a positive way, and that's priceless.
FullB: A lot of teachers feel like they have to be this like, alter ego. Like for me, honestly who I am in the classroom is who I am in life. Did you have any, like, uh-oh moments, when you were like , I have no idea what I'm doing, like once you were in the classroom? All the time. All the time and I still kinda do. A lot of people thought that I was just a fun teacher. Oh he's just , all his kids, they're not really learning anything. I hate when teachers think that just because their class is rigorous that they can't have any fun. It's not until when my test scores came back, my AP scores and they were better than theirs , you don't even have to say anything. Yeah. I am very German but I am very about living life and working hard and being rigorous but having fun the entire time we're doing it. Because that's life. I really come to work with a smile on my face every single day. And that's what it's all about, right?

FullB: So going back into the time when you were first starting out and into producing, how is it like coping with being dyslexic and trying to work around that? When I came out and I had this film , I then started looking for jobs and I just was trying to figure out what should be the next step and going for job interviews and I was nervous about working for other people. I was worried that people would find out that there were skills that I really couldn't do. So I shied away from certain things and that led me to people who were being independent filmmakers, because they were more peers  and we were all saying, okay , let's go raise money. Let's go try to do this. And in retrospect, it was great and it sort of lead me down an interesting path , but I think it was partly, cuz I was scared to do the other. I was scared that I would be found out. I think the best thing about having LD that helped me in film is I've never been somebody who assumed you wouldn't make mistakes. I've never thought that anything was gon na be a straight line and that you get there quickly. That's just not how I've learned and how my life ever went in school, certainly. So I think that's sort of applicable to most young people that you have to be willing to assume that might happen to you, but don't you think a lot of LD kids already know that. You're already kinda prepared that, that's gon na be true. So I think if you're not ashamed of that, if you own that, it makes it so much easier.

FullA: go through any traditional channels. I never went to, like, a proper film school or ... worked on traditional film sets and learned my way up the way that other people might. In the 1980s, Michael Stipe from R.E.M. had sort of like a film group that was giving money to underground filmmakers , and he saw some of the stuff that I'd done , and I went down to Athens, Georgia, where his band, R.E.M., was based and where there were a lot of other artists and filmmakers. I wasn't specifically trying to do music videos or feature films or documentaries or whatever. Just kind of made these personal, experimental films, and then people that would see those would respond to 'em and ask me to go do other things with them or for them. It's an element of like putting yourself at the right place at the right time. Like I definitely left the wrong place in New Jersey and went to Athens, Georgia, which, at that time, felt like where I belonged. But, you know, it's your life and you need to... go hit all these different experiences while you can.
FullB: So I started as a Hispanic woman in sports reporting , okay? So that may be, if not as white as the tech industry, it's pretty close. Literally, my very first job, I had someone sit down and say to me so, you know why you got this job, right? And the implication was because I was a Hispanic woman. And I said, because I am amazing. I learned really early on that there was going to be a lot of people that would be, like. Well you only got this job because of this or you can't do this because of this. I had people say like do you like tech or do you like, and the answer's like would you ask a doctor do you like blood no. Or it's like do you understand how this works and you wouldn't do that in any other field or if there's lots of other people who look more like they should be in tech than me. There's a lot of people who will totally write you off because there's not that many people who look like you. There's a lot of negativity and some people like I said , I come from a background where it's like whatever. Shut up , don't listen to those people and ignore them and use them as motivation. Yeah, so I mean it's about being willing to figure out what's best for you and go on your own path. And sometimes there's starts and stops , but it's life.
EventsA: Michael Stipe saw some of the stuff that the narrator had done — The narrator went down to Athens, Georgia — People responded to the narrator's personal, experimental films — People asked the narrator to do other things with them or for them — The narrator left New Jersey — The narrator went to Athens, Georgia

It's about what you want to do.
