EventsB: I wrote some compositions. — My mother put the compositions in for an arts festival. — The time came for giving out the awards and prizes. — He held my compositions above his head. — He said the compositions were so bad that he could not consider them for the competition. — He said I should be discouraged from ever composing again.

Q12: Just shows people coming out of tough situations.
Q13: Showed two people overcoming very tough things
FullA: I'm from El Salvador. I came to the United States when I was eight years old. My mom left me at age four with my grandma and my sister that was two years old at the time. Obviously searching for the American dream. So I was in El Salvador. My grandma raised me until I was eight and I remember one day she's like so your mom says one of you can go with her. And that's cuz my mum had finally saved enough money to pay a coyotaje. And so my mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States and so I remember being with a group of people and I was the only child. I'm lucky that I was I was okay the whole time , but it was a journey of about over a month. How do you still have a story of yourself that you identify with, that a lot of people don't relate to. But then still have this professional grounding, this world that you've created for yourself? I think it traces back to family. I get my work ethic from my mother. And it's because in high school she was working all the time. The financial struggle that I saw at home, also pushed me to complete my four year degree cuz I knew I wanted more. And even today, she still has the same lifestyle. I live at home with her still. But ever since the day I came back from college, I support financially. So I know that I have to provide rent money in order for my mom, my sister, my niece to have a home. Cuz my sister's also a single mom.
FullB: August of 2005 , I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina. And then September of 2005 was when I received my cancer diagnosis. So it's like this happened and then this happened. And so, hey, you're a veteran now. And I really didn't know what that meant. Mm-hm. But it basically meant that I was on my own. And I had thought at that particular time that maybe I was an isolated case and then I saw that there were tens of thousands of women veterans who were homeless. Is that what helped motivate you to provide this non-profit organization for homeless women and children? Yes, it definitely was. It's ultimately like everything came full circle, that maybe this is why I went through these things. So I had to be that catalyst, to be that voice for this forgotten population.
EventsA: My mom left me with my grandma and my sister — My grandma raised me until I was eight — My mom said one of us could go with her — My mom saved enough money to pay a coyotaje — My mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States — I traveled with a group of people to the United States — I completed my four year degree — I came back from college — I started supporting my family financially — I provided rent money for my mom, sister, and niece
EventsB: I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina — I received my cancer diagnosis

Q12: They both show a person that had to strive and grind to get where they were.
Q13: There is similarties, in persistence, but they are two pretty different overall styles and careers
FullA: I am judge Elaine Marshall. I am the Director and Presiding Judge for the City of Houston Municipal Courts. And I was going to go to college to be a doctor. That worked out real well until biology, and cut them up and bleeding and all that stuff. You couldn't handle it. Nah, that just wasn't. Everyone kept saying that you talk so much , you probably should go to law school. When I first became a prosecutor, they would send us to different schools for career day. And when I became a judge, did same thing. The thing that stuck out to me the most was one time I went to a school as a judge , and they told them who I was and they said , all rise. So the kids stood up and four of the black kids that were sitting on the thing went , she's black. Wow. And it was like, yeah. Now you see. I came up just like they did, in a public school and those sorts of things. So it's good to give back. You will find so many different places where you can go that you'll make a difference.
FullB: I went to school, because I loved coding and I wanted to develop a coding career. And I reached out to a band that I liked and said, hey, long shot , but could I make you guys a website? And to my surprise, they emailed back like ten minutes later. And they're like yeah, actually , we'd really love for you to make us a website. How about two t-shirts and a CD in trade for it and I thought that was a great bargain. And so I made them a website. So yeah , I mean, I did my first or my second website for two t-shirts and a CD. So technically, not a fair market trade. Yeah. But at the time, the value proposition for me was way higher. And so you've got ta choose your shots. Yeah. And you will definitely do things in the course of your career that will be undervalued  and the trick is to choose the right ones, and to not do it too much. So throughout your career and in particular in those formative stages, you've got to go the extra mile. You've got ta work really hard. There's just no shortcut to it. Every now and then, one in a million gets lucky literary wins the rotary and everybody else whose ever achieved some great level of success has worked incredibly hard to get there.
EventsA: She decided not to go to college to be a doctor — She became a prosecutor — She went to different schools for career day as a prosecutor — She became a judge — She went to a school as a judge — The kids at the school stood up and said all rise — Four black kids at the school expressed surprise that she was black
EventsB: I went to school — I reached out to a band that I liked and asked if I could make them a website — They emailed back ten minutes later — They agreed to have me make them a website in exchange for two t-shirts and a CD — I made them a website

Q12: They are different, but similar in regards to how the stories unfold
Q13: They are both about stumbling upon and action that leads to big success.
FullA: have the confidence or believe in some way or some fashion they'll find themselves. It always terrified me. I have four degrees and never really had any interest in any of them. I was miserable, except in my off-hours, when I was chasing whatever that I liked to do for fun, which was music and comic books and movies. And what happened was, I lost my job, left my wife , and I was homeless. Had no place to live. A guy that was uh, in a search firm, a headhunter, knew all my passions about comic books and movies and music. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. '' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. You don't want to be put into that position of luck ... making a difference in your life at a later age. Be in charge of your destiny now.
FullB: I always grew up with tea being a stable at our dining table. One of my colleagues from my previous job, knew a recruiter at eBay and he recommended me and they ended up hiring me. But one day I was trying to make loose-leaf tea at my desk , and by the time I would make it , I would be late for a meeting. And every time I tried to use tea bags instead, I was never satisfied with the quality because it was not as flavorful, it didn't have as much aroma. That was my first point of inspiration to think about the idea for tea drops. It took me about a year and a half of experimenting. I would spend my weekends and my week nights kind of blending and I was obsessed with figuring it out. And once I had that, I started sharing it with my colleagues and friends and family. Now we're available in over 1,600 retail stores. My logic was, even if this failed, even if nothing ever comes of it, I know I would have gained so much in trying
EventsA: lost my job — left my wife — was homeless — a headhunter told me Marvel Comics was looking for somebody with a business background who reads comic books — became president of Marvel Comics
EventsB: A colleague recommended me to a recruiter at eBay — They hired me — I tried to make loose-leaf tea at my desk — I tried to use tea bags instead — I thought about the idea for tea drops — I spent about a year and a half experimenting — I started sharing tea drops with colleagues, friends, and family — Tea drops became available in over 1,600 retail stores

Q12: I do no see anything similar when the stories are presented this way.
Q13: They are both based on doing something that you actually love, thinking outside the box.
FullA: And so I had kind of just spent three years, three-four years, um, just kind of working service jobs. I finally enrolled back in college , but I really didn't know what I wanted to do. And so I ended up , you know, I mean, basically partying my one year in college away. You know , my grades were so bad , I wasn't invited to go back. I think, just kind of at the back of my mind , I had always wanted to do something that was creative. But, you know, when you're growing up on the reservation, I mean, you can be creative, but you probably won't get paid for it. 'Cause when I started doing radio, I absolutely loved it  and, you know , I just ran with it. I tried to do the best job that I could. It was while I was doing that job that I stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary that I worked on. I mean , I kind of just went with the film thing from there. I think you just know when you discover what it is that you want to do.
FullB: and uh, loved it. You know, I was in one of those graduate programs and on, you know, a good salary , and I enjoyed it , but I always felt like I couldn't express myself enough and there was perhaps, ah, some environment somewhere where I could really make a difference. And you know , I was almost nine years in the bank. I could have gotten my superannuation and been set up with a nice house somewhere. I didn't wan na be that person in years, you know, in years in the future, uh, and not have had taken risks. And I was in a very comfortable environment , and I just didn't have this need to take a risk , and I was like excited about taking a risk and not really knowing what the outcome would be. And uh, we didn't know a whole lot back then , but we just made our classes so much fun. People would laugh the whole way through , and so as a result, it just exploded. We went from 23 people our first night to about 200 people after eight weeks. If you've got that feeling inside that there's something else, it's very hard to get rid of -- which is a good thing. I think there's that something driving you to say , " Well there's something else " out there . ''
EventsA: enrolled back in college — partied the one year in college away — was not invited to go back to college — started doing radio — stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary — worked on the first documentary
EventsB: I was in one of those graduate programs — I was almost nine years in the bank — We made our classes fun — The number of people in the class grew from 23 to about 200 after eight weeks

Q12: The stories about about helping people, and someone who needs help.
Q13: One is about someone who desires to help people, and the other is about someone who might need kindness from someone.
FullA: being six years old , postcards coming into my family, as one after another of the relatives that my parents had were, you know, dead in the concentration camps. And I remember just being very affected by that as a six or seven year old. I became convinced right then , I think, that I did not want to be one of those people. I wanted to be a kind of person that helped other people. That instead of bringing suffering , I wanted to try to alleviate suffering. And what better way to try to alleviate the suffering of human beings than being a doctor? I think everyone has to make a choice which will bring themselves inner peace and happiness as the best they can achieve it. No matter what you do, you will have an opportunity to impact on other people's lives, just by who you are and the way you act.
FullB: and the next minute, you know , I'm thrown over 50 feet from a car  and they thought I died, you know? And they thought I'd never walk again. And people have often asked was I not angry or bitter , and the answer is no. It just is.  Everything seems so minimal, you know, when I'm sitting here talking to you. But just, you know, your mother, the accident...  why not just, " You know what, I cant ''? Like, you know --?  What would have been my option? You see it, don't you? You're sitting, waiting on the first of the month to get a check. Stuck in a wheelchair. You know... That-that's an option? I don't take reality checks from anybody. I want to follow what my passion is in life more than anything else. Don't give me a reality check because reality will tell you what you can't do. " You need to deal " with the real world. '' No, my world is real to me.
EventsA: Postcards came into the family from deceased relatives in concentration camps — The narrator became convinced that they did not want to be like those people — The narrator decided to become a person who helped others — The narrator decided to become a doctor to alleviate human suffering
EventsB: He was thrown over 50 feet from a car — People thought he died — People thought he would never walk again

Q12: They come about in a completely different manner.
Q13: I think they are both based on doing something you have never done before.
FullA: Made a couple bucks and I wanted to go race. I read about a guy in Motor Trend Magazine who raced at Pike's Peak and he was just basically an average guy. And we're actually friends now , his name is C Van Tune, he was the editor at Motor Trend. I'm like, man, if that guy can do it , maybe I can do it. So in 1991, I bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4. I thought, well, I wan na go race at Pike's Peak. I got the rulebook, had to put a roll cage in it. And I thought, well, maybe I could modify it too, to make it to go faster. Before I went to Pike's Peak, I read about a race in Nevada called the Silver State Classic. It's a 90 mile race in Nevada where they take a public highway, a state highway , and they just shut it down. And you go as fast as you can go from one city to the next. And so I averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles. So I went 90 miles in 34 minutes. And at that point, I was totally hooked. I got fourth place in the race.
FullB: You know , you're not becoming a doctor where you're changing people's lives physically, but sometimes you make people's lives emotionally a little better. When I was about three years old, I said, " Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, " what do you call that? '' She says, " A comic, a comedian. '' I went, " That's what I wan na be. '' I think a lot of people know what they wan na do , but they don't have the courage to really follow it. I mean, maybe you have maybe a perception that we have never a waning moment of thinking, " This isn't worth it. '' Or doubt or " Oh my gosh '' all the time -- all the time, especially as an actor. The fear of failure is-is what gets you all the time. When you're actually going through the failure, you're like,  " How am I gon na get out of this? " This is bad , but how am I gon na get out of it ? '' But the fear of failure is what keeps people from trying anyway.
EventsA: bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4 in 1991 — got the rulebook for Pike's Peak race — put a roll cage in the car — read about the Silver State Classic race in Nevada — raced 90 miles in the Silver State Classic — averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles — finished fourth place in the Silver State Classic race
EventsB: I said, 'Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, what do you call that?' — She said, 'A comic, a comedian.' — I said, 'That's what I wanna be.'

Q12: Story A seems like a really tough scenario to be in. Story B just sounds like a happy story of success
Q13: Story A explains a large personal struggle and B is more of a success story
FullA: Going from your high school in Brooklyn to going into college. What was that transition like? That was 1971. You guys were not even thought about. I left Brooklyn and went to Michigan , and I didn't know anybody , and I was scared and insecure, and couldn't even complete a sentence. My sophomore year in college, I was donating blood in order to eat. You remember those things. I'm 61 years old , so I think at this stage in my life I'm responsible for 300,000 people who work for this company. And my clear purpose to them and the communities we serve, and my own family, is to enhance their lives in ways that I can do as the head of this company.
FullB: Originally, I thought I was just gon na be a contractor. Then I decided I was gon na study architecture so I moved out to California. And throughout all that, Eli and I met each other out in California. And I tried Switchel for the first time. A month later, we sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont. And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. It takes a lot of time to manage people when you bring them on. So I'm gon na go for the person who's already shows that they're halfway there.
EventsA: left Brooklyn and went to Michigan — was scared and insecure — couldn't complete a sentence — donated blood in order to eat
EventsB: I decided to study architecture — I moved out to California — Eli and I met each other in California — I tried Switchel for the first time — We sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont

Q12: A is a story about perseverance and B is more of a personal acceptance thing
Q13: Story A was a good example of overcoming obstacles and thriving. Story B is just touching on confidence and comfort
FullA: My own personal story, I have come to understand that it's a teaching story  and it is my greatest credential, to be really honest with you , is where I've been. I had a childhood that was with a certain privilege but also with a certain degree of violence in my environment and an overlay of alcoholism. And so by the time I was a teenager  and I was slipping into disordered eating, and drug use and abuse, promiscuity, and just poor choices at certain levels. I was really angry. And I didn't know why. And I didn't know what to do with all my emotions. So I was hungry when I could get around good teachers. And I fortunately did and I began dancing. And it was no question in my being that I needed to be moving my body. But it wasn't like okay , and now I'll take steps A, B, and C.  And that's the biggest message I wan na give to all the young people, to know that it's just one right step at a time to build a beautiful career and a life work.
FullB: of airplanes. I mean, just, airplanes was it. I had to fly 'em , I had to build 'em. I had to understand them, study them. The whole nine yards. I was out there in Key West in A7s. It was, um, my second kind of go around ah, to kind of qualify at the ship. And there were plenty of people in front of me that had not qualified and they were sort of farmed off to other careers. Between now and the next three minutes it takes to fly aboard , I'm either gon na get a thumbs up or that's it. You live your life for moments like that. For me, it was, you know, really all about perseverance. Whether it's pride or something else, but failure was just not an option. I'm not gon na wash out. I'm not gon na give up. You have to force yourself out of your comfort zone , I think, a lot of the time just to see who you are and how the world reacts to you.
EventsA: I had a childhood with a certain degree of violence and an overlay of alcoholism — I slipped into disordered eating, drug use and abuse, and promiscuity as a teenager — I was really angry — I was hungry when I could get around good teachers — I began dancing
EventsB: He flew airplanes. — He built airplanes. — He studied airplanes. — He was in Key West in A7s. — He tried to qualify at the ship for the second time. — He faced a moment where he would either get a thumbs up or fail.

Q12: One found a different path and the other realized they already had a great job
Q13: They both touch on personal struggles with school and life in general. They both found a way to overcome their shortcomings
FullA: My passion was always to find a way to make a difference. But it wasn't until later in life that I really understood how to channel that passion. Right out of high school, I was being recruited to play football at Pittsburgh college and the first day of class, I didn't go. Because I couldn't figure out, A, how I was gon na get from where I  live to Pittsburgh College which was at least, 45 minutes away. There was nobody around me to really help me understand the value of what that university could provide me. So I just turned it down. I didn't understand where I was going or how I was gon na get there. But I went, walked into the doors of a community college and then the community college pulled me in. Now, I have the privilege of serving as the chancellor for the California Community Colleges. So I have the pleasure of representing more than 2.1 million students to have the opportunity to finish a quality college credential and get into a job, or to transfer and something that gives them an opportunity to really achieve what they wan na achieve. But that's what it did for me and that's given me the opportunity to really fulfill my passion and take it from there.
FullB: The expectations on both sides, from my mother and father, were always that you do well in school. There was never a question about whether or not I would go to college. It was when I got to college and lost my support and scaffolding system that I completely fell apart. I had been so successful for so long and I could not figure out why I could not pull it together. Because I struggled. I really, and now I understand and know it was my ADHD. I had no clue at the time what it was. I started working in the classroom and I, like, the first day in the classroom. I fell in love. What I discovered was preschoolers all to some degree have ADHD. So, we got along fine. So, they have 10 minute attention spans , so do I, so , the activities were cool. It was just , it was the perfect job for me. I was like, why didn't anybody tell me I could do this before. But I didn't really get my act together until probably my late 20s or early 30s. I accept that I have challenges and it's sometimes I'm not gon na do stuff right , and so when I, laughter, for me, you mean being able to laugh at stuff, accepting it, being able to laugh at it. Being able to forgive myself and other people. I think are the keys to just making it work. And then just move on to the next hurdle cuz there's always gon na be another hurdle.
EventsA: I was recruited to play football at Pittsburgh college — I didn't go to the first day of class at Pittsburgh college — I turned down the opportunity to attend Pittsburgh college — I walked into the doors of a community college — The community college pulled me in — I served as the chancellor for the California Community Colleges
EventsB: I got to college and lost my support and scaffolding system — I completely fell apart — I started working in the classroom — I fell in love with working in the classroom — I discovered that preschoolers have ADHD — I got along fine with preschoolers — I realized the job was perfect for me — I got my act together in my late 20s or early 30s — I accepted that I have challenges — I learned to laugh at stuff and forgive myself and others

Q12: One had an accident that made them reconsider, the other decided to make a change after being worn out
Q13: They both made a change in their profession for something that related to their personal desires more
FullA: and surfing and when I was really young, and skiing. So those, that's really where my passion was. In my teenage years, you know, I had a business sense , but I was more so building a professional surfing career. And I had an accident, um, my first year in college. I broke my neck right before I was gon na go on the pro tour. So everything kind of shifted of like, " Okay, well maybe you should just go " to school and then take that focus and turn it a little bit " into uh, you know, the action sports industry. '' In my head, I was determined that Volcom was gon na be the greatest thing ever, so it was like... even if we didn't know how to make clo - We didn't know what we were doing. But we were doing it. Don't be too um , you know, burdened by, " I don't know " exactly what I'm gon na do and if what I'm studying " is gon na relate to it. '' You'll find yourself moving around , but hopefully, you gravitate towards what you like. And I think, you know, money and all that kind of stuff is secondary.
FullB: I did. So I guess where we'd like to start is just kind of, we're like here. How you got from our age to where you are now, managing life? I spent 17 years at IBM right out of school. And I didn't take responsibility or any initiative regarding my career. And that was a big mistake. But finally, I got tired of it , so I started taking control of my career. That really helped , I got myself a job at Charles Schwab and got moved out here. But towards the end of my time at Schwab, I started this little hobby, Craigslist. The initial idea was just that I would send friends, maybe 10 or 12, notices about what I thought were cool events. Then people started making suggestions of new categories like jobs and it just keep growing. And by the end of 98, that's when I decided it was time to make it a real company.
EventsA: He had an accident in his first year in college. — He broke his neck right before he was going to go on the pro tour.
EventsB: I spent 17 years at IBM — I got tired of it — I started taking control of my career — I got a job at Charles Schwab — I moved out here — I started a hobby, Craigslist — I sent friends notices about cool events — People made suggestions of new categories — I decided to make Craigslist a real company

Q12: Sequence A was already in a related profession involving the water.  Sequence B made a decision to better their lives
Q13: They both were familiar with a profession but decided to take a path that fit them better
FullA: I was learning how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy, to figure out whether their ships are gon na be able to get through a storm or not. How big are the waves gon na be in two days time out in the middle of the Pacific? And it turned out that my students started using that to figure out when to go surfing. And I was in academia , I was in that track. So when I did make that decision to leave there were some people that were shocked  and also people thought it was a waste of a Ph.D, even though my original aim was to join the Navy. I ended up not feeling all that comfortable with the fact that a lot of the research I was doing was effectively weapons systems. But now what I do is, people get up in the morning and they can say , should I go surfing today or not? And they can look at what we make and go , yeah , I might go surf, and it puts smiles on people's faces.
FullB: I come from farm worker parents. It wasn't until I married and I was 28 years of age that I realized that I wasn't gon na go anywhere unless I have an education. So I had to turn my life around to do  what I wanted to do, and what I wanted to do was be in this world of media. So I went to a community college and I transferred to UCLA , and I became a writer. And so, from that to what I do today, I'm an advocate. I do civil rights, civil rights and specifically, in media. When reporting about the Latino community, it was a crime blotter. It was Maria killed Jose because Jose molested her child and the child was doing drugs on the side. It was like that , it was terrible. So we formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition, because how we are perceived is always going to be the way that we are treated. If we're perceived that being the laborers out in the field and so forth, you'll be treated that way. And, we're that, sure of course we are. Right? But the fact is that we're also a great deal more. Never believe that somebody else is gon na do it for you. You have to take the bull by the horns and make the changes.
EventsA: I learned how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy — My students started using the maps to figure out when to go surfing — I made the decision to leave academia — People were shocked by my decision to leave — People thought it was a waste of a Ph.D — I ended up not feeling comfortable with the research I was doing
EventsB: I married at 28 years of age — I realized that I needed an education — I turned my life around — I went to a community college — I transferred to UCLA — I became a writer — I became an advocate — We formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition

A guy that was uh, in a search firm, a headhunter, knew all my passions about comic books and movies and music. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. '' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. You don't want to be put into that position of luck ... making a difference in your life at a later age. Be in charge of your destiny now.
FullB: I went to school for welding, design, pouring metal, and working in the foundry, and all of these crazy things , I thought it was everything. I really just had to drop everything and start over and just move , and I just explored. And I took some time off  and I was doing my thing, traveling out here to Colorado, and just kind of experimenting with different processes. I ended up blowing glass and trying it for the first time, and falling in love, like that's it , that's my life.

FullA: I am Kimberly Lazer , I'm the curator of Behavioral Husbandry and Welfare for Oklahoma City Zoo. So I spend a lot of time looking, observing, learning everything we can about the species and about what their needs are to give them many choices in their environment. So that they have varied days and they have a very dynamic environment that they're living in. When I was five years old, I had an encounter with a dolphin. And I was able to look that animal in the eye and that was it for me. I wanted to dedicate my life to working with animals. When I left college, I thought, well, that's it , I'm ready. Put me in a job , I know what to do. And what I found was the animals were the best teachers. They have taught me humility. I think that's a big one. They've taught me compassion, to be a little bit more open and be very understanding. Especially to other human beings. That was something I learned when I left college. I had amazing experiences in college and I loved my classes but I don't think I really started becoming well rounded until I got out of the classroom. And I really started learning the real world stuff. So talk to people, hear their stories, and keep an open mind because every person has something to teach you.
FullB: I think it was an LA Times that my dad sent me , and it was just a really ambiguous ad saying, photographers, editors, technicians needed for sports photography agency. And I was like, what is this about? I was an athlete at one point in my life , I like sports, so let's check it out. At that point, didn't really much experience in photography. Realized  I was kind of out of my league for their photography positions, but the door was open to be an editor. So I immediately jumped to that job, knowing that in the back of my head I want to be a photographer , so I just took that opportunity knowing that I was eventually going to parlay it into to where I wanted to go. So in my spare time I'd go out and take photos, cuz the thing was, working for that company allowed me the access that I wanted to get to take photos at sporting events. And I didn't think that I'd be here 25 years later still kind of doing it. The moment you capture something and you just know you've got it in your camera , it's magical. So I just walked through the doors that were opened for me , and I just took them and here I am now. And I'm just fortunate to do something that I love , and it trips me out that I get paid for it. So doors are going to open and close , and it's going to come down to which ones you walk through

FullA: I got shot in June 2007. I took a bullet side-to-side through the knee on a house raid , so it basically blew my knee out. Everything that I wanted to do or I wanted to be revolved around being a soldier. So I struggled. What do you see most on social media and on the news? You see PTSD, suicide, all these veterans struggling, that's the trendy story. But we just need to change that rhetoric, instead of talking about all these bad things, talk about the positive things, the things that we learn, that we are capable of that make us great. Instead of cowering from challenges, we learn to face our fears , we learn to face those obstacles, and so use those things we learned in the military to not just live in the civilian world but thrive.

Were you worried? I was worried. The thing is I saw a lot of my friends struggle with not trying in fear of what could be. And my thing, I've always had the personality that was like, I need to know. Q12: Both of these people truly feel that they had to overcome prejudice and stereotypes to earn their places in careers that even they would not have thought were idyllic for people like them.

FullA: go through any traditional channels. I never went to, like, a proper film school or ... worked on traditional film sets and learned my way up the way that other people might. In the 1980s, Michael Stipe from R.E.M. had sort of like a film group that was giving money to underground filmmakers , and he saw some of the stuff that I'd done , and I went down to Athens, Georgia, where his band, R.E.M., was based and where there were a lot of other artists and filmmakers. I wasn't specifically trying to do music videos or feature films or documentaries or whatever. Just kind of made these personal, experimental films, and then people that would see those would respond to 'em and ask me to go do other things with them or for them. It's an element of like putting yourself at the right place at the right time. Like I definitely left the wrong place in New Jersey and went to Athens, Georgia, which, at that time, felt like where I belonged. But, you know, it's your life and you need to... go hit all these different experiences while you can.
FullB: So I started as a Hispanic woman in sports reporting , okay? So that may be, if not as white as the tech industry, it's pretty close. Literally, my very first job, I had someone sit down and say to me so, you know why you got this job, right? And the implication was because I was a Hispanic woman. And I said, because I am amazing. I learned really early on that there was going to be a lot of people that would be, like. Well you only got this job because of this or you can't do this because of this. I had people say like do you like tech or do you like, and the answer's like would you ask a doctor do you like blood no. Or it's like do you understand how this works and you wouldn't do that in any other field or if there's lots of other people who look more like they should be in tech than me. There's a lot of people who will totally write you off because there's not that many people who look like you. There's a lot of negativity and some people like I said , I come from a background where it's like whatever. Shut up , don't listen to those people and ignore them and use them as motivation. Yeah, so I mean it's about being willing to figure out what's best for you and go on your own path. And sometimes there's starts and stops , but it's life.
EventsA: Michael Stipe saw some of the stuff that the narrator had done — The narrator went down to Athens, Georgia — People responded to the narrator's personal, experimental films — People asked the narrator to do other things with them or for them — The narrator left New Jersey — The narrator went to Athens, Georgia

Q12: Story B has a male narrator who left his band in order to become an insurance company worker, whereas Story A features a narrator that is female, dealt with homophobia, and still is trying to cope with a lack of acceptance from loved ones.
Q13: Story A has a narrator and primary character who spoke about the trauma of being abandoned by their family, physically and mentally abused, and choosing to be transparent in their truth moving forward with people. Story B was focused on a narrator who chose to find a pathway of career validation as an insurance brokerage company's vice president.
FullA: When I was a kid, I used to hide everything, like hide all the terrible details of my life. And kind of pull them close to me and try to make them look like something else to other people when I told the story. Yeah. And I think when I was 17 and I went away to college , I got very tired of trying to keep track of all my lies. So I decided I would never tell a lie again. I got to tired of it , I walked right in to my college roommate , and I just kinda blurted out like, my mother left me when I was a baby , my father doesn't want me and my cousins all tried to rape me. And I'm not a Christian anymore , I don't believe in God, and I'm here on a scholarship. And I don't think she spoke to me again for the rest of the semester , but basically I think that was a valuable accident I happened upon because after that I was just like the tell all girl. The tell too much girl. And I think when I became a lesbian I continued to be that kind of person, telling everyone about it in a culture that was violently homophobic.
FullB: My name is David Shotts , I'm the Vice President at Ascend Insurance Brokerage and we work directly with the entertainment industry. So, we work with music venues, music festivals, touring artists, event safety, event security companies. I kinda got into this industry by accident. I was playing in a band  and we were touring the country, and having a lot of fun, and not really thinking about insurance, to be quite honest. My broker said no one knows this industry like you, come to work for me , and I have just kind of found out I was really good at it. It's cool because I'll talk to people and I'll tell them  what I do and most commonly people are like, I didn't even know you could get insurance for that. I think it's kind of the beauty of the industry is that the insurance is everywhere. It doesn't just stop with home, auto, life. So if you're into extreme sports, I know a brokerage in California that focuses on extreme sports. If you're into hunting and fishing, I know underwriters that specialize in that industry. Get an idea of what's out there. If you're sitting there going I'm not quite sure what I wan na do in this industry, that's okay. As I said earlier, there's a lot of opportunity in this industry so feel around.
EventsA: I went away to college — I decided I would never tell a lie again — I walked right in to my college roommate — I blurted out my personal story to my roommate — My roommate did not speak to me for the rest of the semester — I became a lesbian — I told everyone about being a lesbian in a homophobic culture
EventsB: David Shotts played in a band — David Shotts toured the country with his band — David Shotts' broker invited him to work for him — David Shotts started working in the insurance industry

Q12: Both of these people had unconventional paths to finding success and their success still had adversity and low odds of success attached to it.
Q13: These stories have narrators who achieved success and inspiration later in their lives than they would have intended, yet they still felt a void that needed support and love to make it worthwhile to them.
FullA: A few years ago I had a bit of a scare. My appendix ruptured on tour and I came close to dying. And it was the same week that my first song went into the top 20. After more than 20 years of making music - Wow. We had a song, Say Hey I Love You. Goes into the top 20. And I'm on this gurney being wheeled down to perhaps my death. And I get this text. Your song's in the top 20, and I'm like, didn't even matter. Yeah. I was like , whatever. I was like , I just wan na see my kids again. I wan na be with my family. And I can appreciate having made music for that long that it's a nice thing to have a lot of people hear your song. But If I can't share with my family, it doesn't matter. At this point in my life, I'm 48. I have two sons. I have one who's 27 and I have one who's 15. And I still feel like I'm 22 years old. I still have the same passion for what I do with music. And I have this life that I feel is fulfilling in so many ways that I feel happy most of the time.
FullB: I'm 53 years old , I'm trying to decide what I'm gon na do when I grow up. My grandfather farmed , he went out and said , hey do you wan na plant a garden? And I got started that way , we planted some radishes in a spot about this big and I thought it was the coolest thing. I was debating between agriculture and ornamental horticulture, like growing flowers. But I thought if I'm gon na spend my life doing something, I would rather spend my life helping to feed the world. So our job is to develop a hybrid seed that will help the farmer in his business. So if you take two inbreds, like that , and you cross them , that's your hybrid. So people are like, why do you have hybrids? It's like, that's why I have hybrids. Some people feel like , okay , I just wan na make a lot of money. But if you can find something you have a passion for, you love it, you think about it in the morning when you wake up. And then you can figure out an intersection of that thing with something that you can make a living doing , That's a pretty sweet place to be.
EventsA: My appendix ruptured on tour — I came close to dying — My first song went into the top 20 — I was on a gurney being wheeled down — I got a text saying my song was in the top 20
EventsB: Grandfather asked if they wanted to plant a garden — They planted some radishes in a small spot — They debated between agriculture and ornamental horticulture — They decided to spend their life helping to feed the world — They developed a hybrid seed to help farmers — They crossed two inbred plants to create a hybrid

FullA: The single worst job I ever had was washing dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. And I was the guy who was doing the communicable diseases stuff. So I had to wear the heavy gloves, and man, that stuff was just nasty. And so the whenever I started working my way up the ladder, reminding myself of, well, I could be doing that, which was always very helpful. And also I think it helped me to never look down on somebody for what they're doing, because if somebody looked down at me washing those eight patients ' dishes, they would of misjudged me completely. Remember, that anybody who tells you that they kind of woke up and were whoever they were, they're kidding you, right? So everybody gets started somewhere. If somebody figured something out, you can too, cuz they did the hard part. They figured it out the first time, right? And so when we meet with a lot of these folks, just know that where you are right now, that could be you in 10, 20 years. Don't measure yourself in terms of my gosh , I've got so far to go. If you end up not running a marathon anytime soon, my father used to run them. I remember him training , and it was a little bit of time, right? And eventually, you get there. Just know that if you keep plugging away, it will work out, right? I'm a big believer , you do the right things, good things happen.
FullB: Like let's say I went out with my husband and we went to dinner and we were meeting people. And they're like, " Oh, what do you do? '' I was like, " Oh, I make things. '' And we'd get in the car  and he'd be like, " Why didn't you say " you were an artist ? '' And I was like , " Well, " you know , I don't know . '' I mean I went to school for it , you know , I make images. But I was just having a hard time I guess accepting that as who I was or what I was going to be. I think I used to really obsess or focus on what I wasn't doing rather than what I was doing. And I think that's a huge... something that can really paralyze you. So I think it's really good to say, " What am I working on? " What is great? What am I happy about? " What am I doing good? '' And to do that and then know that you have a whole life. You'll get there.
EventsA: The narrator washed dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. — The narrator wore heavy gloves to handle communicable diseases. — The narrator started working their way up the ladder. — The narrator remembered that they could be doing the dishwashing job. — The narrator recalled their father training to run marathons.
EventsB: I went out with my husband — We went to dinner — We were meeting people — I said I make things — We got in the car — He asked why I didn't say I was an artist

Q12: both are different in making process. the story build different plots
Q13: both stories talk about the school days but the development are different.
FullA: I wanted to be an artist when I was in high school , but I actually started in nursing school. We were really poor , and my dad died when I was six , and I saw my mom struggle working in a sewing factory. And I thought , well this is crazy to be a starving artist. I better do something practical. So I went to school for nursing. And photography and me was a better fit. It just felt like a better fit. So, started at the Miami Herald as a staff photographer, just from there moved on to do international stories, so I bounced around a lot. I traveled a whole lot. You know, when you can capture a moment, capture history , I don't know, just preserve that second of time, that's meaningful in some way. If it makes you feel, it's probably gon na make someone else feel too. But those were the moments that I always look for. And I feel like there's all different types of photography that you have to appreciate. You can do all these stylized beautiful perfectly composed pictures , but for me, journalism, I think the only thing that matters is the content in the moment and making someone feel. Because you can make someone think, but to make someone feel is the ultimate goal. The more you can do to connect people, the less hatred there will be in the world, the more understanding there will be.
FullB: and I suddenly realized something about science that I hadn't know before which was that if I wanted to be in science I'd have to pick one thing and I liked everything way too much to pick one thing. I really loved writing. I really loved helping students and teaching and I loved art  and with all that known, I kind of went off to Boston University with a vague idea of something communications. I did not know  and it wasn't until I was in my sophomore year and I was taking that first journalism class that they teach and then one day Professor Brand said, " What are you majoring in? '' And I said, " I don't know. PR? '' And he said, " PR?! " The best people are in journalism , you can do this! You could be in journalism , '' and I thought, " Wow . '' In hindsight everything has come together almost eerily logically. How did you prepare to take those risks when nothing really felt like it was going to come together? People would say to me, " Oh newspaper? " You'll never get a job in a newspaper. Never! '' I thought, ` Why not? It could happen to me , it's as likely as anybody else. ' And then my job is, make it as likely as I can make it by being as good as I can.

FullA: So I'm a program manager at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and I work in our Criminal Justice Reform Department and we're working to safely reform the criminal justice system. Reduce incarceration while keeping our neighborhood safe , and it's an exciting role , I really love what I do. I love meeting the people who've been impacted by our criminal justice system. I'm also system-impacted. I ultimately spent 12 years in state corrections and it was definitely the toughest part of my life. I came out and I owned what got me incarcerated. Really was able to dive down deep in myself and really think how did I get there. One of things that it's given me is it's given me a perspective that other programs managers that are working in criminal justice reform don't have. I don't know how many different ways we have to recycle a plastic bottle, right? We think of people as disposable  and we've got ta shift the narrative around that, right? We don't want people leaving our jails and prisons and not having opportunities to thrive and contribute. I think there's a lot of work to be done here. And it's a really crazy turn of events of where I've ended up in life , but I feel like I'm where I should be.
FullB: My name is Tom Arviso, Jr. , I'm the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated. And I've been here about 27 years now. And I started here as a college intern. And I studied journalism with the intent of becoming a sports writer. That was my passion. But once I got here to the Navajo Times, things just kind of gradually evolved , and I just kind of rose through the ranks to the point where now I'm running the company. I never looked back ever since I started doing that and just been trying to go and do as much as I can possibly do in regards to telling stories, telling people stories, and being good at it. Being right. Being ethical. Being honest. This profession, it's a field where you really have to have a passion for what you're doing, a belief in being a storyteller. If you're sincere about what you do, about your craft, about being a good journalist, then things will fall into place for you if you're patient.
EventsA: I spent 12 years in state corrections — I came out — I owned what got me incarcerated — I thought deeply about how I got incarcerated

FullA: 19 years ago, actually, I started working for SLUG Magazine. The previous owner of SLUG heard about me, and called me up and asked me to shoot a cover. So that's how I first became a staff member of SLUG, was shooting a cover. And then from that point forward, I became a managing editor , and then two years later, I had the opportunity to take over the magazine , and that's when I officially became editor and then publisher. And I've always felt different from my family , and from kind of being part of the peer group that I grew up in, I just always didn't quite connect. But then I kind of learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is, and the work here that we could do to find others that feel that way. Where they may not feel that way at home, or at school, or in a lot of other environments. But here in SLUG Magazine, we can really appreciate them for being different. I think it goes back to that love, right? I really love doing what I do, and hearing these stories from these individuals that come up to you and say hey , I would not be where I am today if it wasn't for my experience with SLUG Magazine. Hearing that feedback and that validation from other individuals about how we've affected their lives in a positive way, and that's priceless.
FullB: A lot of teachers feel like they have to be this like, alter ego. Like for me, honestly who I am in the classroom is who I am in life. Did you have any, like, uh-oh moments, when you were like , I have no idea what I'm doing, like once you were in the classroom? All the time. All the time and I still kinda do. A lot of people thought that I was just a fun teacher. Oh he's just , all his kids, they're not really learning anything. I hate when teachers think that just because their class is rigorous that they can't have any fun. It's not until when my test scores came back, my AP scores and they were better than theirs , you don't even have to say anything. Yeah. I am very German but I am very about living life and working hard and being rigorous but having fun the entire time we're doing it. Because that's life. I really come to work with a smile on my face every single day. And that's what it's all about, right?
EventsA: I started working for SLUG Magazine — The previous owner of SLUG called me up and asked me to shoot a cover — I shot a cover — I became a managing editor — I had the opportunity to take over the magazine — I officially became editor and then publisher — I learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is — Individuals came up to me and said they would not be where they are today if it wasn't for their experience with SLUG Magazine
EventsB: The narrator had moments of uncertainty in the classroom — The narrator's test scores and AP scores came back better than others

However, the beginning of each story is quite different, since position of the first author is one of uncertainty and exploration, while the other other knew the direction they wanted to take. Therefore, I rate the stories overall "moderately similar".
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I knew during high school that I wanted to study biology and I did try out the research field for a little while. I then took a teaching job in the middle school , and after that, I took a curriculum writing and editing job. You know , I did some good jobs but I did go into them not knowing if okay I'm gon na love this and this is gon na be what I do for the rest of my life. And I think that sometimes young people put that pressure on themselves. I need to know exactly what I'm going to do for the rest of my life and I need to know it now. Yeah. And it's not really realistic , nor do I think that it's necessarily helpful. Just having experiences, those can really help you know who you are and what you want to be about.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I tried out the research field for a little while — I took a teaching job in the middle school — I took a curriculum writing and editing job

FullB: I always grew up with tea being a stable at our dining table. One of my colleagues from my previous job, knew a recruiter at eBay and he recommended me and they ended up hiring me. But one day I was trying to make loose-leaf tea at my desk , and by the time I would make it , I would be late for a meeting. And every time I tried to use tea bags instead, I was never satisfied with the quality because it was not as flavorful, it didn't have as much aroma. That was my first point of inspiration to think about the idea for tea drops. It took me about a year and a half of experimenting. I would spend my weekends and my week nights kind of blending and I was obsessed with figuring it out. And once I had that, I started sharing it with my colleagues and friends and family. Now we're available in over 1,600 retail stores. My logic was, even if this failed, even if nothing ever comes of it, I know I would have gained so much in trying

FullA: I'm an Assistant Professor in Astronomy at California Institute of Technology and Caltech. And I study the dynamic universe. So what I do is, with the beautiful telescopes here at Palomar Observatory, we have some robotic telescopes that are continuously making a movie of the night sky. So we image the sky over and over again and we look for what changed. You might go out there and think universe is the same old thing every time , but it's actually not. It's full of these little explosions, which last for a very short amount of time , so they're very But they're very energetic. It's like cosmic fireworks lighting up our sky. So why did you choose to pursue the degree path that you did? I would say that in my own case, I mean , it was not at all clear that one day I would do a PhD. I grew up on a farm in India with 100 cows and fields of weeds and chick peas. And I had left home when I was 15 , and I was a girl in India in a small place. The entire community was up in arms, you know? There were people like neighbors, relatives , you name it. People I haven't even seen before coming into the house and trying to talk my parents out of this crazy decision to send their daughter alone on this journey into other end of the world to pursue something called Astronomy or whatever that was. The community was completely unsupportive. How did you deal with that? In my case, the best way to deal with it was to just let that fade away in the background and not engage with the two directly, but focus on what is motivating me, on what is giving me joy and just let everything else just fade away in the background.
FullB: My dad turned into a alcoholic and became abusive. I got kicked out. And I'm just trying to , I guess find positivity, and I guess trying to stay happy on top of everything. Coming from someone who dealt with being homeless, what kind of advice can I have? I would never forget being 15 years old, put out of the house, Butt naked, out of a bathtub, Christmas Day in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, at the point of a shotgun, by my stepfather. Until I went into the military, the worst violence I ever saw was at home. So I make a decision, no. I don't wan na live like that. I could've become a stepfather. I could've become another alcoholic, wife beating, child abusing, illiterate loser. And a lot of people would've said, well look where he's from he didn't have a choice. Well I did have a choice. That pain, how I dealt with it. I made the commitment , this will never happen again to another child. And I wan na start with this one in my arms. This stops with me.
EventsA: I studied the dynamic universe — I used robotic telescopes at Palomar Observatory to make a movie of the night sky — I imaged the sky repeatedly to look for changes — I grew up on a farm in India — I left home when I was 15 — The community tried to talk my parents out of sending me away — I decided to focus on my motivation and joy and ignore the community's opposition
EventsB: My dad turned into an alcoholic and became abusive — I got kicked out — I was put out of the house, butt naked, out of a bathtub, on Christmas Day in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, at the point of a shotgun by my stepfather — I went into the military — I made a decision not to live like that — I made the commitment that this will never happen again to another child

FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. FullA: Born and raised here in Detroit. I went to public school. I knew I wanted to go to college but didn't know how I was gon na get there. Out of college, I did sales for a number of years just kind of really trying to find my way. And my wife was a student here at Wayne Community College , they had an opportunity, an opening on the phones. One day the chancellor of the college was on the other end and I had no clue. And I was just excited to be answering phones for the college. And he wanted to meet me and I had opportunities to advance from there. Now I am the associate vice chancellor for students services. So, I tell everybody, I'm not supposed to be here, statistically speaking. I'm a black male  and I grew up in Detroit with all the gang violence, with all the drug violence. So, don't be defined by the neighborhoods that you came from. Don't be defined by whether or not you're a first generation college student, whether you're a minority. Whatever that is, you can go and do and be whoever you wan na be.

Be respectful to people and that goes a long way whether you're in management or whether you're the employee. Treat people how you want to be treated. FullA: I started my career in law as a paralegal. So I thought I was gon na be a lawyer and then I kinda never met a happy lawyer. Coming from that environment , I went into film and TV. It is sales , it is pitching , it is being able to speak , I was like, wow that's a great job , I wan na do that. So at that point I convinced some investors to take a chance on something really different. I felt there was a real void in terms of translating video games to proper entertainment. And as I went on my journey to focus on providing an independent, go to source for Esports  and competitive gaming thought well, wait a minute. We can really build the news unlike any other. And so I created Gamer World News and it's growing today. I had a long career in TV and TV syndication and all that, and that switched. And I wouldn't have thought I'd be on national news as a contributor, that wasn't my path. But that led me to do it. So push yourself to do things that are a little outside your comfort zone, that you actually don't think you're qualified for.

And that was one of the draws to this organization. Because not only do I know a lot about marketing, and public relations, and communications, and can do that in my sleep, I'm growing. I'm still growing , and one of the things I wan na do is help others through life coaching. And what advice would you give? Two things, one breathe. Give yourself a chance just to breathe. And the other one would be to find yourself in some quiet moments , and kinda have an internal conversation about what it is, am I on the right track? Yeah. And when you know you're on the right track, it's okay, I'm on the right track. I'm doing the right thing. And just know where you are right now is where you're supposed to be. This is where I'm supposed to be.

It takes a lot of time to manage people when you bring them on. So I'm gon na go for the person who's already shows that they're halfway there.

EventsB: I decided to study architecture — I moved out to California — Eli and I met each other in California — I tried Switchel for the first time — We sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont

Q12: The event sequences talk about different career choices.
Q13: They both shared a similiar story line where one wasn't aware of whether what they were doing was right.
FullA: I work here at Fossil. I'm an IT solution manager working in the e-commerce division. Typically a day in e-commerce for me , I manage a team that we're currently rolling out global websites for fossil.com. But I didn't know growing up what is it that I wanted to do , okay? I took a leap of faith , and so in 2000 I started a company called BTV Corporation and where I was doing consulting work for about eight years. It was a little bit risky , but I think the way to advance , you're going to have to take risk, right? But you want it to be a calculated risk. You want to make sure that you're making smart decisions, okay, and not impulse decisions, if you will. So, would my life be different had I not started my own company or even came to Fossil? I'm sure it would be. I don't know what that would be , but I would say , in the end, I am happy with where that journey took me and I appreciate all those that's been around me to kinda support me through that effort.
FullB: When I was really little I think I had a few teachers when I was in kindergarten and first grade that I just adored. And so I would come home and practice being a teacher. From then on, I kind of just thought that's what I wanted to do. And I actually didn't know that I was dyslexic until I started my college career. I did a little part-time internship in a first grade room  and in that classroom, there were kiddos with dyslexia. And so I was learning more with the teacher, just kind of asking questions. And the more that I learned about it, the more it hit home that that's exactly what was going on with me as a kiddo. But it's amazing to get to teach student with dyslexia now. And know exactly what they're going through. It's just , it's really neat that they had that, they had that connection with me.
EventsA: I took a leap of faith — I started a company called BTV Corporation in 2000 — I did consulting work for about eight years
EventsB: I had a few teachers in kindergarten and first grade that I adored — I came home and practiced being a teacher — I started my college career — I did a part-time internship in a first grade room — I learned about dyslexia with the teacher — I realized that I was dyslexic as a kid — I taught students with dyslexia

FullA: to hot air ballooning, and my interest in politics continued. And so in 1972, I kicked off my campaign for the state senate. Oh, sometimes life's overwhelming still. I guess when I think back on it, I mean , you just keep moving forward. For me, doing the next right thing is, is just a good , is a good byword for me.
FullB: And they really, really wanted me to follow their footsteps. In the meantime, I hated their guts , and I hated what they do. Even though they were educating me towards that, they were teaching me for academical drawings and stuff like that, which I am thankful for right now. It helps me to think visually. It helps me immensely , but I wanted to be rebellious. I wanted to do something else , I wanted to explore something that I didn't know. They took it very painfully. So when I just ask my parents to leave me alone, not that politely, and ah, kind of went away in a search of ultimate fusion in life. Everything is the fusion, and as long as you acknowledge existence of the fusion , and as long as you are driven to find your own fusion, your own alchemy, of incompatible elements, you'll be fine.
