Q12: Sequence A focuses on doing stuff to be recruited for more projects while Sequence B is about defending her presence in a job against stereotypes.
Q13: The two stories focus on choosing the path that is the most inconvenient.
FullA: go through any traditional channels. I never went to, like, a proper film school or ... worked on traditional film sets and learned my way up the way that other people might. In the 1980s, Michael Stipe from R.E.M. had sort of like a film group that was giving money to underground filmmakers , and he saw some of the stuff that I'd done , and I went down to Athens, Georgia, where his band, R.E.M., was based and where there were a lot of other artists and filmmakers. I wasn't specifically trying to do music videos or feature films or documentaries or whatever. Just kind of made these personal, experimental films, and then people that would see those would respond to 'em and ask me to go do other things with them or for them. It's an element of like putting yourself at the right place at the right time. Like I definitely left the wrong place in New Jersey and went to Athens, Georgia, which, at that time, felt like where I belonged. But, you know, it's your life and you need to... go hit all these different experiences while you can.
FullB: So I started as a Hispanic woman in sports reporting , okay? So that may be, if not as white as the tech industry, it's pretty close. Literally, my very first job, I had someone sit down and say to me so, you know why you got this job, right? And the implication was because I was a Hispanic woman. And I said, because I am amazing. I learned really early on that there was going to be a lot of people that would be, like. Well you only got this job because of this or you can't do this because of this. I had people say like do you like tech or do you like, and the answer's like would you ask a doctor do you like blood no. Or it's like do you understand how this works and you wouldn't do that in any other field or if there's lots of other people who look more like they should be in tech than me. There's a lot of people who will totally write you off because there's not that many people who look like you. There's a lot of negativity and some people like I said , I come from a background where it's like whatever. Shut up , don't listen to those people and ignore them and use them as motivation. Yeah, so I mean it's about being willing to figure out what's best for you and go on your own path. And sometimes there's starts and stops , but it's life.
EventsA: Michael Stipe saw some of the stuff that the narrator had done — The narrator went down to Athens, Georgia — People responded to the narrator's personal, experimental films — People asked the narrator to do other things with them or for them — The narrator left New Jersey — The narrator went to Athens, Georgia
EventsB: I started as a Hispanic woman in sports reporting — I had someone sit down and say to me that I got the job because I was a Hispanic woman — I said I got the job because I am amazing — I learned that people would say I only got the job because of my background — I had people ask me if I liked tech — I told myself to ignore negative people and use them as motivation

Q12: Both had a change in their lives which altered their reality.
Q13: Story A revolves around trauma while story B revolves more around curiosity. The only reason I said they were slightly similar is because of the narrative and how both show that life rarely follows the initial plan.
FullA: I'd been a real estate agent , I owned an art gallery. I thought, really, my main pur-goal was to really be a good wife, a good mother , and then my life changed completely. My second son was born with a lung disease. They didn't think he'd make it , he got jaundice, and when I brought him home, he'd lost the ability to wake to feed, and so I mean for me, I thought, watching him struggle to breathe, I'd never take breathing for granted again. And I think that's sort of the beginning of me becoming an environmentalist. And so many times, I feel like I'm paying back the debt, because why should I be so lucky? What can I do to survive this life and be a success, so when the end of my road comes -- which people don't wan na talk about, 'cause the end of the road is gon na come for us -- I can look back  and say, " I really feel good about it ''? And it may not be something globally. I think that if you touch anyone's life , then you're a success.
FullB: from Canada you could ever figure out how to make movies.  Right? So I just figured I'd be going into engineering , so I took lots of maths and sciences all through high school getting ready for that. And at the last minute, I heard about this school that taught film production not too far away , and I got accepted there. Went from film production to animation to computer animation, for me. And, ah, that was inter - really interesting because it had the sort of scientific side, math and science, which I was, you know, really good at. And it had this artistic side. So I could program one minute , and then I could go , you know, fool around with animation, look at cartoons and stuff. I had a few jobs where it would be like, " Oh... great... I got ta go to work ...  '' And, you know, I sort of knew all along, " Okay, I don't want to spend my life doing this . '' You know , you'll find something, you know? And don't worry about it being the perfect thing because I think no decision is absolute, first of all, you know? I've certainly had several changes along the way. A lot of people have.
EventsA: Her second son was born with a lung disease — He got jaundice — She brought him home — He lost the ability to wake to feed — She watched him struggle to breathe
EventsB: I took lots of maths and sciences all through high school — I heard about a school that taught film production — I got accepted at the film production school — I went from film production to animation to computer animation

Q12: The only thing similar is the pivot in their lives.
Q13: Both emphasize that as a community/organization grows, the leader must eventually stop doing everything by themselves.
FullA: I'm really an early stage person. I love to make the new thing and so as something gets bigger and more structured , I usually hand it off to people and there's people who love to run stuff that's structured. So when I joined Google we were about 1,200 people and when I left we're over 50 or 60,000 people, so it was sort of fly the plane while you're building the plane. I had gone from working in Silicon Valley and working at Google on a lot of topics. It was fun, incredible teammates. And then I was in Africa for some work with some entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya and I got an email and it said email from the US CTO. And so 33 days later, President Obama called and offered me the job which was incredible. It's an honor to get to serve your country. So when you're doing this work, know that you belong. We all come with different histories and those histories are culture add. There's this weird idea that Silicon Valley had of culture fit. It's very destructive. I don't want you to fit , I want you to add.
FullB: The point of which I decided to be entrepreneur was when talking point just took off. It snowballed from there. So, I have to say my entrepreneurship journey is pretty accidental. Often the public image of an entrepeneur is very glamorous, but actually a lot of my work is not glamorous. And I don't think people see that from the outside. A lot of my role is essentially being a champion. I'm a doer at heart. And it's going from I'm a real doer to I need to delegate or I need to be able to align everyone to get to the same big vision and the big goal. And it's not just me anymore, so kind of a a chicken and an egg where it's both hard and challenging, but exciting.
EventsA: joined Google when it had about 1,200 people — left Google when it had over 50,000 people — went to Africa for work with entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya — received an email from the US CTO — President Obama called and offered the job 33 days later
EventsB: Talking Point took off — I decided to be an entrepreneur

Q12: Both speakers leave their initial life for their next life.
Q13: Story A is about what makes them happy personally while Story B is about how to change an entire community. It is similar in the sense of how both speakers realized their current path didn't go with their values.
FullA: I was learning how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy, to figure out whether their ships are gon na be able to get through a storm or not. How big are the waves gon na be in two days time out in the middle of the Pacific? And it turned out that my students started using that to figure out when to go surfing. And I was in academia , I was in that track. So when I did make that decision to leave there were some people that were shocked  and also people thought it was a waste of a Ph.D, even though my original aim was to join the Navy. I ended up not feeling all that comfortable with the fact that a lot of the research I was doing was effectively weapons systems. But now what I do is, people get up in the morning and they can say , should I go surfing today or not? And they can look at what we make and go , yeah , I might go surf, and it puts smiles on people's faces.
FullB: I come from farm worker parents. It wasn't until I married and I was 28 years of age that I realized that I wasn't gon na go anywhere unless I have an education. So I had to turn my life around to do  what I wanted to do, and what I wanted to do was be in this world of media. So I went to a community college and I transferred to UCLA , and I became a writer. And so, from that to what I do today, I'm an advocate. I do civil rights, civil rights and specifically, in media. When reporting about the Latino community, it was a crime blotter. It was Maria killed Jose because Jose molested her child and the child was doing drugs on the side. It was like that , it was terrible. So we formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition, because how we are perceived is always going to be the way that we are treated. If we're perceived that being the laborers out in the field and so forth, you'll be treated that way. And, we're that, sure of course we are. Right? But the fact is that we're also a great deal more. Never believe that somebody else is gon na do it for you. You have to take the bull by the horns and make the changes.
EventsA: I learned how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy — My students started using the maps to figure out when to go surfing — I made the decision to leave academia — People were shocked by my decision to leave — People thought it was a waste of a Ph.D — I ended up not feeling comfortable with the research I was doing
EventsB: I married at 28 years of age — I realized that I needed an education — I turned my life around — I went to a community college — I transferred to UCLA — I became a writer — I became an advocate — We formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition

Q12: They both seem to happen by accident. Other than that, they are wildly different paths.
Q13: They're both written in an insane manner, and they're both about employment. Otherwise, the stories are vastly different in most ways.
FullA: 19 years ago, actually, I started working for SLUG Magazine. The previous owner of SLUG heard about me, and called me up and asked me to shoot a cover. So that's how I first became a staff member of SLUG, was shooting a cover. And then from that point forward, I became a managing editor , and then two years later, I had the opportunity to take over the magazine , and that's when I officially became editor and then publisher. And I've always felt different from my family , and from kind of being part of the peer group that I grew up in, I just always didn't quite connect. But then I kind of learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is, and the work here that we could do to find others that feel that way. Where they may not feel that way at home, or at school, or in a lot of other environments. But here in SLUG Magazine, we can really appreciate them for being different. I think it goes back to that love, right? I really love doing what I do, and hearing these stories from these individuals that come up to you and say hey , I would not be where I am today if it wasn't for my experience with SLUG Magazine. Hearing that feedback and that validation from other individuals about how we've affected their lives in a positive way, and that's priceless.
FullB: And the first summer I was out there I got my commercial fishing license because we had no other way to make money. Well, I ended up living on Nantucket for four more years and building this business. And even two or three years into Nantucket Nectars, my parents were like, " You're starting a juice company? " Are you kidding me? What do you mean you're " starting a juice company? Who starts a juice company? '' Could anyone have ever predicted my path? You know, " Okay, this is how you're going " to make it. You should move to Nantucket, " start a boat business, end up being a fisherman, " and then get into distribution, and start a juice business. " That's how you get into juice. '' Like, who would ever say that?
EventsA: I started working for SLUG Magazine — The previous owner of SLUG called me up and asked me to shoot a cover — I shot a cover — I became a managing editor — I had the opportunity to take over the magazine — I officially became editor and then publisher — I learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is — Individuals came up to me and said they would not be where they are today if it wasn't for their experience with SLUG Magazine
EventsB: I got my commercial fishing license — I ended up living on Nantucket for four more years — I built this business — My parents questioned me about starting a juice company

Q12: Both are progressions from youth to career, but they aren't quite on the same level of detail
Q13: Both stories involve turning passions into careers.
FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
FullB: I always knew I wanted to do journalism since I was a little kid. I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade. But by the time I graduated , I still didn't know if I wanted to do newspaper, or if I wanted to do TV and I ended up doing TV. And I just feel like, I just really enjoy just talking to people, in general. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. I feel sometimes like, am I stunting myself in my career? Am I where I'm supposed to be right now? Am I doing all that I can to get to the next point? But you don't always know if you're doing the right thing , but I don't know , it works out. I feel like things work themselves out. They do. They just do.
EventsA: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science
EventsB: I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade — I graduated — I ended up doing TV

Q12: The framing of these does not line up at all. One is a progression of thought & reality, the other is just a single story.
Q13: They're both about how these people go their start. But they drift in much different directions.
FullA: I am judge Elaine Marshall. I am the Director and Presiding Judge for the City of Houston Municipal Courts. And I was going to go to college to be a doctor. That worked out real well until biology, and cut them up and bleeding and all that stuff. You couldn't handle it. Nah, that just wasn't. Everyone kept saying that you talk so much , you probably should go to law school. When I first became a prosecutor, they would send us to different schools for career day. And when I became a judge, did same thing. The thing that stuck out to me the most was one time I went to a school as a judge , and they told them who I was and they said , all rise. So the kids stood up and four of the black kids that were sitting on the thing went , she's black. Wow. And it was like, yeah. Now you see. I came up just like they did, in a public school and those sorts of things. So it's good to give back. You will find so many different places where you can go that you'll make a difference.
FullB: I went to school, because I loved coding and I wanted to develop a coding career. And I reached out to a band that I liked and said, hey, long shot , but could I make you guys a website? And to my surprise, they emailed back like ten minutes later. And they're like yeah, actually , we'd really love for you to make us a website. How about two t-shirts and a CD in trade for it and I thought that was a great bargain. And so I made them a website. So yeah , I mean, I did my first or my second website for two t-shirts and a CD. So technically, not a fair market trade. Yeah. But at the time, the value proposition for me was way higher. And so you've got ta choose your shots. Yeah. And you will definitely do things in the course of your career that will be undervalued  and the trick is to choose the right ones, and to not do it too much. So throughout your career and in particular in those formative stages, you've got to go the extra mile. You've got ta work really hard. There's just no shortcut to it. Every now and then, one in a million gets lucky literary wins the rotary and everybody else whose ever achieved some great level of success has worked incredibly hard to get there.
EventsA: She decided not to go to college to be a doctor — She became a prosecutor — She went to different schools for career day as a prosecutor — She became a judge — She went to a school as a judge — The kids at the school stood up and said all rise — Four black kids at the school expressed surprise that she was black
EventsB: I went to school — I reached out to a band that I liked and asked if I could make them a website — They emailed back ten minutes later — They agreed to have me make them a website in exchange for two t-shirts and a CD — I made them a website

Q13: Both are stories of progression & figuring it out as you go. But one is more structured while the other is free flowing
FullA: By the time I was in 6th grade, I'd already decided I was gon na be an engineer, just couldn't decide what engineer. And I chose to go to GMI engineering management institute and hired on with Ford Motor Company. Everybody that hired on had to manage the shop floor and then after that I kind of liked operations. So I went into manufacturing engineering for a few years before coming to Cummins, getting into quality here. And then also manufacturing, engineering on assembly, and machining, before becoming the plant manager of this facility. Kinda sounds cliche , but there's a couple things that we always talk about with managers, etc.. Be respectful to people and that goes a long way whether you're in management or whether you're the employee. Treat people how you want to be treated. Everyone says that but there's really a lot of truth to that in life. And that will get you a long way is what I've found out.
FullB: of my Ph.D. studentship, and, um, I had done some high priority imaging of bacteria. And then the BBC News broke that they found life on Mars, that this guy from NASA had got, uh, images of this, what he thought was a bacteria on the surface of that rock you've just been looking at. Looked him up , ah, phoned international directory inquiries , got the number, phoned Johnson Space Center, got his name, gave him a bell and said, " I can get better images than that, " mate. '' Cut long story short , he sent me a bit of meteorite so me and a couple of mates sat in a pub figuring out what to do with this piece of Mars. So we planned it out and got some good research done. And then they offered me a job. I did my Ph.D. in how microbes eat metals, ah, to decontaminate nuclear structures of radioactivity by using bacteria.  Life is a gift. And your life is a gift. No one has the right to tell you how to use that gift.

Q12: Both are related to school subjects and entering related jobs.
Q13: Both stories involve the uncertainty of not knowing what you will do with your life.
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I knew during high school that I wanted to study biology and I did try out the research field for a little while. I then took a teaching job in the middle school , and after that, I took a curriculum writing and editing job. You know , I did some good jobs but I did go into them not knowing if okay I'm gon na love this and this is gon na be what I do for the rest of my life. And I think that sometimes young people put that pressure on themselves. I need to know exactly what I'm going to do for the rest of my life and I need to know it now. Yeah. And it's not really realistic , nor do I think that it's necessarily helpful. Just having experiences, those can really help you know who you are and what you want to be about.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I tried out the research field for a little while — I took a teaching job in the middle school — I took a curriculum writing and editing job

Q12: Both involve moving somewhere and trying new things.
Q13: Both relate to speaking of the purpose of their jobs.
FullA: Going from your high school in Brooklyn to going into college. What was that transition like? That was 1971. You guys were not even thought about. I left Brooklyn and went to Michigan , and I didn't know anybody , and I was scared and insecure, and couldn't even complete a sentence. My sophomore year in college, I was donating blood in order to eat. You remember those things. I'm 61 years old , so I think at this stage in my life I'm responsible for 300,000 people who work for this company. And my clear purpose to them and the communities we serve, and my own family, is to enhance their lives in ways that I can do as the head of this company.
FullB: Originally, I thought I was just gon na be a contractor. Then I decided I was gon na study architecture so I moved out to California. And throughout all that, Eli and I met each other out in California. And I tried Switchel for the first time. A month later, we sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont. And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
FullB: I always knew I wanted to do journalism since I was a little kid. I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade. But by the time I graduated , I still didn't know if I wanted to do newspaper, or if I wanted to do TV and I ended up doing TV. And I just feel like, I just really enjoy just talking to people, in general. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. I feel sometimes like, am I stunting myself in my career? Am I where I'm supposed to be right now? Am I doing all that I can to get to the next point? But you don't always know if you're doing the right thing , but I don't know , it works out. I feel like things work themselves out. They do. They just do.
EventsA: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science
EventsB: I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade — I graduated — I ended up doing TV

But we just need to change that rhetoric, instead of talking about all these bad things, talk about the positive things, the things that we learn, that we are capable of that make us great. FullA: I'm from El Salvador. I came to the United States when I was eight years old. My mom left me at age four with my grandma and my sister that was two years old at the time. Obviously searching for the American dream. So I was in El Salvador. My grandma raised me until I was eight and I remember one day she's like so your mom says one of you can go with her. And that's cuz my mum had finally saved enough money to pay a coyotaje. And so my mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States and so I remember being with a group of people and I was the only child. I'm lucky that I was I was okay the whole time , but it was a journey of about over a month. How do you still have a story of yourself that you identify with, that a lot of people don't relate to. But then still have this professional grounding, this world that you've created for yourself? I think it traces back to family. I get my work ethic from my mother. And it's because in high school she was working all the time. The financial struggle that I saw at home, also pushed me to complete my four year degree cuz I knew I wanted more. And even today, she still has the same lifestyle. I live at home with her still. But ever since the day I came back from college, I support financially. So I know that I have to provide rent money in order for my mom, my sister, my niece to have a home. Cuz my sister's also a single mom.
FullB: August of 2005 , I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina. And then September of 2005 was when I received my cancer diagnosis. So it's like this happened and then this happened. And so, hey, you're a veteran now. And I really didn't know what that meant. Mm-hm. But it basically meant that I was on my own. And I had thought at that particular time that maybe I was an isolated case and then I saw that there were tens of thousands of women veterans who were homeless. Is that what helped motivate you to provide this non-profit organization for homeless women and children? Yes, it definitely was. It's ultimately like everything came full circle, that maybe this is why I went through these things. So I had to be that catalyst, to be that voice for this forgotten population.
EventsA: My mom left me with my grandma and my sister — My grandma raised me until I was eight — My mom said one of us could go with her — My mom saved enough money to pay a coyotaje — My mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States — I traveled with a group of people to the United States — I completed my four year degree — I came back from college — I started supporting my family financially — I provided rent money for my mom, sister, and niece
EventsB: I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina — I received my cancer diagnosis

FullA: So at Alchemy we are taking the concept of chemistry and science and turning them into game based learning tools for students and for instructors, but in a way that allows for experimentation and play. The path was going toward academic chemistry. I was good at chemistry , I was good at research and all that stuff. But I realized that I always liked working with young people. So I actually, in 1994, went and worked at Detroit Country Day School, which is a private school. And started my job there and loved it, and raised my children. They went through the school , they went to U of M. And after that I started sort of feeling like not as connected to my school as it used to be, because my kids were gone. So I started to look for new things and that was the beginning of Alchemy. And if my learning tools can be shown to help students from everywhere get better. And there's like 50 % fail organic chemistry. If I could cut that down to 40 %, I think that would be success. But, this is not an easy path, it's really hard. But if you're solving a problem that you know needs to be solved, then the hurdles don't feel quite so high.
FullB: where you weren't truly able to talk about emotions, you know. So writing was my vehicle, the doorway out of there. I worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading , and I was so insecure that if there was 50 people listening to me and one person yawning, I'd feel like I failed. And I'd see that person yawning , and I'd have to do something else , you know , I'd have to climb on the chair or, go in their face. And one person got up and applauded , and after a year, after a lifetime of no encouragement, that one person applauding was enough to make me feel, have the confidence to find my destiny. Believe in that destiny, that there's something for you , and then someday it's gon na materialize.
EventsA: went and worked at Detroit Country Day School in 1994 — started my job at Detroit Country Day School — raised my children — my children went through the school — my children went to U of M — started to look for new things — began Alchemy
EventsB: worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading — saw one person yawning — did something else by climbing on the chair or going in their face — one person got up and applauded

Q12: They both realized they didn't like what they were going for and went to do something else
Q13: They are both about trying to figure out what the person really wants to do with their life
FullA: with my guidance counselor and we decided that, you know, I had an artistic streak and I was good in math , and therefore I should be an architect. And I think it was about the third year in school , I realized I wasn't really that good at it and I kind of didn't even like it that much. And the next couple of years were pretty scary 'cause um , I-I had a degree in something I was pretty sure I was never gon na use. And I just kind of didn't know what course my life was gon na take. By the time I graduated from college I actually had a few nationally-released records , and they didn't make that big of a splash or make that much money , but it was enough to get me thinking like, " Wow, well this would be cool " to do this for a living. I like this more than being " an architect or hovering over a drawing board " for 20 hours a day. '' It's a clichÃ © , but you do have to kind of follow your dreams. Especially, you guys are all young , and, you know , this is the time to do it. If I were you, I would definitely go for what makes you happy. The big irony of my life and my career is that I've outlasted most of the people I've parodied over the years.
FullB: I have an education degree, and then math as a minor. And I did teaching for six years , but I still wanted to do that, just not in the education system, so I became a corporate trainer. Which is how I ended up with AT&T. People wanted teachers that could the teach the math or the sciences. I'm like , that's the easy part, yeah sure, I'll do that. My family did not want me to be a teacher. Math was like my ultimate favorite subject. So my teachers, my parents, they were like, you need to be engineer. You need to be engineer. So I came to Texas , went to a really strong engineering school, and it was not the best experience. And I said, if this is what engineering is, I don't wan na do it. So at that time, without telling anyone, went back to school that next semester and studied to be a teacher. My mother was like, you're never gon na make any money. Like okay, I'll figure that part out later. It's like okay, yeah , I may be a broke teacher , but I'll be a happy teacher , and I'll be doing so much good and it would be worth it.
EventsA: I decided to become an architect with my guidance counselor — I realized I wasn't good at architecture and didn't like it — I graduated from college — I had a few nationally-released records
EventsB: became a corporate trainer — ended up with AT&T — came to Texas — went to a strong engineering school — decided not to do engineering — went back to school the next semester — studied to be a teacher

Q12: They talk about hardships but found something positive later
Q13: They both talk about an uncertainty
FullA: I remember when I turned 30 , I was so depressed on that birthday cuz I felt like I had not accomplished what I needed to and what my friends had accomplished. I just felt that all the people around me had it so much more together than I did , and I should say I started Linda.com when I was 40 , so I'm gon na turn 60 in January. And I didn't touch a computer until I was 28 years old. So I had a lot of life between when I found my career, my calling. And I definitely felt that I wasn't good enough and that I, and I don't know, I think almost , that's almost normal. You're in the majority of people who don't know what they want and what they like until they experience it.
FullB: The median wealth of a white family is about $ 110,000. The median wealth of black and Latino families combined is somewhere around 15 to $ 20,000. The only way for us to boost that from 15 to 100,000 is to do things like tech. But I feel like when you go to college, you're taking , you're not just in this bubble, you're taking all of your family responsibilities with you. That responsibility, that burden of my family doesn't have money to pay bills, or to pay rent, or to, that stays with you. So then how are you going to class, and you're thinking, okay, let me study for the CS test, but my mom's calling me because there's not enough food to eat, or my sister's calling me because they don't have supplies for school, or new clothes, or anything. And so you're bringing all of those things with you. So finding people to be able to relate to that  are advisors or councilors that you can talk to about those things, that understand you and can relate to you has really helped because they understand me, they get it, Iâ $ ™ m validated. Okay, now I can focus on taking this test, or studying for this exam , or doing whatever else you need to do
EventsA: I turned 30 — I felt depressed on my 30th birthday — I started Linda.com when I was 40 — I didn't touch a computer until I was 28
EventsB: The median wealth of a white family was about $110,000 — The median wealth of black and Latino families combined was around $15,000 to $20,000 — The speaker felt that going to college involved taking family responsibilities along — The speaker's mom called because there was not enough food to eat — The speaker's sister called because they did not have supplies for school or new clothes — The speaker found advisors or counselors who could relate and understand their situation — The speaker felt validated by the advisors or counselors

Q12: The 2 topics just go in different directions. One is making the environment better at school, and the other is about YouTube
Q13: The 2 topics are completely different. One is about stopping fights in school and the other is internet information
FullA: Generally, the schools that we work in are pretty negative environments. Our students grow up in homes where they don't necessarily get a chance to learn proper anger management techniques. And so you see a lot of students who get in fights. Or they throw something so that they can get suspended. Or they do something so that they don't have to be there. There's usually something behind that, whether it's they don't feel they are able to succeed. Whether it's they're afraid of what might happen if they do succeed. Whether it's afraid that they are just unable to grasp a concept, so it's kind of sad , but there's always a bright light. City here is there to find those bright lights and make them brighter. We work with kids in attendance, behavior, and course performance, English and math. And our numbers show it, where at the beginning of the year there's so many suspensions, so many fights , and then by the end of the year those are all decreased. You talk about going to something and really wanting to help. What about the people that just don't seem to want it? How did that feel? How'd you work through that? We had these little catchphrases that people throw around , and one of them is, this is hard, be strong. Find something that they do know how to do. Find something that they do like to do, and build that relationship on that. I know that what I do right now is very important. And I'm influencing a student everyday. Every student can succeed , we just need to find the right way to make that happen.
FullB: I started early on, about three years ago , I was doing a YouTube channel, kind of a joke , I was just like , this is fun , I want to make my friend laugh. Hi, I am Mad Bath, during that Boardman Shelton, remember that looking cool and confident outweight everything. Training on the range  is like Crossfit, it is not complete untill you take a selfie. Ooh, I like that one. We started to getting likes and viewership and a following , this could be something. I didn't know how to edit videos , but you have to find self motivation, focus on the end goal, right? So I just spend 40 hours a week on fricking YouTube searching what I wanted. We're the information age , so anything you wan na do is at your fingertips. If you take the time out of your day to really focus, you're gon na be successful.
EventsA: Students got in fights. — Students threw something to get suspended. — Students did something to avoid being at school. — The number of suspensions and fights decreased by the end of the year.
EventsB: I started a YouTube channel about three years ago — I made my friend laugh — We started getting likes and viewership and a following — I spent 40 hours a week on YouTube searching what I wanted

Q12: They progress in different ways with one is health related, and the other is about a career
Q13: One is talking about their future, and the other is talking about a difficulty of being a mom of a sick child
FullA: being anxious about my future. I think I started to make plans or ... to really think of what I'm going to do by the time I was 30. I run into students or young designers who say, " Oh, you know , like, I really wanted to study art, " but my parents said, ` Oh , you'll never make any money '' ` with that , ' so I studied graphic design instead . '' And I think that almost always is a mistake. Because, uh, if you don't have the passion for it, you're not gon na be a great graphic designer. So I really think that, that figuring out what you have passion at and pursuing that is a very very worthwhile thing.
FullB: I'd been a real estate agent , I owned an art gallery. I thought, really, my main pur-goal was to really be a good wife, a good mother , and then my life changed completely. My second son was born with a lung disease. They didn't think he'd make it , he got jaundice, and when I brought him home, he'd lost the ability to wake to feed, and so I mean for me, I thought, watching him struggle to breathe, I'd never take breathing for granted again. And I think that's sort of the beginning of me becoming an environmentalist. And so many times, I feel like I'm paying back the debt, because why should I be so lucky? What can I do to survive this life and be a success, so when the end of my road comes -- which people don't wan na talk about, 'cause the end of the road is gon na come for us -- I can look back  and say, " I really feel good about it ''? And it may not be something globally. I think that if you touch anyone's life , then you're a success.
EventsA: I started to make plans for my future. — I ran into students or young designers who said they wanted to study art but their parents discouraged them. — I studied graphic design instead.
EventsB: Her second son was born with a lung disease — He got jaundice — She brought him home — He lost the ability to wake to feed — She watched him struggle to breathe

Q12: One is more technical
Q13: One is talking about like racing, and the other is talking about achieving goals
FullA: Made a couple bucks and I wanted to go race. I read about a guy in Motor Trend Magazine who raced at Pike's Peak and he was just basically an average guy. And we're actually friends now , his name is C Van Tune, he was the editor at Motor Trend. I'm like, man, if that guy can do it , maybe I can do it. So in 1991, I bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4. I thought, well, I wan na go race at Pike's Peak. I got the rulebook, had to put a roll cage in it. And I thought, well, maybe I could modify it too, to make it to go faster. Before I went to Pike's Peak, I read about a race in Nevada called the Silver State Classic. It's a 90 mile race in Nevada where they take a public highway, a state highway , and they just shut it down. And you go as fast as you can go from one city to the next. And so I averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles. So I went 90 miles in 34 minutes. And at that point, I was totally hooked. I got fourth place in the race.
FullB: You know , you're not becoming a doctor where you're changing people's lives physically, but sometimes you make people's lives emotionally a little better. When I was about three years old, I said, " Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, " what do you call that? '' She says, " A comic, a comedian. '' I went, " That's what I wan na be. '' I think a lot of people know what they wan na do , but they don't have the courage to really follow it. I mean, maybe you have maybe a perception that we have never a waning moment of thinking, " This isn't worth it. '' Or doubt or " Oh my gosh '' all the time -- all the time, especially as an actor. The fear of failure is-is what gets you all the time. When you're actually going through the failure, you're like,  " How am I gon na get out of this? " This is bad , but how am I gon na get out of it ? '' But the fear of failure is what keeps people from trying anyway.
EventsA: bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4 in 1991 — got the rulebook for Pike's Peak race — put a roll cage in the car — read about the Silver State Classic race in Nevada — raced 90 miles in the Silver State Classic — averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles — finished fourth place in the Silver State Classic race
EventsB: I said, 'Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, what do you call that?' — She said, 'A comic, a comedian.' — I said, 'That's what I wanna be.'

Q12: They describe a life change from an unplanned experience
Q13: Both stories are about personal and professional invention.
FullA: you know, heavy civil tunneling for-for railroads, for highway tunnels, for that kind of stuff. So at 20, I was going to school at Colorado State University, majoring in construction management. Someone that we were buying stuff from said, " Hey , I'm selling a bunch " of tunneling stuff out to Napa Valley. '' I was like, " Ne-never even heard of it, never ...  '' I mean, I never even drank wine , I drank beer. So I-I didn't even have any idea where Napa Valley was. So we came out here , and thank goodness there was another contractor digging a tunnel that was, they were in trouble. We talked to them. " Sure, we can do that. '' And we did , and we, and we built a beautiful cave , and it's just been going since then. Right now, you guys have got nothing to lose. And that's like when we started this company, my wife and I. We sat down and talked , we were still young enough that if we lost everything, so what? I just have to go get a job , that's where I came from anyhow.
FullB: much like you -- went through uni and I was fairly driven and I wanted to achieve some things and...  Yep.  it wasn't'til I went tree-planting and we would spend up to two months living as this kind of tribe. I went to some absolutely incredible natural places , and you'd be out there all by yourself all day long planting trees. My whole value set just sort of changed. I went from being , I wanted to be successful, to I wanted to be... compassionate about the environment and about social issues. And that, my whole life just changed direction. The very fact that you're doing this and you're asking these questions and you're committed to that path of action means you'll find a way. You know , you got a unique opportunity to live a really extraordinary life, so go for it.
EventsA: I was going to school at Colorado State University — Someone said they were selling tunneling stuff to Napa Valley — We came out to Napa Valley — We talked to another contractor who was in trouble — We agreed to do the tunneling work — We built a cave — My wife and I started a company — We sat down and talked about starting the company
EventsB: went tree-planting — spent up to two months living as a tribe — went to some incredible natural places — planted trees all day long — changed whole value set — changed life direction

Q12: A is about choice and growth, B is about catastrophe and survival.
Q13: Both stories emphasize on choosing one's own path in response to life's circumstances
FullA: that they got me into college and had to work pretty hard to keep me there. So they managed to keep me in school , but I was free after that. So we kind of made a bargain. And I found this little town in northern California, uh, that I said, " Good, I'll stay here. '' And uh, ended up at a little zen Buddhist community. People had been telling me , " You know , you'd make a good psychotherapist , you'd make " a good psychotherapist . '' I knew then what I wanted to do was I wanted to...  in a sense, bring ... bring Buddhism out of the zen centers into the regular world. Being a lawyer or a doctor is an idea. Every day, getting up and having to do what it actually means to be a lawyer or a doctor or a zen teacher or a therapist or a carpenter, or whatever you choose , that's the reality of your situation. Life isn't an image.
FullB: and the next minute, you know , I'm thrown over 50 feet from a car  and they thought I died, you know? And they thought I'd never walk again. And people have often asked was I not angry or bitter , and the answer is no. It just is.  Everything seems so minimal, you know, when I'm sitting here talking to you. But just, you know, your mother, the accident...  why not just, " You know what, I cant ''? Like, you know --?  What would have been my option? You see it, don't you? You're sitting, waiting on the first of the month to get a check. Stuck in a wheelchair. You know... That-that's an option? I don't take reality checks from anybody. I want to follow what my passion is in life more than anything else. Don't give me a reality check because reality will tell you what you can't do. " You need to deal " with the real world. '' No, my world is real to me.
EventsA: They got me into college — They managed to keep me in school — I found a little town in northern California — I ended up at a little zen Buddhist community — People told me I'd make a good psychotherapist — I knew what I wanted to do
EventsB: He was thrown over 50 feet from a car — People thought he died — People thought he would never walk again

Q12: A is about how they sold their first jar at the farmers market. B is about how the writer did not join UN.
Q13: Both stories talk about the theme of unexpected career paths leading to meaningful work.
FullA: Originally, I thought I was just gon na be a contractor. Then I decided I was gon na study architecture so I moved out to California. And throughout all that, Eli and I met each other out in California. And I tried Switchel for the first time. A month later, we sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont. And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. It takes a lot of time to manage people when you bring them on. So I'm gon na go for the person who's already shows that they're halfway there.
FullB: I'd be a UN official. Early on, I won an award, at age 15, was sent around the world. Um...  and uh, transformation. And I knew, " My life's international work. '' And I was gon na learn languages , and you know , I just knew it. And I could say , " Well I " was blessed with clarity and a great breakthrough . '' And it would have been logical for me to now set focus on that. But happily, I did this  and I did that, and-and I stumbled and I didn't join the UN. But I had a very enriching and confusing bundle of experiences , but it allowed me to have an eclectic set of tools that I think really made it possible for me to make a difference. If you aren't completely uncomfortable, completely off-balance, completely beyond your competence, you're missing. Because it's in being off-balance that you really see.
EventsA: I decided to study architecture — I moved out to California — Eli and I met each other in California — I tried Switchel for the first time — We sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont
EventsB: I won an award at age 15 — I was sent around the world — I had a great breakthrough — I stumbled — I didn't join the UN

Q12: The two events differ in their nature, logic, progression and focus.
Q13: Both stories talk about the joy and excitement of work despite the challenges that occur.
FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
FullB: I always knew I wanted to do journalism since I was a little kid. I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade. But by the time I graduated , I still didn't know if I wanted to do newspaper, or if I wanted to do TV and I ended up doing TV. And I just feel like, I just really enjoy just talking to people, in general. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. I feel sometimes like, am I stunting myself in my career? Am I where I'm supposed to be right now? Am I doing all that I can to get to the next point? But you don't always know if you're doing the right thing , but I don't know , it works out. I feel like things work themselves out. They do. They just do.
EventsA: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science
EventsB: I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade — I graduated — I ended up doing TV

And I think that's what really got me embedded in the computer world. Uh, now I'm here working with this robot which is ...  ah, her name is Nexi. And this one is kind of designed to do personal interaction between humans and robots.  I can tell you that I'm sad, mad, confused, excited, or even bored, just by moving my face. Q12: Both in chronological order to how they got to where they are today.
Q13: Story A is about finding fulfillment in your career and its importance. Story B is about finding sucess through adversity or setbacks in the career setting.
FullA: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
FullB: So going back into the time when you were first starting out and into producing, how is it like coping with being dyslexic and trying to work around that? When I came out and I had this film , I then started looking for jobs and I just was trying to figure out what should be the next step and going for job interviews and I was nervous about working for other people. I was worried that people would find out that there were skills that I really couldn't do. So I shied away from certain things and that led me to people who were being independent filmmakers, because they were more peers  and we were all saying, okay , let's go raise money. Let's go try to do this. And in retrospect, it was great and it sort of lead me down an interesting path , but I think it was partly, cuz I was scared to do the other. I was scared that I would be found out. I think the best thing about having LD that helped me in film is I've never been somebody who assumed you wouldn't make mistakes. I've never thought that anything was gon na be a straight line and that you get there quickly. That's just not how I've learned and how my life ever went in school, certainly. So I think that's sort of applicable to most young people that you have to be willing to assume that might happen to you, but don't you think a lot of LD kids already know that. You're already kinda prepared that, that's gon na be true. So I think if you're not ashamed of that, if you own that, it makes it so much easier.
EventsA: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop
EventsB: I came out and had a film — I started looking for jobs — I went for job interviews — I shied away from certain things — I met people who were independent filmmakers — We decided to raise money — We tried to make a film

Q12: Event sequence A showcases the backstory of wanting to become a teacher and Event sequence B showcases the happenstance of becoming one.
Q13: Both are about people who aspire to be a teacher.
FullA: Becoming a teacher really became , I think, a calling for me in high school. My mother's an alcoholic, and home life became chaotic , and that stress started to manifest itself in my self esteem, my expectations for myself at school and so I started to really waver. And then 11th grade, I had AP English with Mister Shirts  and this was a guy on fire for literature and made that place absolutely, infectiously joyful and he really made me want to excel , and so it brings a tear to my eye. To think , I mean, to really think about it, and I've lived it. I saw the door of opportunity closing and to know that a teacher put their hand out and held it open for me to walk through it. You know and the idea that I could do that for other kids, that I could spend my life doing that. You know, that is the highest calling.
FullB: I have an education degree, and then math as a minor. And I did teaching for six years , but I still wanted to do that, just not in the education system, so I became a corporate trainer. Which is how I ended up with AT&T. People wanted teachers that could the teach the math or the sciences. I'm like , that's the easy part, yeah sure, I'll do that. My family did not want me to be a teacher. Math was like my ultimate favorite subject. So my teachers, my parents, they were like, you need to be engineer. You need to be engineer. So I came to Texas , went to a really strong engineering school, and it was not the best experience. And I said, if this is what engineering is, I don't wan na do it. So at that time, without telling anyone, went back to school that next semester and studied to be a teacher. My mother was like, you're never gon na make any money. Like okay, I'll figure that part out later. It's like okay, yeah , I may be a broke teacher , but I'll be a happy teacher , and I'll be doing so much good and it would be worth it.

FullA: I don't think I'll ever find a job that I'm as good at as I was at being an infantry officer. I went from being a captain in the Marine Corps, in command of 950 marines and sailors. And I was in a cubicle next to a 23 year old, looking through spreadsheets to see if there were duplicate hospitals in them. You couldn't have wasted my experience or skill sets more , but that's all part of it. You can not expect your first employer or the people that you're interviewing with or the community you moved to , you can't expect them to know everything about you and understand your value right off the bat. By the way at the same time, I've also got ta fight these guys that wan na beat me up on national TV because that helped me pay my bills as well. Q13: Each person talks about their education to their career, what they have learned along the way, and makes a reflective point at the end.
FullA: I come from farm worker parents. It wasn't until I married and I was 28 years of age that I realized that I wasn't gon na go anywhere unless I have an education. So I had to turn my life around to do  what I wanted to do, and what I wanted to do was be in this world of media. So I went to a community college and I transferred to UCLA , and I became a writer. And so, from that to what I do today, I'm an advocate. I do civil rights, civil rights and specifically, in media. When reporting about the Latino community, it was a crime blotter. It was Maria killed Jose because Jose molested her child and the child was doing drugs on the side. It was like that , it was terrible. So we formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition, because how we are perceived is always going to be the way that we are treated. If we're perceived that being the laborers out in the field and so forth, you'll be treated that way. And, we're that, sure of course we are. Right? But the fact is that we're also a great deal more. Never believe that somebody else is gon na do it for you. You have to take the bull by the horns and make the changes.
FullB: It's sort of a pattern in my life. I didn't get my culinary degree -- I got thrown out -- but I mean , I went and apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe , so, that's really where I learned. But going from a fine dining chef to running , you know, a beer bar seems like it's a downgrade in a way, but it really wasn't. It was actually , there's a lot of things that are more challenging about what I do. We didn't have a business plan. Didn't write one , there's no such thing. I've never written a business plan in my life. Yeah, I learned everything on the fly. I learned how to tap kegs -- never tapped a beer keg in my life. It's been amazingly educational, but sometimes you just learn by doing. Again, there's no school for this. Culinary school didn't teach me this. No one told me what to do -- not my dad, my mom. I did what I wanted to do without any exterior influence. When you say, " Where do you " find the motivation? '' The only motivation that's ever genuine comes from within.
EventsA: I married at 28 years of age — I realized that I needed an education — I turned my life around — I went to a community college — I transferred to UCLA — I became a writer — I became an advocate — We formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition
EventsB: I got thrown out of my culinary degree program — I apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe — I went from being a fine dining chef to running a beer bar — I learned how to tap kegs

FullB: The power of finding out something which people aren't talking about was actually very important to me. And that's basically what I've done much of my life, almost all of it. I'm one of six children. My parents worked in the media. My mother was a writer for women's magazines, my father wrote radio plays and did television, and so we all became very interested in story and narrative. I thought there are people who actually will pay you to do this kind of work , so maybe I ought to go into news. So I spent a lot of my life in print journalism, daily newspapers. I was in the newsroom of the Washington Post all during Watergate. I was both an editor and a reporter. I was sent to Moscow at one point, for four years, as Moscow Bureau Chief, which was an extraordinary encounter with a society whose citizens were denied access to factual information. Period. And it made it even more important to use the powers that are given to us in these open and democratic societies in a way that will inform others. So, what has been part of my life just started out in a certain pattern. It just stayed in that course ever since , and now I'm at NPR. What this place does , and other great icons of journalism, the reporting of fact conveyed in a non-polemical, civil dialogue to readers, listeners, viewers, and bring to them extraordinary information they couldn't possibly have any other way. It comes down to this. Thomas Jefferson, before he wrote the Declaration of Independence, in thinking about this republic, these people were going to try to invent in the late 1700s, made a very clear observation. He basically said that people can not be both ignorant and free.

FullA: I started my career in law as a paralegal. So I thought I was gon na be a lawyer and then I kinda never met a happy lawyer. Coming from that environment , I went into film and TV. And had I known that software was a career that was an obtainable thing for me to do , I would have hands down done it much earlier. But I think also even when I was in school, the idea of computer science classes just seemed really intimidating. From a distance, it looks so complex. But then if you actually learn how to code, it's like, every line is actually very simple. Pretty much just, I sunk my teeth in and was like, I got ta just do it until I make it happen. And so from then on, as a professional software engineer, you're building stuff everyday. And they ask me, what do you want to work on? I'm like , I wan na work on something I haven't done before. I mean , I don't know how to do it immediately, but I know how to figure it out.
EventsA: I was in Chile — I was about to finish college — I spoke English before I came here — I didn't get out of my apartment for about a year — I came across an ad — They were looking for a coordinator — I started teaching — I loved teaching

FullA: 19 years ago, actually, I started working for SLUG Magazine. The previous owner of SLUG heard about me, and called me up and asked me to shoot a cover. So that's how I first became a staff member of SLUG, was shooting a cover. And then from that point forward, I became a managing editor , and then two years later, I had the opportunity to take over the magazine , and that's when I officially became editor and then publisher. And I've always felt different from my family , and from kind of being part of the peer group that I grew up in, I just always didn't quite connect. But then I kind of learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is, and the work here that we could do to find others that feel that way. Where they may not feel that way at home, or at school, or in a lot of other environments. But here in SLUG Magazine, we can really appreciate them for being different. I think it goes back to that love, right? I really love doing what I do, and hearing these stories from these individuals that come up to you and say hey , I would not be where I am today if it wasn't for my experience with SLUG Magazine. Hearing that feedback and that validation from other individuals about how we've affected their lives in a positive way, and that's priceless.

A lot of people thought that I was just a fun teacher. Oh he's just , all his kids, they're not really learning anything. I hate when teachers think that just because their class is rigorous that they can't have any fun. It's not until when my test scores came back, my AP scores and they were better than theirs , you don't even have to say anything. Yeah. I am very German but I am very about living life and working hard and being rigorous but having fun the entire time we're doing it. Because that's life. I really come to work with a smile on my face every single day. And that's what it's all about, right?

I didn't wan na be that person in years, you know, in years in the future, uh, and not have had taken risks. FullA: This is our physical space in Los Angeles. We started it in 2002, ten years ago as I mentioned in honor of my folks who were community activists and died much too early in my life. Losing my family very young was kind of a life changing experience. I've been working in the film industry for a number of years  and so to kind of channel that energy and that angst I was feeling, I wanted to open a school, a cinema and a retail space. I really don't want today just to be about me and because obviously Lisa Marr is a teacher. We fell in love, she'll tell the story much better than I, but literally on the opening day - I was walking around in my neighborhood of Echo Park and I walked into a storefront and there was this man there and he had a beard and he said , we're opening a film center today. She was walking down the street  and I said we're opening a film center and she's like, really? And she came in and she started volunteering and we had this platonic relationship that evolved into a romantic relationship. It was the beginning of a whole new chapter in my life. I had just started making films. I had been in a band for many years and did some photography and painting and there was this space right in my own neighborhood that was opening and encouraging people to come in and exchange ideas and watch films together and make their own movies. The education, in the last 10 years we've taught a couple of thousand kids for free. So for the ten year anniversary, we decided let's take everything we do on the road. Again, for us, filmmaking is about storytelling. It's not about the technology , it's not about expensive equipment , it's about an idea and some energy.
FullB: He was exploring the deep sea, deep sea submersible. And I asked my dad, " What does that guy do? '' Ah, and he said, " He's a marine biologist. '' And really, that was it , okay. " I'm gon na be a marine " biologist. '' You know , I knew I could go to school and be a marine biologist , you know? I knew that there was a degree that I could get. But nobody really ever counseled that a degree wasn't a job. And it wasn't until the last year or two that I had the epiphany that, okay , I'm gon na have my degree, my life's dream, but that's not a job. I don't have a career leaving college. I don't know what I wan na do. I knew what I wanted to do for my whole life. Too many times, people are doing things because they think they should be doing them.

Q13: the first story is about pivoting in life and finding new things you are passionate about. The second story is about being in the middle of something you don't realize is influencing you bc you're so close to it
FullA: In first grade when they asked me what I wanted to do, I said I want to study the stars. So, it's lucky that it worked out. Most of the times people say, I wan na be a football player, whatever, movie star, it doesn't work out. In my case it worked out , but I was lucky that way. Astronomy, before I went to college, was something I really thought I could do. But I just doubt myself a lot. Was there any moments where you really doubted yourself? Of course, all the time. It's inevitable. When you're trying to push yourself, there are always moments when you think, maybe this is too hard , maybe I can not do it. But my answer to that is that, if you don't feel that way, it means you're not pushing yourself enough. If you never go out of your comfort zone, then you're not really trying very hard. It's part of learning and part of growing up , is figuring out things that you didn't know you could do, and then you do them. Sometimes you fail. Sometimes you succeed. Let's put it this way. First of all, in research most of what you do, fails miserably, because you're trying to do something that nobody knows how to do. So you have to really like failure. Embrace failure. Accept that failure is gon na be part of the process.
FullB: I think, in the history of this country at least. I mean I see your t-shirt where it has, uh, the Black Panthers. So I was born in Chicago when all that stuff was happening. When you're born in that environment, it's kind of like, " Yeah, you're supposed to be " doing something around social justice , '' because, you know, I saw Chicago burn down. I saw , you know... the tanks roll through our neighborhood. And I didn't realize I had that whole wealth of history and knowledge and activity going on around me because I was in it. Sometimes when you're doing something you love, it doesn't -- you don't find it , it finds you.

There's just no ...  there's just no reason to have to go through anything that hard, you know? But I didn't see it when I was a kid. If it's a burning desire and you can't think of nothin ' else , you might have a chance. If you think you do and you're willing to roll the dice, then you go do it , but you'll never find out unless you do try, you know? That's the other side of the coin.
FullB: I went to school for welding, design, pouring metal, and working in the foundry, and all of these crazy things , I thought it was everything. And there was this moment , I remember just thinking , this is not me , this is not what I want to be in my life. I really just had to drop everything and start over and just move , and I just explored. And I took some time off  and I was doing my thing, traveling out here to Colorado, and just kind of experimenting with different processes. I ended up blowing glass and trying it for the first time, and falling in love, like that's it , that's my life.
EventsA: He said to go to school and get all the degrees you can get. — He said to get into business and make all the money you can get. — He said to start a band or a night-club. — He said not to do it the hard way like they did. — He said he probably would have went to school if he went back. — He said he had been in a lot of trouble in his life. — He said he had been to prison twice.

Story B is about a driven individual who chooses an unconventional lifestyle (tree‑planting for two months) to pursue personal values and change their life direction. Both involve youthful risk‑taking and a shift in life path, but the contexts and motivations are quite different—one is entrepreneurial/business‑focused, the other is value‑driven environmental action. Hence they share some thematic resemblance but are not strongly aligned.
FullA: you know, heavy civil tunneling for-for railroads, for highway tunnels, for that kind of stuff. So at 20, I was going to school at Colorado State University, majoring in construction management. Someone that we were buying stuff from said, " Hey , I'm selling a bunch " of tunneling stuff out to Napa Valley. '' I was like, " Ne-never even heard of it, never ...  '' I mean, I never even drank wine , I drank beer. So I-I didn't even have any idea where Napa Valley was. So we came out here , and thank goodness there was another contractor digging a tunnel that was, they were in trouble. We talked to them. " Sure, we can do that. '' And we did , and we, and we built a beautiful cave , and it's just been going since then. Right now, you guys have got nothing to lose. And that's like when we started this company, my wife and I. We sat down and talked , we were still young enough that if we lost everything, so what? I just have to go get a job , that's where I came from anyhow.
FullB: much like you -- went through uni and I was fairly driven and I wanted to achieve some things and...  Yep.  it wasn't'til I went tree-planting and we would spend up to two months living as this kind of tribe. I went to some absolutely incredible natural places , and you'd be out there all by yourself all day long planting trees. My whole value set just sort of changed. I went from being , I wanted to be successful, to I wanted to be... compassionate about the environment and about social issues. And that, my whole life just changed direction. The very fact that you're doing this and you're asking these questions and you're committed to that path of action means you'll find a way. You know , you got a unique opportunity to live a really extraordinary life, so go for it.
EventsA: I was going to school at Colorado State University — Someone said they were selling tunneling stuff to Napa Valley — We came out to Napa Valley — We talked to another contractor who was in trouble — We agreed to do the tunneling work — We built a cave — My wife and I started a company — We sat down and talked about starting the company
EventsB: went tree-planting — spent up to two months living as a tribe — went to some incredible natural places — planted trees all day long — changed whole value set — changed life direction
