Q12: they all talk about physical activities
Q13: The two stories are on different line
FullA: This is our physical space in Los Angeles. We started it in 2002, ten years ago as I mentioned in honor of my folks who were community activists and died much too early in my life. Losing my family very young was kind of a life changing experience. I've been working in the film industry for a number of years  and so to kind of channel that energy and that angst I was feeling, I wanted to open a school, a cinema and a retail space. I really don't want today just to be about me and because obviously Lisa Marr is a teacher. We fell in love, she'll tell the story much better than I, but literally on the opening day - I was walking around in my neighborhood of Echo Park and I walked into a storefront and there was this man there and he had a beard and he said , we're opening a film center today. She was walking down the street  and I said we're opening a film center and she's like, really? And she came in and she started volunteering and we had this platonic relationship that evolved into a romantic relationship. It was the beginning of a whole new chapter in my life. I had just started making films. I had been in a band for many years and did some photography and painting and there was this space right in my own neighborhood that was opening and encouraging people to come in and exchange ideas and watch films together and make their own movies. The education, in the last 10 years we've taught a couple of thousand kids for free. So for the ten year anniversary, we decided let's take everything we do on the road. Again, for us, filmmaking is about storytelling. It's not about the technology , it's not about expensive equipment , it's about an idea and some energy.
FullB: He was exploring the deep sea, deep sea submersible. And I asked my dad, " What does that guy do? '' Ah, and he said, " He's a marine biologist. '' And really, that was it , okay. " I'm gon na be a marine " biologist. '' You know , I knew I could go to school and be a marine biologist , you know? I knew that there was a degree that I could get. But nobody really ever counseled that a degree wasn't a job. And it wasn't until the last year or two that I had the epiphany that, okay , I'm gon na have my degree, my life's dream, but that's not a job. I don't have a career leaving college. I don't know what I wan na do. I knew what I wanted to do for my whole life. Too many times, people are doing things because they think they should be doing them.
EventsA: Started the physical space in Los Angeles in 2002 — Walked into a storefront in Echo Park on the opening day — Met a man with a beard who said they were opening a film center — Lisa Marr walked down the street and entered the film center — Lisa Marr started volunteering at the film center — Their platonic relationship evolved into a romantic relationship — Decided to take everything they do on the road for the ten year anniversary
EventsB: He was exploring the deep sea in a deep sea submersible. — He asked his dad what the man did. — His dad said the man was a marine biologist. — He decided he was going to be a marine biologist. — He had the epiphany that having a degree was not a job.

FullA: In that time I got a DUI and that pretty much devastated or destroyed my college aspirations , or at least it did in my mind. I saw , I'm like this is a sign from God or whatever it is, I'm not meant to be doing what I'm doing. I disassociated from my situation for the first time probably in my entire life. I realize that I didn't have to do anything for anybody else. I guess it was a given me back a tool set, the experience allowed me to disassociate and take a look at my situation objectively and say, how do I feel about this? What emotional response am I gon na choose in this environment?
FullB: 'cause the gangs were getting just very crazy. I ended up coming back and kind of got jumped into a gang. Q12: Story A has a few actions done and then a declaration of not dealing with those actions. Story B presents an issue and the life progression after that, while showing the actions done to succeed.
Q13: Story A is about a person that is overwhelmed with life and wants to run away from it. Story B is about a person that went through hardships but persevered and found lots of success despite where they came from.
FullA: I feel like okay I'm aware of these issues , I'm aware of a lot of things we talked about, they're not new to me. But I'm not in-depth, hands on, like full body immersed into how chaotic this is. So how do you put your mind at ease everyday? I'm not kidding when I say I cry a lot. I'd like to say oh I meditate and it makes it okay. I do meditate and then I cry you know. Honestly, I think if we're not feeling really deeply about this stuff. I think there's a problem. At least once a month, I declare that I'm just going to walk away from all of it and become a potter. That's my thing. I don't know how to make pots  but, in my mind I'm going to be a potter. And my thinking in this is not that I just want to cop out and not do this anymore , but I want to put beauty in the world. There's a real place for that. Thank God we have poets and potters and artists and it's a wonderful thing to do. I thank God we also have people who are addressing all the ugliness head on and dealing with that. It's a collective endeavor.
FullB: We grew up kind of dysfunctional and poor, still a lot of like alcoholism and stuff and a lot of bad stuff in our neighborhood like drug dealing and what have you. I ended up getting pregnant really young and then getting married right after that. So I was 19, 20  but I was like, my god , I'm a teen pregnancy just like every other woman in my family. I totally saw everybody's face go , I knew it was too good to be true and that kinda hurt. It's like, I didn't even feel bad for myself. I felt guilty for everyone else. So, I had started writing on the web as a house wife. I had my blog and then I started getting jobs and then finally someone else online published a book. And I was so jealous that I was like, that's it I'm giving myself a year to write a book and get it published. I think there's just this mind set that you're gon na do one thing and that's the thing that's going to be your career. I don't think you're gon na pick one thing right now. And that's what you better get your degree in , and that's what you better spend nine hours a day doing , or you're gon na fail. The only mistake you can make now is to not do anything.
EventsA: I cried a lot — I meditated — I declared that I was going to walk away from all of it and become a potter
EventsB: I ended up getting pregnant really young — I got married right after that — I started writing on the web as a house wife — I started getting jobs — someone else online published a book — I gave myself a year to write a book and get it published

Q12: Story A presents different jobs this person tried out. Story B presents a story about trying for something and it failing.
Q13: Story A is about finding yourself and trying out different career paths to see what fits. Story B is a story about chasing your passion and having other people stomp on your dreams while telling you not to even try new things.
FullA: I knew during high school that I wanted to study biology and I did try out the research field for a little while. I then took a teaching job in the middle school , and after that, I took a curriculum writing and editing job. You know , I did some good jobs but I did go into them not knowing if okay I'm gon na love this and this is gon na be what I do for the rest of my life. And I think that sometimes young people put that pressure on themselves. I need to know exactly what I'm going to do for the rest of my life and I need to know it now. Yeah. And it's not really realistic , nor do I think that it's necessarily helpful. Just having experiences, those can really help you know who you are and what you want to be about.
FullB: I wrote some compositions. You know , as kids do, I just wrote these little things , and my mother put them in for an arts festival in our village. Everybody, in England, every village has an arts festival. And the time came for giving out the awards and prizes. And he held my compositions above his head  and he said, " These compositions are so bad that not only can I not consider " them for the competition , that goes without saying, " but this young man should be discouraged from ever " composing again . '' That's what he said. So it's important to know what you're after. And then if you know what you're after and you really want it , then you don't look around wondering if you're better or worse than the next person. Because it's not about that. It's about what you want to do.
EventsA: I tried out the research field for a little while — I took a teaching job in the middle school — I took a curriculum writing and editing job
EventsB: I wrote some compositions. — My mother put the compositions in for an arts festival. — The time came for giving out the awards and prizes. — He held my compositions above his head. — He said the compositions were so bad that he could not consider them for the competition. — He said I should be discouraged from ever composing again.

Q12: Both stories present a sequence of moving for a career followed by what they did after that career.
Q13: Story A had a career in the military to avoid an unfulfilling future and found a place that kept him fed while also giving him skills with guns. Story B was about a person that had an unfullilling life as a lawyer and fell back on a hobby that became a successful career.
FullA: When I joined the military, I had literally nothing. I was in a holding center, in a juvenile holding center and my recruiter came and rescued me. Needless to say , when I went to boot camp, I thought it was actually kind of easy and like I had never had so much food before in my life. When I joined the military, I originally signed up as a gunner's mate. I got out, felt like something was missing, I ended up moving out here for a job, and I was, like, guns , I know guns. I can do this job, that was easy. That was my turnaround moment. Okay.
FullB: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
EventsA: I joined the military — My recruiter came and rescued me — I went to boot camp — I signed up as a gunner's mate — I got out — I moved out here for a job
EventsB: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop

Q12: Both tell what started their passion, followed by their next step in life, followed by what they did with their passion.
Q13: Both stories are about what these two people find joy in. Story A was about a person able to combine their abilities as a designer and engineer to create really innovative clothing. Story B is about a person who has a passion for journalism but isn't doing exactly everything they want to do.
FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
FullB: I always knew I wanted to do journalism since I was a little kid. I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade. But by the time I graduated , I still didn't know if I wanted to do newspaper, or if I wanted to do TV and I ended up doing TV. And I just feel like, I just really enjoy just talking to people, in general. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. I feel sometimes like, am I stunting myself in my career? Am I where I'm supposed to be right now? Am I doing all that I can to get to the next point? But you don't always know if you're doing the right thing , but I don't know , it works out. I feel like things work themselves out. They do. They just do.
EventsA: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science
EventsB: I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade — I graduated — I ended up doing TV

Q12: Both stories present the moment that started their career paths and what progressed their paths until they found their calling.
Q13: Both stories are about how these two people found their passion in their chosen career paths. Both people went after their goals and found fulfillment that was able to last a lifetime in their fields.
FullA: I am Kimberly Lazer , I'm the curator of Behavioral Husbandry and Welfare for Oklahoma City Zoo. So I spend a lot of time looking, observing, learning everything we can about the species and about what their needs are to give them many choices in their environment. So that they have varied days and they have a very dynamic environment that they're living in. When I was five years old, I had an encounter with a dolphin. And I was able to look that animal in the eye and that was it for me. I wanted to dedicate my life to working with animals. When I left college, I thought, well, that's it , I'm ready. Put me in a job , I know what to do. And what I found was the animals were the best teachers. They have taught me humility. I think that's a big one. They've taught me compassion, to be a little bit more open and be very understanding. Especially to other human beings. That was something I learned when I left college. I had amazing experiences in college and I loved my classes but I don't think I really started becoming well rounded until I got out of the classroom. And I really started learning the real world stuff. So talk to people, hear their stories, and keep an open mind because every person has something to teach you.
FullB: I think it was an LA Times that my dad sent me , and it was just a really ambiguous ad saying, photographers, editors, technicians needed for sports photography agency. And I was like, what is this about? I was an athlete at one point in my life , I like sports, so let's check it out. At that point, didn't really much experience in photography. Realized  I was kind of out of my league for their photography positions, but the door was open to be an editor. So I immediately jumped to that job, knowing that in the back of my head I want to be a photographer , so I just took that opportunity knowing that I was eventually going to parlay it into to where I wanted to go. So in my spare time I'd go out and take photos, cuz the thing was, working for that company allowed me the access that I wanted to get to take photos at sporting events. And I didn't think that I'd be here 25 years later still kind of doing it. The moment you capture something and you just know you've got it in your camera , it's magical. So I just walked through the doors that were opened for me , and I just took them and here I am now. And I'm just fortunate to do something that I love , and it trips me out that I get paid for it. So doors are going to open and close , and it's going to come down to which ones you walk through
EventsA: I had an encounter with a dolphin — I looked the dolphin in the eye — I wanted to dedicate my life to working with animals — I left college — I found that the animals were the best teachers — The animals taught me humility — The animals taught me compassion — I started learning the real world stuff — I talked to people — I heard their stories — I kept an open mind
EventsB: Dad sent an LA Times ad — I checked out the ad — I realized I was out of my league for photography positions — I took the editor job — I took photos in my spare time — Working for the company allowed me access to take photos at sporting events — I captured a moment with my camera — I walked through the doors that were opened for me

Q12: I'm not very sure about this explanation
Q13: These stories are quite similar to one another because they both have inspiring goals they want but not sure if there jobs will get them far away without any extra push even though there's some insecurity involved.
FullA: The single worst job I ever had was washing dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. And I was the guy who was doing the communicable diseases stuff. So I had to wear the heavy gloves, and man, that stuff was just nasty. And so the whenever I started working my way up the ladder, reminding myself of, well, I could be doing that, which was always very helpful. And also I think it helped me to never look down on somebody for what they're doing, because if somebody looked down at me washing those eight patients ' dishes, they would of misjudged me completely. Remember, that anybody who tells you that they kind of woke up and were whoever they were, they're kidding you, right? So everybody gets started somewhere. If somebody figured something out, you can too, cuz they did the hard part. They figured it out the first time, right? And so when we meet with a lot of these folks, just know that where you are right now, that could be you in 10, 20 years. Don't measure yourself in terms of my gosh , I've got so far to go. If you end up not running a marathon anytime soon, my father used to run them. I remember him training , and it was a little bit of time, right? And eventually, you get there. Just know that if you keep plugging away, it will work out, right? I'm a big believer , you do the right things, good things happen.
FullB: Like let's say I went out with my husband and we went to dinner and we were meeting people. And they're like, " Oh, what do you do? '' I was like, " Oh, I make things. '' And we'd get in the car  and he'd be like, " Why didn't you say " you were an artist ? '' And I was like , " Well, " you know , I don't know . '' I mean I went to school for it , you know , I make images. But I was just having a hard time I guess accepting that as who I was or what I was going to be. I think I used to really obsess or focus on what I wasn't doing rather than what I was doing. And I think that's a huge... something that can really paralyze you. So I think it's really good to say, " What am I working on? " What is great? What am I happy about? " What am I doing good? '' And to do that and then know that you have a whole life. You'll get there.
EventsA: The narrator washed dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. — The narrator wore heavy gloves to handle communicable diseases. — The narrator started working their way up the ladder. — The narrator remembered that they could be doing the dishwashing job. — The narrator recalled their father training to run marathons.
EventsB: I went out with my husband — We went to dinner — We were meeting people — I said I make things — We got in the car — He asked why I didn't say I was an artist

Q12: I think they both involve almost the same outcomes and move from a decision to a result.
Q13: This is similar because they share success stories of how they overcame challenges and gain some insight after completing goals.
FullA: I am judge Elaine Marshall. I am the Director and Presiding Judge for the City of Houston Municipal Courts. And I was going to go to college to be a doctor. That worked out real well until biology, and cut them up and bleeding and all that stuff. You couldn't handle it. Nah, that just wasn't. Everyone kept saying that you talk so much , you probably should go to law school. When I first became a prosecutor, they would send us to different schools for career day. And when I became a judge, did same thing. The thing that stuck out to me the most was one time I went to a school as a judge , and they told them who I was and they said , all rise. So the kids stood up and four of the black kids that were sitting on the thing went , she's black. Wow. And it was like, yeah. Now you see. I came up just like they did, in a public school and those sorts of things. So it's good to give back. You will find so many different places where you can go that you'll make a difference.
FullB: I went to school, because I loved coding and I wanted to develop a coding career. And I reached out to a band that I liked and said, hey, long shot , but could I make you guys a website? And to my surprise, they emailed back like ten minutes later. And they're like yeah, actually , we'd really love for you to make us a website. How about two t-shirts and a CD in trade for it and I thought that was a great bargain. And so I made them a website. So yeah , I mean, I did my first or my second website for two t-shirts and a CD. So technically, not a fair market trade. Yeah. But at the time, the value proposition for me was way higher. And so you've got ta choose your shots. Yeah. And you will definitely do things in the course of your career that will be undervalued  and the trick is to choose the right ones, and to not do it too much. So throughout your career and in particular in those formative stages, you've got to go the extra mile. You've got ta work really hard. There's just no shortcut to it. Every now and then, one in a million gets lucky literary wins the rotary and everybody else whose ever achieved some great level of success has worked incredibly hard to get there.
EventsA: She decided not to go to college to be a doctor — She became a prosecutor — She went to different schools for career day as a prosecutor — She became a judge — She went to a school as a judge — The kids at the school stood up and said all rise — Four black kids at the school expressed surprise that she was black
EventsB: I went to school — I reached out to a band that I liked and asked if I could make them a website — They emailed back ten minutes later — They agreed to have me make them a website in exchange for two t-shirts and a CD — I made them a website

Q12: They both pushed through their fears and kept on pursuing dreams.
Q13: This two stories are very inspiring because they didn't let the negative effects and actions take over what they wanted to pursue in their lifetime. They were setback by people in their community but overcame fears and work things through.
FullA: I'm an Assistant Professor in Astronomy at California Institute of Technology and Caltech. And I study the dynamic universe. So what I do is, with the beautiful telescopes here at Palomar Observatory, we have some robotic telescopes that are continuously making a movie of the night sky. So we image the sky over and over again and we look for what changed. You might go out there and think universe is the same old thing every time , but it's actually not. It's full of these little explosions, which last for a very short amount of time , so they're very But they're very energetic. It's like cosmic fireworks lighting up our sky. So why did you choose to pursue the degree path that you did? I would say that in my own case, I mean , it was not at all clear that one day I would do a PhD. I grew up on a farm in India with 100 cows and fields of weeds and chick peas. And I had left home when I was 15 , and I was a girl in India in a small place. The entire community was up in arms, you know? There were people like neighbors, relatives , you name it. People I haven't even seen before coming into the house and trying to talk my parents out of this crazy decision to send their daughter alone on this journey into other end of the world to pursue something called Astronomy or whatever that was. The community was completely unsupportive. How did you deal with that? In my case, the best way to deal with it was to just let that fade away in the background and not engage with the two directly, but focus on what is motivating me, on what is giving me joy and just let everything else just fade away in the background.

Q12: Both of these stories shows progression from education to work and advancement to higher positions.
Q13: The stories both involved dedicated people in their fields and wanted to succeed to become something better within themselves instead of working a regular job.
FullA: When I got out of college, I went into the Army Reserve, through the Communications Officer. And ended up back in 89 getting a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory. At an Engineer and Developing Technology, to make weapons smarter, new technology to be able to kind of carry weapons. And so this whole focus was on creating capability. But when you're in the entrepreneurship world and the commercial world, that's a different mindset. Yeah. See, when I worked for the government. I could spend the government money on my ideas. But I'm out here as an entrepreneur , I have to spend my own money. So that was hard for me, to try to get that switch going on. My approach, and what I always tell people is you have to start connecting, networking. And a lot of people thinks that's hard , but it is not really hard. It's just a matter of meeting people , and let them know what you do or what you wan na do.
FullB: My wife and I call ourselves, laughingly, that we're fixers , so it's our job now to go in and help institutions and organizations that are flailing or floundering. Because my wife, myself, we come from a generation where we were told Indians are good with their hands, they're not meant for college. So just get a high school education and go to work. What drove me truly was, I wanted to help my people and I went to Community College , transferred to Black Hills State College , graduated from there in 1985. And immediately after law school, immediately came home to the reservation and there were no jobs in the Legal Profession. But the college had a directors position in institutional development and they hired me. And lo and behold they hired me as the acting president in 1991. So that's become the passion now is to help our children and our grandchildren to succeed and to again, instill with them a higher passion than just a job from eight to five.
EventsA: I got out of college — I went into the Army Reserve through the Communications Officer — I got a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory — I worked at an Engineer and Developing Technology to make weapons smarter — I tried to get the switch going on from government work to entrepreneurship
EventsB: I went to Community College — I transferred to Black Hills State College — I graduated from Black Hills State College in 1985 — I finished law school — I came home to the reservation — The college hired me as a director in institutional development — The college hired me as the acting president in 1991

Q12: very different stories because one side accomplished an applause while the other story wanted to seek a different option.
Q13: Both of the stories are uniquely different and similar in a type of way because both the people overcome obstacles in their path to become something better than weren't instead of quitting.
FullA: So at Alchemy we are taking the concept of chemistry and science and turning them into game based learning tools for students and for instructors, but in a way that allows for experimentation and play. The path was going toward academic chemistry. I was good at chemistry , I was good at research and all that stuff. But I realized that I always liked working with young people. So I actually, in 1994, went and worked at Detroit Country Day School, which is a private school. And started my job there and loved it, and raised my children. They went through the school , they went to U of M. And after that I started sort of feeling like not as connected to my school as it used to be, because my kids were gone. So I started to look for new things and that was the beginning of Alchemy. And if my learning tools can be shown to help students from everywhere get better. And there's like 50 % fail organic chemistry. If I could cut that down to 40 %, I think that would be success. But, this is not an easy path, it's really hard. But if you're solving a problem that you know needs to be solved, then the hurdles don't feel quite so high.
FullB: where you weren't truly able to talk about emotions, you know. So writing was my vehicle, the doorway out of there. I worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading , and I was so insecure that if there was 50 people listening to me and one person yawning, I'd feel like I failed. And I'd see that person yawning , and I'd have to do something else , you know , I'd have to climb on the chair or, go in their face. And one person got up and applauded , and after a year, after a lifetime of no encouragement, that one person applauding was enough to make me feel, have the confidence to find my destiny. Believe in that destiny, that there's something for you , and then someday it's gon na materialize.
EventsA: went and worked at Detroit Country Day School in 1994 — started my job at Detroit Country Day School — raised my children — my children went through the school — my children went to U of M — started to look for new things — began Alchemy
EventsB: worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading — saw one person yawning — did something else by climbing on the chair or going in their face — one person got up and applauded

Q12: One story was by luck or chance of even getting a job, while the other story was a 'build up' of a idea and business rather than just pursuing hope when you were in a state of desperation...
Q13: Both of these stories revolve around jobs and taking an initial leap to focus on something you  love outside of your profession or job, and turn this into a method of business or sustenance.
FullA: have the confidence or believe in some way or some fashion they'll find themselves. It always terrified me. I have four degrees and never really had any interest in any of them. I was miserable, except in my off-hours, when I was chasing whatever that I liked to do for fun, which was music and comic books and movies. And what happened was, I lost my job, left my wife , and I was homeless. Had no place to live. A guy that was uh, in a search firm, a headhunter, knew all my passions about comic books and movies and music. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. '' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. You don't want to be put into that position of luck ... making a difference in your life at a later age. Be in charge of your destiny now.
FullB: I always grew up with tea being a stable at our dining table. One of my colleagues from my previous job, knew a recruiter at eBay and he recommended me and they ended up hiring me. But one day I was trying to make loose-leaf tea at my desk , and by the time I would make it , I would be late for a meeting. And every time I tried to use tea bags instead, I was never satisfied with the quality because it was not as flavorful, it didn't have as much aroma. That was my first point of inspiration to think about the idea for tea drops. It took me about a year and a half of experimenting. I would spend my weekends and my week nights kind of blending and I was obsessed with figuring it out. And once I had that, I started sharing it with my colleagues and friends and family. Now we're available in over 1,600 retail stores. My logic was, even if this failed, even if nothing ever comes of it, I know I would have gained so much in trying
EventsA: lost my job — left my wife — was homeless — a headhunter told me Marvel Comics was looking for somebody with a business background who reads comic books — became president of Marvel Comics
EventsB: A colleague recommended me to a recruiter at eBay — They hired me — I tried to make loose-leaf tea at my desk — I tried to use tea bags instead — I thought about the idea for tea drops — I spent about a year and a half experimenting — I started sharing tea drops with colleagues, friends, and family — Tea drops became available in over 1,600 retail stores

I would never forget being 15 years old, put out of the house, Butt naked, out of a bathtub, Christmas Day in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, at the point of a shotgun, by my stepfather. Until I went into the military, the worst violence I ever saw was at home. So I make a decision, no. I don't wan na live like that. I could've become a stepfather. I could've become another alcoholic, wife beating, child abusing, illiterate loser. And a lot of people would've said, well look where he's from he didn't have a choice. Well I did have a choice. Q12: These themes are similar in action by recognition of learning something about themselves through physical or external validation or exposure, and then taking this learning into a new venture or idea
Q13: These are similar in the fact that both narrators do not really understand what their true purpose really is, or lack any type of true guidance in how they should go about their life with all these people (family) around them in particular.
FullA: I was born and raised in Chicago , but my first language is Spanish because everybody in my family spoke Spanish. From the moment I learned a bit of English, I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter. I started seeing kind of more of how the disenfranchised were being treated. This was pretty much the ah-hah moment for me and the other co-founder Victor Arellano. We were at the Department of Homeland Security here in Chicago. I was gon na do an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test. So this Polish couple gets called , federal agent comes up that's gon na administer the test. And he says , well, where's your interpreter? And they were just kind of like, I don't know. And she yells out at the crowd in the waiting room, does anybody here speak Polish? Some lady raises her hand , she's like, I speak Polish. So mind you , now one of the most important interviews of this couple's life lays in the balance of a person that says she speaks Polish, which she very well might. But how do you know how much her proficiency is in that language? And that's kinda like, where we're just like, you know what? There has to be a better way , there has to be a better way. So that's kind of where Interpreter Tap was born.
FullB: and um, co-owner of two restaurants, and how did you get from where you were at our age to where you are right now?  [New Zealand accent] I suppose at your age, I left school and really the same thing, I was totally unsure of what I wanted to do. I had um , a burning passion, which was not to cook -- mine was to travel. Went to Israel and worked on a kabutz for six months  'cause I met an Israeli guy and thought, " Oh this is quite cool . '' And started cooking in the kitchens there , and I was cooking with a couple of women who said to me then, " My god, you've got such a good talent for this. '' Then came home and thought, " Yup, this is what I'm gon na do. " I can just sort of live at Mum and Dad's " and save and go through uni, '' and then just started from there.  What kept you from just going out and doing something else?  'Cause I knew I couldn't, I didn't wan na do anything else. I knew, no matter how hard it was gon na be, I had to just keep going. I just had to keep going. 'Cause really, the whole thing is, you're focusing on what you wan na do.
EventsA: I learned a bit of English — I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter — I started seeing how the disenfranchised were being treated — I and Victor Arellano were at the Department of Homeland Security in Chicago — I did an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test — A federal agent asked the Polish couple where their interpreter was — A woman in the waiting room said she spoke Polish — Interpreter Tap was born
EventsB: left school — went to Israel — worked on a kabutz for six months — met an Israeli guy — started cooking in the kitchens there — cooked with a couple of women who praised my talent — came home — decided to pursue cooking — started university

Q12: Again, one of these is more guided in terms of education and learning to like a job or yourself more, as compared to someone who lost everything and is more about ego and being respected by their contributions
Q13: These are not really similar, they are different in tone in regards to being more optimistic versus pessimistic, as well as age range and hope for the future/ego
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I worked in technology up until 1998 in which I struck out on my own and I built an engineering company. Had good contracts. 9/11 hits a couple of years later, and all of a sudden a lot of the major corporations and people  I was dealing with, their stocks fell, and they stopped giving work. I went and became a screener at the airport. I want you to think about this. I worked for a major corporation, I'm a screener, people that were my clients and then I work with , were coming through the airport. You got me reminiscing and thinking back here. But, I stuck to my principles. I knew I was better than this, all right? And I had a plan. So I took what I knew, even though I was working in terrorism and mass transit, I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl. And so, I knew from that, I was as good or better than anybody there.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I struck out on my own — I built an engineering company — 9/11 happened — major corporations and people I was dealing with stopped giving work — I became a screener at the airport — I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl

Q12: The first sequence shows a progression of growth but the second shows a progression of discovery.
Q13: The first story is about someone deciding to take a risk, the second is about someone opening their eyes to consider a career opportunity they hadn’t thought about before.
FullA: and uh, loved it. You know, I was in one of those graduate programs and on, you know, a good salary , and I enjoyed it , but I always felt like I couldn't express myself enough and there was perhaps, ah, some environment somewhere where I could really make a difference. And you know , I was almost nine years in the bank. I could have gotten my superannuation and been set up with a nice house somewhere. I didn't wan na be that person in years, you know, in years in the future, uh, and not have had taken risks. And I was in a very comfortable environment , and I just didn't have this need to take a risk , and I was like excited about taking a risk and not really knowing what the outcome would be. And uh, we didn't know a whole lot back then , but we just made our classes so much fun. People would laugh the whole way through , and so as a result, it just exploded. We went from 23 people our first night to about 200 people after eight weeks. If you've got that feeling inside that there's something else, it's very hard to get rid of -- which is a good thing. I think there's that something driving you to say , " Well there's something else " out there . ''
FullB: " to be a flight attendant. '' So I was applying for the flight attendant positions and nothing was coming open for me. And then a friend of mine was like, " Well, why don't you, " have you considered being a pilot and flying the plane? '' I was like , " No, I never considered that. " It never crossed my mind. '' [Pilot # 2] We never really saw people in the cockpit that looked like us. And so now, we can give that type of exposure. [Pilot # 1] You still find some people that don't like maybe seeing us up there in the cockpit. But, you know, this is how it's gon na be. So, this is the generation where all doors are open, there's no excuses anymore.
EventsA: I was in one of those graduate programs — I was almost nine years in the bank — We made our classes fun — The number of people in the class grew from 23 to about 200 after eight weeks
EventsB: I was applying for the flight attendant positions — A friend suggested I consider being a pilot and flying the plane

FullA: The single worst job I ever had was washing dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. And I was the guy who was doing the communicable diseases stuff. So I had to wear the heavy gloves, and man, that stuff was just nasty. And so the whenever I started working my way up the ladder, reminding myself of, well, I could be doing that, which was always very helpful. And also I think it helped me to never look down on somebody for what they're doing, because if somebody looked down at me washing those eight patients ' dishes, they would of misjudged me completely. Remember, that anybody who tells you that they kind of woke up and were whoever they were, they're kidding you, right? So everybody gets started somewhere. If somebody figured something out, you can too, cuz they did the hard part. They figured it out the first time, right? And so when we meet with a lot of these folks, just know that where you are right now, that could be you in 10, 20 years. Don't measure yourself in terms of my gosh , I've got so far to go. If you end up not running a marathon anytime soon, my father used to run them. I remember him training , and it was a little bit of time, right? And eventually, you get there. Just know that if you keep plugging away, it will work out, right? I'm a big believer , you do the right things, good things happen.
FullB: Like let's say I went out with my husband and we went to dinner and we were meeting people. And they're like, " Oh, what do you do? '' I was like, " Oh, I make things. '' And we'd get in the car  and he'd be like, " Why didn't you say " you were an artist ? '' And I was like , " Well, " you know , I don't know . '' I mean I went to school for it , you know , I make images. But I was just having a hard time I guess accepting that as who I was or what I was going to be. I think I used to really obsess or focus on what I wasn't doing rather than what I was doing. And I think that's a huge... something that can really paralyze you. So I think it's really good to say, " What am I working on? " What is great? What am I happy about? " What am I doing good? '' And to do that and then know that you have a whole life. You'll get there.
EventsA: The narrator washed dishes at a hospital in Philadelphia. — The narrator wore heavy gloves to handle communicable diseases. — The narrator started working their way up the ladder. — The narrator remembered that they could be doing the dishwashing job. — The narrator recalled their father training to run marathons.
EventsB: I went out with my husband — We went to dinner — We were meeting people — I said I make things — We got in the car — He asked why I didn't say I was an artist

Q12: Both sequences of events show them using their skills which leads into turning them into a career
Q13: The first story is about someone blending two careers together. The second is about someone making a decision between two different careers.
FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
FullB: I always knew I wanted to do journalism since I was a little kid. I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade. But by the time I graduated , I still didn't know if I wanted to do newspaper, or if I wanted to do TV and I ended up doing TV. And I just feel like, I just really enjoy just talking to people, in general. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. I feel sometimes like, am I stunting myself in my career? Am I where I'm supposed to be right now? Am I doing all that I can to get to the next point? But you don't always know if you're doing the right thing , but I don't know , it works out. I feel like things work themselves out. They do. They just do.
EventsA: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science
EventsB: I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade — I graduated — I ended up doing TV

Q12: In sequence A the event sequences start with setbacks and lead to a realization of missing something that’s desired. In sequence B the events are a gradual progression towards attaining something that’s desired.
Q13: The first story the person was working jobs that wasn’t their dream of writing and realized they missed it. In the second story the person got a job in the area that was their dream right away.
FullA: here in Boston. And uh, I went for a semester , realized I wasn't gon na be able to go back because of kind of financial hardship, and took two years off from school and was working. I pretty much had always realized that I wanted to write from a pretty young age. I had always enjoyed writing. I did sports for a while , and then I actually left sports 'cause I wasn't sure if writing definitely was what I wanted to do , and I feel like I-I wanted to test myself. At night, I would work at a supermarket , and I was like, shagging carriages for like two years. And I actually worked at a bookstore for a little while , and I booked all the bands that played -- they had like a cafÃ © that would have live music there every weekend , and I, you know, worked in the cafÃ © making coffee and doing all that stuff. And ah, I realized at the end of maybe like a year, a year  and a half, that I-I totally missed writing, totally missed sports. It was probably one of the most valuable lessons that I learned in my life , was just going away from it for a little while to see how much I would miss it.

Q12: The first is a positive sequence of discovery of talents and opportunities. The second is a sequence of setbacks leading up to a decision to change direction to something else.
Q13: Both stories involve working in the film industry but the first is someone going into it and the second is someone coming out of it.
FullA: from Canada you could ever figure out how to make movies.  Right? So I just figured I'd be going into engineering , so I took lots of maths and sciences all through high school getting ready for that. And at the last minute, I heard about this school that taught film production not too far away , and I got accepted there. Went from film production to animation to computer animation, for me. And, ah, that was inter - really interesting because it had the sort of scientific side, math and science, which I was, you know, really good at. And it had this artistic side. So I could program one minute , and then I could go , you know, fool around with animation, look at cartoons and stuff. I had a few jobs where it would be like, " Oh... great... I got ta go to work ...  '' And, you know, I sort of knew all along, " Okay, I don't want to spend my life doing this . '' You know , you'll find something, you know? And don't worry about it being the perfect thing because I think no decision is absolute, first of all, you know? I've certainly had several changes along the way. A lot of people have.
FullB: I-I was , you know , my voice broke , and all of a sudden I got tall. And I.. And I had , you know , I was -- I had kinda given up, to tell you , 'cause honest , I had come down to Los Angeles and done a couple auditions. And I got this one job and then the financing fell apart in the movie so it didn't end up happening. And I was very ready to sort of call it a day and go, " All right, I had my little run and now I got ta go to college . '' Because I thought that's what you were supposed to do. And I got ta find a stable job, because that's what I thought you were supposed to do. And thankfully it didn't quite crumble for me that way. You know , there's so many different ways to go at life. You know, the paths that we're told that we get through the television, that we get , they're just a tiny little sliver.
EventsA: I took lots of maths and sciences all through high school — I heard about a school that taught film production — I got accepted at the film production school — I went from film production to animation to computer animation
EventsB: My voice broke — I got tall — I came down to Los Angeles — I did a couple auditions — I got one job — The financing fell apart in the movie — I was ready to call it a day — I decided to go to college

Q12: Both stories talk about trying something new
Q13: Both stories were talking about taking risks and stepping outside of oneself
FullA: and uh, loved it. You know, I was in one of those graduate programs and on, you know, a good salary , and I enjoyed it , but I always felt like I couldn't express myself enough and there was perhaps, ah, some environment somewhere where I could really make a difference. And you know , I was almost nine years in the bank. I could have gotten my superannuation and been set up with a nice house somewhere. I didn't wan na be that person in years, you know, in years in the future, uh, and not have had taken risks. And I was in a very comfortable environment , and I just didn't have this need to take a risk , and I was like excited about taking a risk and not really knowing what the outcome would be. And uh, we didn't know a whole lot back then , but we just made our classes so much fun. People would laugh the whole way through , and so as a result, it just exploded. We went from 23 people our first night to about 200 people after eight weeks. If you've got that feeling inside that there's something else, it's very hard to get rid of -- which is a good thing. I think there's that something driving you to say , " Well there's something else " out there . ''

And then a friend of mine was like, " Well, why don't you, " have you considered being a pilot and flying the plane? '' I was like , " No, I never considered that. " It never crossed my mind. '' [Pilot # 2] We never really saw people in the cockpit that looked like us. And so now, we can give that type of exposure. [Pilot # 1] You still find some people that don't like maybe seeing us up there in the cockpit. But, you know, this is how it's gon na be. Q12: Both stories are about learning one's true calling and learning how to overcome the doubts
Q13: Both stories are about searching and finding oneself
FullA: We are creating soft multi-layered forms that interact with environments. And create a space in cities that open up our imagination and allow us to think about a different way of being. So I had $ 300 and for graduation I got a plane ticket to Bali. And I went off on my own and started walking through the rice fields until I found a little house to rent. I went as a painter, I shipped all my paints and they got lost , and that is how I became a sculpture, because I had no paint. I was in a fishing village , they had fishing twine, and began just experimenting, and from there I had this dream of bringing it back home. I applied to seven art schools and I was rejected by all seven. And that turned out to be the luckiest thing ever in my life, because it forced me to have to learn how to teach myself. The education to do what I do, there is no program. If I had gone to a program, it might have led me somewhere , but it wouldn't have been as authentic a direction. Any kind of life where you're trying to do something new, and creative, your gon na hit rejections all the time. My mom had a saying for that too, it's like just toughen up, let it come at me. Just because you're rejecting me from every single art school I've applied to, that doesn't mean you get to say that I'm not an artist. The thing I had to teach myself after college, was how to hear my own voice, like honestly I just didn't even know it to recognize it. Making decisions is gon na happen to you your whole life , they are always hard, you've got to figure out how to make them. And you have to listen to yourself , and so getting to know yourself is maybe the work of this phase of your life.
FullB: So when I was your age, I think I had just decided that I thought I wanted to try this new field called biomedical engineering, which my dad had encouraged me to explore. And so I was in college , and I was taking classes. And so I had to figure out what to do for the summer , and I was walking by this lab. And on the door of the lab, it said artificial organs. So that sounded really cool to me, because it was like a mix of biomaterials and engineering , and it was very applied. I could understand why you would wan na do nerve regeneration. So that summer, the third summer, was when I finally found the right interface for me. How do you hope your applications will change the role of science in medicine? We've invented these nano sensors that you can inject, that can roam around your body looking for disease, and then emit a signal in the urine. In our long term vision is that this could help with cancer detection in resource poor settings. In just speaking about finding your way, what advice would you give to younger women in science about finding their way in this field, and what road blocks would you like to talk about? So I think for me, one of the biggest road blocks was internal. I don't know if you guys have read about the impostor syndrome. I mean , I certainly had that. I was always worried that I didn't belong at the table, that somehow I'd been some fluke of admission , and it was only a matter of time before people found me out. And in fact it's really, that uniqueness is what makes you different, what makes you valuable.
EventsA: I had $300 — I got a plane ticket to Bali for graduation — I went off on my own — I started walking through the rice fields — I found a little house to rent — I shipped all my paints — My paints got lost — I became a sculpture because I had no paint — I began experimenting with fishing twine — I had a dream of bringing it back home — I applied to seven art schools — I was rejected by all seven art schools — I had to learn how to teach myself — I had to teach myself how to hear my own voice
EventsB: I decided to try the field of biomedical engineering — I was in college taking classes — I walked by a lab with a door that said artificial organs — I found the right interface for me that summer — We invented nano sensors that can be injected to detect disease — I experienced impostor syndrome

Q12: Both stories are about finding one's calling through different options
Q13: Both stories are about trying different things and coming to an option that feels right
FullA: Where were you when you were our age, 22, 23? I was in Chile. I was about to finish college. And I have a bachelor's in linguistics, English linguistics, so I spoke English before i came here. And at that time the only possibility I'd say that was offered to me was to teach English. I was coming from the third world to the first world. I didn't get out of my apartment for about year. And then I came across this ad. They were looking for a coordinator in this place. I think that there are roads for you in life. And if you want to take a different road life is always going to take you back to that one. For example, teaching for me. As soon as I started teaching, I loved it.
FullB: I went to UC Berkeley and I started out as a philosophy major and an art major. And then I took anthropology. And then I thought, you know, I wan na do theater. And then after I got out, I like, I'm just going to try to get a real job but I wanted to be in a place that felt right and I applied to the Asian art museum. I applied for the program assistant position in performing arts , and I have museum experience , I have my anthro background , I have theater. It just kind of came together , and it was totally unplanned. The thing is, I never knew a job like what I have now existed or could exist. I just sort of positioned myself with things that really felt right. It's really a matter of instinct on some level and a broad plotting of things. Did you ever, after making the decision, be like, what am I doing, like doubting yourself? No. Really? You just went straight for it? The truth is, I've felt just pretty open about how the future will pan out. Your path is what you make of it. There are positions out there , there are careers out there that you can fit into. But there also things that you can make yourself and you have to just trust that you have something unique to offer and to be consistent with that in your choices.
EventsA: I was in Chile — I was about to finish college — I spoke English before I came here — I didn't get out of my apartment for about a year — I came across an ad — They were looking for a coordinator — I started teaching — I loved teaching
EventsB: I went to UC Berkeley — I started out as a philosophy major and an art major — I took anthropology — I decided I wanted to do theater — I got out of UC Berkeley — I applied to the Asian art museum — I applied for the program assistant position in performing arts

Q12: Both are about people overcoming hardships to move ahead
Q13: Both of them are about turning ideals into reality
FullA: being six years old , postcards coming into my family, as one after another of the relatives that my parents had were, you know, dead in the concentration camps. And I remember just being very affected by that as a six or seven year old. I became convinced right then , I think, that I did not want to be one of those people. I wanted to be a kind of person that helped other people. That instead of bringing suffering , I wanted to try to alleviate suffering. And what better way to try to alleviate the suffering of human beings than being a doctor? I think everyone has to make a choice which will bring themselves inner peace and happiness as the best they can achieve it. No matter what you do, you will have an opportunity to impact on other people's lives, just by who you are and the way you act.
FullB: and the next minute, you know , I'm thrown over 50 feet from a car  and they thought I died, you know? And they thought I'd never walk again. And people have often asked was I not angry or bitter , and the answer is no. It just is.  Everything seems so minimal, you know, when I'm sitting here talking to you. But just, you know, your mother, the accident...  why not just, " You know what, I cant ''? Like, you know --?  What would have been my option? You see it, don't you? You're sitting, waiting on the first of the month to get a check. Stuck in a wheelchair. You know... That-that's an option? I don't take reality checks from anybody. I want to follow what my passion is in life more than anything else. Don't give me a reality check because reality will tell you what you can't do. " You need to deal " with the real world. '' No, my world is real to me.
EventsA: Postcards came into the family from deceased relatives in concentration camps — The narrator became convinced that they did not want to be like those people — The narrator decided to become a person who helped others — The narrator decided to become a doctor to alleviate human suffering
EventsB: He was thrown over 50 feet from a car — People thought he died — People thought he would never walk again

Q12: Both show growth in the progression.
Q13: These are both showing how they find different experiences important and how to find that for yourself.
FullA: My name's Laura , I run Allied Woodshop. We're a collective woodshop. We are home to about eight furniture makers who make their living making furniture in the shop here. And we also teach woodworking classes. Most people think I make my living making furniture , but most of my time is spent managing Allied Woodshop. My whole family has this ethic of working with their hands and being able to do things for themselves. And that's something that I grew up with and I saw , and it's not something that I had in my jobs. I was finding myself in jobs where I was behind computers , I was on the phone. I thought the work was very important , but, at the end of the day, I wasn't very happy with how my time was spent during the day. And so I eventually took a year off, moved up to Northern California. Went to the Krenov School. It's a year-long certificate program on furniture making. That's kind of how I got into woodworking. It's something that keeps me feeling like I'm connected to my family and my roots. So be introspective, and do some soul-searching and think about what your strengths are, what it is that you love to do, and figure out if there's a way to turn that into your career path.
FullB: So I graduated from high school in 2007 and took a trip to Tanzania. Where I met this wonderful young man named John. He told me he wanted to become President of Tanzania which I thought was awesome. But I learned shortly thereafter that he actually couldn't afford to go to high school. You just kind of take a lot of things for granted like I  took the fact that I could go to school for granted, that I could go to college for granted. That's what made this experience of meeting John so shocking to me. And then from there I was inspired to create the School Fund, which is a nonprofit that connects people with student in the developing world that just need a bit of money to continue their education. So one of the things that I think is really awesome about being a young person is, we don't always see all the roadblocks that other adults might see. So here I saw this kid John and I was like, wow this is a big problem, let's do something about it. And I didn't necessarily see all the road blocks of , oh we have to register as a non profit and yadda yadda yadda. We just threw it out there and kinda got going with something. I think it's important that everyone of all ages finds a way to give back, so spend a little time figuring out what you're passionate about and what you enjoy doing and don't be afraid to just jump start and get going with something.
EventsA: She took a year off — She moved up to Northern California — She went to the Krenov School — She completed a year-long certificate program on furniture making
EventsB: graduated from high school in 2007 — took a trip to Tanzania — met a young man named John — learned that John couldn't afford to go to high school — was inspired to create the School Fund

Q12: Both give a sequence of events but aren't really related.
Q13: Both speak of a person being kind of lost in life and then coming to a realization of what was important to them.
FullA: from Alaska as I could, I went to New York. And then after Cornell, I had like a complete sort of fall-apart where I didn't know what to do. And all my friends were doing important things like going straight to law school or medical school. I started working on the weekends at a cheese stand. I sold cheese in a like farmer's market for two years. I mean that sort of process went on  and eventually, I went back to graduate school. I got a um, Master's in a program called Communication, Culture, and Technology. But what I realize now is that I had not created space from my routine and my structure to think more broadly. And when I thought about different jobs I wanted, I was only thinking in terms of the amount of money I was making at that point. It took me a long time to start questioning the whole foundation of that, which was , " Maybe I don't need to make this much money . ''
FullB: My parents divorced when I was nine, and. Went up on this big adventure , and it turned into a big sailing trip , and we were three years, the whole adventure. When I finished the trip, I wound up, uh, back in Seattle , but I just started getting really tired of the daily grind, the nine to five. I'm not really sure what it was. I just started losing traction , and I needed some big goal to motivate me. I needed something to happen. And I started thinking about the VendÃ © e Globe, which is the non-stop around-the-world race that no American had finished. And so I-I just stuck it out and was real careful and I made it to the finish and had this great welcome in France. One important factor for me to handle all this, in all these different things I want to do, is to come to a conclusion not so much about what you want to do, but how you want to do it.
EventsA: I went to New York — I had a complete fall-apart after Cornell — I started working on the weekends at a cheese stand — I sold cheese in a farmer's market for two years — I went back to graduate school — I got a Master's in Communication, Culture, and Technology
EventsB: My parents divorced when I was nine — I went on a big sailing trip — I finished the trip — I wound up back in Seattle — I started thinking about the Vendée Globe race — I stuck it out and made it to the finish — I had a great welcome in France

Q12: These show similar concise events.
Q13: One is about working hard and the other is just about experiences.
FullA: Originally, I thought I was just gon na be a contractor. Then I decided I was gon na study architecture so I moved out to California. And throughout all that, Eli and I met each other out in California. And I tried Switchel for the first time. A month later, we sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont. And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. It takes a lot of time to manage people when you bring them on. So I'm gon na go for the person who's already shows that they're halfway there.
FullB: I'd be a UN official. Early on, I won an award, at age 15, was sent around the world. Um...  and uh, transformation. And I knew, " My life's international work. '' And I was gon na learn languages , and you know , I just knew it. And I could say , " Well I " was blessed with clarity and a great breakthrough . '' And it would have been logical for me to now set focus on that. But happily, I did this  and I did that, and-and I stumbled and I didn't join the UN. But I had a very enriching and confusing bundle of experiences , but it allowed me to have an eclectic set of tools that I think really made it possible for me to make a difference. If you aren't completely uncomfortable, completely off-balance, completely beyond your competence, you're missing. Because it's in being off-balance that you really see.
EventsA: I decided to study architecture — I moved out to California — Eli and I met each other in California — I tried Switchel for the first time — We sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont
EventsB: I won an award at age 15 — I was sent around the world — I had a great breakthrough — I stumbled — I didn't join the UN

Q12: They main events are told at different times in each story.
Q13: The first story was about going down a new career path; the second is about a straight unchanging career path.
FullA: I am judge Elaine Marshall. I am the Director and Presiding Judge for the City of Houston Municipal Courts. And I was going to go to college to be a doctor. That worked out real well until biology, and cut them up and bleeding and all that stuff. You couldn't handle it. Nah, that just wasn't. Everyone kept saying that you talk so much , you probably should go to law school. When I first became a prosecutor, they would send us to different schools for career day. And when I became a judge, did same thing. The thing that stuck out to me the most was one time I went to a school as a judge , and they told them who I was and they said , all rise. So the kids stood up and four of the black kids that were sitting on the thing went , she's black. Wow. And it was like, yeah. Now you see. I came up just like they did, in a public school and those sorts of things. So it's good to give back. You will find so many different places where you can go that you'll make a difference.
FullB: I went to school, because I loved coding and I wanted to develop a coding career. And I reached out to a band that I liked and said, hey, long shot , but could I make you guys a website? And to my surprise, they emailed back like ten minutes later. And they're like yeah, actually , we'd really love for you to make us a website. How about two t-shirts and a CD in trade for it and I thought that was a great bargain. And so I made them a website. So yeah , I mean, I did my first or my second website for two t-shirts and a CD. So technically, not a fair market trade. Yeah. But at the time, the value proposition for me was way higher. And so you've got ta choose your shots. Yeah. And you will definitely do things in the course of your career that will be undervalued  and the trick is to choose the right ones, and to not do it too much. So throughout your career and in particular in those formative stages, you've got to go the extra mile. You've got ta work really hard. There's just no shortcut to it. Every now and then, one in a million gets lucky literary wins the rotary and everybody else whose ever achieved some great level of success has worked incredibly hard to get there.
EventsA: She decided not to go to college to be a doctor — She became a prosecutor — She went to different schools for career day as a prosecutor — She became a judge — She went to a school as a judge — The kids at the school stood up and said all rise — Four black kids at the school expressed surprise that she was black
EventsB: I went to school — I reached out to a band that I liked and asked if I could make them a website — They emailed back ten minutes later — They agreed to have me make them a website in exchange for two t-shirts and a CD — I made them a website

FullA: when I was four, but um ... growing up without a mother -- 'cause she died when I was six -- growing up with just my dad and my brother , I was obviously very, um, just very independent and strong-willed. And being the little surfy chick that I was , it just made me realize that wasn't the avenue I wanted to go down. Ultimately, to become successful in anything , you have to be relatively selfish. You have to be so one-dimensional. I also believe that there's no such thing as a mistake , it's only a learning experience. The only mistake is not learning from it. But even then, you're just gon na be given the opportunity to learn it and learn it and learn it until such time as you do. So I made the same " mistake '' over and over again until I actually got the lesson.

And I remember on that Friday, before I quit , I said that was the last time I was gon na ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke. I would oftentimes get a little disheartened , and I would never, of course, tell them. FullA: July 20th, 1988, 27 years ago yesterday, I broke my neck in a diving accident. It left me a quadriplegic at the cervical four, five level. And I was always so ashamed of having this learning disability. I never told anybody about my learning disability. I went all the way through college getting the accommodations for being in a wheel chair and not letting anybody know that I was dyslexic. There is no wheelchair for dyslexia. And I struggle with that everyday.

I think we've always been just really adventurous. And our parents decided to come here because it was a better place for better opportunity. You know , they thought, " Oh look , you know, we're gon na have a new life, " and the girls can become lawyers and accountants -- '' [sister # 3] " They won't end up being seamstresses . '' [sister # 2] So we actually ended up being exactly what they didn't want us to be, which is seamstresses. I think with our parents , we've always had to prove to them that we could do something. I just remember a lot of fighting and a lot of crying. And them just going , " Well we didn't come here for you to do this . '' And I'm like, " Well it's not for you, like, I can't live " what you want me to be. ''

FullA: I'm really an early stage person. I love to make the new thing and so as something gets bigger and more structured , I usually hand it off to people and there's people who love to run stuff that's structured. So when I joined Google we were about 1,200 people and when I left we're over 50 or 60,000 people, so it was sort of fly the plane while you're building the plane. I had gone from working in Silicon Valley and working at Google on a lot of topics. It was fun, incredible teammates. And then I was in Africa for some work with some entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya and I got an email and it said email from the US CTO. And so 33 days later, President Obama called and offered me the job which was incredible. It's an honor to get to serve your country. So when you're doing this work, know that you belong. We all come with different histories and those histories are culture add. There's this weird idea that Silicon Valley had of culture fit. It's very destructive. I don't want you to fit , I want you to add.
FullB: The point of which I decided to be entrepreneur was when talking point just took off. It snowballed from there. So, I have to say my entrepreneurship journey is pretty accidental. Often the public image of an entrepeneur is very glamorous, but actually a lot of my work is not glamorous. And I don't think people see that from the outside. A lot of my role is essentially being a champion. I'm a doer at heart. And it's going from I'm a real doer to I need to delegate or I need to be able to align everyone to get to the same big vision and the big goal. And it's not just me anymore, so kind of a a chicken and an egg where it's both hard and challenging, but exciting.
EventsA: joined Google when it had about 1,200 people — left Google when it had over 50,000 people — went to Africa for work with entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya — received an email from the US CTO — President Obama called and offered the job 33 days later
