FullA: In first grade when they asked me what I wanted to do, I said I want to study the stars. So, it's lucky that it worked out. Most of the times people say, I wan na be a football player, whatever, movie star, it doesn't work out. In my case it worked out , but I was lucky that way. Astronomy, before I went to college, was something I really thought I could do. But I just doubt myself a lot. Was there any moments where you really doubted yourself? Of course, all the time. It's inevitable. When you're trying to push yourself, there are always moments when you think, maybe this is too hard , maybe I can not do it. But my answer to that is that, if you don't feel that way, it means you're not pushing yourself enough. If you never go out of your comfort zone, then you're not really trying very hard. It's part of learning and part of growing up , is figuring out things that you didn't know you could do, and then you do them. Sometimes you fail. Sometimes you succeed. Let's put it this way. First of all, in research most of what you do, fails miserably, because you're trying to do something that nobody knows how to do. So you have to really like failure. Embrace failure. Accept that failure is gon na be part of the process.
FullB: I think, in the history of this country at least. I mean I see your t-shirt where it has, uh, the Black Panthers. So I was born in Chicago when all that stuff was happening. When you're born in that environment, it's kind of like, " Yeah, you're supposed to be " doing something around social justice , '' because, you know, I saw Chicago burn down. I saw , you know... the tanks roll through our neighborhood. And I didn't realize I had that whole wealth of history and knowledge and activity going on around me because I was in it. Sometimes when you're doing something you love, it doesn't -- you don't find it , it finds you.
EventsA: They asked me what I wanted to do in first grade — I said I wanted to study the stars — It worked out for me — I doubted myself a lot before college
EventsB: I was born in Chicago when all that stuff was happening — I saw Chicago burn down — I saw the tanks roll through our neighborhood

Q12: The first has a lot of outside influence with a final decision made by the speaker, while the second one is all self motivated
Q13: Both are about having an open mind when it comes to your life and career and taking opportunities that might not work out.
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I knew during high school that I wanted to study biology and I did try out the research field for a little while. I then took a teaching job in the middle school , and after that, I took a curriculum writing and editing job. You know , I did some good jobs but I did go into them not knowing if okay I'm gon na love this and this is gon na be what I do for the rest of my life. And I think that sometimes young people put that pressure on themselves. I need to know exactly what I'm going to do for the rest of my life and I need to know it now. Yeah. And it's not really realistic , nor do I think that it's necessarily helpful. Just having experiences, those can really help you know who you are and what you want to be about.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I tried out the research field for a little while — I took a teaching job in the middle school — I took a curriculum writing and editing job

Q12: The first one is about the influence of a great teacher mixed with a hard home life. The second mostly talks about the specific career steps.
Q13: They both were about their passions for teaching and they got there. They also had a casual and stream of consciousness manner to them.
FullA: Becoming a teacher really became , I think, a calling for me in high school. My mother's an alcoholic, and home life became chaotic , and that stress started to manifest itself in my self esteem, my expectations for myself at school and so I started to really waver. And then 11th grade, I had AP English with Mister Shirts  and this was a guy on fire for literature and made that place absolutely, infectiously joyful and he really made me want to excel , and so it brings a tear to my eye. To think , I mean, to really think about it, and I've lived it. I saw the door of opportunity closing and to know that a teacher put their hand out and held it open for me to walk through it. You know and the idea that I could do that for other kids, that I could spend my life doing that. You know, that is the highest calling.
FullB: I have an education degree, and then math as a minor. And I did teaching for six years , but I still wanted to do that, just not in the education system, so I became a corporate trainer. Which is how I ended up with AT&T. People wanted teachers that could the teach the math or the sciences. I'm like , that's the easy part, yeah sure, I'll do that. My family did not want me to be a teacher. Math was like my ultimate favorite subject. So my teachers, my parents, they were like, you need to be engineer. You need to be engineer. So I came to Texas , went to a really strong engineering school, and it was not the best experience. And I said, if this is what engineering is, I don't wan na do it. So at that time, without telling anyone, went back to school that next semester and studied to be a teacher. My mother was like, you're never gon na make any money. Like okay, I'll figure that part out later. It's like okay, yeah , I may be a broke teacher , but I'll be a happy teacher , and I'll be doing so much good and it would be worth it.
EventsA: My home life became chaotic — I started to waver in my self esteem and expectations for myself at school — I had AP English with Mister Shirts in 11th grade — Mister Shirts made the class joyful — Mister Shirts made me want to excel — A teacher held the door of opportunity open for me to walk through
EventsB: became a corporate trainer — ended up with AT&T — came to Texas — went to a strong engineering school — decided not to do engineering — went back to school the next semester — studied to be a teacher

Q12: Both talking about moving jobs but the first one is much more task oriented and the second one is just negatives about the first job.
Q13: Mostly similar in the fact that they are talking about jobs they liked and jobs that didnt fit them. But the first one was much more emotional and had many parts. The second one was more straightforward with the person just changing where they worked instead of what they worked on.
FullA: I don't think I'll ever find a job that I'm as good at as I was at being an infantry officer. I went from being a captain in the Marine Corps, in command of 950 marines and sailors. Every Friday I would go out to our Liberty Formation before I launched them for the weekend , and you just see this massive sea of servicemen and women that I was in command of. It was awe inspiring and humbling and it was just an awesome opportunity. I ended up taking a job with a medical IT company. And I was in a cubicle next to a 23 year old, looking through spreadsheets to see if there were duplicate hospitals in them. You couldn't have wasted my experience or skill sets more , but that's all part of it. You can not expect your first employer or the people that you're interviewing with or the community you moved to , you can't expect them to know everything about you and understand your value right off the bat. You have to go in and you've got ta show them. You've got to compete again and so I had a lot of fun. Figuring out, okay, how do I become a non profit leader and build a non profit? By the way at the same time, I've also got ta fight these guys that wan na beat me up on national TV because that helped me pay my bills as well. So trying to juggle all those while we were having kids and everything , it was a wild, crazy transition for sure.
FullB: Wasn't a good experience. Didn't think I was gon na like practicing law and definitely didn't like where I was doing it. And I think like a lot of people who are in their first real job, you get a little freaked out when you're unhappy. Because, " What kind of risks " am I taking if I leave this place? " Am I ever gon na get a job again? " What does it say about me as a person that I've made " the wrong choice here? '' It's nonsense. You just go on to the next thing and you kind of keep going. I finally kind of decided to make the jump and went to another firm , and it was absolutely night and day difference. All the kind of weird directions that my career has taken wasn't the result of plotting it out even at that time. A lot of it was happenstance. Just, you kind of work hard, keep your eyes open.
EventsA: He was a captain in the Marine Corps in command of 950 marines and sailors — He went out to the Liberty Formation before launching the servicemen and women for the weekend — He took a job with a medical IT company — He looked through spreadsheets to see if there were duplicate hospitals — He figured out how to become a non profit leader and build a non profit — He fought on national TV to help pay his bills
EventsB: Did not like practicing law — Did not like where I was doing it — Decided to make the jump — Went to another firm

Q12: The first one is a whole journey from one skillset to a big job. The second is a straight line with no details.
Q13: Both are about being big picture people for larger projects and the successes that can be found in knowing your strengths.
FullA: I'm really an early stage person. I love to make the new thing and so as something gets bigger and more structured , I usually hand it off to people and there's people who love to run stuff that's structured. So when I joined Google we were about 1,200 people and when I left we're over 50 or 60,000 people, so it was sort of fly the plane while you're building the plane. I had gone from working in Silicon Valley and working at Google on a lot of topics. It was fun, incredible teammates. And then I was in Africa for some work with some entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya and I got an email and it said email from the US CTO. And so 33 days later, President Obama called and offered me the job which was incredible. It's an honor to get to serve your country. So when you're doing this work, know that you belong. We all come with different histories and those histories are culture add. There's this weird idea that Silicon Valley had of culture fit. It's very destructive. I don't want you to fit , I want you to add.
FullB: The point of which I decided to be entrepreneur was when talking point just took off. It snowballed from there. So, I have to say my entrepreneurship journey is pretty accidental. Often the public image of an entrepeneur is very glamorous, but actually a lot of my work is not glamorous. And I don't think people see that from the outside. A lot of my role is essentially being a champion. I'm a doer at heart. And it's going from I'm a real doer to I need to delegate or I need to be able to align everyone to get to the same big vision and the big goal. And it's not just me anymore, so kind of a a chicken and an egg where it's both hard and challenging, but exciting.
EventsA: joined Google when it had about 1,200 people — left Google when it had over 50,000 people — went to Africa for work with entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya — received an email from the US CTO — President Obama called and offered the job 33 days later
EventsB: Talking Point took off — I decided to be an entrepreneur

FullB: I worked in technology up until 1998 in which I struck out on my own and I built an engineering company. Q12: Not similar. Story A has a more somber tone and Story B is more of a list of accomplishments.
Q13: I find no direct connection to these stories. Story A is a mother saying she switched paths after her son was born due to health issues and Story B was more about job hopping but finding something they enjoyed doing.
FullA: I'd been a real estate agent , I owned an art gallery. I thought, really, my main pur-goal was to really be a good wife, a good mother , and then my life changed completely. My second son was born with a lung disease. They didn't think he'd make it , he got jaundice, and when I brought him home, he'd lost the ability to wake to feed, and so I mean for me, I thought, watching him struggle to breathe, I'd never take breathing for granted again. And I think that's sort of the beginning of me becoming an environmentalist. And so many times, I feel like I'm paying back the debt, because why should I be so lucky? What can I do to survive this life and be a success, so when the end of my road comes -- which people don't wan na talk about, 'cause the end of the road is gon na come for us -- I can look back  and say, " I really feel good about it ''? And it may not be something globally. I think that if you touch anyone's life , then you're a success.
FullB: from Canada you could ever figure out how to make movies.  Right? So I just figured I'd be going into engineering , so I took lots of maths and sciences all through high school getting ready for that. And at the last minute, I heard about this school that taught film production not too far away , and I got accepted there. Went from film production to animation to computer animation, for me. And, ah, that was inter - really interesting because it had the sort of scientific side, math and science, which I was, you know, really good at. And it had this artistic side. So I could program one minute , and then I could go , you know, fool around with animation, look at cartoons and stuff. I had a few jobs where it would be like, " Oh... great... I got ta go to work ...  '' And, you know, I sort of knew all along, " Okay, I don't want to spend my life doing this . '' You know , you'll find something, you know? And don't worry about it being the perfect thing because I think no decision is absolute, first of all, you know? I've certainly had several changes along the way. A lot of people have.
EventsA: Her second son was born with a lung disease — He got jaundice — She brought him home — He lost the ability to wake to feed — She watched him struggle to breathe

Q12: With the stories presenting this way the overall connection is not there. Ultimately, they both decided on a motivation that drives them, but I don't think it's something that is similar. Story A is more academic focused, and Story B is escaping an abusive relationship with family.
Q13: I can see some correlations mostly that the story tellers were both 15 years of age when they had big life changing events happen. They both had their personal struggles that lead them to pursue a better life.
FullA: I'm an Assistant Professor in Astronomy at California Institute of Technology and Caltech. And I study the dynamic universe. So what I do is, with the beautiful telescopes here at Palomar Observatory, we have some robotic telescopes that are continuously making a movie of the night sky. So we image the sky over and over again and we look for what changed. You might go out there and think universe is the same old thing every time , but it's actually not. It's full of these little explosions, which last for a very short amount of time , so they're very But they're very energetic. It's like cosmic fireworks lighting up our sky. So why did you choose to pursue the degree path that you did? I would say that in my own case, I mean , it was not at all clear that one day I would do a PhD. I grew up on a farm in India with 100 cows and fields of weeds and chick peas. And I had left home when I was 15 , and I was a girl in India in a small place. The entire community was up in arms, you know? There were people like neighbors, relatives , you name it. People I haven't even seen before coming into the house and trying to talk my parents out of this crazy decision to send their daughter alone on this journey into other end of the world to pursue something called Astronomy or whatever that was. The community was completely unsupportive. How did you deal with that? In my case, the best way to deal with it was to just let that fade away in the background and not engage with the two directly, but focus on what is motivating me, on what is giving me joy and just let everything else just fade away in the background.
FullB: My dad turned into a alcoholic and became abusive. I got kicked out. And I'm just trying to , I guess find positivity, and I guess trying to stay happy on top of everything. Coming from someone who dealt with being homeless, what kind of advice can I have? I would never forget being 15 years old, put out of the house, Butt naked, out of a bathtub, Christmas Day in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, at the point of a shotgun, by my stepfather. Until I went into the military, the worst violence I ever saw was at home. So I make a decision, no. I don't wan na live like that. I could've become a stepfather. I could've become another alcoholic, wife beating, child abusing, illiterate loser. And a lot of people would've said, well look where he's from he didn't have a choice. Well I did have a choice. That pain, how I dealt with it. I made the commitment , this will never happen again to another child. And I wan na start with this one in my arms. This stops with me.
EventsA: I studied the dynamic universe — I used robotic telescopes at Palomar Observatory to make a movie of the night sky — I imaged the sky repeatedly to look for changes — I grew up on a farm in India — I left home when I was 15 — The community tried to talk my parents out of sending me away — I decided to focus on my motivation and joy and ignore the community's opposition
EventsB: My dad turned into an alcoholic and became abusive — I got kicked out — I was put out of the house, butt naked, out of a bathtub, on Christmas Day in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, at the point of a shotgun by my stepfather — I went into the military — I made a decision not to live like that — I made the commitment that this will never happen again to another child

FullA: I remember when I turned 30 , I was so depressed on that birthday cuz I felt like I had not accomplished what I needed to and what my friends had accomplished. I just felt that all the people around me had it so much more together than I did , and I should say I started Linda.com when I was 40 , so I'm gon na turn 60 in January. And I didn't touch a computer until I was 28 years old. So I had a lot of life between when I found my career, my calling. And I definitely felt that I wasn't good enough and that I, and I don't know, I think almost , that's almost normal. You're in the majority of people who don't know what they want and what they like until they experience it.
FullB: We had a lot of bad things happen on our tour , we had the double truck suicide bomb, blew up our base , we had multiple mass casualties , there's some really bad stuff that happened out there. I know a lot of guys that have true PTSD, and struggle with it , and they struggled with, finding something that identify themselves with, and have some sort of self worth. My self worth comes from working, and feeding my family, and doing something that I enjoy. The area we have chosen to hunt in is much higher , and in more difficult terrain, but that's where the big bull taur live. Little time just being by yourself in nature that, that's what recharges my batteries. There's just something about being outdoors that does it for me, always has, ever since I was a little kid.
EventsA: I turned 30 — I felt depressed on my 30th birthday — I started Linda.com when I was 40 — I didn't touch a computer until I was 28
EventsB: a double truck suicide bomb happened — the base blew up — multiple mass casualties occurred

FullA: And so I had kind of just spent three years, three-four years, um, just kind of working service jobs. I finally enrolled back in college , but I really didn't know what I wanted to do. But, you know, when you're growing up on the reservation, I mean, you can be creative, but you probably won't get paid for it. It was while I was doing that job that I stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary that I worked on. I mean , I kind of just went with the film thing from there. FullA: Well... what's the chances of makin ' it? About like hittin ' the lottery.  [British accent] I mean, are you saying, " Don't take the chance ''?  I say go to school and get all the degrees you can get, get into business, make all the money you can get. Then start a band or a night - club. Don't do it the hard way like we did.  Does that mean that if you went back, you'd do it differently?  I probably would've went to school.  Why?  I-I'll tell you this : I've been in a lot of trouble in my life. I've been to prison twice. There's just no ...  there's just no reason to have to go through anything that hard, you know? But I didn't see it when I was a kid. If it's a burning desire and you can't think of nothin ' else , you might have a chance. If you think you do and you're willing to roll the dice, then you go do it , but you'll never find out unless you do try, you know? That's the other side of the coin.

I ended up blowing glass and trying it for the first time, and falling in love, like that's it , that's my life.

FullA: And I didn't think anything of it  and then there was a show, a car show. So I went to this car show  and I go all right, washed my car and waxed it , hey, it's kinda cool , so I'll take you there. A company called Go Rhino. They came up to me and said , hey, if we give you our brush cards for free, will you put it on your car, and when you go to the next show, put our sticker on your car? I go, yeah, of course I will. Once I got like a bunch of sponsors and they gave me stuff for free , and I did it. And it ended up on a magazine. It did a cover, this and that. I'm like , I wan na do another one.
FullB: The power of finding out something which people aren't talking about was actually very important to me. And that's basically what I've done much of my life, almost all of it. I'm one of six children. My parents worked in the media. My mother was a writer for women's magazines, my father wrote radio plays and did television, and so we all became very interested in story and narrative. I thought there are people who actually will pay you to do this kind of work , so maybe I ought to go into news. So I spent a lot of my life in print journalism, daily newspapers. I was in the newsroom of the Washington Post all during Watergate. I was both an editor and a reporter. I was sent to Moscow at one point, for four years, as Moscow Bureau Chief, which was an extraordinary encounter with a society whose citizens were denied access to factual information. Period. And it made it even more important to use the powers that are given to us in these open and democratic societies in a way that will inform others. So, what has been part of my life just started out in a certain pattern. It just stayed in that course ever since , and now I'm at NPR. What this place does , and other great icons of journalism, the reporting of fact conveyed in a non-polemical, civil dialogue to readers, listeners, viewers, and bring to them extraordinary information they couldn't possibly have any other way. It comes down to this. Thomas Jefferson, before he wrote the Declaration of Independence, in thinking about this republic, these people were going to try to invent in the late 1700s, made a very clear observation. He basically said that people can not be both ignorant and free.
EventsA: went to a car show — washed and waxed my car — went to the car show with someone — a company called Go Rhino offered free brush cards — put the brush cards on my car — put the Go Rhino sticker on my car at the next show — got a bunch of sponsors who gave me stuff for free — put the sponsors' items on my car — appeared on a magazine cover
EventsB: I spent a lot of my life in print journalism — I was in the newsroom of the Washington Post all during Watergate — I was both an editor and a reporter — I was sent to Moscow for four years as Moscow Bureau Chief — I started working at NPR

FullA: I grew up loving design, loving art. And I kinda knew I wanted to do something like that , but I couldn't pinpoint this job. So I kinda picked a ballpark major that seemed approximately where I wanted to go. Here's a big path to go down , and over the years it'll eventually start narrowing. So what I've actually done over the years is I have a great job where I earn a salary , and it's nice. But on the side I teach coding to women to kinda help them enter the tech world. So it's a good combination of having a great day job, which I enjoy doing and I get fulfillment out of. But then I also get to do these other things that are also interesting to me , and it's a great way to give back to the community using skills and stuff that I enjoy doing.
FullB: I enlisted for three years , and two of those years were spent in France. One year in the southwest, and one year in Paris. And this is where I really learned to eat. Uh, I'm from a Creole Acadian family, but  -- and my mother was a wonderful, wonderful cook. So I grew up with good food, which I think is very important, uh, if you eventually want to write about food. On returning, um...  from France, I went to work as a general assignment reporter at the newspaper, so I went to my editor and I said, " I don't wan na do this anymore , and is there anything else " I can do? '' And when he said, uh, " We need a restaurant reviewer , '' I said, " Why don't we just stop right there? '' And I'm sure of it , there are millions like me, who start a job and find that it's a perfect fit. It's just the greatest feeling you could possibly have.
EventsA: I picked a ballpark major that seemed approximately where I wanted to go — I got a great job where I earned a salary — I taught coding to women to help them enter the tech world
EventsB: I enlisted for three years — I spent two years in France — I spent one year in the southwest of France — I spent one year in Paris — I returned from France — I went to work as a general assignment reporter at the newspaper — I told my editor I didn't want to do the job anymore — My editor said they needed a restaurant reviewer — I decided to become a restaurant reviewer

FullA: My own personal story, I have come to understand that it's a teaching story  and it is my greatest credential, to be really honest with you , is where I've been. I had a childhood that was with a certain privilege but also with a certain degree of violence in my environment and an overlay of alcoholism. And so by the time I was a teenager  and I was slipping into disordered eating, and drug use and abuse, promiscuity, and just poor choices at certain levels. I was really angry. And I didn't know why. And I didn't know what to do with all my emotions. So I was hungry when I could get around good teachers. And I fortunately did and I began dancing. And it was no question in my being that I needed to be moving my body. But it wasn't like okay , and now I'll take steps A, B, and C.  And that's the biggest message I wan na give to all the young people, to know that it's just one right step at a time to build a beautiful career and a life work.
FullB: of airplanes. I mean, just, airplanes was it. I had to fly 'em , I had to build 'em. I had to understand them, study them. The whole nine yards. I was out there in Key West in A7s. It was, um, my second kind of go around ah, to kind of qualify at the ship. And there were plenty of people in front of me that had not qualified and they were sort of farmed off to other careers. Between now and the next three minutes it takes to fly aboard , I'm either gon na get a thumbs up or that's it. You live your life for moments like that. For me, it was, you know, really all about perseverance. Whether it's pride or something else, but failure was just not an option. I'm not gon na wash out. I'm not gon na give up. You have to force yourself out of your comfort zone , I think, a lot of the time just to see who you are and how the world reacts to you.
EventsA: I had a childhood with a certain degree of violence and an overlay of alcoholism — I slipped into disordered eating, drug use and abuse, and promiscuity as a teenager — I was really angry — I was hungry when I could get around good teachers — I began dancing
EventsB: He flew airplanes. — He built airplanes. — He studied airplanes. — He was in Key West in A7s. — He tried to qualify at the ship for the second time. — He faced a moment where he would either get a thumbs up or fail.

FullA: five or six bands, you know, 'cause people would come to me and go , " Oh we got a band, too . '' And by having the most popular band in St. Louis, which was a band called the . We were-became the radio station's band, which meant they played like 80-100 commercials a week. " Hey, the , " we playin ' at 66 Drive-In. '' And it'd be, " Steve on trumpet [do-do-do-do-do-do ] '' So being the popular band in town , I started booking other bands, 'cause when I was already booked, I didn't see any reason to turn people down. I said, " Wait a second, let me see if I can get another band. '' Well, that eventually led to booking 1100 bands. So we were the largest band-booking agency in the country , and I was like 18 years old. So went from local bands, regional bands, to national bands. And the first show we did was in 1969 was the Grateful Dead. You guys sitting here all have ideas. Whether you pursue them ot not is up to you. Don't later on look back and say , " God, I wish " I would've done that. ''
FullB: something with business. I didn't know exactly what I was going to do. My passion wasn't there , but that's where the money was at. And I'm thinking, " This oughta pay the bills , " I ` ma have a family. This is what I'm going to do. " I'm just gon na paint on the side. '' But it got to that point where I couldn't work because I kept hearing that I got to pursue my dream as a, as an artist. That Obama shoe came to me. And I woke up at two o'clock in the morning and I painted that shoe. And I went to the mall and took a picture, put it on MySpace. No big deal. Didn't think nothing of it. And then like the first big thing that happened was the Smithsonian e-mailin ' me and I thought it was a joke. And I cried. I was like, I was almost homeless in January. Like, had I quit, had I quit a month before I made that shoe , had I quit an hour before I made that shoe, and decided, " I'm just gon na forget about art , '' this would have never happened.
EventsA: became the radio station's band — played 80-100 commercials a week — started booking other bands — booked 1100 bands — became the largest band-booking agency in the country — did the first show in 1969 with the Grateful Dead
EventsB: I woke up at two o'clock in the morning — I painted that shoe — I went to the mall and took a picture — I put the picture on MySpace — The Smithsonian emailed me — I cried

Q12: The Linda.com story is about finding passion while the median wealth story is about struggling to relate to others due to wealth issues.
Q13: One story is about getting into tech at whatever age and the other is about the struggles of being a minority in school.
FullA: I remember when I turned 30 , I was so depressed on that birthday cuz I felt like I had not accomplished what I needed to and what my friends had accomplished. I just felt that all the people around me had it so much more together than I did , and I should say I started Linda.com when I was 40 , so I'm gon na turn 60 in January. And I didn't touch a computer until I was 28 years old. So I had a lot of life between when I found my career, my calling. And I definitely felt that I wasn't good enough and that I, and I don't know, I think almost , that's almost normal. You're in the majority of people who don't know what they want and what they like until they experience it.
FullB: The median wealth of a white family is about $ 110,000. The median wealth of black and Latino families combined is somewhere around 15 to $ 20,000. The only way for us to boost that from 15 to 100,000 is to do things like tech. But I feel like when you go to college, you're taking , you're not just in this bubble, you're taking all of your family responsibilities with you. That responsibility, that burden of my family doesn't have money to pay bills, or to pay rent, or to, that stays with you. So then how are you going to class, and you're thinking, okay, let me study for the CS test, but my mom's calling me because there's not enough food to eat, or my sister's calling me because they don't have supplies for school, or new clothes, or anything. And so you're bringing all of those things with you. So finding people to be able to relate to that  are advisors or councilors that you can talk to about those things, that understand you and can relate to you has really helped because they understand me, they get it, Iâ $ ™ m validated. Okay, now I can focus on taking this test, or studying for this exam , or doing whatever else you need to do
EventsA: I turned 30 — I felt depressed on my 30th birthday — I started Linda.com when I was 40 — I didn't touch a computer until I was 28
EventsB: The median wealth of a white family was about $110,000 — The median wealth of black and Latino families combined was around $15,000 to $20,000 — The speaker felt that going to college involved taking family responsibilities along — The speaker's mom called because there was not enough food to eat — The speaker's sister called because they did not have supplies for school or new clothes — The speaker found advisors or counselors who could relate and understand their situation — The speaker felt validated by the advisors or counselors

Q12: Both stories tell of how these people managed to integrate passions into their lives.
Q13: Both of them share the experience of having a passion but not a job in that passion. They both manage to integrate that passion into their lives while keeping their job.
FullA: I grew up loving design, loving art. And I kinda knew I wanted to do something like that , but I couldn't pinpoint this job. But then I also get to do these other things that are also interesting to me , and it's a great way to give back to the community using skills and stuff that I enjoy doing.

Uh, I'm from a Creole Acadian family, but  -- and my mother was a wonderful, wonderful cook. So I grew up with good food, which I think is very important, uh, if you eventually want to write about food. On returning, um...  from France, I went to work as a general assignment reporter at the newspaper, so I went to my editor and I said, " I don't wan na do this anymore , and is there anything else " I can do? '' And when he said, uh, " We need a restaurant reviewer , '' I said, " Why don't we just stop right there? '' And I'm sure of it , there are millions like me, who start a job and find that it's a perfect fit. It's just the greatest feeling you could possibly have.
