Q12: I understand this structure better. I can see now that the bootcamp story involved the person leaving that job for something else. I am not sure what job they do now but it aligns more with the scuba story.
Q13: Both of them explore this concept of finding something you like to do for a job. They diverge when it comes to experience. The bootcamp story implies this person found their "dream job" right away while the scuba story takes a while for the person to realize they truly want to do scuba work.
FullA: When I joined the military, I had literally nothing. I was in a holding center, in a juvenile holding center and my recruiter came and rescued me. Needless to say , when I went to boot camp, I thought it was actually kind of easy and like I had never had so much food before in my life. When I joined the military, I originally signed up as a gunner's mate. I got out, felt like something was missing, I ended up moving out here for a job, and I was, like, guns , I know guns. I can do this job, that was easy. That was my turnaround moment. Okay.
FullB: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
EventsA: I joined the military — My recruiter came and rescued me — I went to boot camp — I signed up as a gunner's mate — I got out — I moved out here for a job
EventsB: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop

Q12: I feel the camera story doesn't share the same passion. It seems they are more interested in money than photography.
Q13: Both of the stories seem to be about aimless people getting inspired to get into a creative job.
FullA: And so I had kind of just spent three years, three-four years, um, just kind of working service jobs. I finally enrolled back in college , but I really didn't know what I wanted to do. And so I ended up , you know, I mean, basically partying my one year in college away. You know , my grades were so bad , I wasn't invited to go back. I think, just kind of at the back of my mind , I had always wanted to do something that was creative. But, you know, when you're growing up on the reservation, I mean, you can be creative, but you probably won't get paid for it. 'Cause when I started doing radio, I absolutely loved it  and, you know , I just ran with it. I tried to do the best job that I could. It was while I was doing that job that I stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary that I worked on. I mean , I kind of just went with the film thing from there. I think you just know when you discover what it is that you want to do.
FullB: how to use his camera. And we were climbing and I took this one shot with it , and then he tried to sell his photography and this one company bought one photo , and it was the one that I took with his camera. And at the time, whatever, I could, I lived off of nothing , you know, and they paid $ 500 for the photo. And I was like, " I could live on $ 500 a month easy living " out of the back of my car! I only have to take 12 photos " a year. And I could live, like, like, " on the road forever. '' One of my mentors, I love it, I mean, it's a simple idea, he's just like, " Commit, " and then figure it out. '' Because you can't get anywhere unless you commit to something. And never think that you won't be questioning your decision when you're like, doing that... 'cause you will. I still do , you know.
EventsA: enrolled back in college — partied the one year in college away — was not invited to go back to college — started doing radio — stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary — worked on the first documentary
EventsB: I took one shot with his camera — he tried to sell his photography — one company bought one photo — they paid $500 for the photo

Q12: They both say they got out of education and tried to work in the field they studied. They end up doing something different in the end.
Q13: They both share having expectations that were challenged when they moved up.
FullA: When I got out of college, I went into the Army Reserve, through the Communications Officer. And ended up back in 89 getting a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory. At an Engineer and Developing Technology, to make weapons smarter, new technology to be able to kind of carry weapons. And so this whole focus was on creating capability. But when you're in the entrepreneurship world and the commercial world, that's a different mindset. Yeah. See, when I worked for the government. I could spend the government money on my ideas. But I'm out here as an entrepreneur , I have to spend my own money. So that was hard for me, to try to get that switch going on. My approach, and what I always tell people is you have to start connecting, networking. And a lot of people thinks that's hard , but it is not really hard. It's just a matter of meeting people , and let them know what you do or what you wan na do.
FullB: My wife and I call ourselves, laughingly, that we're fixers , so it's our job now to go in and help institutions and organizations that are flailing or floundering. Because my wife, myself, we come from a generation where we were told Indians are good with their hands, they're not meant for college. So just get a high school education and go to work. What drove me truly was, I wanted to help my people and I went to Community College , transferred to Black Hills State College , graduated from there in 1985. And immediately after law school, immediately came home to the reservation and there were no jobs in the Legal Profession. But the college had a directors position in institutional development and they hired me. And lo and behold they hired me as the acting president in 1991. So that's become the passion now is to help our children and our grandchildren to succeed and to again, instill with them a higher passion than just a job from eight to five.
EventsA: I got out of college — I went into the Army Reserve through the Communications Officer — I got a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory — I worked at an Engineer and Developing Technology to make weapons smarter — I tried to get the switch going on from government work to entrepreneurship
EventsB: I went to Community College — I transferred to Black Hills State College — I graduated from Black Hills State College in 1985 — I finished law school — I came home to the reservation — The college hired me as a director in institutional development — The college hired me as the acting president in 1991

Q12: These sequences are not similar because in sequence A it is driven by chaos and loss, and sequence B is driven by alignment and discovery.
Q13: I would say the are mostly similar because in one story the artist became a sculptor by accident and the scientist found her calling by chance.
FullA: We are creating soft multi-layered forms that interact with environments. And create a space in cities that open up our imagination and allow us to think about a different way of being. So I had $ 300 and for graduation I got a plane ticket to Bali. And I went off on my own and started walking through the rice fields until I found a little house to rent. I went as a painter, I shipped all my paints and they got lost , and that is how I became a sculpture, because I had no paint. I was in a fishing village , they had fishing twine, and began just experimenting, and from there I had this dream of bringing it back home. I applied to seven art schools and I was rejected by all seven. And that turned out to be the luckiest thing ever in my life, because it forced me to have to learn how to teach myself. The education to do what I do, there is no program. If I had gone to a program, it might have led me somewhere , but it wouldn't have been as authentic a direction. Any kind of life where you're trying to do something new, and creative, your gon na hit rejections all the time. My mom had a saying for that too, it's like just toughen up, let it come at me. Just because you're rejecting me from every single art school I've applied to, that doesn't mean you get to say that I'm not an artist. The thing I had to teach myself after college, was how to hear my own voice, like honestly I just didn't even know it to recognize it. Making decisions is gon na happen to you your whole life , they are always hard, you've got to figure out how to make them. And you have to listen to yourself , and so getting to know yourself is maybe the work of this phase of your life.
FullB: So when I was your age, I think I had just decided that I thought I wanted to try this new field called biomedical engineering, which my dad had encouraged me to explore. And so I was in college , and I was taking classes. And so I had to figure out what to do for the summer , and I was walking by this lab. And on the door of the lab, it said artificial organs. So that sounded really cool to me, because it was like a mix of biomaterials and engineering , and it was very applied. I could understand why you would wan na do nerve regeneration. So that summer, the third summer, was when I finally found the right interface for me. How do you hope your applications will change the role of science in medicine? We've invented these nano sensors that you can inject, that can roam around your body looking for disease, and then emit a signal in the urine. In our long term vision is that this could help with cancer detection in resource poor settings. In just speaking about finding your way, what advice would you give to younger women in science about finding their way in this field, and what road blocks would you like to talk about? So I think for me, one of the biggest road blocks was internal. I don't know if you guys have read about the impostor syndrome. I mean , I certainly had that. I was always worried that I didn't belong at the table, that somehow I'd been some fluke of admission , and it was only a matter of time before people found me out. And in fact it's really, that uniqueness is what makes you different, what makes you valuable.
EventsA: I had $300 — I got a plane ticket to Bali for graduation — I went off on my own — I started walking through the rice fields — I found a little house to rent — I shipped all my paints — My paints got lost — I became a sculpture because I had no paint — I began experimenting with fishing twine — I had a dream of bringing it back home — I applied to seven art schools — I was rejected by all seven art schools — I had to learn how to teach myself — I had to teach myself how to hear my own voice
EventsB: I decided to try the field of biomedical engineering — I was in college taking classes — I walked by a lab with a door that said artificial organs — I found the right interface for me that summer — We invented nano sensors that can be injected to detect disease — I experienced impostor syndrome

Q12: I would say these event sequences are moderately similar because Both stories involve an individual taking something they did for themselves (research/car care) and moving it into a public space where a third party (Investment firm/Go Rhino) sees its value.
Q13: I would say these stories are slightly similar because Both narrators emphasize that their current success wasn't the original goal. Story A notes it "wasn't a straight road," and Story B depicts a hobby (washing/waxing a car) accidentally turning into a professional sponsorship.
FullA: I was the first one to go to college in my family. As an undergraduate, I found a passion for science  and I focused all my attention on biology, neuroscience. And then all of a sudden, my passion shifted from doing research, research, research to understanding how do I get my invention to the market. And then I did an internship with an investment firm and so after doing that , well, okay? I know how they get funded , I really , really like the startup environment. I'm gon na jump into a startup company that I'm really passionate about , and I met the CEO of Recovery Force. So I was brought onto Recovery Force to help promote the research and support the research through funding through the National Institute of Health. And like I say, it wasn't a straight road, what I thought I was gon na be doing today was not what I originally planned 10 or 15 years ago. There's so many avenues into every type of career path. You have to figure out what is best for you, cuz you can go political , you can go into academics , you can stay. There's so many areas where you can provide value.
FullB: And I didn't think anything of it  and then there was a show, a car show. So I went to this car show  and I go all right, washed my car and waxed it , hey, it's kinda cool , so I'll take you there. A company called Go Rhino. They came up to me and said , hey, if we give you our brush cards for free, will you put it on your car, and when you go to the next show, put our sticker on your car? I go, yeah, of course I will. Once I got like a bunch of sponsors and they gave me stuff for free , and I did it. And it ended up on a magazine. It did a cover, this and that. I'm like , I wan na do another one.
EventsA: I went to college — I found a passion for science — My passion shifted from doing research to understanding how to get my invention to the market — I did an internship with an investment firm — I met the CEO of Recovery Force — I was brought onto Recovery Force to help promote and support research through funding from the National Institute of Health
EventsB: went to a car show — washed and waxed my car — went to the car show with someone — a company called Go Rhino offered free brush cards — put the brush cards on my car — put the Go Rhino sticker on my car at the next show — got a bunch of sponsors who gave me stuff for free — put the sponsors' items on my car — appeared on a magazine cover

Q12: These sequences are not similar because Sequence A follows a "Straight Line" model. The narrator moves from an internship to a professional role within the same ecosystem. Sequence B follows a "Broken Line" model, where the traditional path (interviews) fails or causes anxiety, leading to a complete change in strategy.
Q13: I would say these stories are not similar, because in In Story A, the narrator follows a "horizon" already set by her parents. It is a story of alignment with a known industry. In Story B, the narrator’s path is shaped by avoidance; she shied away from traditional jobs because she was "scared to be found out" due to her dyslexia.
FullA: My parents work in insurance as well. So I kinda knew insurance was on my horizon, cuz everyone's, how did you get into insurance? Everyone always has this stereotype that it's boring , but I interned at Travelers actually for three years all through college. It was so interesting, something everyday, I would like to sit there and get lost in coin notes of, my gosh, are we paying for this? It's just crazy to me , it's like reality TV, right, where these claim notes, this is interesting. So I'm currently an underwriter right now and I work in the construction industry. On the agency side of the house, so my job is to go into insurance agencies and just introduce ourselves. Let us know what Travelers has to offer, what I can bring to the table. So I'm really selling myself and it's something that I personally doing , it's something again new every day. The risks are completely different , it's such a severe class of business. So I just have a niche in construction.
FullB: So going back into the time when you were first starting out and into producing, how is it like coping with being dyslexic and trying to work around that? When I came out and I had this film , I then started looking for jobs and I just was trying to figure out what should be the next step and going for job interviews and I was nervous about working for other people. I was worried that people would find out that there were skills that I really couldn't do. So I shied away from certain things and that led me to people who were being independent filmmakers, because they were more peers  and we were all saying, okay , let's go raise money. Let's go try to do this. And in retrospect, it was great and it sort of lead me down an interesting path , but I think it was partly, cuz I was scared to do the other. I was scared that I would be found out. I think the best thing about having LD that helped me in film is I've never been somebody who assumed you wouldn't make mistakes. I've never thought that anything was gon na be a straight line and that you get there quickly. That's just not how I've learned and how my life ever went in school, certainly. So I think that's sort of applicable to most young people that you have to be willing to assume that might happen to you, but don't you think a lot of LD kids already know that. You're already kinda prepared that, that's gon na be true. So I think if you're not ashamed of that, if you own that, it makes it so much easier.
EventsA: I interned at Travelers for three years during college — I worked as an underwriter in the construction industry — I went into insurance agencies to introduce Travelers and what I could offer
EventsB: I came out and had a film — I started looking for jobs — I went for job interviews — I shied away from certain things — I met people who were independent filmmakers — We decided to raise money — We tried to make a film

Q12: These sequences are not similar since sequence A is an autobiography of a career change, while sequence B is an anecdote about social pressure.
Q13: Both stories are very similar because both stories emphasize that the right path isn't a destination you arrive at, but a state of being. Story A calls it constantly evolving, and story B calls it the bliss path.
FullA: a trial court judge who had to have a very analytical mind. Practice law, former prosecutor, former attorney general. But you know how you keep waking up thinking, " There is something else ''?  Right.  I thought that the judgeship, that being a judge, was it. I know now in my heart , it's not a thing. It is constantly evolving and keeping your heart open. Because look! I'm a television personality. I'm a minister. Tapping into your purpose takes a great deal of discipline. Because you have to ask the question every day that you open your eyes.
FullB: And I remember once telling one of my teachers, one of my advisors, that I was gon na play drums at this, um, gig of some kind. And he was like, " Oh, " nice use of your education. '' And it was really discouraging 'cause he didn't see drumming as valid in any way. My partners and I shared a situation where we didn't know exactly what we wanted to do. We had a variety of interests, as opposed to like these people in college who knew exactly what they wanted to do. But let me just tell you, to get off the path is to die. It's not even an option. If you get off of your bliss path, you're dead. You're just growing old. You're just going through the motions.
EventsA: She practiced law. — She was a former prosecutor. — She was a former attorney general. — She thought that being a judge was the ultimate goal. — She realized that being a judge was not the ultimate goal. — She became a television personality. — She became a minister.
EventsB: Told a teacher that I was going to play drums at a gig — The teacher discouraged me by saying 'Oh, nice use of your education'

Q12: Both stories begin with a casual, low-stakes invitation from an authority figure (Grandfather / Shop Owner) that leads to an immediate hands-on experience (Radishes / Bike ride).
Q13: I would say moderately similar because both paths were ignited by an elder or mentor figure story A being the Grandfather, and story B being the bike shop owner, introducing them to a new activity that felt "cool" or "simple."
FullA: I'm 53 years old , I'm trying to decide what I'm gon na do when I grow up. My grandfather farmed , he went out and said , hey do you wan na plant a garden? And I got started that way , we planted some radishes in a spot about this big and I thought it was the coolest thing. I was debating between agriculture and ornamental horticulture, like growing flowers. But I thought if I'm gon na spend my life doing something, I would rather spend my life helping to feed the world. So our job is to develop a hybrid seed that will help the farmer in his business. So if you take two inbreds, like that , and you cross them , that's your hybrid. So people are like, why do you have hybrids? It's like, that's why I have hybrids. Some people feel like , okay , I just wan na make a lot of money. But if you can find something you have a passion for, you love it, you think about it in the morning when you wake up. And then you can figure out an intersection of that thing with something that you can make a living doing , That's a pretty sweet place to be.
FullB: the Olympics. So I always wanted to be on an Olympic team. And uh, my aunt lived next to a bicycle store , and they had a Sunday morning bicycle ride , and I went on the Sunday morning bike ride. And the owner of the store said, " I can make you an Olympic " cycling team. '' So I stopped playing football , I stopped running track, and I rode a bike. It was pretty simple. From my family, I had, I had great support. It was different in school. I always felt I was challenged because I wanted to race a bike or be a professional athlete. And there was no preparation for that, you know? " What do you mean? " You're gon na do this as a profession? '' You know , part of the challenge of youth is to learn, right? It's the puzzle. That's ... that's what makes life interesting. If you have all the answers, then it'd be very boring.
EventsA: Grandfather asked if they wanted to plant a garden — They planted some radishes in a small spot — They debated between agriculture and ornamental horticulture — They decided to spend their life helping to feed the world — They developed a hybrid seed to help farmers — They crossed two inbred plants to create a hybrid
EventsB: I went on the Sunday morning bike ride — The owner of the store said he could make me an Olympic cycling team — I stopped playing football — I stopped running track — I rode a bike

Q12: One story is about a complicated mission with many steps while the other is a simple change from law to baking.
Q13: Both stories are about following a strong feeling inside and changing life direction because of it. The details are different but the main idea is the same.
FullA: consumer grade cameras, and I bought one in 1989 and said to myself, " One day I'm gon na " make a documentary that makes a difference. '' A friend of a friend came and said, " Do you have a minute? " Let's - let's, ah, go out and get a drink. " I want to talk to you. '' And he said, " I was, I was " in the Russian far East investigating the trade " in Siberian tiger pelts , and they offered to sell me women . '' " Let's do something about it. '' He came to me because I had done international human rights work and I knew a lot about women's issues. It wasn't something I was familiar with in 1995. So I started researching it and then just quit my job two weeks later. and pitched up his office and was like, " Okay. I can wait tables if I need to " in order to make this happen. '' And um, I created a phony company called International Liaison Specializing in Foreign Models, Escorts, and Entertainers. And then we posed as foreign buyers interested in purchasing women. When you have the privilege of freedom and, you know, and-and the opportunity that that affords you , then I think you have a responsibility to , you know, to try to ensure that there - there is actually freedom.
FullB: from lawyer to baker began very quickly once I started practicing law, because I kinda put this out, I didn't like it. It didn't speak to me. You can't make something three-dimensional and share it with other people. It doesn't have a nice smell to it. [Roadtripper # 1] Yeah.  You can't cut it and ask people to eat it. [Roadtripper # 1] Yeah.  And ah, I started baking in 1999. People started liking it. I was like, " There's something " happening here that I need to pay attention to. '' It matters so much just to, um, to follow up that little whisper or voice that's in your head or in your heart. That's the one. It's the one. It feels like it's not , it's scary , you want to deny it , you want to say, " No, I'm going to ignore it . '' But don't do it.
EventsA: bought a consumer grade camera in 1989 — a friend of a friend asked to get a drink to talk — he said he was investigating the trade in Siberian tiger pelts in the Russian far East — he said they offered to sell him women — started researching women's issues in 1995 — quit job two weeks later — pitched up at his office and said he could wait tables to make it happen — created a phony company called International Liaison Specializing in Foreign Models, Escorts, and Entertainers — posed as foreign buyers interested in purchasing women
EventsB: I started practicing law — I started baking in 1999 — People started liking my baking

Q12: Story A is about personal growth and finding a career later in life. Story B is about traumatic events and danger. They are very different
Q13: Story A is about feeling behind in life and finding a career later on. Story B is about finding peace through work and being outdoors
FullA: I remember when I turned 30 , I was so depressed on that birthday cuz I felt like I had not accomplished what I needed to and what my friends had accomplished. I just felt that all the people around me had it so much more together than I did , and I should say I started Linda.com when I was 40 , so I'm gon na turn 60 in January. And I didn't touch a computer until I was 28 years old. So I had a lot of life between when I found my career, my calling. And I definitely felt that I wasn't good enough and that I, and I don't know, I think almost , that's almost normal. You're in the majority of people who don't know what they want and what they like until they experience it.
FullB: We had a lot of bad things happen on our tour , we had the double truck suicide bomb, blew up our base , we had multiple mass casualties , there's some really bad stuff that happened out there. I know a lot of guys that have true PTSD, and struggle with it , and they struggled with, finding something that identify themselves with, and have some sort of self worth. My self worth comes from working, and feeding my family, and doing something that I enjoy. The area we have chosen to hunt in is much higher , and in more difficult terrain, but that's where the big bull taur live. Little time just being by yourself in nature that, that's what recharges my batteries. There's just something about being outdoors that does it for me, always has, ever since I was a little kid.
EventsA: I turned 30 — I felt depressed on my 30th birthday — I started Linda.com when I was 40 — I didn't touch a computer until I was 28
EventsB: a double truck suicide bomb happened — the base blew up — multiple mass casualties occurred

Q12: Both describe a series of events, but one follows a legal career and a powerful moment of representation, while the other is about a totally different kind of job. The goals and progresssions are very different.
Q13: Both talk about careers and learning along the way, but one is about becoming a judge and giving back to the community while the other is about building a tech career through hustle and hard work.
FullA: I am judge Elaine Marshall. I am the Director and Presiding Judge for the City of Houston Municipal Courts. And I was going to go to college to be a doctor. That worked out real well until biology, and cut them up and bleeding and all that stuff. You couldn't handle it. Nah, that just wasn't. Everyone kept saying that you talk so much , you probably should go to law school. When I first became a prosecutor, they would send us to different schools for career day. And when I became a judge, did same thing. The thing that stuck out to me the most was one time I went to a school as a judge , and they told them who I was and they said , all rise. So the kids stood up and four of the black kids that were sitting on the thing went , she's black. Wow. And it was like, yeah. Now you see. I came up just like they did, in a public school and those sorts of things. So it's good to give back. You will find so many different places where you can go that you'll make a difference.
FullB: I went to school, because I loved coding and I wanted to develop a coding career. And I reached out to a band that I liked and said, hey, long shot , but could I make you guys a website? And to my surprise, they emailed back like ten minutes later. And they're like yeah, actually , we'd really love for you to make us a website. How about two t-shirts and a CD in trade for it and I thought that was a great bargain. And so I made them a website. So yeah , I mean, I did my first or my second website for two t-shirts and a CD. So technically, not a fair market trade. Yeah. But at the time, the value proposition for me was way higher. And so you've got ta choose your shots. Yeah. And you will definitely do things in the course of your career that will be undervalued  and the trick is to choose the right ones, and to not do it too much. So throughout your career and in particular in those formative stages, you've got to go the extra mile. You've got ta work really hard. There's just no shortcut to it. Every now and then, one in a million gets lucky literary wins the rotary and everybody else whose ever achieved some great level of success has worked incredibly hard to get there.
EventsA: She decided not to go to college to be a doctor — She became a prosecutor — She went to different schools for career day as a prosecutor — She became a judge — She went to a school as a judge — The kids at the school stood up and said all rise — Four black kids at the school expressed surprise that she was black
EventsB: I went to school — I reached out to a band that I liked and asked if I could make them a website — They emailed back ten minutes later — They agreed to have me make them a website in exchange for two t-shirts and a CD — I made them a website

Q12: One story is about guidance leading to education and finding a career fit while the other is about starting a business and rebuilding after a crisis.
Q13: They both talk about careers, but Story A is about exploring options and getting guidance, while Story B is about setbacks survival and proving self worth after a crisis.
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I worked in technology up until 1998 in which I struck out on my own and I built an engineering company. Had good contracts. 9/11 hits a couple of years later, and all of a sudden a lot of the major corporations and people  I was dealing with, their stocks fell, and they stopped giving work. I went and became a screener at the airport. I want you to think about this. I worked for a major corporation, I'm a screener, people that were my clients and then I work with , were coming through the airport. You got me reminiscing and thinking back here. But, I stuck to my principles. I knew I was better than this, all right? And I had a plan. So I took what I knew, even though I was working in terrorism and mass transit, I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl. And so, I knew from that, I was as good or better than anybody there.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I struck out on my own — I built an engineering company — 9/11 happened — major corporations and people I was dealing with stopped giving work — I became a screener at the airport — I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl

Q12: Both show a clear journey over time where they move from an earlier time in their journey to a later outcome
Q13: Both stories are about people finding purpose in their work and growing into roles they really care about. The details are different but both focus on passion, personal growth, and ending up where they feel they belong
FullA: So I'm a program manager at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and I work in our Criminal Justice Reform Department and we're working to safely reform the criminal justice system. Reduce incarceration while keeping our neighborhood safe , and it's an exciting role , I really love what I do. I love meeting the people who've been impacted by our criminal justice system. I'm also system-impacted. I ultimately spent 12 years in state corrections and it was definitely the toughest part of my life. I came out and I owned what got me incarcerated. Really was able to dive down deep in myself and really think how did I get there. One of things that it's given me is it's given me a perspective that other programs managers that are working in criminal justice reform don't have. I don't know how many different ways we have to recycle a plastic bottle, right? We think of people as disposable  and we've got ta shift the narrative around that, right? We don't want people leaving our jails and prisons and not having opportunities to thrive and contribute. I think there's a lot of work to be done here. And it's a really crazy turn of events of where I've ended up in life , but I feel like I'm where I should be.
FullB: My name is Tom Arviso, Jr. , I'm the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated. And I've been here about 27 years now. And I started here as a college intern. And I studied journalism with the intent of becoming a sports writer. That was my passion. But once I got here to the Navajo Times, things just kind of gradually evolved , and I just kind of rose through the ranks to the point where now I'm running the company. I never looked back ever since I started doing that and just been trying to go and do as much as I can possibly do in regards to telling stories, telling people stories, and being good at it. Being right. Being ethical. Being honest. This profession, it's a field where you really have to have a passion for what you're doing, a belief in being a storyteller. If you're sincere about what you do, about your craft, about being a good journalist, then things will fall into place for you if you're patient.
EventsA: I spent 12 years in state corrections — I came out — I owned what got me incarcerated — I thought deeply about how I got incarcerated
EventsB: Tom Arviso, Jr. started as a college intern at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. rose through the ranks at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. became the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated.

Q12: One worked for 9 years, the other just drifted
Q13: Both are about finding what you want to do
FullA: And so I had kind of just spent three years, three-four years, um, just kind of working service jobs. I finally enrolled back in college , but I really didn't know what I wanted to do. And so I ended up , you know, I mean, basically partying my one year in college away. You know , my grades were so bad , I wasn't invited to go back. I think, just kind of at the back of my mind , I had always wanted to do something that was creative. But, you know, when you're growing up on the reservation, I mean, you can be creative, but you probably won't get paid for it. 'Cause when I started doing radio, I absolutely loved it  and, you know , I just ran with it. I tried to do the best job that I could. It was while I was doing that job that I stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary that I worked on. I mean , I kind of just went with the film thing from there. I think you just know when you discover what it is that you want to do.
FullB: and uh, loved it. You know, I was in one of those graduate programs and on, you know, a good salary , and I enjoyed it , but I always felt like I couldn't express myself enough and there was perhaps, ah, some environment somewhere where I could really make a difference. And you know , I was almost nine years in the bank. I could have gotten my superannuation and been set up with a nice house somewhere. I didn't wan na be that person in years, you know, in years in the future, uh, and not have had taken risks. And I was in a very comfortable environment , and I just didn't have this need to take a risk , and I was like excited about taking a risk and not really knowing what the outcome would be. And uh, we didn't know a whole lot back then , but we just made our classes so much fun. People would laugh the whole way through , and so as a result, it just exploded. We went from 23 people our first night to about 200 people after eight weeks. If you've got that feeling inside that there's something else, it's very hard to get rid of -- which is a good thing. I think there's that something driving you to say , " Well there's something else " out there . ''
EventsA: enrolled back in college — partied the one year in college away — was not invited to go back to college — started doing radio — stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary — worked on the first documentary
EventsB: I was in one of those graduate programs — I was almost nine years in the bank — We made our classes fun — The number of people in the class grew from 23 to about 200 after eight weeks

Q12: Both about change
Q13: They were both about transitions and following flow
FullA: I don't think I'll ever find a job that I'm as good at as I was at being an infantry officer. I went from being a captain in the Marine Corps, in command of 950 marines and sailors. Every Friday I would go out to our Liberty Formation before I launched them for the weekend , and you just see this massive sea of servicemen and women that I was in command of. It was awe inspiring and humbling and it was just an awesome opportunity. I ended up taking a job with a medical IT company. And I was in a cubicle next to a 23 year old, looking through spreadsheets to see if there were duplicate hospitals in them. You couldn't have wasted my experience or skill sets more , but that's all part of it. You can not expect your first employer or the people that you're interviewing with or the community you moved to , you can't expect them to know everything about you and understand your value right off the bat. You have to go in and you've got ta show them. You've got to compete again and so I had a lot of fun. Figuring out, okay, how do I become a non profit leader and build a non profit? By the way at the same time, I've also got ta fight these guys that wan na beat me up on national TV because that helped me pay my bills as well. So trying to juggle all those while we were having kids and everything , it was a wild, crazy transition for sure.
FullB: Wasn't a good experience. Didn't think I was gon na like practicing law and definitely didn't like where I was doing it. And I think like a lot of people who are in their first real job, you get a little freaked out when you're unhappy. Because, " What kind of risks " am I taking if I leave this place? " Am I ever gon na get a job again? " What does it say about me as a person that I've made " the wrong choice here? '' It's nonsense. You just go on to the next thing and you kind of keep going. I finally kind of decided to make the jump and went to another firm , and it was absolutely night and day difference. All the kind of weird directions that my career has taken wasn't the result of plotting it out even at that time. A lot of it was happenstance. Just, you kind of work hard, keep your eyes open.
EventsA: He was a captain in the Marine Corps in command of 950 marines and sailors — He went out to the Liberty Formation before launching the servicemen and women for the weekend — He took a job with a medical IT company — He looked through spreadsheets to see if there were duplicate hospitals — He figured out how to become a non profit leader and build a non profit — He fought on national TV to help pay his bills
EventsB: Did not like practicing law — Did not like where I was doing it — Decided to make the jump — Went to another firm

Q12: The narratives and sequence are not the same
Q13: They are about careers
FullA: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
FullB: I always knew I wanted to do journalism since I was a little kid. I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade. But by the time I graduated , I still didn't know if I wanted to do newspaper, or if I wanted to do TV and I ended up doing TV. And I just feel like, I just really enjoy just talking to people, in general. And I feel like that was why I wanted to do journalism, because everyone's so different, everybody has different stories , and people are just interesting. I love watching TV , I like watching TV, but I never really thought about the possibilities of working in TV. It's just been such an amazing experience. It's a hard job , but it's, I think it's really rewarding. I think it's a dream job that I didn't realize I had. I don't always know if I'm making the right decision while I'm making them. I feel sometimes like, am I stunting myself in my career? Am I where I'm supposed to be right now? Am I doing all that I can to get to the next point? But you don't always know if you're doing the right thing , but I don't know , it works out. I feel like things work themselves out. They do. They just do.
EventsA: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science
EventsB: I was writing for my school paper in fifth grade — I graduated — I ended up doing TV

Q12: I can't see similarities
Q13: They were about completely different things
FullA: A lot of teachers feel like they have to be this like, alter ego. Like for me, honestly who I am in the classroom is who I am in life. Did you have any, like, uh-oh moments, when you were like , I have no idea what I'm doing, like once you were in the classroom? All the time. All the time and I still kinda do. A lot of people thought that I was just a fun teacher. Oh he's just , all his kids, they're not really learning anything. I hate when teachers think that just because their class is rigorous that they can't have any fun. It's not until when my test scores came back, my AP scores and they were better than theirs , you don't even have to say anything. Yeah. I am very German but I am very about living life and working hard and being rigorous but having fun the entire time we're doing it. Because that's life. I really come to work with a smile on my face every single day. And that's what it's all about, right?
FullB: executive producer for a network. Um , that led into the Commonwealth Games  and uh, I did the ceremonies for that and they were received well. That led to an invitation to come to Los Angeles , and I ended up being director of production for the LA games ' ceremonies in ' 84. Ended up in 1990 doing the Singapore Independence celebrations. Ninety-two, I was exec producer to Barcelona Olympics ceremonies, then ultimately, the Sydney Olympics, the ceremonies. New Year's Eve ceremonies for Sydney's building up to the millennium. Then I returned to America again to live. I sort of spent a lot of time traveling backwards and forwards. So in terms of a career path, mine was totally unpredictable. It wasn't anything that I ever had in mind at the beginning that this is what I was gon na do. So in the end, my advice to you would be totally hedonistic. Just get out there and do whatever you want to do , but it's got ta feel right.
EventsA: The narrator had moments of uncertainty in the classroom — The narrator's test scores and AP scores came back better than others
EventsB: did the ceremonies for the Commonwealth Games — received the ceremonies well — received an invitation to come to Los Angeles — became director of production for the LA games' ceremonies in 1984 — did the Singapore Independence celebrations in 1990 — was executive producer for the Barcelona Olympics ceremonies in 1992 — was executive producer for the Sydney Olympics ceremonies — did New Year's Eve ceremonies for Sydney's millennium buildup — returned to America to live

Q12: One is about doing, the other is about wanting
Q13: One is about doing your dream, the other is about why you don't do your dream
FullA: Made a couple bucks and I wanted to go race. I read about a guy in Motor Trend Magazine who raced at Pike's Peak and he was just basically an average guy. And we're actually friends now , his name is C Van Tune, he was the editor at Motor Trend. I'm like, man, if that guy can do it , maybe I can do it. So in 1991, I bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4. I thought, well, I wan na go race at Pike's Peak. I got the rulebook, had to put a roll cage in it. And I thought, well, maybe I could modify it too, to make it to go faster. Before I went to Pike's Peak, I read about a race in Nevada called the Silver State Classic. It's a 90 mile race in Nevada where they take a public highway, a state highway , and they just shut it down. And you go as fast as you can go from one city to the next. And so I averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles. So I went 90 miles in 34 minutes. And at that point, I was totally hooked. I got fourth place in the race.
FullB: You know , you're not becoming a doctor where you're changing people's lives physically, but sometimes you make people's lives emotionally a little better. When I was about three years old, I said, " Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, " what do you call that? '' She says, " A comic, a comedian. '' I went, " That's what I wan na be. '' I think a lot of people know what they wan na do , but they don't have the courage to really follow it. I mean, maybe you have maybe a perception that we have never a waning moment of thinking, " This isn't worth it. '' Or doubt or " Oh my gosh '' all the time -- all the time, especially as an actor. The fear of failure is-is what gets you all the time. When you're actually going through the failure, you're like,  " How am I gon na get out of this? " This is bad , but how am I gon na get out of it ? '' But the fear of failure is what keeps people from trying anyway.
EventsA: bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4 in 1991 — got the rulebook for Pike's Peak race — put a roll cage in the car — read about the Silver State Classic race in Nevada — raced 90 miles in the Silver State Classic — averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles — finished fourth place in the Silver State Classic race
EventsB: I said, 'Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, what do you call that?' — She said, 'A comic, a comedian.' — I said, 'That's what I wanna be.'

FullA: when I was four, but um ... growing up without a mother -- 'cause she died when I was six -- growing up with just my dad and my brother , I was obviously very, um, just very independent and strong-willed. And my dad's best friend was a stockbroker, and for some reason, because I was so good with money, that I decided that I was, that I would be a really good stockbroker. And fortunately, throughout high school, we had work exchange and work experience, and um , they used to send me off with all sorts of random checks and things to, you know, with million dollars in my hand to go and deliver somewhere, and I had no idea where I was going or how to get there. And being the little surfy chick that I was , it just made me realize that wasn't the avenue I wanted to go down. Ultimately, to become successful in anything , you have to be relatively selfish. You have to be so one-dimensional. I also believe that there's no such thing as a mistake , it's only a learning experience. The only mistake is not learning from it. But even then, you're just gon na be given the opportunity to learn it and learn it and learn it until such time as you do. So I made the same " mistake '' over and over again until I actually got the lesson.
FullB: They would always listen to this great jazz station called KADX. And one, for I just saw what they were doing  and they were having the best time, laughing and listening to this great music , and I said, " Can I, can I do that with you next week ? '' He said, " Okay, son. '' So I actually came to sort of a reckoning in my life at a very early age , and it was the last time that I worked at a fast-food restaurant. And I remember on that Friday, before I quit , I said that was the last time I was gon na ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke. I would oftentimes get a little disheartened , and I would never, of course, tell them. When I would hear parents tell my students that, you know, " You got ta grow up and get a real job, '' I would think that a real job that is a s-s-successful job for someone is a job that is driven by their passion and their love, and not a job that's just there because you're getting the paycheck.
EventsA: Her mother died when she was six — She decided she would be a stockbroker — She was sent off with million dollars in checks to deliver somewhere — She realized being a stockbroker was not the avenue she wanted to go down — She made the same mistake over and over again until she learned the lesson
EventsB: They were having the best time, laughing and listening to music. — I asked if I could do that with them next week. — He said okay. — I came to a reckoning in my life at a very early age. — I worked at a fast-food restaurant for the last time. — I said that was the last time I was going to ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke.
