Then I returned to America again to live. I sort of spent a lot of time traveling backwards and forwards. So in terms of a career path, mine was totally unpredictable. It wasn't anything that I ever had in mind at the beginning that this is what I was gon na do. So in the end, my advice to you would be totally hedonistic. Just get out there and do whatever you want to do , but it's got ta feel right.
EventsA: The narrator had moments of uncertainty in the classroom — The narrator's test scores and AP scores came back better than others
EventsB: did the ceremonies for the Commonwealth Games — received the ceremonies well — received an invitation to come to Los Angeles — became director of production for the LA games' ceremonies in 1984 — did the Singapore Independence celebrations in 1990 — was executive producer for the Barcelona Olympics ceremonies in 1992 — was executive producer for the Sydney Olympics ceremonies — did New Year's Eve ceremonies for Sydney's millennium buildup — returned to America to live

FullA: I was born and raised in Chicago , but my first language is Spanish because everybody in my family spoke Spanish. From the moment I learned a bit of English, I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter. I started seeing kind of more of how the disenfranchised were being treated. This was pretty much the ah-hah moment for me and the other co-founder Victor Arellano. We were at the Department of Homeland Security here in Chicago. I was gon na do an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test. So this Polish couple gets called , federal agent comes up that's gon na administer the test. And he says , well, where's your interpreter? And they were just kind of like, I don't know. And she yells out at the crowd in the waiting room, does anybody here speak Polish? Some lady raises her hand , she's like, I speak Polish. So mind you , now one of the most important interviews of this couple's life lays in the balance of a person that says she speaks Polish, which she very well might. But how do you know how much her proficiency is in that language? And that's kinda like, where we're just like, you know what? There has to be a better way , there has to be a better way. So that's kind of where Interpreter Tap was born.
FullB: and um, co-owner of two restaurants, and how did you get from where you were at our age to where you are right now?  [New Zealand accent] I suppose at your age, I left school and really the same thing, I was totally unsure of what I wanted to do. I had um , a burning passion, which was not to cook -- mine was to travel. Went to Israel and worked on a kabutz for six months  'cause I met an Israeli guy and thought, " Oh this is quite cool . '' And started cooking in the kitchens there , and I was cooking with a couple of women who said to me then, " My god, you've got such a good talent for this. '' Then came home and thought, " Yup, this is what I'm gon na do. " I can just sort of live at Mum and Dad's " and save and go through uni, '' and then just started from there.  What kept you from just going out and doing something else?  'Cause I knew I couldn't, I didn't wan na do anything else. I knew, no matter how hard it was gon na be, I had to just keep going. I just had to keep going. 'Cause really, the whole thing is, you're focusing on what you wan na do.
EventsA: I learned a bit of English — I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter — I started seeing how the disenfranchised were being treated — I and Victor Arellano were at the Department of Homeland Security in Chicago — I did an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test — A federal agent asked the Polish couple where their interpreter was — A woman in the waiting room said she spoke Polish — Interpreter Tap was born
EventsB: left school — went to Israel — worked on a kabutz for six months — met an Israeli guy — started cooking in the kitchens there — cooked with a couple of women who praised my talent — came home — decided to pursue cooking — started university

FullA: Born and raised here in Detroit. I went to public school. I knew I wanted to go to college but didn't know how I was gon na get there. Had a very supportive family, but financially , we didn't have any money tucked away. And fortunately, I was able to get a scholarship to a college. Got my Bachelor's degree in communication. Out of college, I did sales for a number of years just kind of really trying to find my way. And my wife was a student here at Wayne Community College , they had an opportunity, an opening on the phones. One day the chancellor of the college was on the other end and I had no clue. And I was just excited to be answering phones for the college. And he wanted to meet me and I had opportunities to advance from there. Now I am the associate vice chancellor for students services. So, I tell everybody, I'm not supposed to be here, statistically speaking. I'm a black male  and I grew up in Detroit with all the gang violence, with all the drug violence. So, don't be defined by the neighborhoods that you came from. Don't be defined by whether or not you're a first generation college student, whether you're a minority. Whatever that is, you can go and do and be whoever you wan na be.
FullB: You were there for Toy Story and. I was there for Toy, that's what I was hired to do, is Toy Story. Art direct Toy Story. Cool. Every project is so different. Every four years is a four year graduate course in the subject matter of that film. And just to take advantage of that, have fun with some research. Once you get interested in something, go and find out as much as you can about it. It's not that hard to do, especially with the Internet. You can always get a dozen books on the subject and just read through them, and just keep doing that. That's really it.
EventsA: I got a scholarship to a college — I got my Bachelor's degree in communication — I did sales for a number of years — My wife was a student at Wayne Community College — I answered phones for the college — The chancellor of the college wanted to meet me — I had opportunities to advance from there — I became the associate vice chancellor for student services
EventsB: You were there for Toy Story. — I was hired to art direct Toy Story.

FullA: So I'm a program manager at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and I work in our Criminal Justice Reform Department and we're working to safely reform the criminal justice system. Reduce incarceration while keeping our neighborhood safe , and it's an exciting role , I really love what I do. I love meeting the people who've been impacted by our criminal justice system. I'm also system-impacted. I ultimately spent 12 years in state corrections and it was definitely the toughest part of my life. I came out and I owned what got me incarcerated. Really was able to dive down deep in myself and really think how did I get there. One of things that it's given me is it's given me a perspective that other programs managers that are working in criminal justice reform don't have. I don't know how many different ways we have to recycle a plastic bottle, right? We think of people as disposable  and we've got ta shift the narrative around that, right? We don't want people leaving our jails and prisons and not having opportunities to thrive and contribute. I think there's a lot of work to be done here. And it's a really crazy turn of events of where I've ended up in life , but I feel like I'm where I should be.
FullB: My name is Tom Arviso, Jr. , I'm the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated. And I've been here about 27 years now. And I started here as a college intern. And I studied journalism with the intent of becoming a sports writer. That was my passion. But once I got here to the Navajo Times, things just kind of gradually evolved , and I just kind of rose through the ranks to the point where now I'm running the company. I never looked back ever since I started doing that and just been trying to go and do as much as I can possibly do in regards to telling stories, telling people stories, and being good at it. Being right. Being ethical. Being honest. This profession, it's a field where you really have to have a passion for what you're doing, a belief in being a storyteller. If you're sincere about what you do, about your craft, about being a good journalist, then things will fall into place for you if you're patient.
EventsA: I spent 12 years in state corrections — I came out — I owned what got me incarcerated — I thought deeply about how I got incarcerated
EventsB: Tom Arviso, Jr. started as a college intern at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. rose through the ranks at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. became the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated.

Q12: Both event sequences are about people starting new jobs/careers however the trajectories are very different
Q13: Both stories involve someone starting a new career
FullA: have the confidence or believe in some way or some fashion they'll find themselves. It always terrified me. I have four degrees and never really had any interest in any of them. I was miserable, except in my off-hours, when I was chasing whatever that I liked to do for fun, which was music and comic books and movies. And what happened was, I lost my job, left my wife , and I was homeless. Had no place to live. A guy that was uh, in a search firm, a headhunter, knew all my passions about comic books and movies and music. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. '' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. You don't want to be put into that position of luck ... making a difference in your life at a later age. Be in charge of your destiny now.
FullB: I always grew up with tea being a stable at our dining table. One of my colleagues from my previous job, knew a recruiter at eBay and he recommended me and they ended up hiring me. But one day I was trying to make loose-leaf tea at my desk , and by the time I would make it , I would be late for a meeting. And every time I tried to use tea bags instead, I was never satisfied with the quality because it was not as flavorful, it didn't have as much aroma. That was my first point of inspiration to think about the idea for tea drops. It took me about a year and a half of experimenting. I would spend my weekends and my week nights kind of blending and I was obsessed with figuring it out. And once I had that, I started sharing it with my colleagues and friends and family. Now we're available in over 1,600 retail stores. My logic was, even if this failed, even if nothing ever comes of it, I know I would have gained so much in trying
EventsA: lost my job — left my wife — was homeless — a headhunter told me Marvel Comics was looking for somebody with a business background who reads comic books — became president of Marvel Comics
EventsB: A colleague recommended me to a recruiter at eBay — They hired me — I tried to make loose-leaf tea at my desk — I tried to use tea bags instead — I thought about the idea for tea drops — I spent about a year and a half experimenting — I started sharing tea drops with colleagues, friends, and family — Tea drops became available in over 1,600 retail stores

Q12: Both event sequences describe how each person initially started out in their career and the steps they took to advance in their careers
Q13: Both stories involve a person describing how they started out working in their respective fields
FullA: My parents work in insurance as well. So I kinda knew insurance was on my horizon, cuz everyone's, how did you get into insurance? Everyone always has this stereotype that it's boring , but I interned at Travelers actually for three years all through college. It was so interesting, something everyday, I would like to sit there and get lost in coin notes of, my gosh, are we paying for this? It's just crazy to me , it's like reality TV, right, where these claim notes, this is interesting. So I'm currently an underwriter right now and I work in the construction industry. On the agency side of the house, so my job is to go into insurance agencies and just introduce ourselves. Let us know what Travelers has to offer, what I can bring to the table. So I'm really selling myself and it's something that I personally doing , it's something again new every day. The risks are completely different , it's such a severe class of business. So I just have a niche in construction.
FullB: So going back into the time when you were first starting out and into producing, how is it like coping with being dyslexic and trying to work around that? When I came out and I had this film , I then started looking for jobs and I just was trying to figure out what should be the next step and going for job interviews and I was nervous about working for other people. I was worried that people would find out that there were skills that I really couldn't do. So I shied away from certain things and that led me to people who were being independent filmmakers, because they were more peers  and we were all saying, okay , let's go raise money. Let's go try to do this. And in retrospect, it was great and it sort of lead me down an interesting path , but I think it was partly, cuz I was scared to do the other. I was scared that I would be found out. I think the best thing about having LD that helped me in film is I've never been somebody who assumed you wouldn't make mistakes. I've never thought that anything was gon na be a straight line and that you get there quickly. That's just not how I've learned and how my life ever went in school, certainly. So I think that's sort of applicable to most young people that you have to be willing to assume that might happen to you, but don't you think a lot of LD kids already know that. You're already kinda prepared that, that's gon na be true. So I think if you're not ashamed of that, if you own that, it makes it so much easier.
EventsA: I interned at Travelers for three years during college — I worked as an underwriter in the construction industry — I went into insurance agencies to introduce Travelers and what I could offer
EventsB: I came out and had a film — I started looking for jobs — I went for job interviews — I shied away from certain things — I met people who were independent filmmakers — We decided to raise money — We tried to make a film

Q12: Both event sequences describe how the person came to work in their respective fields
Q13: Both stories involve a person starting a career where they did a lot of learning as they went
FullA: It's sort of a pattern in my life. I didn't get my culinary degree -- I got thrown out -- but I mean , I went and apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe , so, that's really where I learned. But going from a fine dining chef to running , you know, a beer bar seems like it's a downgrade in a way, but it really wasn't. It was actually , there's a lot of things that are more challenging about what I do. We didn't have a business plan. Didn't write one , there's no such thing. I've never written a business plan in my life. Yeah, I learned everything on the fly. I learned how to tap kegs -- never tapped a beer keg in my life. It's been amazingly educational, but sometimes you just learn by doing. Again, there's no school for this. Culinary school didn't teach me this. No one told me what to do -- not my dad, my mom. I did what I wanted to do without any exterior influence. When you say, " Where do you " find the motivation? '' The only motivation that's ever genuine comes from within.
FullB: So when I was your age, I think I had just decided that I thought I wanted to try this new field called biomedical engineering, which my dad had encouraged me to explore. And so I was in college , and I was taking classes. And so I had to figure out what to do for the summer , and I was walking by this lab. And on the door of the lab, it said artificial organs. So that sounded really cool to me, because it was like a mix of biomaterials and engineering , and it was very applied. I could understand why you would wan na do nerve regeneration. So that summer, the third summer, was when I finally found the right interface for me. How do you hope your applications will change the role of science in medicine? We've invented these nano sensors that you can inject, that can roam around your body looking for disease, and then emit a signal in the urine. In our long term vision is that this could help with cancer detection in resource poor settings. In just speaking about finding your way, what advice would you give to younger women in science about finding their way in this field, and what road blocks would you like to talk about? So I think for me, one of the biggest road blocks was internal. I don't know if you guys have read about the impostor syndrome. I mean , I certainly had that. I was always worried that I didn't belong at the table, that somehow I'd been some fluke of admission , and it was only a matter of time before people found me out. And in fact it's really, that uniqueness is what makes you different, what makes you valuable.
EventsA: I got thrown out of my culinary degree program — I apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe — I went from being a fine dining chef to running a beer bar — I learned how to tap kegs
EventsB: I decided to try the field of biomedical engineering — I was in college taking classes — I walked by a lab with a door that said artificial organs — I found the right interface for me that summer — We invented nano sensors that can be injected to detect disease — I experienced impostor syndrome

Q12: Event sequence A describes a person experiencing a "reckoning" about their dissatisfaction in working in the fast food industry and Event sequence B is more of a very brief timeline of how Netflix was started
Q13: Both stories involve a person who had a job they didn't really like, and later on tells how they were able to get started in the jobs that they really wanted
FullA: They would always listen to this great jazz station called KADX. And one, for I just saw what they were doing  and they were having the best time, laughing and listening to this great music , and I said, " Can I, can I do that with you next week ? '' He said, " Okay, son. '' So I actually came to sort of a reckoning in my life at a very early age , and it was the last time that I worked at a fast-food restaurant. And I remember on that Friday, before I quit , I said that was the last time I was gon na ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke. I would oftentimes get a little disheartened , and I would never, of course, tell them. When I would hear parents tell my students that, you know, " You got ta grow up and get a real job, '' I would think that a real job that is a s-s-successful job for someone is a job that is driven by their passion and their love, and not a job that's just there because you're getting the paycheck.
FullB: but I didn't think that I wanted to go teach math. And I was 24, 25 , and I thought, " Okay, well maybe I'll try " computers . '' And you know, this was 25 years ago, so it was just beginning as a field in an area. Umm... you know , I got a job serving coffee in a computer company that had a lab for teaching people. That was maybe for four or five years and I got lucky and came up with an idea for a product and was able to start a company around that. It was a very specific, technical product. And then I started Netflix, which has been the last ten years, which has been just a complete joy. You hear the phrase a lot that life's random in the way it worked out. And I don't think I was any different than any of you guys at, you know, 20.
EventsA: They were having the best time, laughing and listening to music. — I asked if I could do that with them next week. — He said okay. — I came to a reckoning in my life at a very early age. — I worked at a fast-food restaurant for the last time. — I said that was the last time I was going to ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke.
EventsB: got a job serving coffee in a computer company — came up with an idea for a product — started a company around that product — started Netflix

Q12: In these two examples, the stories are not similar at all; Event sequence A describes a person's ambitions back in first grade, while Event sequence B describes another person witnessing political events in Chicago
Q13:
Story A is about a person who wanted to become an astronomer when they were younger.
Story B appears to be about someone who grew up in an environment where they were exposed to the social justice movement.
Both stories involve formative experiences at a young age, but otherwise they aren't very similar in my opinion.
FullA: In first grade when they asked me what I wanted to do, I said I want to study the stars. So, it's lucky that it worked out. Most of the times people say, I wan na be a football player, whatever, movie star, it doesn't work out. In my case it worked out , but I was lucky that way. Astronomy, before I went to college, was something I really thought I could do. But I just doubt myself a lot. Was there any moments where you really doubted yourself? Of course, all the time. It's inevitable. When you're trying to push yourself, there are always moments when you think, maybe this is too hard , maybe I can not do it. But my answer to that is that, if you don't feel that way, it means you're not pushing yourself enough. If you never go out of your comfort zone, then you're not really trying very hard. It's part of learning and part of growing up , is figuring out things that you didn't know you could do, and then you do them. Sometimes you fail. Sometimes you succeed. Let's put it this way. First of all, in research most of what you do, fails miserably, because you're trying to do something that nobody knows how to do. So you have to really like failure. Embrace failure. Accept that failure is gon na be part of the process.
FullB: I think, in the history of this country at least. I mean I see your t-shirt where it has, uh, the Black Panthers. So I was born in Chicago when all that stuff was happening. When you're born in that environment, it's kind of like, " Yeah, you're supposed to be " doing something around social justice , '' because, you know, I saw Chicago burn down. I saw , you know... the tanks roll through our neighborhood. And I didn't realize I had that whole wealth of history and knowledge and activity going on around me because I was in it. Sometimes when you're doing something you love, it doesn't -- you don't find it , it finds you.
EventsA: They asked me what I wanted to do in first grade — I said I wanted to study the stars — It worked out for me — I doubted myself a lot before college
EventsB: I was born in Chicago when all that stuff was happening — I saw Chicago burn down — I saw the tanks roll through our neighborhood

Q12: As I said in my previous response, the story is similar: They're both about the choices they made and paths they followed to end up where they are.
Q13: They're about different topics, but they're both about following meandering paths to get where they are today. "It's about the journey, not the destination" vibes.
FullA: It's sort of a pattern in my life. I didn't get my culinary degree -- I got thrown out -- but I mean , I went and apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe , so, that's really where I learned. But going from a fine dining chef to running , you know, a beer bar seems like it's a downgrade in a way, but it really wasn't. It was actually , there's a lot of things that are more challenging about what I do. We didn't have a business plan. Didn't write one , there's no such thing. I've never written a business plan in my life. Yeah, I learned everything on the fly. I learned how to tap kegs -- never tapped a beer keg in my life. It's been amazingly educational, but sometimes you just learn by doing. Again, there's no school for this. Culinary school didn't teach me this. No one told me what to do -- not my dad, my mom. I did what I wanted to do without any exterior influence. When you say, " Where do you " find the motivation? '' The only motivation that's ever genuine comes from within.
FullB: One of the things that's difficult for me to describe myself is, I've had multiple experiences , and I think all of which have been very significant in my evolution. Originally majoring in geology because I liked rocks, And when they threw physics at me , I decided that this was not for me. But I clearly didn't know what I was doing. When I came up here, I jumped from job to job trying to figure out , I mean, seven months at a time, trying to figure out what I wanted to do. And again, it took years later when I discovered community education , and I really, I felt the passion. I was wondering , yeah. What's that like? What's that like to kind of be searching for yourself and not find it yet? I don't think the search ever ends, first of all. And I don't think one ever finds oneself. I think it's a constant journey. I think it's a constant search. And, trying to enjoy it as I go along. I see more and more the pressure on your generation and that before you, of making decisions about life. That somehow, if you don't decide where you go and how to get there, there's failure up ahead. But I do think that when I allowed myself the enjoyment of the journey and was not fearful that it would leave me to a dead end, then it was fun.
EventsA: I got thrown out of my culinary degree program — I apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe — I went from being a fine dining chef to running a beer bar — I learned how to tap kegs
EventsB: Majored in geology — Decided physics was not for me — Jumped from job to job — Discovered community education — Felt passion for community education

Q12: One is about overcoming a tough background, and the other is about deep interests in a topic and one key event.
Q13: They're about different topics and have different focuses in terms of paths followed. The first is more of a history of how they got to where they are, and the second is about their interests.
FullA: My own personal story, I have come to understand that it's a teaching story  and it is my greatest credential, to be really honest with you , is where I've been. I had a childhood that was with a certain privilege but also with a certain degree of violence in my environment and an overlay of alcoholism. And so by the time I was a teenager  and I was slipping into disordered eating, and drug use and abuse, promiscuity, and just poor choices at certain levels. I was really angry. And I didn't know why. And I didn't know what to do with all my emotions. So I was hungry when I could get around good teachers. And I fortunately did and I began dancing. And it was no question in my being that I needed to be moving my body. But it wasn't like okay , and now I'll take steps A, B, and C.  And that's the biggest message I wan na give to all the young people, to know that it's just one right step at a time to build a beautiful career and a life work.
FullB: of airplanes. I mean, just, airplanes was it. I had to fly 'em , I had to build 'em. I had to understand them, study them. The whole nine yards. I was out there in Key West in A7s. It was, um, my second kind of go around ah, to kind of qualify at the ship. And there were plenty of people in front of me that had not qualified and they were sort of farmed off to other careers. Between now and the next three minutes it takes to fly aboard , I'm either gon na get a thumbs up or that's it. You live your life for moments like that. For me, it was, you know, really all about perseverance. Whether it's pride or something else, but failure was just not an option. I'm not gon na wash out. I'm not gon na give up. You have to force yourself out of your comfort zone , I think, a lot of the time just to see who you are and how the world reacts to you.
EventsA: I had a childhood with a certain degree of violence and an overlay of alcoholism — I slipped into disordered eating, drug use and abuse, and promiscuity as a teenager — I was really angry — I was hungry when I could get around good teachers — I began dancing
EventsB: He flew airplanes. — He built airplanes. — He studied airplanes. — He was in Key West in A7s. — He tried to qualify at the ship for the second time. — He faced a moment where he would either get a thumbs up or fail.

Q12: The first is much longer form, and the second is more a retelling of a specific event.
Q13: These just seem completely different to me, it's hard to point to specifics.
FullA: I was a biology major , and there's so many different pathways that you can go, if it's like medical field, or is it gon na be research, teaching. For me, I had more of a passion of kind of the environment, particularly working with animals. Did I have the pathway  figured out, by no means, no at that time, right? So I also got involved in a atmospheric chemistry lab , so nothing to do with animals , but a lot to do with the environment. I loved that, but I was like, well , I really wan na still apply this to animals. So I went on to graduate school , and I enjoyed teaching, cuz I also worked as a teaching assistant at CSU Long Beach. And I started teaching marine science classes and ecology classes. I had one student email me, he was thanking me the following semester, he said, after taking your class and another instructor's class , it's made me to change my major. Now I'm gon na go into environmental science or marine science , and you're like, wow, okay. What I look forward to the most now is kind of, I guess, passing my passion on for what I do to students.
FullB: when I was about 23 -- and I knew nothing about fashion , I knew no one -- I remember the night before the opening , I was crying and ironing in the shop. Crying and ironing, thinking, " Who did I think I was " that I could do this? '' Crying, ironing, crying. I finally went home at 4 o'clock to be open again at 9am in the morning. And that day, I had lines outside my shop. That day I did the turnover I hoped I'd do in a week. I did it in that day. In a week, I did the turnover I hoped I'd do in a month. And it never stopped. It went on from there. As you achieve success, along will come people who want to spoil it. And that is, um, difficult. It's not easy. But I believe that when you do put yourself on this journey, it's actually about a journey of self-expression , it's a journey about how you live your life , and it's a huge personal growth journey.
EventsA: I got involved in an atmospheric chemistry lab — I went on to graduate school — I worked as a teaching assistant at CSU Long Beach — I started teaching marine science classes and ecology classes — One student emailed me thanking me and said he changed his major to environmental science or marine science
EventsB: I cried and ironed in the shop the night before the opening — I went home at 4 o'clock — I opened the shop at 9am — I had lines outside my shop — I did the turnover I hoped to do in a week in that day — I did the turnover I hoped to do in a month in a week

We've invented these nano sensors that you can inject, that can roam around your body looking for disease, and then emit a signal in the urine. In our long term vision is that this could help with cancer detection in resource poor settings. In just speaking about finding your way, what advice would you give to younger women in science about finding their way in this field, and what road blocks would you like to talk about? So I think for me, one of the biggest road blocks was internal. I don't know if you guys have read about the impostor syndrome. I mean , I certainly had that. I was always worried that I didn't belong at the table, that somehow I'd been some fluke of admission , and it was only a matter of time before people found me out. And in fact it's really, that uniqueness is what makes you different, what makes you valuable.
EventsA: I got thrown out of my culinary degree program — I apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe — I went from being a fine dining chef to running a beer bar — I learned how to tap kegs
EventsB: I decided to try the field of biomedical engineering — I was in college taking classes — I walked by a lab with a door that said artificial organs — I found the right interface for me that summer — We invented nano sensors that can be injected to detect disease — I experienced impostor syndrome

Q12: The first has a real "a-ha" moment (i.e., it's more focused), whereas the second is more meandering.
Q13: They're about different topics and have different structures, though in both they say something like "that was it for me" or "it's magical."
FullA: I am Kimberly Lazer , I'm the curator of Behavioral Husbandry and Welfare for Oklahoma City Zoo. So I spend a lot of time looking, observing, learning everything we can about the species and about what their needs are to give them many choices in their environment. So that they have varied days and they have a very dynamic environment that they're living in. When I was five years old, I had an encounter with a dolphin. And I was able to look that animal in the eye and that was it for me. I wanted to dedicate my life to working with animals. When I left college, I thought, well, that's it , I'm ready. Put me in a job , I know what to do. And what I found was the animals were the best teachers. They have taught me humility. I think that's a big one. They've taught me compassion, to be a little bit more open and be very understanding. Especially to other human beings. That was something I learned when I left college. I had amazing experiences in college and I loved my classes but I don't think I really started becoming well rounded until I got out of the classroom. And I really started learning the real world stuff. So talk to people, hear their stories, and keep an open mind because every person has something to teach you.
FullB: I think it was an LA Times that my dad sent me , and it was just a really ambiguous ad saying, photographers, editors, technicians needed for sports photography agency. And I was like, what is this about? I was an athlete at one point in my life , I like sports, so let's check it out. At that point, didn't really much experience in photography. Realized  I was kind of out of my league for their photography positions, but the door was open to be an editor. So I immediately jumped to that job, knowing that in the back of my head I want to be a photographer , so I just took that opportunity knowing that I was eventually going to parlay it into to where I wanted to go. So in my spare time I'd go out and take photos, cuz the thing was, working for that company allowed me the access that I wanted to get to take photos at sporting events. And I didn't think that I'd be here 25 years later still kind of doing it. The moment you capture something and you just know you've got it in your camera , it's magical. So I just walked through the doors that were opened for me , and I just took them and here I am now. And I'm just fortunate to do something that I love , and it trips me out that I get paid for it. So doors are going to open and close , and it's going to come down to which ones you walk through
EventsA: I had an encounter with a dolphin — I looked the dolphin in the eye — I wanted to dedicate my life to working with animals — I left college — I found that the animals were the best teachers — The animals taught me humility — The animals taught me compassion — I started learning the real world stuff — I talked to people — I heard their stories — I kept an open mind
EventsB: Dad sent an LA Times ad — I checked out the ad — I realized I was out of my league for photography positions — I took the editor job — I took photos in my spare time — Working for the company allowed me access to take photos at sporting events — I captured a moment with my camera — I walked through the doors that were opened for me

FullA: and uh, loved it. You know, I was in one of those graduate programs and on, you know, a good salary , and I enjoyed it , but I always felt like I couldn't express myself enough and there was perhaps, ah, some environment somewhere where I could really make a difference. And you know , I was almost nine years in the bank. I could have gotten my superannuation and been set up with a nice house somewhere. I didn't wan na be that person in years, you know, in years in the future, uh, and not have had taken risks. And I was in a very comfortable environment , and I just didn't have this need to take a risk , and I was like excited about taking a risk and not really knowing what the outcome would be. And uh, we didn't know a whole lot back then , but we just made our classes so much fun. People would laugh the whole way through , and so as a result, it just exploded. We went from 23 people our first night to about 200 people after eight weeks. If you've got that feeling inside that there's something else, it's very hard to get rid of -- which is a good thing. I think there's that something driving you to say , " Well there's something else " out there . ''
FullB: " to be a flight attendant. '' So I was applying for the flight attendant positions and nothing was coming open for me. And then a friend of mine was like, " Well, why don't you, " have you considered being a pilot and flying the plane? '' I was like , " No, I never considered that. " It never crossed my mind. '' [Pilot # 2] We never really saw people in the cockpit that looked like us. And so now, we can give that type of exposure. [Pilot # 1] You still find some people that don't like maybe seeing us up there in the cockpit. But, you know, this is how it's gon na be. Q12: You can overcome and persevere if you try hard enough
Q13: One has a past with the nazi and not anger toward it and the other was damaged in a car accident and holds no anger toward his past
FullA: being six years old , postcards coming into my family, as one after another of the relatives that my parents had were, you know, dead in the concentration camps. And I remember just being very affected by that as a six or seven year old. I became convinced right then , I think, that I did not want to be one of those people. I wanted to be a kind of person that helped other people. That instead of bringing suffering , I wanted to try to alleviate suffering. And what better way to try to alleviate the suffering of human beings than being a doctor? I think everyone has to make a choice which will bring themselves inner peace and happiness as the best they can achieve it. No matter what you do, you will have an opportunity to impact on other people's lives, just by who you are and the way you act.
FullB: and the next minute, you know , I'm thrown over 50 feet from a car  and they thought I died, you know? And they thought I'd never walk again. And people have often asked was I not angry or bitter , and the answer is no. It just is.  Everything seems so minimal, you know, when I'm sitting here talking to you. But just, you know, your mother, the accident...  why not just, " You know what, I cant ''? Like, you know --?  What would have been my option? You see it, don't you? You're sitting, waiting on the first of the month to get a check. Stuck in a wheelchair. You know... That-that's an option? I don't take reality checks from anybody. I want to follow what my passion is in life more than anything else. Don't give me a reality check because reality will tell you what you can't do. " You need to deal " with the real world. '' No, my world is real to me.
EventsA: Postcards came into the family from deceased relatives in concentration camps — The narrator became convinced that they did not want to be like those people — The narrator decided to become a person who helped others — The narrator decided to become a doctor to alleviate human suffering
EventsB: He was thrown over 50 feet from a car — People thought he died — People thought he would never walk again

Q12: one is about becoming accepting of one self and the other is just some rich person
Q13: hiding  their life story and secrets while the other is a ceo where you have no secrets
FullA: When I was a kid, I used to hide everything, like hide all the terrible details of my life. And kind of pull them close to me and try to make them look like something else to other people when I told the story. Yeah. And I think when I was 17 and I went away to college , I got very tired of trying to keep track of all my lies. So I decided I would never tell a lie again. I got to tired of it , I walked right in to my college roommate , and I just kinda blurted out like, my mother left me when I was a baby , my father doesn't want me and my cousins all tried to rape me. And I'm not a Christian anymore , I don't believe in God, and I'm here on a scholarship. And I don't think she spoke to me again for the rest of the semester , but basically I think that was a valuable accident I happened upon because after that I was just like the tell all girl. The tell too much girl. And I think when I became a lesbian I continued to be that kind of person, telling everyone about it in a culture that was violently homophobic.
FullB: My name is David Shotts , I'm the Vice President at Ascend Insurance Brokerage and we work directly with the entertainment industry. So, we work with music venues, music festivals, touring artists, event safety, event security companies. I kinda got into this industry by accident. I was playing in a band  and we were touring the country, and having a lot of fun, and not really thinking about insurance, to be quite honest. My broker said no one knows this industry like you, come to work for me , and I have just kind of found out I was really good at it. It's cool because I'll talk to people and I'll tell them  what I do and most commonly people are like, I didn't even know you could get insurance for that. I think it's kind of the beauty of the industry is that the insurance is everywhere. It doesn't just stop with home, auto, life. So if you're into extreme sports, I know a brokerage in California that focuses on extreme sports. If you're into hunting and fishing, I know underwriters that specialize in that industry. Get an idea of what's out there. If you're sitting there going I'm not quite sure what I wan na do in this industry, that's okay. As I said earlier, there's a lot of opportunity in this industry so feel around.
EventsA: I went away to college — I decided I would never tell a lie again — I walked right in to my college roommate — I blurted out my personal story to my roommate — My roommate did not speak to me for the rest of the semester — I became a lesbian — I told everyone about being a lesbian in a homophobic culture
EventsB: David Shotts played in a band — David Shotts toured the country with his band — David Shotts' broker invited him to work for him — David Shotts started working in the insurance industry

Q12: The grateful dead is nostalgic and so is myspace

FullA: five or six bands, you know, 'cause people would come to me and go , " Oh we got a band, too . '' And by having the most popular band in St. Louis, which was a band called the . We were-became the radio station's band, which meant they played like 80-100 commercials a week. " Hey, the , " we playin ' at 66 Drive-In. '' And it'd be, " Steve on trumpet [do-do-do-do-do-do ] '' So being the popular band in town , I started booking other bands, 'cause when I was already booked, I didn't see any reason to turn people down. I said, " Wait a second, let me see if I can get another band. '' Well, that eventually led to booking 1100 bands. So we were the largest band-booking agency in the country , and I was like 18 years old. So went from local bands, regional bands, to national bands. And the first show we did was in 1969 was the Grateful Dead. You guys sitting here all have ideas. Whether you pursue them ot not is up to you. Don't later on look back and say , " God, I wish " I would've done that. ''
FullB: something with business. I didn't know exactly what I was going to do. My passion wasn't there , but that's where the money was at. And I'm thinking, " This oughta pay the bills , " I ` ma have a family. This is what I'm going to do. " I'm just gon na paint on the side. '' But it got to that point where I couldn't work because I kept hearing that I got to pursue my dream as a, as an artist. That Obama shoe came to me. And I woke up at two o'clock in the morning and I painted that shoe. And I went to the mall and took a picture, put it on MySpace. No big deal. Didn't think nothing of it. And then like the first big thing that happened was the Smithsonian e-mailin ' me and I thought it was a joke. And I cried. I was like, I was almost homeless in January. Like, had I quit, had I quit a month before I made that shoe , had I quit an hour before I made that shoe, and decided, " I'm just gon na forget about art , '' this would have never happened.

Q12: one was coming from a child perspectives and the other is an adult
Q13: one shows his passion paid off at a remarkable time and the other doesnt want to stop and has ambitions
FullA: A few years ago I had a bit of a scare. My appendix ruptured on tour and I came close to dying. And it was the same week that my first song went into the top 20. After more than 20 years of making music - Wow. We had a song, Say Hey I Love You. Goes into the top 20. And I'm on this gurney being wheeled down to perhaps my death. And I get this text. Your song's in the top 20, and I'm like, didn't even matter. Yeah. I was like , whatever. I was like , I just wan na see my kids again. I wan na be with my family. And I can appreciate having made music for that long that it's a nice thing to have a lot of people hear your song. But If I can't share with my family, it doesn't matter. At this point in my life, I'm 48. I have two sons. I have one who's 27 and I have one who's 15. And I still feel like I'm 22 years old. I still have the same passion for what I do with music. And I have this life that I feel is fulfilling in so many ways that I feel happy most of the time.
FullB: I'm 53 years old , I'm trying to decide what I'm gon na do when I grow up. My grandfather farmed , he went out and said , hey do you wan na plant a garden? And I got started that way , we planted some radishes in a spot about this big and I thought it was the coolest thing. I was debating between agriculture and ornamental horticulture, like growing flowers. But I thought if I'm gon na spend my life doing something, I would rather spend my life helping to feed the world. So our job is to develop a hybrid seed that will help the farmer in his business. So if you take two inbreds, like that , and you cross them , that's your hybrid. So people are like, why do you have hybrids? It's like, that's why I have hybrids. Some people feel like , okay , I just wan na make a lot of money. But if you can find something you have a passion for, you love it, you think about it in the morning when you wake up. And then you can figure out an intersection of that thing with something that you can make a living doing , That's a pretty sweet place to be.
EventsA: My appendix ruptured on tour — I came close to dying — My first song went into the top 20 — I was on a gurney being wheeled down — I got a text saying my song was in the top 20
EventsB: Grandfather asked if they wanted to plant a garden — They planted some radishes in a small spot — They debated between agriculture and ornamental horticulture — They decided to spend their life helping to feed the world — They developed a hybrid seed to help farmers — They crossed two inbred plants to create a hybrid

Q12: One went rock bottom and got a job as the head of marvel, the other got a job but then developed a new business.
Q13: They both talk about job transitions but the first one has a bit of a rock bottom when the second is just someone who is curious and passionate
FullA: have the confidence or believe in some way or some fashion they'll find themselves. It always terrified me. I have four degrees and never really had any interest in any of them. I was miserable, except in my off-hours, when I was chasing whatever that I liked to do for fun, which was music and comic books and movies. And what happened was, I lost my job, left my wife , and I was homeless. Had no place to live. A guy that was uh, in a search firm, a headhunter, knew all my passions about comic books and movies and music. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. '' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. You don't want to be put into that position of luck ... making a difference in your life at a later age. Be in charge of your destiny now.
FullB: I always grew up with tea being a stable at our dining table. One of my colleagues from my previous job, knew a recruiter at eBay and he recommended me and they ended up hiring me. But one day I was trying to make loose-leaf tea at my desk , and by the time I would make it , I would be late for a meeting. And every time I tried to use tea bags instead, I was never satisfied with the quality because it was not as flavorful, it didn't have as much aroma. That was my first point of inspiration to think about the idea for tea drops. It took me about a year and a half of experimenting. I would spend my weekends and my week nights kind of blending and I was obsessed with figuring it out. And once I had that, I started sharing it with my colleagues and friends and family. Now we're available in over 1,600 retail stores. My logic was, even if this failed, even if nothing ever comes of it, I know I would have gained so much in trying
EventsA: lost my job — left my wife — was homeless — a headhunter told me Marvel Comics was looking for somebody with a business background who reads comic books — became president of Marvel Comics
EventsB: A colleague recommended me to a recruiter at eBay — They hired me — I tried to make loose-leaf tea at my desk — I tried to use tea bags instead — I thought about the idea for tea drops — I spent about a year and a half experimenting — I started sharing tea drops with colleagues, friends, and family — Tea drops became available in over 1,600 retail stores

Q12: They are slightly similar, both individuals started with a personal interest (Neuroscience / Car detailing) and experienced a "lightbulb moment" where they realized they could turn that interest into a commercial venture.
Q13: These two stories couldn’t be more different—one is about high-level academic research and NIH funding, while the other is about car shows and aftermarket brush guards.
FullA: I was the first one to go to college in my family. As an undergraduate, I found a passion for science  and I focused all my attention on biology, neuroscience. And then all of a sudden, my passion shifted from doing research, research, research to understanding how do I get my invention to the market. And then I did an internship with an investment firm and so after doing that , well, okay? I know how they get funded , I really , really like the startup environment. I'm gon na jump into a startup company that I'm really passionate about , and I met the CEO of Recovery Force. So I was brought onto Recovery Force to help promote the research and support the research through funding through the National Institute of Health. And like I say, it wasn't a straight road, what I thought I was gon na be doing today was not what I originally planned 10 or 15 years ago. There's so many avenues into every type of career path. You have to figure out what is best for you, cuz you can go political , you can go into academics , you can stay. There's so many areas where you can provide value.
FullB: And I didn't think anything of it  and then there was a show, a car show. So I went to this car show  and I go all right, washed my car and waxed it , hey, it's kinda cool , so I'll take you there. A company called Go Rhino. They came up to me and said , hey, if we give you our brush cards for free, will you put it on your car, and when you go to the next show, put our sticker on your car? I go, yeah, of course I will. Once I got like a bunch of sponsors and they gave me stuff for free , and I did it. And it ended up on a magazine. It did a cover, this and that. I'm like , I wan na do another one.
EventsA: I went to college — I found a passion for science — My passion shifted from doing research to understanding how to get my invention to the market — I did an internship with an investment firm — I met the CEO of Recovery Force — I was brought onto Recovery Force to help promote and support research through funding from the National Institute of Health

Q12: Both discuss job transition but that is where the similarities stop, one is forced military change, the other is a person not liking their job.
Q13: Both tell tales of moving on to a different role. However one is a forced change from going military into the working world. The other was a job choice that he didn't like.
FullA: I don't think I'll ever find a job that I'm as good at as I was at being an infantry officer. I went from being a captain in the Marine Corps, in command of 950 marines and sailors. Every Friday I would go out to our Liberty Formation before I launched them for the weekend , and you just see this massive sea of servicemen and women that I was in command of. It was awe inspiring and humbling and it was just an awesome opportunity. I ended up taking a job with a medical IT company. And I was in a cubicle next to a 23 year old, looking through spreadsheets to see if there were duplicate hospitals in them. You couldn't have wasted my experience or skill sets more , but that's all part of it. You can not expect your first employer or the people that you're interviewing with or the community you moved to , you can't expect them to know everything about you and understand your value right off the bat. You have to go in and you've got ta show them. You've got to compete again and so I had a lot of fun. Figuring out, okay, how do I become a non profit leader and build a non profit? By the way at the same time, I've also got ta fight these guys that wan na beat me up on national TV because that helped me pay my bills as well. So trying to juggle all those while we were having kids and everything , it was a wild, crazy transition for sure.
FullB: Wasn't a good experience. Didn't think I was gon na like practicing law and definitely didn't like where I was doing it. And I think like a lot of people who are in their first real job, you get a little freaked out when you're unhappy. Because, " What kind of risks " am I taking if I leave this place? " Am I ever gon na get a job again? " What does it say about me as a person that I've made " the wrong choice here? '' It's nonsense. You just go on to the next thing and you kind of keep going. I finally kind of decided to make the jump and went to another firm , and it was absolutely night and day difference. All the kind of weird directions that my career has taken wasn't the result of plotting it out even at that time. A lot of it was happenstance. Just, you kind of work hard, keep your eyes open.
EventsA: He was a captain in the Marine Corps in command of 950 marines and sailors — He went out to the Liberty Formation before launching the servicemen and women for the weekend — He took a job with a medical IT company — He looked through spreadsheets to see if there were duplicate hospitals — He figured out how to become a non profit leader and build a non profit — He fought on national TV to help pay his bills
EventsB: Did not like practicing law — Did not like where I was doing it — Decided to make the jump — Went to another firm

Q12: One was a hard switch the second was a forced switch
Q13: One was about changing from playing with taxpayer dollars moving to their own money, the second was not being able to find the ideal job but going into one that was available.
FullA: When I got out of college, I went into the Army Reserve, through the Communications Officer. And ended up back in 89 getting a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory. At an Engineer and Developing Technology, to make weapons smarter, new technology to be able to kind of carry weapons. And so this whole focus was on creating capability. But when you're in the entrepreneurship world and the commercial world, that's a different mindset. Yeah. See, when I worked for the government. I could spend the government money on my ideas. But I'm out here as an entrepreneur , I have to spend my own money. So that was hard for me, to try to get that switch going on. My approach, and what I always tell people is you have to start connecting, networking. And a lot of people thinks that's hard , but it is not really hard. It's just a matter of meeting people , and let them know what you do or what you wan na do.
FullB: My wife and I call ourselves, laughingly, that we're fixers , so it's our job now to go in and help institutions and organizations that are flailing or floundering. Because my wife, myself, we come from a generation where we were told Indians are good with their hands, they're not meant for college. So just get a high school education and go to work. What drove me truly was, I wanted to help my people and I went to Community College , transferred to Black Hills State College , graduated from there in 1985. And immediately after law school, immediately came home to the reservation and there were no jobs in the Legal Profession. But the college had a directors position in institutional development and they hired me. And lo and behold they hired me as the acting president in 1991. So that's become the passion now is to help our children and our grandchildren to succeed and to again, instill with them a higher passion than just a job from eight to five.
EventsA: I got out of college — I went into the Army Reserve through the Communications Officer — I got a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory — I worked at an Engineer and Developing Technology to make weapons smarter — I tried to get the switch going on from government work to entrepreneurship
EventsB: I went to Community College — I transferred to Black Hills State College — I graduated from Black Hills State College in 1985 — I finished law school — I came home to the reservation — The college hired me as a director in institutional development — The college hired me as the acting president in 1991

Q12: One is onward and upward, the second is massive set back and handling that negativity
Q13: One is talking about College and moving forward with life and the second is a massive set back in life.
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I worked in technology up until 1998 in which I struck out on my own and I built an engineering company. Had good contracts. 9/11 hits a couple of years later, and all of a sudden a lot of the major corporations and people  I was dealing with, their stocks fell, and they stopped giving work. I went and became a screener at the airport. I want you to think about this. I worked for a major corporation, I'm a screener, people that were my clients and then I work with , were coming through the airport. You got me reminiscing and thinking back here. But, I stuck to my principles. I knew I was better than this, all right? And I had a plan. So I took what I knew, even though I was working in terrorism and mass transit, I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl. And so, I knew from that, I was as good or better than anybody there.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I struck out on my own — I built an engineering company — 9/11 happened — major corporations and people I was dealing with stopped giving work — I became a screener at the airport — I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl

Q12: The theme of realizing that what the author is doing is not satisfying to them is still present, and there are some slight similarities present in both stories.
Q13: There were some slight similarities present in the stories of "finding your calling" or a job that is what you want, but otherwise the stories were different.
FullA: when I was four, but um ... growing up without a mother -- 'cause she died when I was six -- growing up with just my dad and my brother , I was obviously very, um, just very independent and strong-willed. And my dad's best friend was a stockbroker, and for some reason, because I was so good with money, that I decided that I was, that I would be a really good stockbroker. And fortunately, throughout high school, we had work exchange and work experience, and um , they used to send me off with all sorts of random checks and things to, you know, with million dollars in my hand to go and deliver somewhere, and I had no idea where I was going or how to get there. And being the little surfy chick that I was , it just made me realize that wasn't the avenue I wanted to go down. Ultimately, to become successful in anything , you have to be relatively selfish. You have to be so one-dimensional. I also believe that there's no such thing as a mistake , it's only a learning experience. The only mistake is not learning from it. But even then, you're just gon na be given the opportunity to learn it and learn it and learn it until such time as you do. So I made the same " mistake '' over and over again until I actually got the lesson.
FullB: They would always listen to this great jazz station called KADX. And one, for I just saw what they were doing  and they were having the best time, laughing and listening to this great music , and I said, " Can I, can I do that with you next week ? '' He said, " Okay, son. '' So I actually came to sort of a reckoning in my life at a very early age , and it was the last time that I worked at a fast-food restaurant. And I remember on that Friday, before I quit , I said that was the last time I was gon na ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke. I would oftentimes get a little disheartened , and I would never, of course, tell them. When I would hear parents tell my students that, you know, " You got ta grow up and get a real job, '' I would think that a real job that is a s-s-successful job for someone is a job that is driven by their passion and their love, and not a job that's just there because you're getting the paycheck.
EventsA: Her mother died when she was six — She decided she would be a stockbroker — She was sent off with million dollars in checks to deliver somewhere — She realized being a stockbroker was not the avenue she wanted to go down — She made the same mistake over and over again until she learned the lesson
EventsB: They were having the best time, laughing and listening to music. — I asked if I could do that with them next week. — He said okay. — I came to a reckoning in my life at a very early age. — I worked at a fast-food restaurant for the last time. — I said that was the last time I was going to ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke.

Q13: The only similarity that I saw in both stories were that they saw a problem and made a business around the solution. However, one story was about a nonprofit, and the other was about a home brewing business. There were only slight similarities present.
FullA: So I entered foster care when I was about three and a half years old. During that time, I had 14 different foster homes. I wasn't always placed in the most ideal circumstances. These were people who had problems with drugs, alcohol, violence, pedophilia. So I had this sense of I've got ta do something. I've got ta say something , this is not okay, and that kind of kept eating at me. And I think that's the motivation that kept me from turning to drugs, or running away, or becoming part of that statistic, that label that they expected of me. I had to do something differently. And so all of that gave me this perspective that it's not enough to complain about something if you're not willing to be a part of the solution. So a really big sticking point for me was that I'm not just going to walk around complaining about foster care or complaining about this system of care that's not protecting kids, no. I wan na be directly involved in the very system that failed me so that I can make it better. And I ultimately opened a non-profit organization that provides direct services to children and families. So all of my experiences kind of led to me serving others in a way that I wish I had been served when I was a young person.
FullB: towards food that I did. And so we would entertain a lot of our friends. And so all the wine dinners, all of a sudden , somehow we started home brewing. It was a simple enough question that deserved a simple answer. " Well there aren't any good American beers , " well we will supply the pipeline. '' And so we started a really naive way of thinking , but I really believe that all good thoughts come out of just a desire, a simple idea. And then the passion that you have is gon na really drive that.
EventsA: I entered foster care when I was about three and a half years old — I had 14 different foster homes — I decided I had to do something and say something about my situation — I resolved not to turn to drugs, run away, or become part of the negative statistics — I decided not to just complain about foster care but to be part of the solution — I decided to be directly involved in the system that failed me — I opened a non-profit organization that provides direct services to children and families
EventsB: They entertained a lot of their friends. — They started home brewing.

Q12: There are similarities present in the progression of the story, from venturing somewhere, to going somewhere new, to starting a new "job" of sorts.
Q13: The themes present in both stories are different- one is about acceptance of a job, finding something that the author is okay with doing, and the other is about not being stuck in a job that you hate for the rest of your life.
FullA: When I joined the military, I had literally nothing. I was in a holding center, in a juvenile holding center and my recruiter came and rescued me. Needless to say , when I went to boot camp, I thought it was actually kind of easy and like I had never had so much food before in my life. When I joined the military, I originally signed up as a gunner's mate. I got out, felt like something was missing, I ended up moving out here for a job, and I was, like, guns , I know guns. I can do this job, that was easy. That was my turnaround moment. Okay.
FullB: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
EventsA: I joined the military — My recruiter came and rescued me — I went to boot camp — I signed up as a gunner's mate — I got out — I moved out here for a job
EventsB: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop

Q12: Event sequence A had the character go through a much more desperate time in their life in the beginning.
FullA: have the confidence or believe in some way or some fashion they'll find themselves. It always terrified me. I have four degrees and never really had any interest in any of them. I was miserable, except in my off-hours, when I was chasing whatever that I liked to do for fun, which was music and comic books and movies. And what happened was, I lost my job, left my wife , and I was homeless. Had no place to live. A guy that was uh, in a search firm, a headhunter, knew all my passions about comic books and movies and music. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. '' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. You don't want to be put into that position of luck ... making a difference in your life at a later age. Be in charge of your destiny now.
FullB: I went to school for welding, design, pouring metal, and working in the foundry, and all of these crazy things , I thought it was everything. And there was this moment , I remember just thinking , this is not me , this is not what I want to be in my life. I really just had to drop everything and start over and just move , and I just explored. And I took some time off  and I was doing my thing, traveling out here to Colorado, and just kind of experimenting with different processes. I ended up blowing glass and trying it for the first time, and falling in love, like that's it , that's my life.
EventsA: lost my job — left my wife — was homeless — a headhunter told me Marvel Comics was looking for somebody with a business background who reads comic books — became president of Marvel Comics
EventsB: I went to school for welding, design, pouring metal, and working in the foundry — I thought it was everything — I remembered thinking this is not me — I had to drop everything and start over — I moved — I took some time off — I traveled to Colorado — I experimented with different processes — I ended up blowing glass for the first time — I fell in love with blowing glass

FullA: I'm an Assistant Professor in Astronomy at California Institute of Technology and Caltech. And I study the dynamic universe. So what I do is, with the beautiful telescopes here at Palomar Observatory, we have some robotic telescopes that are continuously making a movie of the night sky. So we image the sky over and over again and we look for what changed. You might go out there and think universe is the same old thing every time , but it's actually not. It's full of these little explosions, which last for a very short amount of time , so they're very But they're very energetic. It's like cosmic fireworks lighting up our sky. So why did you choose to pursue the degree path that you did? I would say that in my own case, I mean , it was not at all clear that one day I would do a PhD. I grew up on a farm in India with 100 cows and fields of weeds and chick peas. And I had left home when I was 15 , and I was a girl in India in a small place. The entire community was up in arms, you know? There were people like neighbors, relatives , you name it. People I haven't even seen before coming into the house and trying to talk my parents out of this crazy decision to send their daughter alone on this journey into other end of the world to pursue something called Astronomy or whatever that was. The community was completely unsupportive. How did you deal with that? In my case, the best way to deal with it was to just let that fade away in the background and not engage with the two directly, but focus on what is motivating me, on what is giving me joy and just let everything else just fade away in the background.
FullB: I've been put in situations where, if you don't talk to this person, your opportunity is gon na pass you by. But once you tell yourself, you know what, I'm gon na not let this opportunity pass, it's just a conscious decision. You know what, I'm just gon na go with it. What's the worst that can happen? And now it's kind of natural. If I need to talk to somebody, I might not want to , but I'll go up and be like yo let's handle this business , you have to have that. You know? Even if you shy, like you just got ta push through it. Once you get through that little fear, everything just comes. So where do you see like your confidence level now? Just I know that I can, like there's nothing you can tell me that I can't do, you know what I'm saying? So, just knowing that in the back of my mind. I got this, no matter what. Even if I don't make it today, I'm gon na make it tomorrow. If I fail today, then I'm gon na get right back up, and do it again. So, knowing that, just having that failure , and then coming back from it. The ground comes under me. I'm just going build a new ground.
EventsA: I studied the dynamic universe — I used robotic telescopes at Palomar Observatory to make a movie of the night sky — I imaged the sky repeatedly to look for changes — I grew up on a farm in India — I left home when I was 15 — The community tried to talk my parents out of sending me away — I decided to focus on my motivation and joy and ignore the community's opposition
EventsB: I told myself I was not going to let the opportunity pass — I decided to go with it — I went up to talk to somebody despite feeling shy — I pushed through my fear — I experienced failure — I got right back up and did it again

If it's a burning desire and you can't think of nothin ' else , you might have a chance. If you think you do and you're willing to roll the dice, then you go do it , but you'll never find out unless you do try, you know? That's the other side of the coin.
