Q12: Both individuals take advantage of the opportunities that present themselves.
Q13: Both stories contain individuals who are not afraid to jump headlong into a new task, role, or project. The apparent difference between the two appears to be that the individual in story B shows more of a willingness to adapt to different roles alongside the progression of the project. Whereas the individual in story A seems more static in her role and enjoys being a catalyst for many different things rather than sticking around too long.
FullA: I'm really an early stage person. I love to make the new thing and so as something gets bigger and more structured , I usually hand it off to people and there's people who love to run stuff that's structured. So when I joined Google we were about 1,200 people and when I left we're over 50 or 60,000 people, so it was sort of fly the plane while you're building the plane. I had gone from working in Silicon Valley and working at Google on a lot of topics. It was fun, incredible teammates. And then I was in Africa for some work with some entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya and I got an email and it said email from the US CTO. And so 33 days later, President Obama called and offered me the job which was incredible. It's an honor to get to serve your country. So when you're doing this work, know that you belong. We all come with different histories and those histories are culture add. There's this weird idea that Silicon Valley had of culture fit. It's very destructive. I don't want you to fit , I want you to add.
FullB: The point of which I decided to be entrepreneur was when talking point just took off. It snowballed from there. So, I have to say my entrepreneurship journey is pretty accidental. Often the public image of an entrepeneur is very glamorous, but actually a lot of my work is not glamorous. And I don't think people see that from the outside. A lot of my role is essentially being a champion. I'm a doer at heart. And it's going from I'm a real doer to I need to delegate or I need to be able to align everyone to get to the same big vision and the big goal. And it's not just me anymore, so kind of a a chicken and an egg where it's both hard and challenging, but exciting.
EventsA: joined Google when it had about 1,200 people — left Google when it had over 50,000 people — went to Africa for work with entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya — received an email from the US CTO — President Obama called and offered the job 33 days later
EventsB: Talking Point took off — I decided to be an entrepreneur

Q12: Both had moments of realization that planted seeds that inspired working outside of the box.
Q13: Both align with the idea of escaping the 'maze' so to speak, and doing passionate work instead.
FullA: or work in the office or not work. And so I worked in an office , and every place that I worked at I ended up computerizing. Ended up starting a company, um, in manufacturing. But I always, always knew that I was meant to do something to help other people. And I was in Niger. And there was a little girl that came up to me with flies on her face. And I just felt that that's intolerable. I mean, for one thing, that could have been my granddaughter. How could I not do something? I think that I have the opportunity to live what I think should be the American Dream, when what I think should be the American Dream is that we use these resources, we use these talents, to help those that didn't get that.
FullB: rainy, in Seattle, on a project, drinking a tea like this one actually. I was just like, " I can't do this anymore. '' People put up their entire life in their cubicle farm , and it's like their pictures of their vacations , and it's like, " I'm outta here. " This is it. '' And I was drinking a tea, and, " Wow. '' Everyone I went to said it was a horrible idea. " You're doomed to failure, you have no experience, " retail's a painful existence, '' um... " Coffee's where it's at , " so what are you thinking ? '' So it's hard to, how do you kick yourself in the pants? Like, is it easier to get a job and kind of pay the rent, or is the pain of not knowing what your self-actualization greater? And generally, I think, pursuing that pain is pursuing the unknown, which is frightening , and most people don't do it. That's why. It's easier just to just go, just follow the path. But you may wake up in 50 years saying, " What was my, gosh, what the heck did I do? ''
EventsA: worked in an office — computerized every place that I worked at — started a company in manufacturing — was in Niger — a little girl with flies on her face came up to me
EventsB: I said I can't do this anymore. — I decided I'm outta here. — I was drinking a tea. — Everyone I went to said it was a horrible idea.

Q12: The stories begin at different stages of success. Sequence A was a gradual climb to success, with one step building off of another. Sequence B was unexpected, overnight success that came as a result of tenacity, hard work, and a stroke of luck.
Q13: Both stories deal with the importance of taking risks in order to gain a reward and caution against giving up before realizing your potential.
FullA: five or six bands, you know, 'cause people would come to me and go , " Oh we got a band, too . '' And by having the most popular band in St. Louis, which was a band called the . We were-became the radio station's band, which meant they played like 80-100 commercials a week. " Hey, the , " we playin ' at 66 Drive-In. '' And it'd be, " Steve on trumpet [do-do-do-do-do-do ] '' So being the popular band in town , I started booking other bands, 'cause when I was already booked, I didn't see any reason to turn people down. I said, " Wait a second, let me see if I can get another band. '' Well, that eventually led to booking 1100 bands. So we were the largest band-booking agency in the country , and I was like 18 years old. So went from local bands, regional bands, to national bands. And the first show we did was in 1969 was the Grateful Dead. You guys sitting here all have ideas. Whether you pursue them ot not is up to you. Don't later on look back and say , " God, I wish " I would've done that. ''
FullB: something with business. I didn't know exactly what I was going to do. My passion wasn't there , but that's where the money was at. And I'm thinking, " This oughta pay the bills , " I ` ma have a family. This is what I'm going to do. " I'm just gon na paint on the side. '' But it got to that point where I couldn't work because I kept hearing that I got to pursue my dream as a, as an artist. That Obama shoe came to me. And I woke up at two o'clock in the morning and I painted that shoe. And I went to the mall and took a picture, put it on MySpace. No big deal. Didn't think nothing of it. And then like the first big thing that happened was the Smithsonian e-mailin ' me and I thought it was a joke. And I cried. I was like, I was almost homeless in January. Like, had I quit, had I quit a month before I made that shoe , had I quit an hour before I made that shoe, and decided, " I'm just gon na forget about art , '' this would have never happened.
EventsA: became the radio station's band — played 80-100 commercials a week — started booking other bands — booked 1100 bands — became the largest band-booking agency in the country — did the first show in 1969 with the Grateful Dead
EventsB: I woke up at two o'clock in the morning — I painted that shoe — I went to the mall and took a picture — I put the picture on MySpace — The Smithsonian emailed me — I cried

FullA: A few years ago I had a bit of a scare. My appendix ruptured on tour and I came close to dying. And it was the same week that my first song went into the top 20. After more than 20 years of making music - Wow. We had a song, Say Hey I Love You. Goes into the top 20. And I'm on this gurney being wheeled down to perhaps my death. And I get this text. Your song's in the top 20, and I'm like, didn't even matter. Yeah. I was like , whatever. I was like , I just wan na see my kids again. I wan na be with my family. And I can appreciate having made music for that long that it's a nice thing to have a lot of people hear your song. But If I can't share with my family, it doesn't matter. At this point in my life, I'm 48. I have two sons. I have one who's 27 and I have one who's 15. And I still feel like I'm 22 years old. I still have the same passion for what I do with music. And I have this life that I feel is fulfilling in so many ways that I feel happy most of the time.
FullB: I'm 53 years old , I'm trying to decide what I'm gon na do when I grow up. My grandfather farmed , he went out and said , hey do you wan na plant a garden? And I got started that way , we planted some radishes in a spot about this big and I thought it was the coolest thing. I was debating between agriculture and ornamental horticulture, like growing flowers. But I thought if I'm gon na spend my life doing something, I would rather spend my life helping to feed the world. So our job is to develop a hybrid seed that will help the farmer in his business. So if you take two inbreds, like that , and you cross them , that's your hybrid. So people are like, why do you have hybrids? It's like, that's why I have hybrids. Some people feel like , okay , I just wan na make a lot of money. But if you can find something you have a passion for, you love it, you think about it in the morning when you wake up. And then you can figure out an intersection of that thing with something that you can make a living doing , That's a pretty sweet place to be.
EventsA: My appendix ruptured on tour — I came close to dying — My first song went into the top 20 — I was on a gurney being wheeled down — I got a text saying my song was in the top 20
EventsB: Grandfather asked if they wanted to plant a garden — They planted some radishes in a small spot — They debated between agriculture and ornamental horticulture — They decided to spend their life helping to feed the world — They developed a hybrid seed to help farmers — They crossed two inbred plants to create a hybrid

FullA: and the next minute, you know , I'm thrown over 50 feet from a car  and they thought I died, you know? And they thought I'd never walk again. And people have often asked was I not angry or bitter , and the answer is no. It just is.  Everything seems so minimal, you know, when I'm sitting here talking to you. But just, you know, your mother, the accident...  why not just, " You know what, I cant ''? Like, you know --?  What would have been my option? You see it, don't you? You're sitting, waiting on the first of the month to get a check. Stuck in a wheelchair. You know... That-that's an option? I don't take reality checks from anybody. I want to follow what my passion is in life more than anything else. Don't give me a reality check because reality will tell you what you can't do. " You need to deal " with the real world. '' No, my world is real to me.
FullB: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.

EventsB: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop

FullA: Where were you when you were our age, 22, 23? I was in Chile. I was about to finish college. And I have a bachelor's in linguistics, English linguistics, so I spoke English before i came here. And at that time the only possibility I'd say that was offered to me was to teach English. I was coming from the third world to the first world. I didn't get out of my apartment for about year. And then I came across this ad. They were looking for a coordinator in this place. I think that there are roads for you in life. And if you want to take a different road life is always going to take you back to that one. For example, teaching for me. As soon as I started teaching, I loved it.
FullB: I went to UC Berkeley and I started out as a philosophy major and an art major. And then I took anthropology. And then I thought, you know, I wan na do theater. And then after I got out, I like, I'm just going to try to get a real job but I wanted to be in a place that felt right and I applied to the Asian art museum. I applied for the program assistant position in performing arts , and I have museum experience , I have my anthro background , I have theater. It just kind of came together , and it was totally unplanned. The thing is, I never knew a job like what I have now existed or could exist. I just sort of positioned myself with things that really felt right. It's really a matter of instinct on some level and a broad plotting of things. Did you ever, after making the decision, be like, what am I doing, like doubting yourself? No. Really? You just went straight for it? The truth is, I've felt just pretty open about how the future will pan out. Your path is what you make of it. There are positions out there , there are careers out there that you can fit into. But there also things that you can make yourself and you have to just trust that you have something unique to offer and to be consistent with that in your choices.
EventsA: I was in Chile — I was about to finish college — I spoke English before I came here — I didn't get out of my apartment for about a year — I came across an ad — They were looking for a coordinator — I started teaching — I loved teaching
EventsB: I went to UC Berkeley — I started out as a philosophy major and an art major — I took anthropology — I decided I wanted to do theater — I got out of UC Berkeley — I applied to the Asian art museum — I applied for the program assistant position in performing arts

FullA: I grew up loving design, loving art. And I kinda knew I wanted to do something like that , but I couldn't pinpoint this job. So I kinda picked a ballpark major that seemed approximately where I wanted to go. Here's a big path to go down , and over the years it'll eventually start narrowing. So what I've actually done over the years is I have a great job where I earn a salary , and it's nice. But on the side I teach coding to women to kinda help them enter the tech world. So it's a good combination of having a great day job, which I enjoy doing and I get fulfillment out of. But then I also get to do these other things that are also interesting to me , and it's a great way to give back to the community using skills and stuff that I enjoy doing.
FullB: I enlisted for three years , and two of those years were spent in France. One year in the southwest, and one year in Paris. And this is where I really learned to eat. Uh, I'm from a Creole Acadian family, but  -- and my mother was a wonderful, wonderful cook. So I grew up with good food, which I think is very important, uh, if you eventually want to write about food. On returning, um...  from France, I went to work as a general assignment reporter at the newspaper, so I went to my editor and I said, " I don't wan na do this anymore , and is there anything else " I can do? '' And when he said, uh, " We need a restaurant reviewer , '' I said, " Why don't we just stop right there? '' And I'm sure of it , there are millions like me, who start a job and find that it's a perfect fit. It's just the greatest feeling you could possibly have.

'' He said, " Okay, son. '' So I actually came to sort of a reckoning in my life at a very early age , and it was the last time that I worked at a fast-food restaurant. When I would hear parents tell my students that, you know, " You got ta grow up and get a real job, '' I would think that a real job that is a s-s-successful job for someone is a job that is driven by their passion and their love, and not a job that's just there because you're getting the paycheck.
FullB: but I didn't think that I wanted to go teach math. And I was 24, 25 , and I thought, " Okay, well maybe I'll try " computers . '' And you know, this was 25 years ago, so it was just beginning as a field in an area. Umm... you know , I got a job serving coffee in a computer company that had a lab for teaching people. That was maybe for four or five years and I got lucky and came up with an idea for a product and was able to start a company around that. It was a very specific, technical product. And then I started Netflix, which has been the last ten years, which has been just a complete joy. You hear the phrase a lot that life's random in the way it worked out. And I don't think I was any different than any of you guys at, you know, 20.
EventsA: They were having the best time, laughing and listening to music. — I asked if I could do that with them next week. — He said okay. — I came to a reckoning in my life at a very early age. — I worked at a fast-food restaurant for the last time. — I said that was the last time I was going to ask anybody if they wanted fries with that Coke.
EventsB: got a job serving coffee in a computer company — came up with an idea for a product — started a company around that product — started Netflix

FullA: with my guidance counselor and we decided that, you know, I had an artistic streak and I was good in math , and therefore I should be an architect. And I think it was about the third year in school , I realized I wasn't really that good at it and I kind of didn't even like it that much. And the next couple of years were pretty scary 'cause um , I-I had a degree in something I was pretty sure I was never gon na use. And I just kind of didn't know what course my life was gon na take. By the time I graduated from college I actually had a few nationally-released records , and they didn't make that big of a splash or make that much money , but it was enough to get me thinking like, " Wow, well this would be cool " to do this for a living. I like this more than being " an architect or hovering over a drawing board " for 20 hours a day. '' It's a clichÃ © , but you do have to kind of follow your dreams. Especially, you guys are all young , and, you know , this is the time to do it. If I were you, I would definitely go for what makes you happy. The big irony of my life and my career is that I've outlasted most of the people I've parodied over the years.
FullB: my uncle did was give me a copy of Doom on a floppy disk. It was a lot about games. But um, through the games, ah, I learned a lot about computers , you know. And I think that's what really got me embedded in the computer world. Uh, now I'm here working with this robot which is ...  ah, her name is Nexi. And this one is kind of designed to do personal interaction between humans and robots.  I can tell you that I'm sad, mad, confused, excited, or even bored, just by moving my face.  You never know where these things lead. You just kind of have hope and faith that like, what you're doing is gon na lead to something bigger.
EventsA: I decided to become an architect with my guidance counselor — I realized I wasn't good at architecture and didn't like it — I graduated from college — I had a few nationally-released records
EventsB: My uncle gave me a copy of Doom on a floppy disk. — I learned a lot about computers through the games. — I worked with a robot named Nexi designed for personal interaction between humans and robots. — I expressed emotions by moving my face.

Q12: Story A has a longer progression and different outcome.
Q13: Both stories use hard work or toughness as a motivator.
FullA: a few record deals and we had , we'd been touring across the country. And we had a deal with a network to do a television show based on The Aquabats. Just going to a network with it, we were going to end up in this kind of development again , so we were like, " Okay, that's it. " We're doing it ourselves. '' We were just naive about it. Like, " Let's put it on the internet. '' So we put a trailer on the internet. And sure enough, we had like two million hits in like... a week. While you're young, you can take chances. But once you get, you know, start having kids , you need to have a steady income. It's hard. It was tough. That's what our culture is losing. We're losing the like, " Make things tough on yourself " so that you're stronger. ''
FullB: You were there for Toy Story and. I was there for Toy, that's what I was hired to do, is Toy Story. Art direct Toy Story. Cool. Every project is so different. Every four years is a four year graduate course in the subject matter of that film. And just to take advantage of that, have fun with some research. Once you get interested in something, go and find out as much as you can about it. It's not that hard to do, especially with the Internet. You can always get a dozen books on the subject and just read through them, and just keep doing that. That's really it.
EventsA: We had record deals. — We toured across the country. — We had a deal with a network to do a television show based on The Aquabats. — We decided to do the show ourselves. — We put a trailer on the internet. — The trailer got two million hits in a week.
EventsB: You were there for Toy Story. — I was hired to art direct Toy Story.

Q12: Both starting doing something they wanted to do and it ended up working out.
Q13: Both stories highlight the character’s strong desire to do what they want even if it has a negative outcome.
FullA: have the confidence or believe in some way or some fashion they'll find themselves. It always terrified me. I have four degrees and never really had any interest in any of them. I was miserable, except in my off-hours, when I was chasing whatever that I liked to do for fun, which was music and comic books and movies. And what happened was, I lost my job, left my wife , and I was homeless. Had no place to live. A guy that was uh, in a search firm, a headhunter, knew all my passions about comic books and movies and music. And he's the one who said, " Marvel Comics, they're looking " for somebody who actually reads comic books " that has a business background. '' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. You don't want to be put into that position of luck ... making a difference in your life at a later age. Be in charge of your destiny now.
FullB: I always grew up with tea being a stable at our dining table. One of my colleagues from my previous job, knew a recruiter at eBay and he recommended me and they ended up hiring me. But one day I was trying to make loose-leaf tea at my desk , and by the time I would make it , I would be late for a meeting. And every time I tried to use tea bags instead, I was never satisfied with the quality because it was not as flavorful, it didn't have as much aroma. That was my first point of inspiration to think about the idea for tea drops. It took me about a year and a half of experimenting. I would spend my weekends and my week nights kind of blending and I was obsessed with figuring it out. And once I had that, I started sharing it with my colleagues and friends and family. Now we're available in over 1,600 retail stores. My logic was, even if this failed, even if nothing ever comes of it, I know I would have gained so much in trying
EventsA: lost my job — left my wife — was homeless — a headhunter told me Marvel Comics was looking for somebody with a business background who reads comic books — became president of Marvel Comics
EventsB: A colleague recommended me to a recruiter at eBay — They hired me — I tried to make loose-leaf tea at my desk — I tried to use tea bags instead — I thought about the idea for tea drops — I spent about a year and a half experimenting — I started sharing tea drops with colleagues, friends, and family — Tea drops became available in over 1,600 retail stores

Q12: The progression from student to teacher took different paths
Q13: They are slightly similar with the fact that teaching and helping others gave them purpose and joy.
FullA: Becoming a teacher really became , I think, a calling for me in high school. My mother's an alcoholic, and home life became chaotic , and that stress started to manifest itself in my self esteem, my expectations for myself at school and so I started to really waver. And then 11th grade, I had AP English with Mister Shirts  and this was a guy on fire for literature and made that place absolutely, infectiously joyful and he really made me want to excel , and so it brings a tear to my eye. To think , I mean, to really think about it, and I've lived it. I saw the door of opportunity closing and to know that a teacher put their hand out and held it open for me to walk through it. You know and the idea that I could do that for other kids, that I could spend my life doing that. You know, that is the highest calling.
FullB: I have an education degree, and then math as a minor. And I did teaching for six years , but I still wanted to do that, just not in the education system, so I became a corporate trainer. Which is how I ended up with AT&T. People wanted teachers that could the teach the math or the sciences. I'm like , that's the easy part, yeah sure, I'll do that. My family did not want me to be a teacher. Math was like my ultimate favorite subject. So my teachers, my parents, they were like, you need to be engineer. You need to be engineer. So I came to Texas , went to a really strong engineering school, and it was not the best experience. And I said, if this is what engineering is, I don't wan na do it. So at that time, without telling anyone, went back to school that next semester and studied to be a teacher. My mother was like, you're never gon na make any money. Like okay, I'll figure that part out later. It's like okay, yeah , I may be a broke teacher , but I'll be a happy teacher , and I'll be doing so much good and it would be worth it.
EventsA: My home life became chaotic — I started to waver in my self esteem and expectations for myself at school — I had AP English with Mister Shirts in 11th grade — Mister Shirts made the class joyful — Mister Shirts made me want to excel — A teacher held the door of opportunity open for me to walk through
EventsB: became a corporate trainer — ended up with AT&T — came to Texas — went to a strong engineering school — decided not to do engineering — went back to school the next semester — studied to be a teacher

Q12: Both left a career for a new job.
Q13: Both stories have characters pursuing jobs they enjoy.
FullA: When I joined the military, I had literally nothing. I was in a holding center, in a juvenile holding center and my recruiter came and rescued me. Needless to say , when I went to boot camp, I thought it was actually kind of easy and like I had never had so much food before in my life. When I joined the military, I originally signed up as a gunner's mate. I got out, felt like something was missing, I ended up moving out here for a job, and I was, like, guns , I know guns. I can do this job, that was easy. That was my turnaround moment. Okay.
FullB: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
EventsA: I joined the military — My recruiter came and rescued me — I went to boot camp — I signed up as a gunner's mate — I got out — I moved out here for a job
EventsB: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop

Q12: Both characters experienced set backs early on.
Q13: Slightly similar with the round about way the characters came to do the thing they were passionate about.
FullA: here in Boston. And uh, I went for a semester , realized I wasn't gon na be able to go back because of kind of financial hardship, and took two years off from school and was working. I pretty much had always realized that I wanted to write from a pretty young age. I had always enjoyed writing. I did sports for a while , and then I actually left sports 'cause I wasn't sure if writing definitely was what I wanted to do , and I feel like I-I wanted to test myself. At night, I would work at a supermarket , and I was like, shagging carriages for like two years. And I actually worked at a bookstore for a little while , and I booked all the bands that played -- they had like a cafÃ © that would have live music there every weekend , and I, you know, worked in the cafÃ © making coffee and doing all that stuff. And ah, I realized at the end of maybe like a year, a year  and a half, that I-I totally missed writing, totally missed sports. It was probably one of the most valuable lessons that I learned in my life , was just going away from it for a little while to see how much I would miss it.
FullB: of my scholarship and working at a comic shop part-time. And at night, after I did my homework, was doing samples and sending them off to all the comic book companies. So I did that for... about two or three years. After 300 rejections, phone rings and they went, " All right, we'll give you a job. '' So I was able to sort of jump right out of college and go right into doing comic books. Now, it was only ten pages , and it was, it was 60 bucks a page. But you don't have to get into the " A '' spot in the first two years of your life. You don't have to do it. You do a lot of interviews , you're going to find out that where they started at 22 and where they're at when you're interviewing them sort of went a little bit like this. You know those Family Circus cartoons, where the kid sort of takes the long way around?
EventsA: went for a semester in Boston — realized I wasn't going to be able to go back because of financial hardship — took two years off from school — worked at a supermarket at night for two years — worked at a bookstore for a little while — booked all the bands that played at the bookstore cafe — worked in the cafe making coffee — realized after a year to a year and a half that I missed writing and sports
EventsB: worked at a comic shop part-time — did samples and sent them off to comic book companies — received 300 rejections — got a job offer from a comic book company — started doing comic books — completed ten pages of comic book work

Q12: First sentence event in both is about a past event that led up to present day and the following sentences described how situations progressed
Q13: The way they are written gramatically and the subject matter/plot are completlely different
FullA: July 20th, 1988, 27 years ago yesterday, I broke my neck in a diving accident. It left me a quadriplegic at the cervical four, five level. The only thing that anybody expected from me was to breathe. Alls I could do was go higher. And so I basically was starting over again at that point. And I was always so ashamed of having this learning disability. I never told anybody about my learning disability. I went all the way through college getting the accommodations for being in a wheel chair and not letting anybody know that I was dyslexic. There is no wheelchair for dyslexia. And I struggle with that everyday.
FullB: It was interesting because we were all really little, like I was six , she was eight , she was eleven. So it was like arriving in this completely foreign country and we didn't have anyone except our parents and the three of us. [sister # 2] We were really excited. I think we've always been just really adventurous. And our parents decided to come here because it was a better place for better opportunity. You know , they thought, " Oh look , you know, we're gon na have a new life, " and the girls can become lawyers and accountants -- '' [sister # 3] " They won't end up being seamstresses . '' [sister # 2] So we actually ended up being exactly what they didn't want us to be, which is seamstresses. I think with our parents , we've always had to prove to them that we could do something. I just remember a lot of fighting and a lot of crying. And them just going , " Well we didn't come here for you to do this . '' And I'm like, " Well it's not for you, like, I can't live " what you want me to be. ''
EventsA: I broke my neck in a diving accident on July 20th, 1988. — The accident left me a quadriplegic at the cervical four, five level. — I started over again at that point. — I never told anybody about my learning disability. — I went all the way through college getting accommodations for being in a wheelchair without letting anybody know that I was dyslexic.
EventsB: They arrived in a completely foreign country. — Their parents decided to come to the new country for better opportunities. — They ended up becoming seamstresses despite their parents' wishes. — They had a lot of fighting and crying with their parents about their life choices.

Q12: First sentence is an event that took place in the past and ultimately led to last sentence which is present day.  The sentences in the middle are events that are meant to show how the initial plan resulted in something different
Q13: Only slightly similar because they are both written so poorly and nearly impossible to understand.  As well, the first story has a clear question and answer structure .
FullA: Originally, I thought I was just gon na be a contractor. Then I decided I was gon na study architecture so I moved out to California. And throughout all that, Eli and I met each other out in California. And I tried Switchel for the first time. A month later, we sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont. And we've done it again every week. Can you just talk about what is in it? Yeah, of course. Switchel is an American heritage beverage originally created by farmers for a hay-time thirst quencher. Back then it was the first functional beverage. And it's still a functional beverage now. But we just had fun creating versatile uses for it. Do you guys have any advice based on your experiences for people trying to think about how to find work or life that's meaningful for them? Show up. Show up and do the work. Make yourself valuable. It takes a lot of time to manage people when you bring them on. So I'm gon na go for the person who's already shows that they're halfway there.
FullB: I'd be a UN official. Early on, I won an award, at age 15, was sent around the world. Um...  and uh, transformation. And I knew, " My life's international work. '' And I was gon na learn languages , and you know , I just knew it. And I could say , " Well I " was blessed with clarity and a great breakthrough . '' And it would have been logical for me to now set focus on that. But happily, I did this  and I did that, and-and I stumbled and I didn't join the UN. But I had a very enriching and confusing bundle of experiences , but it allowed me to have an eclectic set of tools that I think really made it possible for me to make a difference. If you aren't completely uncomfortable, completely off-balance, completely beyond your competence, you're missing. Because it's in being off-balance that you really see.
EventsA: I decided to study architecture — I moved out to California — Eli and I met each other in California — I tried Switchel for the first time — We sold the first jar at the farmer's market in Vermont
EventsB: I won an award at age 15 — I was sent around the world — I had a great breakthrough — I stumbled — I didn't join the UN

'' And I was 45 years old...  44 years old before I became president of Marvel Comics, Spiderman's boss. And there was this moment , I remember just thinking , this is not me , this is not what I want to be in my life. I really just had to drop everything and start over and just move , and I just explored.
