Q12: Slightly similar in that the series of events are disconnected and don't at all summarize the story adequately.  They both miss key information and are without start and finish
Q13: First story aims to show that you must be passionate about your work and the second shares a story about how life can change instantly and entirely switch your focus
FullA: being anxious about my future. I think I started to make plans or ... to really think of what I'm going to do by the time I was 30. I run into students or young designers who say, " Oh, you know , like, I really wanted to study art, " but my parents said, ` Oh , you'll never make any money '' ` with that , ' so I studied graphic design instead . '' And I think that almost always is a mistake. Because, uh, if you don't have the passion for it, you're not gon na be a great graphic designer. So I really think that, that figuring out what you have passion at and pursuing that is a very very worthwhile thing.
FullB: I'd been a real estate agent , I owned an art gallery. I thought, really, my main pur-goal was to really be a good wife, a good mother , and then my life changed completely. My second son was born with a lung disease. They didn't think he'd make it , he got jaundice, and when I brought him home, he'd lost the ability to wake to feed, and so I mean for me, I thought, watching him struggle to breathe, I'd never take breathing for granted again. And I think that's sort of the beginning of me becoming an environmentalist. And so many times, I feel like I'm paying back the debt, because why should I be so lucky? What can I do to survive this life and be a success, so when the end of my road comes -- which people don't wan na talk about, 'cause the end of the road is gon na come for us -- I can look back  and say, " I really feel good about it ''? And it may not be something globally. I think that if you touch anyone's life , then you're a success.
EventsA: I started to make plans for my future. — I ran into students or young designers who said they wanted to study art but their parents discouraged them. — I studied graphic design instead.
EventsB: Her second son was born with a lung disease — He got jaundice — She brought him home — He lost the ability to wake to feed — She watched him struggle to breathe

Q12: they both actual neglected some important steps along the way that more clearly explain how they transitioned from the first to last event
Q13: They both seem inclined to demonstrate that what you loved to do when you were young can in fact be your future career even if you thought otherwise
FullA: Where were you when you were our age, 22, 23? I was in Chile. I was about to finish college. And I have a bachelor's in linguistics, English linguistics, so I spoke English before i came here. And at that time the only possibility I'd say that was offered to me was to teach English. I was coming from the third world to the first world. I didn't get out of my apartment for about year. And then I came across this ad. They were looking for a coordinator in this place. I think that there are roads for you in life. And if you want to take a different road life is always going to take you back to that one. For example, teaching for me. As soon as I started teaching, I loved it.
FullB: I actually had no idea that tech was a thing. I was in my third year studying chemistry and biology. And I had a friend that graduated , and he taught himself how to code. And we were hanging out , and I was just watching him type away at his computer. And I was like, I used to write code when I was eight years old. And had I known that software was a career that was an obtainable thing for me to do , I would have hands down done it much earlier. But I think also even when I was in school, the idea of computer science classes just seemed really intimidating. From a distance, it looks so complex. But then if you actually learn how to code, it's like, every line is actually very simple. Pretty much just, I sunk my teeth in and was like, I got ta just do it until I make it happen. And so from then on, as a professional software engineer, you're building stuff everyday. And they ask me, what do you want to work on? I'm like , I wan na work on something I haven't done before. I mean , I don't know how to do it immediately, but I know how to figure it out.
EventsA: I was in Chile — I was about to finish college — I spoke English before I came here — I didn't get out of my apartment for about a year — I came across an ad — They were looking for a coordinator — I started teaching — I loved teaching
EventsB: A friend graduated and taught himself how to code — I watched him type at his computer — I remembered writing code when I was eight years old — I decided to learn to code seriously — I became a professional software engineer

FullA: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
FullB: So going back into the time when you were first starting out and into producing, how is it like coping with being dyslexic and trying to work around that? When I came out and I had this film , I then started looking for jobs and I just was trying to figure out what should be the next step and going for job interviews and I was nervous about working for other people. I was worried that people would find out that there were skills that I really couldn't do. So I shied away from certain things and that led me to people who were being independent filmmakers, because they were more peers  and we were all saying, okay , let's go raise money. Let's go try to do this. And in retrospect, it was great and it sort of lead me down an interesting path , but I think it was partly, cuz I was scared to do the other. I was scared that I would be found out. I think the best thing about having LD that helped me in film is I've never been somebody who assumed you wouldn't make mistakes. I've never thought that anything was gon na be a straight line and that you get there quickly. That's just not how I've learned and how my life ever went in school, certainly. So I think that's sort of applicable to most young people that you have to be willing to assume that might happen to you, but don't you think a lot of LD kids already know that. You're already kinda prepared that, that's gon na be true. So I think if you're not ashamed of that, if you own that, it makes it so much easier.
EventsA: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop
EventsB: I came out and had a film — I started looking for jobs — I went for job interviews — I shied away from certain things — I met people who were independent filmmakers — We decided to raise money — We tried to make a film

FullA: It's sort of a pattern in my life. I didn't get my culinary degree -- I got thrown out -- but I mean , I went and apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe , so, that's really where I learned. But going from a fine dining chef to running , you know, a beer bar seems like it's a downgrade in a way, but it really wasn't. It was actually , there's a lot of things that are more challenging about what I do. We didn't have a business plan. Didn't write one , there's no such thing. I've never written a business plan in my life. Yeah, I learned everything on the fly. I learned how to tap kegs -- never tapped a beer keg in my life. It's been amazingly educational, but sometimes you just learn by doing. Again, there's no school for this. Culinary school didn't teach me this. No one told me what to do -- not my dad, my mom. I did what I wanted to do without any exterior influence. When you say, " Where do you " find the motivation? '' The only motivation that's ever genuine comes from within.
FullB: One of the things that's difficult for me to describe myself is, I've had multiple experiences , and I think all of which have been very significant in my evolution. Originally majoring in geology because I liked rocks, And when they threw physics at me , I decided that this was not for me. But I clearly didn't know what I was doing. When I came up here, I jumped from job to job trying to figure out , I mean, seven months at a time, trying to figure out what I wanted to do. And again, it took years later when I discovered community education , and I really, I felt the passion. I was wondering , yeah. What's that like? What's that like to kind of be searching for yourself and not find it yet? I don't think the search ever ends, first of all. And I don't think one ever finds oneself. I think it's a constant journey. I think it's a constant search. And, trying to enjoy it as I go along. I see more and more the pressure on your generation and that before you, of making decisions about life. That somehow, if you don't decide where you go and how to get there, there's failure up ahead. But I do think that when I allowed myself the enjoyment of the journey and was not fearful that it would leave me to a dead end, then it was fun.
EventsA: I got thrown out of my culinary degree program — I apprenticed for two-and-a-half years in Europe — I went from being a fine dining chef to running a beer bar — I learned how to tap kegs
EventsB: Majored in geology — Decided physics was not for me — Jumped from job to job — Discovered community education — Felt passion for community education

FullA: In first grade when they asked me what I wanted to do, I said I want to study the stars. So, it's lucky that it worked out. Most of the times people say, I wan na be a football player, whatever, movie star, it doesn't work out. In my case it worked out , but I was lucky that way. Astronomy, before I went to college, was something I really thought I could do. But I just doubt myself a lot. Was there any moments where you really doubted yourself? Of course, all the time. It's inevitable. When you're trying to push yourself, there are always moments when you think, maybe this is too hard , maybe I can not do it. But my answer to that is that, if you don't feel that way, it means you're not pushing yourself enough. If you never go out of your comfort zone, then you're not really trying very hard. It's part of learning and part of growing up , is figuring out things that you didn't know you could do, and then you do them. Sometimes you fail. Sometimes you succeed. Let's put it this way. First of all, in research most of what you do, fails miserably, because you're trying to do something that nobody knows how to do. So you have to really like failure. Embrace failure. Accept that failure is gon na be part of the process.
FullB: I think, in the history of this country at least. I mean I see your t-shirt where it has, uh, the Black Panthers. So I was born in Chicago when all that stuff was happening. When you're born in that environment, it's kind of like, " Yeah, you're supposed to be " doing something around social justice , '' because, you know, I saw Chicago burn down. I saw , you know... the tanks roll through our neighborhood. And I didn't realize I had that whole wealth of history and knowledge and activity going on around me because I was in it. Sometimes when you're doing something you love, it doesn't -- you don't find it , it finds you.
EventsA: They asked me what I wanted to do in first grade — I said I wanted to study the stars — It worked out for me — I doubted myself a lot before college
EventsB: I was born in Chicago when all that stuff was happening — I saw Chicago burn down — I saw the tanks roll through our neighborhood

FullA: five or six bands, you know, 'cause people would come to me and go , " Oh we got a band, too . '' And by having the most popular band in St. Louis, which was a band called the . We were-became the radio station's band, which meant they played like 80-100 commercials a week. " Hey, the , " we playin ' at 66 Drive-In. '' And it'd be, " Steve on trumpet [do-do-do-do-do-do ] '' So being the popular band in town , I started booking other bands, 'cause when I was already booked, I didn't see any reason to turn people down. I said, " Wait a second, let me see if I can get another band. '' Well, that eventually led to booking 1100 bands. So we were the largest band-booking agency in the country , and I was like 18 years old. So went from local bands, regional bands, to national bands. And the first show we did was in 1969 was the Grateful Dead. You guys sitting here all have ideas. Whether you pursue them ot not is up to you. Don't later on look back and say , " God, I wish " I would've done that. ''
FullB: something with business. I didn't know exactly what I was going to do. My passion wasn't there , but that's where the money was at. And I'm thinking, " This oughta pay the bills , " I ` ma have a family. This is what I'm going to do. " I'm just gon na paint on the side. '' But it got to that point where I couldn't work because I kept hearing that I got to pursue my dream as a, as an artist. That Obama shoe came to me. And I woke up at two o'clock in the morning and I painted that shoe. And I went to the mall and took a picture, put it on MySpace. No big deal. Didn't think nothing of it. And then like the first big thing that happened was the Smithsonian e-mailin ' me and I thought it was a joke. And I cried. I was like, I was almost homeless in January. Like, had I quit, had I quit a month before I made that shoe , had I quit an hour before I made that shoe, and decided, " I'm just gon na forget about art , '' this would have never happened.
EventsA: became the radio station's band — played 80-100 commercials a week — started booking other bands — booked 1100 bands — became the largest band-booking agency in the country — did the first show in 1969 with the Grateful Dead
EventsB: I woke up at two o'clock in the morning — I painted that shoe — I went to the mall and took a picture — I put the picture on MySpace — The Smithsonian emailed me — I cried

FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I worked in technology up until 1998 in which I struck out on my own and I built an engineering company. Had good contracts. 9/11 hits a couple of years later, and all of a sudden a lot of the major corporations and people  I was dealing with, their stocks fell, and they stopped giving work. I went and became a screener at the airport. I want you to think about this. I worked for a major corporation, I'm a screener, people that were my clients and then I work with , were coming through the airport. You got me reminiscing and thinking back here. But, I stuck to my principles. I knew I was better than this, all right? And I had a plan. So I took what I knew, even though I was working in terrorism and mass transit, I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl. And so, I knew from that, I was as good or better than anybody there.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I struck out on my own — I built an engineering company — 9/11 happened — major corporations and people I was dealing with stopped giving work — I became a screener at the airport — I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl

Q12: Both event sequences were set in motion by what the people wanted to do. They did they things that interests them.
Q13: Both stories stressed the importance of being independent. How being independent will ultimately lead you on a life path.
FullA: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
FullB: So going back into the time when you were first starting out and into producing, how is it like coping with being dyslexic and trying to work around that? When I came out and I had this film , I then started looking for jobs and I just was trying to figure out what should be the next step and going for job interviews and I was nervous about working for other people. I was worried that people would find out that there were skills that I really couldn't do. So I shied away from certain things and that led me to people who were being independent filmmakers, because they were more peers  and we were all saying, okay , let's go raise money. Let's go try to do this. And in retrospect, it was great and it sort of lead me down an interesting path , but I think it was partly, cuz I was scared to do the other. I was scared that I would be found out. I think the best thing about having LD that helped me in film is I've never been somebody who assumed you wouldn't make mistakes. I've never thought that anything was gon na be a straight line and that you get there quickly. That's just not how I've learned and how my life ever went in school, certainly. So I think that's sort of applicable to most young people that you have to be willing to assume that might happen to you, but don't you think a lot of LD kids already know that. You're already kinda prepared that, that's gon na be true. So I think if you're not ashamed of that, if you own that, it makes it so much easier.
EventsA: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop
EventsB: I came out and had a film — I started looking for jobs — I went for job interviews — I shied away from certain things — I met people who were independent filmmakers — We decided to raise money — We tried to make a film

Q12: Both sequences involved soul searching that proved fruitful.
Q13: Both individuals marched to the beat of their own drum. They're both doing things they enjoy doing.
FullA: 19 years ago, actually, I started working for SLUG Magazine. The previous owner of SLUG heard about me, and called me up and asked me to shoot a cover. So that's how I first became a staff member of SLUG, was shooting a cover. And then from that point forward, I became a managing editor , and then two years later, I had the opportunity to take over the magazine , and that's when I officially became editor and then publisher. And I've always felt different from my family , and from kind of being part of the peer group that I grew up in, I just always didn't quite connect. But then I kind of learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is, and the work here that we could do to find others that feel that way. Where they may not feel that way at home, or at school, or in a lot of other environments. But here in SLUG Magazine, we can really appreciate them for being different. I think it goes back to that love, right? I really love doing what I do, and hearing these stories from these individuals that come up to you and say hey , I would not be where I am today if it wasn't for my experience with SLUG Magazine. Hearing that feedback and that validation from other individuals about how we've affected their lives in a positive way, and that's priceless.
FullB: And the first summer I was out there I got my commercial fishing license because we had no other way to make money. Well, I ended up living on Nantucket for four more years and building this business. And even two or three years into Nantucket Nectars, my parents were like, " You're starting a juice company? " Are you kidding me? What do you mean you're " starting a juice company? Who starts a juice company? '' Could anyone have ever predicted my path? You know, " Okay, this is how you're going " to make it. You should move to Nantucket, " start a boat business, end up being a fisherman, " and then get into distribution, and start a juice business. " That's how you get into juice. '' Like, who would ever say that?
EventsA: I started working for SLUG Magazine — The previous owner of SLUG called me up and asked me to shoot a cover — I shot a cover — I became a managing editor — I had the opportunity to take over the magazine — I officially became editor and then publisher — I learned to appreciate Salt Lake City for what it is — Individuals came up to me and said they would not be where they are today if it wasn't for their experience with SLUG Magazine
EventsB: I got my commercial fishing license — I ended up living on Nantucket for four more years — I built this business — My parents questioned me about starting a juice company

Q12: The events in sequence B are more life and death as well as shorter.
Q13: Both people are in situations where they help others through their actions. Their early hardships molded them into helpful people.
FullA: I'm from El Salvador. I came to the United States when I was eight years old. My mom left me at age four with my grandma and my sister that was two years old at the time. Obviously searching for the American dream. So I was in El Salvador. My grandma raised me until I was eight and I remember one day she's like so your mom says one of you can go with her. And that's cuz my mum had finally saved enough money to pay a coyotaje. And so my mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States and so I remember being with a group of people and I was the only child. I'm lucky that I was I was okay the whole time , but it was a journey of about over a month. How do you still have a story of yourself that you identify with, that a lot of people don't relate to. But then still have this professional grounding, this world that you've created for yourself? I think it traces back to family. I get my work ethic from my mother. And it's because in high school she was working all the time. The financial struggle that I saw at home, also pushed me to complete my four year degree cuz I knew I wanted more. And even today, she still has the same lifestyle. I live at home with her still. But ever since the day I came back from college, I support financially. So I know that I have to provide rent money in order for my mom, my sister, my niece to have a home. Cuz my sister's also a single mom.
FullB: August of 2005 , I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina. And then September of 2005 was when I received my cancer diagnosis. So it's like this happened and then this happened. And so, hey, you're a veteran now. And I really didn't know what that meant. Mm-hm. But it basically meant that I was on my own. And I had thought at that particular time that maybe I was an isolated case and then I saw that there were tens of thousands of women veterans who were homeless. Is that what helped motivate you to provide this non-profit organization for homeless women and children? Yes, it definitely was. It's ultimately like everything came full circle, that maybe this is why I went through these things. So I had to be that catalyst, to be that voice for this forgotten population.
EventsA: My mom left me with my grandma and my sister — My grandma raised me until I was eight — My mom said one of us could go with her — My mom saved enough money to pay a coyotaje — My mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States — I traveled with a group of people to the United States — I completed my four year degree — I came back from college — I started supporting my family financially — I provided rent money for my mom, sister, and niece
EventsB: I lost everything to Hurricane Katrina — I received my cancer diagnosis

Q12: Story A is more about their experiences with traveling to the US to make a better life for themselves.
Q13: Both stories are about the benefits of working hard and persevering.
FullA: I'm from El Salvador. I came to the United States when I was eight years old. My mom left me at age four with my grandma and my sister that was two years old at the time. Obviously searching for the American dream. So I was in El Salvador. My grandma raised me until I was eight and I remember one day she's like so your mom says one of you can go with her. And that's cuz my mum had finally saved enough money to pay a coyotaje. And so my mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States and so I remember being with a group of people and I was the only child. I'm lucky that I was I was okay the whole time , but it was a journey of about over a month. How do you still have a story of yourself that you identify with, that a lot of people don't relate to. But then still have this professional grounding, this world that you've created for yourself? I think it traces back to family. I get my work ethic from my mother. And it's because in high school she was working all the time. The financial struggle that I saw at home, also pushed me to complete my four year degree cuz I knew I wanted more. And even today, she still has the same lifestyle. I live at home with her still. But ever since the day I came back from college, I support financially. So I know that I have to provide rent money in order for my mom, my sister, my niece to have a home. Cuz my sister's also a single mom.
FullB: That sophomore year was that critical year where everything kind of just hit me that you really have to take ownership of this education thing. The investment you're making in time and money has a lot of risk or potential to be wasted. And I didn't have the good fortune of something being maybe given to me on the back end in terms of a family business or something I could fall back on. I really had to make something happen in school. That wasn't maybe very clear to me, that freshman, first part of sophomore year. But the sophomore year came to a close. I started to get my act together a little bit and find that direction. Maybe as I said earlier, it's really about being drawn to the next adventure in career or life. Some of the most impactful job changes weren't necessarily going to the next higher level of responsibility, but really more what people might consider lateral moves. Those lateral moves really had an impact on expanding my breadth of experience, my understanding. When you're not driven just by the financial rewards , but you're driven by the broader set of rewards, how it makes  you feel inside, how you can impact people around you. I feel those are the things that really start to hit home in terms of making the right choices, at least for me. I think we all have to find that path for ourselves, though.
EventsA: My mom left me with my grandma and my sister — My grandma raised me until I was eight — My mom said one of us could go with her — My mom saved enough money to pay a coyotaje — My mom trusted a coyotaje to bring me to the United States — I traveled with a group of people to the United States — I completed my four year degree — I came back from college — I started supporting my family financially — I provided rent money for my mom, sister, and niece
EventsB: The sophomore year came to a close — I started to get my act together — I found that direction

Q12: Both stories included events that set them on the path they're on today.
Q13: The person in story A took a risk that acted as a life lesson to them. Story B talks about how dyslexia affected them growing up and the challenges that brought.
FullA: I work here at Fossil. I'm an IT solution manager working in the e-commerce division. Typically a day in e-commerce for me , I manage a team that we're currently rolling out global websites for fossil.com. But I didn't know growing up what is it that I wanted to do , okay? I took a leap of faith , and so in 2000 I started a company called BTV Corporation and where I was doing consulting work for about eight years. It was a little bit risky , but I think the way to advance , you're going to have to take risk, right? But you want it to be a calculated risk. You want to make sure that you're making smart decisions, okay, and not impulse decisions, if you will. So, would my life be different had I not started my own company or even came to Fossil? I'm sure it would be. I don't know what that would be , but I would say , in the end, I am happy with where that journey took me and I appreciate all those that's been around me to kinda support me through that effort.
FullB: When I was really little I think I had a few teachers when I was in kindergarten and first grade that I just adored. And so I would come home and practice being a teacher. From then on, I kind of just thought that's what I wanted to do. And I actually didn't know that I was dyslexic until I started my college career. I did a little part-time internship in a first grade room  and in that classroom, there were kiddos with dyslexia. And so I was learning more with the teacher, just kind of asking questions. And the more that I learned about it, the more it hit home that that's exactly what was going on with me as a kiddo. But it's amazing to get to teach student with dyslexia now. And know exactly what they're going through. It's just , it's really neat that they had that, they had that connection with me.
EventsA: I took a leap of faith — I started a company called BTV Corporation in 2000 — I did consulting work for about eight years
EventsB: I had a few teachers in kindergarten and first grade that I adored — I came home and practiced being a teacher — I started my college career — I did a part-time internship in a first grade room — I learned about dyslexia with the teacher — I realized that I was dyslexic as a kid — I taught students with dyslexia

Q12: These event sequences both show a progression of sorts, but it's so different that I wouldn't consider them similar at all because of that. Other than both sequences expressing a progression, everything else is totally unrelated. They are people living different lives in different world with different motivations.
Q13: These stories are very different from one another. First and foremost, each person's motivations are completely different. In story A the guy like getting free stuff in return for sponsoring different companies on his vehicle with stickers or whatever. He seemed to like not only the free merchandise, but the attention as well. In story B the person's main motivation is wanting to educate people and have a meaningful impact on society through media. Very different motivations from very different people. Also the settings in the stories were very very different from one another as well as the writing styles.
FullA: And I didn't think anything of it  and then there was a show, a car show. So I went to this car show  and I go all right, washed my car and waxed it , hey, it's kinda cool , so I'll take you there. A company called Go Rhino. They came up to me and said , hey, if we give you our brush cards for free, will you put it on your car, and when you go to the next show, put our sticker on your car? I go, yeah, of course I will. Once I got like a bunch of sponsors and they gave me stuff for free , and I did it. And it ended up on a magazine. It did a cover, this and that. I'm like , I wan na do another one.
FullB: The power of finding out something which people aren't talking about was actually very important to me. And that's basically what I've done much of my life, almost all of it. I'm one of six children. My parents worked in the media. My mother was a writer for women's magazines, my father wrote radio plays and did television, and so we all became very interested in story and narrative. I thought there are people who actually will pay you to do this kind of work , so maybe I ought to go into news. So I spent a lot of my life in print journalism, daily newspapers. I was in the newsroom of the Washington Post all during Watergate. I was both an editor and a reporter. I was sent to Moscow at one point, for four years, as Moscow Bureau Chief, which was an extraordinary encounter with a society whose citizens were denied access to factual information. Period. And it made it even more important to use the powers that are given to us in these open and democratic societies in a way that will inform others. So, what has been part of my life just started out in a certain pattern. It just stayed in that course ever since , and now I'm at NPR. What this place does , and other great icons of journalism, the reporting of fact conveyed in a non-polemical, civil dialogue to readers, listeners, viewers, and bring to them extraordinary information they couldn't possibly have any other way. It comes down to this. Thomas Jefferson, before he wrote the Declaration of Independence, in thinking about this republic, these people were going to try to invent in the late 1700s, made a very clear observation. He basically said that people can not be both ignorant and free.
EventsA: went to a car show — washed and waxed my car — went to the car show with someone — a company called Go Rhino offered free brush cards — put the brush cards on my car — put the Go Rhino sticker on my car at the next show — got a bunch of sponsors who gave me stuff for free — put the sponsors' items on my car — appeared on a magazine cover
EventsB: I spent a lot of my life in print journalism — I was in the newsroom of the Washington Post all during Watergate — I was both an editor and a reporter — I was sent to Moscow for four years as Moscow Bureau Chief — I started working at NPR

Q12: These events are extremely different from one another. One has all these elements that involve other people and revolve around what she is trying to do to help women being trafficked in Siberia. In story B he mentions when he started practicing law, then goes to I started baking and people liked it. Totally different ball park. Not related whatsoever.
Q13: So at first I was initially thinking there's not really a lot in common here but then I realized both of these people describe doing something because they felt like it was bigger than them, or like it had purpose or something a long those lines. Like they were meant to be doing what they're doing. Also, their writing styles are both a bit chaotic. Not in the exact same way, but nonetheless a bit harder to read than you're average story.
FullA: consumer grade cameras, and I bought one in 1989 and said to myself, " One day I'm gon na " make a documentary that makes a difference. '' A friend of a friend came and said, " Do you have a minute? " Let's - let's, ah, go out and get a drink. " I want to talk to you. '' And he said, " I was, I was " in the Russian far East investigating the trade " in Siberian tiger pelts , and they offered to sell me women . '' " Let's do something about it. '' He came to me because I had done international human rights work and I knew a lot about women's issues. It wasn't something I was familiar with in 1995. So I started researching it and then just quit my job two weeks later. and pitched up his office and was like, " Okay. I can wait tables if I need to " in order to make this happen. '' And um, I created a phony company called International Liaison Specializing in Foreign Models, Escorts, and Entertainers. And then we posed as foreign buyers interested in purchasing women. When you have the privilege of freedom and, you know, and-and the opportunity that that affords you , then I think you have a responsibility to , you know, to try to ensure that there - there is actually freedom.
FullB: from lawyer to baker began very quickly once I started practicing law, because I kinda put this out, I didn't like it. It didn't speak to me. You can't make something three-dimensional and share it with other people. It doesn't have a nice smell to it. [Roadtripper # 1] Yeah.  You can't cut it and ask people to eat it. [Roadtripper # 1] Yeah.  And ah, I started baking in 1999. People started liking it. I was like, " There's something " happening here that I need to pay attention to. '' It matters so much just to, um, to follow up that little whisper or voice that's in your head or in your heart. That's the one. It's the one. It feels like it's not , it's scary , you want to deny it , you want to say, " No, I'm going to ignore it . '' But don't do it.
EventsA: bought a consumer grade camera in 1989 — a friend of a friend asked to get a drink to talk — he said he was investigating the trade in Siberian tiger pelts in the Russian far East — he said they offered to sell him women — started researching women's issues in 1995 — quit job two weeks later — pitched up at his office and said he could wait tables to make it happen — created a phony company called International Liaison Specializing in Foreign Models, Escorts, and Entertainers — posed as foreign buyers interested in purchasing women
EventsB: I started practicing law — I started baking in 1999 — People started liking my baking

Q12: I was torn between selecting moderately similar and slightly similar because they both are describing the events that set them on the path of their creative journey's. That being said... The actual events themselves aren't actually that similar and I feel like a big part of the reason I feel that they are is because I know their whole stories and can attribute those specific events to being what set them on a similar creative journey. However, if I saw these events without having read their stories first I might not think they were really that similar. One describes trial and error - getting kicked out of college, trying radio, then eventually coming to film. The other more or less took one photo with his friends camera and realized there might be something there that he could pursue, so it kind of fell into his lap. At least compared to the person in story A.
Q13: I think these stories are moderately similar fro a few different reasons. First of all, both stories have something to do with a person who was still trying to figure out what they wanted to do in life or was still figuring things out when they discovered what it is they wanted to start doing. They had different motivations it seems (Story A was doing it more because it was something they wanted to pursue and was more passion related, whereas Story B was more or less doing it because they discovered they were good at it and it would be a much needed financial opportunity for them). Another similarity is the actual hobby/career/medium (whatever you call it) Story A ended up getting into film, and Story B discovered photography which are similar in nature. Then one more similarity is the writing style. Both writers were not very coherent and their stories were lacking in structural integrity so to speak.
FullA: And so I had kind of just spent three years, three-four years, um, just kind of working service jobs. I finally enrolled back in college , but I really didn't know what I wanted to do. And so I ended up , you know, I mean, basically partying my one year in college away. You know , my grades were so bad , I wasn't invited to go back. I think, just kind of at the back of my mind , I had always wanted to do something that was creative. But, you know, when you're growing up on the reservation, I mean, you can be creative, but you probably won't get paid for it. 'Cause when I started doing radio, I absolutely loved it  and, you know , I just ran with it. I tried to do the best job that I could. It was while I was doing that job that I stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary that I worked on. I mean , I kind of just went with the film thing from there. I think you just know when you discover what it is that you want to do.
FullB: how to use his camera. And we were climbing and I took this one shot with it , and then he tried to sell his photography and this one company bought one photo , and it was the one that I took with his camera. And at the time, whatever, I could, I lived off of nothing , you know, and they paid $ 500 for the photo. And I was like, " I could live on $ 500 a month easy living " out of the back of my car! I only have to take 12 photos " a year. And I could live, like, like, " on the road forever. '' One of my mentors, I love it, I mean, it's a simple idea, he's just like, " Commit, " and then figure it out. '' Because you can't get anywhere unless you commit to something. And never think that you won't be questioning your decision when you're like, doing that... 'cause you will. I still do , you know.
EventsA: enrolled back in college — partied the one year in college away — was not invited to go back to college — started doing radio — stumbled onto the idea for the first documentary — worked on the first documentary
EventsB: I took one shot with his camera — he tried to sell his photography — one company bought one photo — they paid $500 for the photo

Q12: I wanted to select not similar because they are quite literally exact opposites. One starts in academia then leaves because she was doing something against her morals, the other one pursues an education so that they could do something that stood up for something that they felt was morally right. That being said, that actually makes them more similar than different. Because it's basically the same sequence of events, just flipped. It's totally recognizable in reverse, they are kind of the same journey, just played out in a different directions so I put very similar.
Q13: While both people in each story express their morals, it's in different contexts and aren't really comparable in any way that makes these stories similar. Story A was doing something and stopped doing it on account of feeling like it wasn't the right thing to do (and ended up being happy that the maps they developed to predict waves in the ocean were being used by surfers instead of for Navy weapons systems.) and in Story B they describe making a decision to actively pursue a course of action because it was the right thing to do and he wanted to change the way people perceive Hispanic people in the media. So the stories are kind of opposite in the way they express their morals. Not to mention events and content are very different.
FullA: I was learning how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy, to figure out whether their ships are gon na be able to get through a storm or not. How big are the waves gon na be in two days time out in the middle of the Pacific? And it turned out that my students started using that to figure out when to go surfing. And I was in academia , I was in that track. So when I did make that decision to leave there were some people that were shocked  and also people thought it was a waste of a Ph.D, even though my original aim was to join the Navy. I ended up not feeling all that comfortable with the fact that a lot of the research I was doing was effectively weapons systems. But now what I do is, people get up in the morning and they can say , should I go surfing today or not? And they can look at what we make and go , yeah , I might go surf, and it puts smiles on people's faces.
FullB: I come from farm worker parents. It wasn't until I married and I was 28 years of age that I realized that I wasn't gon na go anywhere unless I have an education. So I had to turn my life around to do  what I wanted to do, and what I wanted to do was be in this world of media. So I went to a community college and I transferred to UCLA , and I became a writer. And so, from that to what I do today, I'm an advocate. I do civil rights, civil rights and specifically, in media. When reporting about the Latino community, it was a crime blotter. It was Maria killed Jose because Jose molested her child and the child was doing drugs on the side. It was like that , it was terrible. So we formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition, because how we are perceived is always going to be the way that we are treated. If we're perceived that being the laborers out in the field and so forth, you'll be treated that way. And, we're that, sure of course we are. Right? But the fact is that we're also a great deal more. Never believe that somebody else is gon na do it for you. You have to take the bull by the horns and make the changes.
EventsA: I learned how to build a specific set of maps for the Navy — My students started using the maps to figure out when to go surfing — I made the decision to leave academia — People were shocked by my decision to leave — People thought it was a waste of a Ph.D — I ended up not feeling comfortable with the research I was doing
EventsB: I married at 28 years of age — I realized that I needed an education — I turned my life around — I went to a community college — I transferred to UCLA — I became a writer — I became an advocate — We formed the National Hispanic Media Coalition

Q12: These sequence of events are incredibly different and have no apparent or even subtle connections.
Q13: I feel like these stories aren't similar to each other in terms of there content or there structure. At first I actually wanted to kind of say that they were ever so slightly similar but after reading each story again I realized that the reason I had that initial hint of a feeling they might be similar was because both stories evoke a good emotion in the storyteller. But the events, motivations and lots of other details are totally different. It's not even really the same positive emotion. In story A the narrator describes his primary motivation as wanting to make a change and help more students get through chemistry and the other person in story B is talking about overcoming fear and self-doubt and finding a spark of confidence in himself. So I feel that they are not similar.
FullA: So at Alchemy we are taking the concept of chemistry and science and turning them into game based learning tools for students and for instructors, but in a way that allows for experimentation and play. The path was going toward academic chemistry. I was good at chemistry , I was good at research and all that stuff. But I realized that I always liked working with young people. So I actually, in 1994, went and worked at Detroit Country Day School, which is a private school. And started my job there and loved it, and raised my children. They went through the school , they went to U of M. And after that I started sort of feeling like not as connected to my school as it used to be, because my kids were gone. So I started to look for new things and that was the beginning of Alchemy. And if my learning tools can be shown to help students from everywhere get better. And there's like 50 % fail organic chemistry. If I could cut that down to 40 %, I think that would be success. But, this is not an easy path, it's really hard. But if you're solving a problem that you know needs to be solved, then the hurdles don't feel quite so high.
FullB: where you weren't truly able to talk about emotions, you know. So writing was my vehicle, the doorway out of there. I worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading , and I was so insecure that if there was 50 people listening to me and one person yawning, I'd feel like I failed. And I'd see that person yawning , and I'd have to do something else , you know , I'd have to climb on the chair or, go in their face. And one person got up and applauded , and after a year, after a lifetime of no encouragement, that one person applauding was enough to make me feel, have the confidence to find my destiny. Believe in that destiny, that there's something for you , and then someday it's gon na materialize.
EventsA: went and worked at Detroit Country Day School in 1994 — started my job at Detroit Country Day School — raised my children — my children went through the school — my children went to U of M — started to look for new things — began Alchemy
EventsB: worked up the courage to read a poem at an open poetry reading — saw one person yawning — did something else by climbing on the chair or going in their face — one person got up and applauded

Q13: Story A is about someone who switched many jobs then landed into news sector creating their own business, Story B is about someone in coaching. The only similarity is marketing.
FullA: I started my career in law as a paralegal. So I thought I was gon na be a lawyer and then I kinda never met a happy lawyer. Coming from that environment , I went into film and TV. I knew all these guys that were selling TV shows, market by market, which was known as a syndicator. It is sales , it is pitching , it is being able to speak , I was like, wow that's a great job , I wan na do that. So at that point I convinced some investors to take a chance on something really different. I felt there was a real void in terms of translating video games to proper entertainment. And as I went on my journey to focus on providing an independent, go to source for Esports  and competitive gaming thought well, wait a minute. We can really build the news unlike any other. And so I created Gamer World News and it's growing today. I had a long career in TV and TV syndication and all that, and that switched. And I wouldn't have thought I'd be on national news as a contributor, that wasn't my path. But that led me to do it. So push yourself to do things that are a little outside your comfort zone, that you actually don't think you're qualified for.
FullB: My friend who ran a consulting company that I worked with at Centera is like Karen please come work with me , I have a job for you. And it's with Holy Redeemer Health System. And I said okay, that sounds like fun. Something else you should know about me, I'm a life coach. I'm a Martha Beck trained life coach, and what that means is I coach women like you. And that was one of the draws to this organization. Because not only do I know a lot about marketing, and public relations, and communications, and can do that in my sleep, I'm growing. I'm still growing , and one of the things I wan na do is help others through life coaching. And what advice would you give? Two things, one breathe. Give yourself a chance just to breathe. And the other one would be to find yourself in some quiet moments , and kinda have an internal conversation about what it is, am I on the right track? Yeah. And when you know you're on the right track, it's okay, I'm on the right track. I'm doing the right thing. And just know where you are right now is where you're supposed to be. This is where I'm supposed to be.
EventsA: Started career in law as a paralegal — Went into film and TV — Convinced some investors to take a chance on something different — Created Gamer World News — Became a contributor on national news
EventsB: My friend asked me to work with her at Holy Redeemer Health System. — I said okay to the job offer.

Q12: I mean, both are in school?
Q13: Story A, is about a life story of someone dreaming of becoming a teacher and wishing to escape their life and open the door for kids like their teacher did for him and his other classmates. Story B, is about someone conflicted in their career paths and what their family wants them to do. Both in each stories are in education and wanting to do good for people.
FullA: Becoming a teacher really became , I think, a calling for me in high school. My mother's an alcoholic, and home life became chaotic , and that stress started to manifest itself in my self esteem, my expectations for myself at school and so I started to really waver. And then 11th grade, I had AP English with Mister Shirts  and this was a guy on fire for literature and made that place absolutely, infectiously joyful and he really made me want to excel , and so it brings a tear to my eye. To think , I mean, to really think about it, and I've lived it. I saw the door of opportunity closing and to know that a teacher put their hand out and held it open for me to walk through it. You know and the idea that I could do that for other kids, that I could spend my life doing that. You know, that is the highest calling.
FullB: I have an education degree, and then math as a minor. And I did teaching for six years , but I still wanted to do that, just not in the education system, so I became a corporate trainer. Which is how I ended up with AT&T. People wanted teachers that could the teach the math or the sciences. I'm like , that's the easy part, yeah sure, I'll do that. My family did not want me to be a teacher. Math was like my ultimate favorite subject. So my teachers, my parents, they were like, you need to be engineer. You need to be engineer. So I came to Texas , went to a really strong engineering school, and it was not the best experience. And I said, if this is what engineering is, I don't wan na do it. So at that time, without telling anyone, went back to school that next semester and studied to be a teacher. My mother was like, you're never gon na make any money. Like okay, I'll figure that part out later. It's like okay, yeah , I may be a broke teacher , but I'll be a happy teacher , and I'll be doing so much good and it would be worth it.
EventsA: My home life became chaotic — I started to waver in my self esteem and expectations for myself at school — I had AP English with Mister Shirts in 11th grade — Mister Shirts made the class joyful — Mister Shirts made me want to excel — A teacher held the door of opportunity open for me to walk through
EventsB: became a corporate trainer — ended up with AT&T — came to Texas — went to a strong engineering school — decided not to do engineering — went back to school the next semester — studied to be a teacher

Q12: Story A, is about a retelling of an cause and effect relationship with the suspensions and decreased fights. Story B, is about an influencer happy about their success on Youtube and searching things for their content.
Q13: Story A, is about a retelling from an assumed teacher staff venting about their experience and hopeful outlook for the school to help their students. Story B is about an influencer telling their story and advice to starting out. Nowhere near the same
FullA: Generally, the schools that we work in are pretty negative environments. Our students grow up in homes where they don't necessarily get a chance to learn proper anger management techniques. And so you see a lot of students who get in fights. Or they throw something so that they can get suspended. Or they do something so that they don't have to be there. There's usually something behind that, whether it's they don't feel they are able to succeed. Whether it's they're afraid of what might happen if they do succeed. Whether it's afraid that they are just unable to grasp a concept, so it's kind of sad , but there's always a bright light. City here is there to find those bright lights and make them brighter. We work with kids in attendance, behavior, and course performance, English and math. And our numbers show it, where at the beginning of the year there's so many suspensions, so many fights , and then by the end of the year those are all decreased. You talk about going to something and really wanting to help. What about the people that just don't seem to want it? How did that feel? How'd you work through that? We had these little catchphrases that people throw around , and one of them is, this is hard, be strong. Find something that they do know how to do. Find something that they do like to do, and build that relationship on that. I know that what I do right now is very important. And I'm influencing a student everyday. Every student can succeed , we just need to find the right way to make that happen.
FullB: I started early on, about three years ago , I was doing a YouTube channel, kind of a joke , I was just like , this is fun , I want to make my friend laugh. Hi, I am Mad Bath, during that Boardman Shelton, remember that looking cool and confident outweight everything. Training on the range  is like Crossfit, it is not complete untill you take a selfie. Ooh, I like that one. We started to getting likes and viewership and a following , this could be something. I didn't know how to edit videos , but you have to find self motivation, focus on the end goal, right? So I just spend 40 hours a week on fricking YouTube searching what I wanted. We're the information age , so anything you wan na do is at your fingertips. If you take the time out of your day to really focus, you're gon na be successful.
EventsA: Students got in fights. — Students threw something to get suspended. — Students did something to avoid being at school. — The number of suspensions and fights decreased by the end of the year.
EventsB: I started a YouTube channel about three years ago — I made my friend laugh — We started getting likes and viewership and a following — I spent 40 hours a week on YouTube searching what I wanted

Q12: One is about a race, other is about childhood memeory.
Q13: Story A and B are both about their origins and what they wanna be, so when they grew up they became their childhood idols/core memories.
FullA: Made a couple bucks and I wanted to go race. I read about a guy in Motor Trend Magazine who raced at Pike's Peak and he was just basically an average guy. And we're actually friends now , his name is C Van Tune, he was the editor at Motor Trend. I'm like, man, if that guy can do it , maybe I can do it. So in 1991, I bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4. I thought, well, I wan na go race at Pike's Peak. I got the rulebook, had to put a roll cage in it. And I thought, well, maybe I could modify it too, to make it to go faster. Before I went to Pike's Peak, I read about a race in Nevada called the Silver State Classic. It's a 90 mile race in Nevada where they take a public highway, a state highway , and they just shut it down. And you go as fast as you can go from one city to the next. And so I averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles. So I went 90 miles in 34 minutes. And at that point, I was totally hooked. I got fourth place in the race.
FullB: You know , you're not becoming a doctor where you're changing people's lives physically, but sometimes you make people's lives emotionally a little better. When I was about three years old, I said, " Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, " what do you call that? '' She says, " A comic, a comedian. '' I went, " That's what I wan na be. '' I think a lot of people know what they wan na do , but they don't have the courage to really follow it. I mean, maybe you have maybe a perception that we have never a waning moment of thinking, " This isn't worth it. '' Or doubt or " Oh my gosh '' all the time -- all the time, especially as an actor. The fear of failure is-is what gets you all the time. When you're actually going through the failure, you're like,  " How am I gon na get out of this? " This is bad , but how am I gon na get out of it ? '' But the fear of failure is what keeps people from trying anyway.
EventsA: bought a Mitsubishi 3000GT VR4 in 1991 — got the rulebook for Pike's Peak race — put a roll cage in the car — read about the Silver State Classic race in Nevada — raced 90 miles in the Silver State Classic — averaged 164 miles an hour for 90 miles — finished fourth place in the Silver State Classic race
EventsB: I said, 'Mommy, what is it those guys that make people laugh, what do you call that?' — She said, 'A comic, a comedian.' — I said, 'That's what I wanna be.'

Q12: Both are different topics, B is about time and A is about numbers of commercials and band booking
Q13: One is about bands, the other is about businesses
FullA: five or six bands, you know, 'cause people would come to me and go , " Oh we got a band, too . '' And by having the most popular band in St. Louis, which was a band called the . We were-became the radio station's band, which meant they played like 80-100 commercials a week. " Hey, the , " we playin ' at 66 Drive-In. '' And it'd be, " Steve on trumpet [do-do-do-do-do-do ] '' So being the popular band in town , I started booking other bands, 'cause when I was already booked, I didn't see any reason to turn people down. I said, " Wait a second, let me see if I can get another band. '' Well, that eventually led to booking 1100 bands. So we were the largest band-booking agency in the country , and I was like 18 years old. So went from local bands, regional bands, to national bands. And the first show we did was in 1969 was the Grateful Dead. You guys sitting here all have ideas. Whether you pursue them ot not is up to you. Don't later on look back and say , " God, I wish " I would've done that. ''
FullB: something with business. I didn't know exactly what I was going to do. My passion wasn't there , but that's where the money was at. And I'm thinking, " This oughta pay the bills , " I ` ma have a family. This is what I'm going to do. " I'm just gon na paint on the side. '' But it got to that point where I couldn't work because I kept hearing that I got to pursue my dream as a, as an artist. That Obama shoe came to me. And I woke up at two o'clock in the morning and I painted that shoe. And I went to the mall and took a picture, put it on MySpace. No big deal. Didn't think nothing of it. And then like the first big thing that happened was the Smithsonian e-mailin ' me and I thought it was a joke. And I cried. I was like, I was almost homeless in January. Like, had I quit, had I quit a month before I made that shoe , had I quit an hour before I made that shoe, and decided, " I'm just gon na forget about art , '' this would have never happened.
EventsA: became the radio station's band — played 80-100 commercials a week — started booking other bands — booked 1100 bands — became the largest band-booking agency in the country — did the first show in 1969 with the Grateful Dead
EventsB: I woke up at two o'clock in the morning — I painted that shoe — I went to the mall and took a picture — I put the picture on MySpace — The Smithsonian emailed me — I cried

Q12: They both were unhappy with their circumstances and declared to make changes. The person in Story B just seems like she has already started taking action on this while the other hasn't yet.
Q13: They are both about re-inventing yourself, but for different circumstances. The person in Story A is still thinking about it, while I feel like the person in Story B is a little ahead of that by already having done something.
FullA: I feel like okay I'm aware of these issues , I'm aware of a lot of things we talked about, they're not new to me. But I'm not in-depth, hands on, like full body immersed into how chaotic this is. So how do you put your mind at ease everyday? I'm not kidding when I say I cry a lot. I'd like to say oh I meditate and it makes it okay. I do meditate and then I cry you know. Honestly, I think if we're not feeling really deeply about this stuff. I think there's a problem. At least once a month, I declare that I'm just going to walk away from all of it and become a potter. That's my thing. I don't know how to make pots  but, in my mind I'm going to be a potter. And my thinking in this is not that I just want to cop out and not do this anymore , but I want to put beauty in the world. There's a real place for that. Thank God we have poets and potters and artists and it's a wonderful thing to do. I thank God we also have people who are addressing all the ugliness head on and dealing with that. It's a collective endeavor.
FullB: We grew up kind of dysfunctional and poor, still a lot of like alcoholism and stuff and a lot of bad stuff in our neighborhood like drug dealing and what have you. I ended up getting pregnant really young and then getting married right after that. So I was 19, 20  but I was like, my god , I'm a teen pregnancy just like every other woman in my family. I totally saw everybody's face go , I knew it was too good to be true and that kinda hurt. It's like, I didn't even feel bad for myself. I felt guilty for everyone else. So, I had started writing on the web as a house wife. I had my blog and then I started getting jobs and then finally someone else online published a book. And I was so jealous that I was like, that's it I'm giving myself a year to write a book and get it published. I think there's just this mind set that you're gon na do one thing and that's the thing that's going to be your career. I don't think you're gon na pick one thing right now. And that's what you better get your degree in , and that's what you better spend nine hours a day doing , or you're gon na fail. The only mistake you can make now is to not do anything.
EventsA: I cried a lot — I meditated — I declared that I was going to walk away from all of it and become a potter
EventsB: I ended up getting pregnant really young — I got married right after that — I started writing on the web as a house wife — I started getting jobs — someone else online published a book — I gave myself a year to write a book and get it published

Q12: Story A has a definite progression to get to where she now is. Story B is just saying they kind of accidentally fell into becoming an entrepreneur.
Q13: I didn't think these were real similar because Story A had a progressive path while it seemed like Story B was "accidental" and maybe just fell into their role.
FullA: I'm really an early stage person. I love to make the new thing and so as something gets bigger and more structured , I usually hand it off to people and there's people who love to run stuff that's structured. So when I joined Google we were about 1,200 people and when I left we're over 50 or 60,000 people, so it was sort of fly the plane while you're building the plane. I had gone from working in Silicon Valley and working at Google on a lot of topics. It was fun, incredible teammates. And then I was in Africa for some work with some entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya and I got an email and it said email from the US CTO. And so 33 days later, President Obama called and offered me the job which was incredible. It's an honor to get to serve your country. So when you're doing this work, know that you belong. We all come with different histories and those histories are culture add. There's this weird idea that Silicon Valley had of culture fit. It's very destructive. I don't want you to fit , I want you to add.
FullB: The point of which I decided to be entrepreneur was when talking point just took off. It snowballed from there. So, I have to say my entrepreneurship journey is pretty accidental. Often the public image of an entrepeneur is very glamorous, but actually a lot of my work is not glamorous. And I don't think people see that from the outside. A lot of my role is essentially being a champion. I'm a doer at heart. And it's going from I'm a real doer to I need to delegate or I need to be able to align everyone to get to the same big vision and the big goal. And it's not just me anymore, so kind of a a chicken and an egg where it's both hard and challenging, but exciting.
EventsA: joined Google when it had about 1,200 people — left Google when it had over 50,000 people — went to Africa for work with entrepreneurs in Uganda and Kenya — received an email from the US CTO — President Obama called and offered the job 33 days later
EventsB: Talking Point took off — I decided to be an entrepreneur

Q12: The progression seems moderately similar because both were doing one thing, then changed and pursued something else.
Q13: They're a little bit similar because both eventually pursued the thing that made them happy.
FullA: When I joined the military, I had literally nothing. I was in a holding center, in a juvenile holding center and my recruiter came and rescued me. Needless to say , when I went to boot camp, I thought it was actually kind of easy and like I had never had so much food before in my life. When I joined the military, I originally signed up as a gunner's mate. I got out, felt like something was missing, I ended up moving out here for a job, and I was, like, guns , I know guns. I can do this job, that was easy. That was my turnaround moment. Okay.
FullB: I was already a pretty avid diver , and enjoyed it enough that I said, well, if I ever don't have a real job or don't like the real job , it's something I'll probably try to pursue full time. So then I came down here to Miami, went to law school, practiced law for about a year and a half. Wasn't really as fulfilling as it needed to be, so at that point I said , I'm gon na fall back on one of my passions and open up a scuba shop. So here we do full service any kinda certification that you would want. It definitely is a much more enjoyable day. So If you think that you like something and you wan na pursue it , pursue it. If it doesn't work out, you've got time for other options. But the last thing that you want is to kind of be stuck in a career for 20, 30 years and hate it.
EventsA: I joined the military — My recruiter came and rescued me — I went to boot camp — I signed up as a gunner's mate — I got out — I moved out here for a job
EventsB: came down to Miami — went to law school — practiced law for about a year and a half — decided to open up a scuba shop

Q12: Both of these struggled with support in their first plan of action, but this resulted in them making decisions that guided them to their true passions.
Q13: They're a little different in that Story A didn't have a college pathway mapped out and Story B always did, but both struggled with lack of support and this resulted in changes that made them understand what they were actually good at.
FullA: My passion was always to find a way to make a difference. But it wasn't until later in life that I really understood how to channel that passion. Right out of high school, I was being recruited to play football at Pittsburgh college and the first day of class, I didn't go. Because I couldn't figure out, A, how I was gon na get from where I  live to Pittsburgh College which was at least, 45 minutes away. There was nobody around me to really help me understand the value of what that university could provide me. So I just turned it down. I didn't understand where I was going or how I was gon na get there. But I went, walked into the doors of a community college and then the community college pulled me in. Now, I have the privilege of serving as the chancellor for the California Community Colleges. So I have the pleasure of representing more than 2.1 million students to have the opportunity to finish a quality college credential and get into a job, or to transfer and something that gives them an opportunity to really achieve what they wan na achieve. But that's what it did for me and that's given me the opportunity to really fulfill my passion and take it from there.
FullB: The expectations on both sides, from my mother and father, were always that you do well in school. There was never a question about whether or not I would go to college. It was when I got to college and lost my support and scaffolding system that I completely fell apart. I had been so successful for so long and I could not figure out why I could not pull it together. Because I struggled. I really, and now I understand and know it was my ADHD. I had no clue at the time what it was. I started working in the classroom and I, like, the first day in the classroom. I fell in love. What I discovered was preschoolers all to some degree have ADHD. So, we got along fine. So, they have 10 minute attention spans , so do I, so , the activities were cool. It was just , it was the perfect job for me. I was like, why didn't anybody tell me I could do this before. But I didn't really get my act together until probably my late 20s or early 30s. I accept that I have challenges and it's sometimes I'm not gon na do stuff right , and so when I, laughter, for me, you mean being able to laugh at stuff, accepting it, being able to laugh at it. Being able to forgive myself and other people. I think are the keys to just making it work. And then just move on to the next hurdle cuz there's always gon na be another hurdle.
EventsA: I was recruited to play football at Pittsburgh college — I didn't go to the first day of class at Pittsburgh college — I turned down the opportunity to attend Pittsburgh college — I walked into the doors of a community college — The community college pulled me in — I served as the chancellor for the California Community Colleges
EventsB: I got to college and lost my support and scaffolding system — I completely fell apart — I started working in the classroom — I fell in love with working in the classroom — I discovered that preschoolers have ADHD — I got along fine with preschoolers — I realized the job was perfect for me — I got my act together in my late 20s or early 30s — I accepted that I have challenges — I learned to laugh at stuff and forgive myself and others

Q12: They both realized what they were good at or what was missing that they could supply and then pursued it.
Q13: They both fell into their true passion while doing other jobs.
FullA: I was born and raised in Chicago , but my first language is Spanish because everybody in my family spoke Spanish. From the moment I learned a bit of English, I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter. I started seeing kind of more of how the disenfranchised were being treated. This was pretty much the ah-hah moment for me and the other co-founder Victor Arellano. We were at the Department of Homeland Security here in Chicago. I was gon na do an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test. So this Polish couple gets called , federal agent comes up that's gon na administer the test. And he says , well, where's your interpreter? And they were just kind of like, I don't know. And she yells out at the crowd in the waiting room, does anybody here speak Polish? Some lady raises her hand , she's like, I speak Polish. So mind you , now one of the most important interviews of this couple's life lays in the balance of a person that says she speaks Polish, which she very well might. But how do you know how much her proficiency is in that language? And that's kinda like, where we're just like, you know what? There has to be a better way , there has to be a better way. So that's kind of where Interpreter Tap was born.
FullB: and um, co-owner of two restaurants, and how did you get from where you were at our age to where you are right now?  [New Zealand accent] I suppose at your age, I left school and really the same thing, I was totally unsure of what I wanted to do. I had um , a burning passion, which was not to cook -- mine was to travel. Went to Israel and worked on a kabutz for six months  'cause I met an Israeli guy and thought, " Oh this is quite cool . '' And started cooking in the kitchens there , and I was cooking with a couple of women who said to me then, " My god, you've got such a good talent for this. '' Then came home and thought, " Yup, this is what I'm gon na do. " I can just sort of live at Mum and Dad's " and save and go through uni, '' and then just started from there.  What kept you from just going out and doing something else?  'Cause I knew I couldn't, I didn't wan na do anything else. I knew, no matter how hard it was gon na be, I had to just keep going. I just had to keep going. 'Cause really, the whole thing is, you're focusing on what you wan na do.
EventsA: I learned a bit of English — I became my grandmother's, my grandfather's, everybody's interpreter — I started seeing how the disenfranchised were being treated — I and Victor Arellano were at the Department of Homeland Security in Chicago — I did an interpretation for a gentleman who was taking a citizenship test — A federal agent asked the Polish couple where their interpreter was — A woman in the waiting room said she spoke Polish — Interpreter Tap was born
EventsB: left school — went to Israel — worked on a kabutz for six months — met an Israeli guy — started cooking in the kitchens there — cooked with a couple of women who praised my talent — came home — decided to pursue cooking — started university

Q12: They both are about their creative contributions
Q13: The first one is about touring with a band and music then somehow on to kids and being an adult. The other is about research and classes and books on a movie. I don't see the relation.
FullA: a few record deals and we had , we'd been touring across the country. And we had a deal with a network to do a television show based on The Aquabats. Just going to a network with it, we were going to end up in this kind of development again , so we were like, " Okay, that's it. " We're doing it ourselves. '' We were just naive about it. Like, " Let's put it on the internet. '' So we put a trailer on the internet. And sure enough, we had like two million hits in like... a week. While you're young, you can take chances. But once you get, you know, start having kids , you need to have a steady income. It's hard. It was tough. That's what our culture is losing. We're losing the like, " Make things tough on yourself " so that you're stronger. ''
FullB: You were there for Toy Story and. I was there for Toy, that's what I was hired to do, is Toy Story. Art direct Toy Story. Cool. Every project is so different. Every four years is a four year graduate course in the subject matter of that film. And just to take advantage of that, have fun with some research. Once you get interested in something, go and find out as much as you can about it. It's not that hard to do, especially with the Internet. You can always get a dozen books on the subject and just read through them, and just keep doing that. That's really it.
