Q12: Both are talking about making a big change in their lives and going for a goal they want.
Q13: Both are talking about the places they are/have been in life. Then to what they want for their futures.
FullA: I feel like okay I'm aware of these issues , I'm aware of a lot of things we talked about, they're not new to me. But I'm not in-depth, hands on, like full body immersed into how chaotic this is. So how do you put your mind at ease everyday? I'm not kidding when I say I cry a lot. I'd like to say oh I meditate and it makes it okay. I do meditate and then I cry you know. Honestly, I think if we're not feeling really deeply about this stuff. I think there's a problem. At least once a month, I declare that I'm just going to walk away from all of it and become a potter. That's my thing. I don't know how to make pots  but, in my mind I'm going to be a potter. And my thinking in this is not that I just want to cop out and not do this anymore , but I want to put beauty in the world. There's a real place for that. Thank God we have poets and potters and artists and it's a wonderful thing to do. I thank God we also have people who are addressing all the ugliness head on and dealing with that. It's a collective endeavor.
FullB: We grew up kind of dysfunctional and poor, still a lot of like alcoholism and stuff and a lot of bad stuff in our neighborhood like drug dealing and what have you. I ended up getting pregnant really young and then getting married right after that. So I was 19, 20  but I was like, my god , I'm a teen pregnancy just like every other woman in my family. I totally saw everybody's face go , I knew it was too good to be true and that kinda hurt. It's like, I didn't even feel bad for myself. I felt guilty for everyone else. So, I had started writing on the web as a house wife. I had my blog and then I started getting jobs and then finally someone else online published a book. And I was so jealous that I was like, that's it I'm giving myself a year to write a book and get it published. I think there's just this mind set that you're gon na do one thing and that's the thing that's going to be your career. I don't think you're gon na pick one thing right now. And that's what you better get your degree in , and that's what you better spend nine hours a day doing , or you're gon na fail. The only mistake you can make now is to not do anything.
EventsA: I cried a lot — I meditated — I declared that I was going to walk away from all of it and become a potter
EventsB: I ended up getting pregnant really young — I got married right after that — I started writing on the web as a house wife — I started getting jobs — someone else online published a book — I gave myself a year to write a book and get it published

Q12: One is a journey of a couple the other is of a kid figuring himself out.
Q13: The first is more of a life story and things falling into place. while the other is about someone feeling lost and out of place.
FullA: This is our physical space in Los Angeles. We started it in 2002, ten years ago as I mentioned in honor of my folks who were community activists and died much too early in my life. Losing my family very young was kind of a life changing experience. I've been working in the film industry for a number of years  and so to kind of channel that energy and that angst I was feeling, I wanted to open a school, a cinema and a retail space. I really don't want today just to be about me and because obviously Lisa Marr is a teacher. We fell in love, she'll tell the story much better than I, but literally on the opening day - I was walking around in my neighborhood of Echo Park and I walked into a storefront and there was this man there and he had a beard and he said , we're opening a film center today. She was walking down the street  and I said we're opening a film center and she's like, really? And she came in and she started volunteering and we had this platonic relationship that evolved into a romantic relationship. It was the beginning of a whole new chapter in my life. I had just started making films. I had been in a band for many years and did some photography and painting and there was this space right in my own neighborhood that was opening and encouraging people to come in and exchange ideas and watch films together and make their own movies. The education, in the last 10 years we've taught a couple of thousand kids for free. So for the ten year anniversary, we decided let's take everything we do on the road. Again, for us, filmmaking is about storytelling. It's not about the technology , it's not about expensive equipment , it's about an idea and some energy.
FullB: He was exploring the deep sea, deep sea submersible. And I asked my dad, " What does that guy do? '' Ah, and he said, " He's a marine biologist. '' And really, that was it , okay. " I'm gon na be a marine " biologist. '' You know , I knew I could go to school and be a marine biologist , you know? I knew that there was a degree that I could get. But nobody really ever counseled that a degree wasn't a job. And it wasn't until the last year or two that I had the epiphany that, okay , I'm gon na have my degree, my life's dream, but that's not a job. I don't have a career leaving college. I don't know what I wan na do. I knew what I wanted to do for my whole life. Too many times, people are doing things because they think they should be doing them.
EventsA: Started the physical space in Los Angeles in 2002 — Walked into a storefront in Echo Park on the opening day — Met a man with a beard who said they were opening a film center — Lisa Marr walked down the street and entered the film center — Lisa Marr started volunteering at the film center — Their platonic relationship evolved into a romantic relationship — Decided to take everything they do on the road for the ten year anniversary
EventsB: He was exploring the deep sea in a deep sea submersible. — He asked his dad what the man did. — His dad said the man was a marine biologist. — He decided he was going to be a marine biologist. — He had the epiphany that having a degree was not a job.

Q12: one is more about the challenges of school and getting to where they are as opposed to the other getting work with those skills.
Q13: They both are about their education and journey to get where they wanted in their careers. Though different types of views on the out come and different types of struggles to overcome.
FullA: I am judge Elaine Marshall. I am the Director and Presiding Judge for the City of Houston Municipal Courts. And I was going to go to college to be a doctor. That worked out real well until biology, and cut them up and bleeding and all that stuff. You couldn't handle it. Nah, that just wasn't. Everyone kept saying that you talk so much , you probably should go to law school. When I first became a prosecutor, they would send us to different schools for career day. And when I became a judge, did same thing. The thing that stuck out to me the most was one time I went to a school as a judge , and they told them who I was and they said , all rise. So the kids stood up and four of the black kids that were sitting on the thing went , she's black. Wow. And it was like, yeah. Now you see. I came up just like they did, in a public school and those sorts of things. So it's good to give back. You will find so many different places where you can go that you'll make a difference.
FullB: I went to school, because I loved coding and I wanted to develop a coding career. And I reached out to a band that I liked and said, hey, long shot , but could I make you guys a website? And to my surprise, they emailed back like ten minutes later. And they're like yeah, actually , we'd really love for you to make us a website. How about two t-shirts and a CD in trade for it and I thought that was a great bargain. And so I made them a website. So yeah , I mean, I did my first or my second website for two t-shirts and a CD. So technically, not a fair market trade. Yeah. But at the time, the value proposition for me was way higher. And so you've got ta choose your shots. Yeah. And you will definitely do things in the course of your career that will be undervalued  and the trick is to choose the right ones, and to not do it too much. So throughout your career and in particular in those formative stages, you've got to go the extra mile. You've got ta work really hard. There's just no shortcut to it. Every now and then, one in a million gets lucky literary wins the rotary and everybody else whose ever achieved some great level of success has worked incredibly hard to get there.
EventsA: She decided not to go to college to be a doctor — She became a prosecutor — She went to different schools for career day as a prosecutor — She became a judge — She went to a school as a judge — The kids at the school stood up and said all rise — Four black kids at the school expressed surprise that she was black
EventsB: I went to school — I reached out to a band that I liked and asked if I could make them a website — They emailed back ten minutes later — They agreed to have me make them a website in exchange for two t-shirts and a CD — I made them a website

Q12: One is a convict story the other is a college success story.
Q13: One is about over coming big life hurdles and turning it around and doing something positive in the world, trying to help others. The other is about working through the ranks and getting an opportunity in life to do something they love.
FullA: So I'm a program manager at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and I work in our Criminal Justice Reform Department and we're working to safely reform the criminal justice system. Reduce incarceration while keeping our neighborhood safe , and it's an exciting role , I really love what I do. I love meeting the people who've been impacted by our criminal justice system. I'm also system-impacted. I ultimately spent 12 years in state corrections and it was definitely the toughest part of my life. I came out and I owned what got me incarcerated. Really was able to dive down deep in myself and really think how did I get there. One of things that it's given me is it's given me a perspective that other programs managers that are working in criminal justice reform don't have. I don't know how many different ways we have to recycle a plastic bottle, right? We think of people as disposable  and we've got ta shift the narrative around that, right? We don't want people leaving our jails and prisons and not having opportunities to thrive and contribute. I think there's a lot of work to be done here. And it's a really crazy turn of events of where I've ended up in life , but I feel like I'm where I should be.
FullB: My name is Tom Arviso, Jr. , I'm the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated. And I've been here about 27 years now. And I started here as a college intern. And I studied journalism with the intent of becoming a sports writer. That was my passion. But once I got here to the Navajo Times, things just kind of gradually evolved , and I just kind of rose through the ranks to the point where now I'm running the company. I never looked back ever since I started doing that and just been trying to go and do as much as I can possibly do in regards to telling stories, telling people stories, and being good at it. Being right. Being ethical. Being honest. This profession, it's a field where you really have to have a passion for what you're doing, a belief in being a storyteller. If you're sincere about what you do, about your craft, about being a good journalist, then things will fall into place for you if you're patient.
EventsA: I spent 12 years in state corrections — I came out — I owned what got me incarcerated — I thought deeply about how I got incarcerated
EventsB: Tom Arviso, Jr. started as a college intern at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. rose through the ranks at the Navajo Times. — Tom Arviso, Jr. became the CEO of the Navajo Time Publishing Company, Incorporated.

Q12: One tells a more traditional narrative with difficulties and growth, focusing more on the person's life as a whole. The other is more like a snapshot of a given moment, focusing on the specific details of a meaningful work project.
Q13: Both people in the stories do the same kinds of things, but they are not framed in the same way. One person focuses more on the big picture and what this job can help them get in life, whereas the other person focuses more on the details of the work and their enjoyment of the job itself.
FullA: When I got out of college, I went into the Army Reserve, through the Communications Officer. And ended up back in 89 getting a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory. At an Engineer and Developing Technology, to make weapons smarter, new technology to be able to kind of carry weapons. And so this whole focus was on creating capability. But when you're in the entrepreneurship world and the commercial world, that's a different mindset. Yeah. See, when I worked for the government. I could spend the government money on my ideas. But I'm out here as an entrepreneur , I have to spend my own money. So that was hard for me, to try to get that switch going on. My approach, and what I always tell people is you have to start connecting, networking. And a lot of people thinks that's hard , but it is not really hard. It's just a matter of meeting people , and let them know what you do or what you wan na do.
FullB: I'm a designer and an engineer. And my work has really focused on blending electronics and computing with art and design. I've done a lot of work in combining textiles and fashion with electronics and computer science. So for example, I developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes. Kind of robotics, except for soft, stretchy things. So it's like this incredibly mathematically rich thing. But culturally, we don't think of it in those terms. So I think the important thing, or what I needed to do for myself, was discovering I could combine kind of art and design with computer science and with electronics. I just started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles. And that was really, really fun and really exciting. It was this tremendous a-ha moment where I felt like I could connect all of the crafty stuff that I had always done as a hobby. And then, using that blend as a way to get kind of new communities of people engaged in electronics and computer science.
EventsA: I got out of college — I went into the Army Reserve through the Communications Officer — I got a job working for the Air Force Research Laboratory — I worked at an Engineer and Developing Technology to make weapons smarter — I tried to get the switch going on from government work to entrepreneurship
EventsB: Developed a kit called LilyPad Arduino that lets you sew electronics into your clothes — Started to play and build stuff with electronics and textiles — Felt a tremendous a-ha moment connecting crafty hobbies with electronics and computer science

FullA: I was the first one to go to college in my family. As an undergraduate, I found a passion for science  and I focused all my attention on biology, neuroscience. And then all of a sudden, my passion shifted from doing research, research, research to understanding how do I get my invention to the market. Q12: I would have tried to write about how both stories were ultimately about using one's past experiences to find better ways to do things, but the summary of sequence "B" leaves a lot of details out. Q13: The themes in the stories are not that similar, on the surface. One person wants to improve the foster system, whereas the other wants to brew alcohol. Ultimately, both stories are about someone trying to find a better way to do something, The main characters are similar on a deeper level. They are dissatisfied with how things are and feel like they can find better ways to do things.
FullA: So I entered foster care when I was about three and a half years old. During that time, I had 14 different foster homes. I wasn't always placed in the most ideal circumstances. These were people who had problems with drugs, alcohol, violence, pedophilia. So I had this sense of I've got ta do something. I've got ta say something , this is not okay, and that kind of kept eating at me. And I think that's the motivation that kept me from turning to drugs, or running away, or becoming part of that statistic, that label that they expected of me. I had to do something differently. And so all of that gave me this perspective that it's not enough to complain about something if you're not willing to be a part of the solution. So a really big sticking point for me was that I'm not just going to walk around complaining about foster care or complaining about this system of care that's not protecting kids, no. I wan na be directly involved in the very system that failed me so that I can make it better. And I ultimately opened a non-profit organization that provides direct services to children and families. So all of my experiences kind of led to me serving others in a way that I wish I had been served when I was a young person.
FullB: towards food that I did. And so we would entertain a lot of our friends. And so all the wine dinners, all of a sudden , somehow we started home brewing. It was a simple enough question that deserved a simple answer. " Well there aren't any good American beers , " well we will supply the pipeline. '' And so we started a really naive way of thinking , but I really believe that all good thoughts come out of just a desire, a simple idea. And then the passion that you have is gon na really drive that.
EventsA: I entered foster care when I was about three and a half years old — I had 14 different foster homes — I decided I had to do something and say something about my situation — I resolved not to turn to drugs, run away, or become part of the negative statistics — I decided not to just complain about foster care but to be part of the solution — I decided to be directly involved in the system that failed me — I opened a non-profit organization that provides direct services to children and families
EventsB: They entertained a lot of their friends. — They started home brewing.

Q12: In both of the sequences, the narrator is traumatized in some way, but in "B", you don't really learn about how it affects them, whereas you do in "A". "B" is missing a lot of the context that makes the stories seem similar. It doesn't have anything contradictory, it's just incomplete.
Q13: The stories both seemingly have to do with trauma and forgiveness. The main character experiences trauma in both stories, but they make a conscious choice to try to learn from it. They realize that others would be OK if they acted out, but they should try to be strong and mature and learn from what happened to them, whether it was something direct or indirect.
FullA: being six years old , postcards coming into my family, as one after another of the relatives that my parents had were, you know, dead in the concentration camps. And I remember just being very affected by that as a six or seven year old. I became convinced right then , I think, that I did not want to be one of those people. I wanted to be a kind of person that helped other people. That instead of bringing suffering , I wanted to try to alleviate suffering. And what better way to try to alleviate the suffering of human beings than being a doctor? I think everyone has to make a choice which will bring themselves inner peace and happiness as the best they can achieve it. No matter what you do, you will have an opportunity to impact on other people's lives, just by who you are and the way you act.
FullB: and the next minute, you know , I'm thrown over 50 feet from a car  and they thought I died, you know? And they thought I'd never walk again. And people have often asked was I not angry or bitter , and the answer is no. It just is.  Everything seems so minimal, you know, when I'm sitting here talking to you. But just, you know, your mother, the accident...  why not just, " You know what, I cant ''? Like, you know --?  What would have been my option? You see it, don't you? You're sitting, waiting on the first of the month to get a check. Stuck in a wheelchair. You know... That-that's an option? I don't take reality checks from anybody. I want to follow what my passion is in life more than anything else. Don't give me a reality check because reality will tell you what you can't do. " You need to deal " with the real world. '' No, my world is real to me.
EventsA: Postcards came into the family from deceased relatives in concentration camps — The narrator became convinced that they did not want to be like those people — The narrator decided to become a person who helped others — The narrator decided to become a doctor to alleviate human suffering
EventsB: He was thrown over 50 feet from a car — People thought he died — People thought he would never walk again

Q12: Someone was given a standardized path to success that didn't work for them, so they found their own way to accomplish what they wanted using what they could do.
Q13: Both people overcame various challenges relating to education, and now both of them work in education, trying to "pay it forward" by helping others in similar ways.
FullA: My passion was always to find a way to make a difference. But it wasn't until later in life that I really understood how to channel that passion. Right out of high school, I was being recruited to play football at Pittsburgh college and the first day of class, I didn't go. Because I couldn't figure out, A, how I was gon na get from where I  live to Pittsburgh College which was at least, 45 minutes away. There was nobody around me to really help me understand the value of what that university could provide me. So I just turned it down. I didn't understand where I was going or how I was gon na get there. But I went, walked into the doors of a community college and then the community college pulled me in. Now, I have the privilege of serving as the chancellor for the California Community Colleges. So I have the pleasure of representing more than 2.1 million students to have the opportunity to finish a quality college credential and get into a job, or to transfer and something that gives them an opportunity to really achieve what they wan na achieve. But that's what it did for me and that's given me the opportunity to really fulfill my passion and take it from there.
FullB: The expectations on both sides, from my mother and father, were always that you do well in school. There was never a question about whether or not I would go to college. It was when I got to college and lost my support and scaffolding system that I completely fell apart. I had been so successful for so long and I could not figure out why I could not pull it together. Because I struggled. I really, and now I understand and know it was my ADHD. I had no clue at the time what it was. I started working in the classroom and I, like, the first day in the classroom. I fell in love. What I discovered was preschoolers all to some degree have ADHD. So, we got along fine. So, they have 10 minute attention spans , so do I, so , the activities were cool. It was just , it was the perfect job for me. I was like, why didn't anybody tell me I could do this before. But I didn't really get my act together until probably my late 20s or early 30s. I accept that I have challenges and it's sometimes I'm not gon na do stuff right , and so when I, laughter, for me, you mean being able to laugh at stuff, accepting it, being able to laugh at it. Being able to forgive myself and other people. I think are the keys to just making it work. And then just move on to the next hurdle cuz there's always gon na be another hurdle.
EventsA: I was recruited to play football at Pittsburgh college — I didn't go to the first day of class at Pittsburgh college — I turned down the opportunity to attend Pittsburgh college — I walked into the doors of a community college — The community college pulled me in — I served as the chancellor for the California Community Colleges
EventsB: I got to college and lost my support and scaffolding system — I completely fell apart — I started working in the classroom — I fell in love with working in the classroom — I discovered that preschoolers have ADHD — I got along fine with preschoolers — I realized the job was perfect for me — I got my act together in my late 20s or early 30s — I accepted that I have challenges — I learned to laugh at stuff and forgive myself and others

Q12: The outlines further define the separation of similarity of either story. No similar transition from beginning to end of each story.
Q13: They told 2 different stories about one’s self commitment to doing something they believe in.
FullA: I'd been a real estate agent , I owned an art gallery. I thought, really, my main pur-goal was to really be a good wife, a good mother , and then my life changed completely. My second son was born with a lung disease. They didn't think he'd make it , he got jaundice, and when I brought him home, he'd lost the ability to wake to feed, and so I mean for me, I thought, watching him struggle to breathe, I'd never take breathing for granted again. And I think that's sort of the beginning of me becoming an environmentalist. And so many times, I feel like I'm paying back the debt, because why should I be so lucky? What can I do to survive this life and be a success, so when the end of my road comes -- which people don't wan na talk about, 'cause the end of the road is gon na come for us -- I can look back  and say, " I really feel good about it ''? And it may not be something globally. I think that if you touch anyone's life , then you're a success.
FullB: from Canada you could ever figure out how to make movies.  Right? So I just figured I'd be going into engineering , so I took lots of maths and sciences all through high school getting ready for that. And at the last minute, I heard about this school that taught film production not too far away , and I got accepted there. Went from film production to animation to computer animation, for me. And, ah, that was inter - really interesting because it had the sort of scientific side, math and science, which I was, you know, really good at. And it had this artistic side. So I could program one minute , and then I could go , you know, fool around with animation, look at cartoons and stuff. I had a few jobs where it would be like, " Oh... great... I got ta go to work ...  '' And, you know, I sort of knew all along, " Okay, I don't want to spend my life doing this . '' You know , you'll find something, you know? And don't worry about it being the perfect thing because I think no decision is absolute, first of all, you know? I've certainly had several changes along the way. A lot of people have.
EventsA: Her second son was born with a lung disease — He got jaundice — She brought him home — He lost the ability to wake to feed — She watched him struggle to breathe
EventsB: I took lots of maths and sciences all through high school — I heard about a school that taught film production — I got accepted at the film production school — I went from film production to animation to computer animation

Q12: The outlines took out the emotionally growth part of the stories.
Q13: The only similarity was a positive outlook for self growth.
FullA: My own personal story, I have come to understand that it's a teaching story  and it is my greatest credential, to be really honest with you , is where I've been. I had a childhood that was with a certain privilege but also with a certain degree of violence in my environment and an overlay of alcoholism. And so by the time I was a teenager  and I was slipping into disordered eating, and drug use and abuse, promiscuity, and just poor choices at certain levels. I was really angry. And I didn't know why. And I didn't know what to do with all my emotions. So I was hungry when I could get around good teachers. And I fortunately did and I began dancing. And it was no question in my being that I needed to be moving my body. But it wasn't like okay , and now I'll take steps A, B, and C.  And that's the biggest message I wan na give to all the young people, to know that it's just one right step at a time to build a beautiful career and a life work.
FullB: of airplanes. I mean, just, airplanes was it. I had to fly 'em , I had to build 'em. I had to understand them, study them. The whole nine yards. I was out there in Key West in A7s. It was, um, my second kind of go around ah, to kind of qualify at the ship. And there were plenty of people in front of me that had not qualified and they were sort of farmed off to other careers. Between now and the next three minutes it takes to fly aboard , I'm either gon na get a thumbs up or that's it. You live your life for moments like that. For me, it was, you know, really all about perseverance. Whether it's pride or something else, but failure was just not an option. I'm not gon na wash out. I'm not gon na give up. You have to force yourself out of your comfort zone , I think, a lot of the time just to see who you are and how the world reacts to you.
EventsA: I had a childhood with a certain degree of violence and an overlay of alcoholism — I slipped into disordered eating, drug use and abuse, and promiscuity as a teenager — I was really angry — I was hungry when I could get around good teachers — I began dancing
EventsB: He flew airplanes. — He built airplanes. — He studied airplanes. — He was in Key West in A7s. — He tried to qualify at the ship for the second time. — He faced a moment where he would either get a thumbs up or fail.

Q12: The paths of these stories do not align
Q13: The stories talked of different life paths
FullA: July 20th, 1988, 27 years ago yesterday, I broke my neck in a diving accident. It left me a quadriplegic at the cervical four, five level. The only thing that anybody expected from me was to breathe. Alls I could do was go higher. And so I basically was starting over again at that point. And I was always so ashamed of having this learning disability. I never told anybody about my learning disability. I went all the way through college getting the accommodations for being in a wheel chair and not letting anybody know that I was dyslexic. There is no wheelchair for dyslexia. And I struggle with that everyday.
FullB: It was interesting because we were all really little, like I was six , she was eight , she was eleven. So it was like arriving in this completely foreign country and we didn't have anyone except our parents and the three of us. [sister # 2] We were really excited. I think we've always been just really adventurous. And our parents decided to come here because it was a better place for better opportunity. You know , they thought, " Oh look , you know, we're gon na have a new life, " and the girls can become lawyers and accountants -- '' [sister # 3] " They won't end up being seamstresses . '' [sister # 2] So we actually ended up being exactly what they didn't want us to be, which is seamstresses. I think with our parents , we've always had to prove to them that we could do something. I just remember a lot of fighting and a lot of crying. And them just going , " Well we didn't come here for you to do this . '' And I'm like, " Well it's not for you, like, I can't live " what you want me to be. ''
EventsA: I broke my neck in a diving accident on July 20th, 1988. — The accident left me a quadriplegic at the cervical four, five level. — I started over again at that point. — I never told anybody about my learning disability. — I went all the way through college getting accommodations for being in a wheelchair without letting anybody know that I was dyslexic.
EventsB: They arrived in a completely foreign country. — Their parents decided to come to the new country for better opportunities. — They ended up becoming seamstresses despite their parents' wishes. — They had a lot of fighting and crying with their parents about their life choices.

Q12: The outline points out the lack of similarity between homosexuality and insurance
Q13: No similarity between insurance and homosexuality
FullA: When I was a kid, I used to hide everything, like hide all the terrible details of my life. And kind of pull them close to me and try to make them look like something else to other people when I told the story. Yeah. And I think when I was 17 and I went away to college , I got very tired of trying to keep track of all my lies. So I decided I would never tell a lie again. I got to tired of it , I walked right in to my college roommate , and I just kinda blurted out like, my mother left me when I was a baby , my father doesn't want me and my cousins all tried to rape me. And I'm not a Christian anymore , I don't believe in God, and I'm here on a scholarship. And I don't think she spoke to me again for the rest of the semester , but basically I think that was a valuable accident I happened upon because after that I was just like the tell all girl. The tell too much girl. And I think when I became a lesbian I continued to be that kind of person, telling everyone about it in a culture that was violently homophobic.
FullB: My name is David Shotts , I'm the Vice President at Ascend Insurance Brokerage and we work directly with the entertainment industry. So, we work with music venues, music festivals, touring artists, event safety, event security companies. I kinda got into this industry by accident. I was playing in a band  and we were touring the country, and having a lot of fun, and not really thinking about insurance, to be quite honest. My broker said no one knows this industry like you, come to work for me , and I have just kind of found out I was really good at it. It's cool because I'll talk to people and I'll tell them  what I do and most commonly people are like, I didn't even know you could get insurance for that. I think it's kind of the beauty of the industry is that the insurance is everywhere. It doesn't just stop with home, auto, life. So if you're into extreme sports, I know a brokerage in California that focuses on extreme sports. If you're into hunting and fishing, I know underwriters that specialize in that industry. Get an idea of what's out there. If you're sitting there going I'm not quite sure what I wan na do in this industry, that's okay. As I said earlier, there's a lot of opportunity in this industry so feel around.
EventsA: I went away to college — I decided I would never tell a lie again — I walked right in to my college roommate — I blurted out my personal story to my roommate — My roommate did not speak to me for the rest of the semester — I became a lesbian — I told everyone about being a lesbian in a homophobic culture
EventsB: David Shotts played in a band — David Shotts toured the country with his band — David Shotts' broker invited him to work for him — David Shotts started working in the insurance industry

Q12: The story outlines are very different events
Q13: The stories are 2 different coming to growth stories.
FullA: In college, I was figuring my life out. I didn't have an exact plan in terms of what I wanted to do. Everybody that acted in the capacity of a guidance counselor to me helped mold me into where I am today. For instance, when I was in high school, my guidance counselor told me , Chris, based on what I know about you, I know you love to be in big cities. I know you love to study human behavior and psychology. We discussed where I might end up in college , so I chose to go to NYU based on that feedback. And when I got my first job in marketing analytics, it's when I realized that hey, this is really cool, I actually really like this. Don't feel like you have to know all the answers right now. The more strict you are in terms of what you think you want to do, plus options you'll have. So think outside the box and keep an open mind.
FullB: I worked in technology up until 1998 in which I struck out on my own and I built an engineering company. Had good contracts. 9/11 hits a couple of years later, and all of a sudden a lot of the major corporations and people  I was dealing with, their stocks fell, and they stopped giving work. I went and became a screener at the airport. I want you to think about this. I worked for a major corporation, I'm a screener, people that were my clients and then I work with , were coming through the airport. You got me reminiscing and thinking back here. But, I stuck to my principles. I knew I was better than this, all right? And I had a plan. So I took what I knew, even though I was working in terrorism and mass transit, I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl. And so, I knew from that, I was as good or better than anybody there.
EventsA: My guidance counselor told me I love to be in big cities — My guidance counselor told me I love to study human behavior and psychology — I chose to go to NYU — I got my first job in marketing analytics — I realized that I really like marketing analytics
EventsB: I struck out on my own — I built an engineering company — 9/11 happened — major corporations and people I was dealing with stopped giving work — I became a screener at the airport — I created interoperability at the 2004 Super Bowl
